ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 2-1. - Village seal described. 
    The village seal shall be the seal now being used by the village, which is circular in form with the 
words "Village of Westmont, Illinois" on the outer circle and the words "Corporate Seal" on the inner circle 
thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 2-1) 
State Law reference Authority of village to have a corporate seal, 65 ILCS 5/2-3-8. 


Sec. 2-2. - Village datum. 
    The datum for the vertical level of the village shall be a horizontal plane of reference to which all 
grades and points of elevations hereafter established and fixed by the village board for public and private 
improvements, or otherwise, shall refer. The reference plane shall be known as the "Village of Westmont, 
1995 Vertical Datum" and is hereby established at Benchmark "BNQ," being the top of the aluminum disk 
mounted to a security rod monument enclosed within an access cover at existing grade located 
approximately 220 feet west of the centerline of Cass Avenue and 56 feet north of the centerline of 
Quincy Street. The datum may be further identified as being 752.90 feet above mean sea level. 
(Code 1972, § 2-2; Ord. No. 95-76, § 1, 12-4-1995) 


Sec. 2-3. - Annexations. 
(a) ?No land shall be annexed to the village unless adequate plans for the development of the land are 
first submitted to the board of trustees providing for the installation and construction of hardtop 
roads, curbs, gutters, and storm sewers throughout the area to be annexed. 
(b) ?No occupancy permit shall be issued until all improvements are completed. 
(c) ?Any person desiring to have property annexed to the village must include in the petition a request 
that the property also be annexed to the Westmont park district. Any petition which omits the request 
to be annexed to the Westmont park district shall not be considered by the board of trustees. 
(d) ?Any person desiring to have property annexed to the village shall be responsible for all fees and 
costs of recordation connected with filing such plat of annexation with the county recorder of deeds. 
(e) ?Any person desiring to enter an annexation agreement with the village for property which is not then 
contiguous to the boundaries of the village shall agree, as part of such annexation agreement, to 
construct any buildings or structures on the property in accordance with all ordinances and 
requirements of the village, including, but not limited to, the building code and zoning ordinance of 
the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-7; Ord. No. 97-67, § 1, 8-4-1997) 


Sec. 2-4. - Local mass transit district established; powers. 
(a) ?The village hereby creates and participates in the creation of a local mass transit district to be 
known as the West Suburban Mass Transit District, pursuant to the provisions of 70 ILCS 3610/3. 
(b) ?It is anticipated that the West Suburban Mass Transit District will encompass the municipalities of 
Naperville, Lisle, Westmont, Clarendon Hills, Hinsdale, Western Springs, LaGrange, Brookfield, 
Riverside, and Berwyn, or some combination of such municipalities or others which shall by 
ordinance create and participate in the creation of such mass transit district. The territorial limits of 
such mass transit district shall be coexistent with the territorial limits of all the participating 
municipalities. 
(c) ?The powers of the West Suburban Mass Transit District shall repose in and be exercised by a board 
of trustees as provided by state law, one of whom shall be appointed by the corporate authority of 
each of the municipalities participating therein. 
(Code 1972, § 2-6) 
State Law reference Local Mass Transit District Act, 70 ILCS 3610/1 et seq. 


Sec. 2-5. - Prevailing wage rates for public works construction. 
(a) ?To the extent and as required by the Prevailing Wage Act, [2] the general prevailing rate of wages in 
this locality for laborers, mechanics and other workers engaged in construction of public works 
coming under the jurisdiction of the village shall be ascertained to be the same as the prevailing rate 
of wages for construction work in the county area as determined annually by the state department of 
labor as of June 1 of each year. The definition of any terms appearing in this section which are also 
used in the aforesaid Act shall be the same as in such Act. 
(b) ?Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to apply the general prevailing rate of wages as 
ascertained in this section to any work or employment except public works construction of the village 
to the extent required by the aforesaid Act. 
(c) ?The village clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested party in the 
main office of this village this determination of the prevailing rate of wages as provided in this 
section. 
(d) ?The village clerk shall mail a copy of the determination of the prevailing rate of wages as provided in 
this section to any employer, to any association of employers, and to any person or association of 
employees who have filed their names and addresses, requesting copies of any determination 
stating the particular rates and the particular class of workers whose wages will be affected by such 
rates. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, §§ 14, 6-21-1993) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
(820 ILCS 130/0.01 et seq.) 


Secs. 2-62-30. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 2-31. - Composition; term; duties and powers. 
    The board of trustees, consisting of six members, shall be elected to office for a four-year term, 
according to the method provided by statute. The board of trustees shall be the legislative department of 
the village government and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated to it by 
statute. 
(Code 1972, § 2-40) 
State Law reference Powers of board of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5 et seq. 


Sec. 2-32. - Oath; salary. 
    The members of the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute, and shall 
receive such compensation as may be provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1972, § 2-41) 
State Law reference Compensation of members of corporate authorities, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-
15. 


Sec. 2-33. - Committees. 
(a) ?The following shall be the standing committees of the board of trustees: 
(1) ?Public information. 
(2) ?Public safety. 
(3) ?Administration and finance. 
(4) ?Public works. 
(5) ?Community development. 
(6) ?Economic development. 
(7) ?Environmental improvement. 
(b) ?Special committees shall be created from time to time as directed by the village board. 
(c) ?The village president shall appoint trustees to serve as chair and vice-chair of each committee to the 
board of trustees, and shall appoint the committee members. The board of trustees shall determine 
the number of members to be appointed to each committee. 
(d) ?Rotation . Standing board of trustee committee chairs and vice-chairs shall rotate every two years 
with the vice-chair moving up to the chair position and the past chair changing committees, unless 
determined otherwise by the village president. The village manager shall prepare a rotational 
schedule that is reviewed and approved every two years by the village president and village board. 
Community members of any standing board committee shall be periodically rotated by the village 
president and reported to the board of trustees. 
(e) ?Public information committee . The public information committee shall be chaired by the village 
clerk. The committee shall be comprised of members that are, from time to time, reviewed by the 
village president and reported to the village board. The public information committee's purpose is to 
provide an informational forum for various community groups and their special and community 
events. 
(f) ?Reserved. 
(g) ?Westmont First Committee . 
(1) ?The intent of the Westmont First Committee is to promote a positive mindset that puts 
Westmont first in shopping, volunteering and making improvements through positive change. 
The committee shall consist of members/residents of the following locations/groups: 
(i) ?Westmont Park District; 
(ii) ?Westmont Library; 
(iii) ?School District 201; 
(iv) ?School District 60; 
(v) ?WRA; 
(vi) ?DBA; 
(vii) ?The Chamber of Commerce; 
(viii) ?Pasquinelli area retailers/resident; 
(ix) ?Ogden Avenue retailers/resident; 
(x) ?Central Business District retailer/resident; 
(xi) ?South Westmont Business District retailer/resident; 
(xii) ?Seniors; 
(xiii) ?Mayslake area; 
(xiv) ?Two at-large members; and 
(xv) ?A member of the Village of Westmont staff. 
Members shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the trustees. 
(2) ?The Westmont First Committee shall meet monthly to discuss and implement methods and 
programs to put Westmont first and shall have the authority to draft and adopt by-laws for the 
governance and operations of the committee. 
(3) ?This committee shall continue to function until such time that it is dissolved by an ordinance 
passed by the board of trustees. 
(h) ?Westmont 100 th Anniversary Committee . The purpose of this committee is to celebrate the 100 th 
anniversary of the village and to promote and market the village's history, accomplishments, 
resources and amenities. This committee shall be comprised of elected officials, village staff and 
members of the public that are appointed by the village president and reported to the board of 
trustees. The village president shall select the chair and co-chair of this committee. This committee 
shall serve until dissolved by the board of trustees. 
(i) ?Sister City Committee . 
(1) ?The intent of the Sister City Committee is to establish and maintain a positive relationship 
between the Village of Westmont and Hsinchu County, Taiwan as well as continue the ongoing 
relationship with TECO-Chicago, which has a cultural center in the village. The committee shall 
consist of seven members, who will be appointed by the mayor will report to the board of 
trustees. The committee positions are as follows and shall consist of at least one village staff 
member and up to six at-large members, who either reside, work or volunteer in the village: 
(i) ?Sister City AmbassadorChair 
(ii) ?Communications directorCo-Chair 
(iii) ?Municipal exchange liaison 
(iv) ?Cultural exchange liaison 
(v) ?Educational exchange liaison 
(vi) ?Economic development liaison 
(vii) ?Village manager 
(2) ?The Sister City Committee shall meet quarterly or as needed to discuss and implement Sister 
City related programs that focus on the areas of municipal exchange, cultural exchange, 
educational exchange, and economic development. The committee shall have the authority to 
draft and adopt by-laws, policies and procedures, an annual budget, and an annual calendar of 
events. Any proposed budget shall be subject to the budget and appropriations ordinance of the 
village. 
(3) ?This committee shall continue to function until such time that it is dissolved by an ordinance 
passed by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 2-42; Ord. No. 09-128, § 1, 8-3-2009; Ord. No. 11-111, § 1, 7-18-2011; Ord. No. 
13-120, § 1, 6-17-2013; Ord. No. 13-154, § 1, 7-11-2013; Ord. No. 13-183, § 1, 9-19-2013; Ord. 
No. 14-76, § 1, 4-17-2014; Ord. No. 14-195, § 1, 12-14-2014; Ord. No. 15-168, § 1, 10-29-2015; 
Ord. No. 17-123, § 1, 8-3-2017; Ord. No. 17-179, § 2, 12-7-2017) 


Secs. 2-342-50. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS 


Sec. 2-51. - Time and place of regular meetings. 
    The village board shall hold its meetings every other Thursday, at 6:00 p.m., and notice of such 
meetings shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of the Open Meetings Act. The meeting 
place of the board of trustees shall be at the village hall unless otherwise ordered by the board. In the 
event that the trustees desire a "First Reading" on a particular ordinance in order to allow time for public 
discussion and input and to reflect upon an issue, there shall be "First Readings" on particular 
ordinances. If a particular ordinance will be subject to a "First Reading," there shall be a notation on the 
agenda and it shall be mentioned in open session. This shall not prevent the board of trustees from 
calling special informational meetings or workshop meetings when specific topics suggest a need to do 
so. 
(Code 1972, § 2-48; Ord. No. 09-205, § 1, 12-21-2009; Ord. No. 13-105, § 1, 5-20-2013; Ord. 
No. 14-20, § 1, 1-23-2014; Ord. No. 14-55, § 1, 3-20-2014; Ord. No. 14-145, § 2, 8-21-2014; 
Ord. No. 15-053, § 2, 4-2-2015) 
State Law reference Ordinance prescribing times and places of meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-
25; Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 


Sec. 2-52. - Special meetings; call; notice. 
    Special meetings of the board of trustees may be called by the village president or by any three 
trustees upon notice as required by the Open Meetings Act. [3] 
(Code 1972, § 2-49) 
State Law reference Special meetings, call, notices, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25. 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
(5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.) 


Sec. 2-53. - Presiding officer. 
    The village mayor shall be the presiding officer at all regular and special meetings of the board of 
trustees and at all times when the board meets as a committee of the whole. If the mayor shall be absent 
from a regular or special meeting of the board of trustees, each trustee in order of rotation shall be the 
presiding officer. A trustee may pass at his option to the next trustee in the rotation order. The village 
clerk shall keep a record of the rotation order. 
(Code 1972, § 2-50) 
State Law reference Presiding officer at meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-30. 


Sec. 2-54. - Quorum; required votes. 
    A majority of the board of trustees shall constitute a quorum to do business. No ordinance, motion or 
resolution shall be passed except upon the favorable vote of a majority of the elected members of the 
board, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1972, § 2-51) 
State Law reference Quorum of corporate authorities, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20; vote required, 65 
ILCS 5/3.1-40-40. 


Sec. 2-55. - Order of business. 
    Village board meeting agenda form: The order of business of regular meetings of the board of 
trustees shall be as follows: 
(1) ?Roll call. 
(2) ?The Pledge of Allegiance. 
(3) ?Open forum. 
(4) ?Reports. 
i. ?Mayor. 
ii. ?Clerk. 
iii. ?Trustee items. 
(5) ?Public hearings.* 
(6) ?Items to be removed from consent agenda. 
(7) ?Consent agenda. 
i. ?Approval of minutes. 
ii. ?Proclamations.* 
iii. ?Resolutions.* 
iv. ?Ordinances.** 
v. ?Miscellaneous. 
1. ?Finance ordinance. 
2. ?Purchasing orders. 
3. ?Bid approval(s).*** 
(8) ?Unfinished business. 
(9) ?New business. 
(10) ?Executive session. 
(11) ?Adjournment. 
* Optional to be added to the agenda as needed. 
** To be used for routine items like declaration of surplus property, approval and publishing of 
official zoning map of the village, waiver of certain application fees by other village 
governmental bodies and other ministerial matters. 
*** When the recommendation is to accept the lowest qualified bidder. 
(Code 1972, § 2-52; Ord. No. 12-108, § 1, 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 13-182, § 1, 9-5-2013; Ord. No. 
15-053, § 3, 4-2-2015; Ord. No. 17-043, § 1, 3-16-2017) 


Sec. 2-56. - Reconsideration of prior action; prerequisites. 
    No vote or action of the board of trustees shall be rescinded at any special meeting of the board of 
trustees unless there is present at such special meeting as many members of the board of trustees as 
were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1972, § 2-53) 
State Law reference Reconsideration, passing over veto, requisites, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-50 et 
seq. 


Sec. 2-57. - When resolutions to be in writing. 
    Any resolutions submitted to the board of trustees shall be reduced to writing before being voted 
upon when requested by any two members of the board. 
(Code 1972, § 2-54) 


Sec. 2-58. - Consent of board required to address meetings; exceptions. 
    No person other than the village president or a member of the board of trustees shall address that 
body at any regular or special meeting, except during open forum or upon consent of a majority of the 
board members present. 
(Code 1972, § 2-55) 


Sec. 2-59. - Clerk to attend meetings and keep minutes. 
    The village clerk shall attend all meetings of the village board and keep a full record of its 
proceedings, which record shall be approved and accepted by the village board as the official minutes of 
their proceedings, and which shall, within ten days of such approval, be available for public inspection. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 


Sec. 2-60. - Rules of order. 
    The village board may adopt rules of order to establish procedures for the conduct of all meetings of 
the village board. In the absence of a specific procedural rule adopted by the village board, Robert's 
Rules of Order, as revised, shall govern the deliberations of the board of trustees except when in conflict 
with any of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 2-56; Ord. No. 09-205, § 2, 12-21-2009) 
State Law reference Determination of rules of proceeding, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-15. 


Sec. 2-61. - Suspension of rules. 
    The rules of order, other than those prescribed by statute, may be suspended at any time by the 
consent of a majority of the members of the village board present at any meeting. 
(Code 1972, § 2-57) 


Sec. 2-62. - Disturbing meetings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting of the board of trustees or of any committee 
thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 2-58) 
State Law reference Punishment of members for disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-11. 


Sec. 2-63. - Taping of executive sessions. 
(a) ?Policy adopted. The policy on taping executive sessions as reflected in the memorandum dated July 
20, 1998, is hereby approved and adopted. 
(b) ?Implementation; applicability. This policy shall be implemented in full on or before July 30, 1998, 
and shall apply to all subsidiary boards and commissions which hold executive sessions during 
televised public meetings. 
(c) ?Procedures. The following procedures should be followed during live and taped cablecasts of all 
village board meetings: 
(1) ?Executive session procedures during live broadcast. Once the village board adjourns to 
executive session the following actions should occur: 
a. ?All microphones will be muted. 
b. ?A wide shot of the room will be displayed during the entire executive session. 
c. ?A character-generated message will be displayed stating: 
Village of Westmont  
Board Meeting  
_____ 
Executive Session  
Month, Day, Year  
The current meeting will resume at the conclusion of the Executive Session. 
d. ?Upon the reconvening of the meeting the microphones shall be turned on and the 
character-generated message removed. 
e. ?If the village board does not feel that it is necessary to tape the remainder of the meeting 
the following should be stated publicly upon adjournment to executive session: "At the 
conclusion of the executive session there shall be no discussion or decisions made prior to 
adjournment of the regular meeting." 
(2) ?Executive session procedures during playback. 
a. ?On all executive sessions that last longer than 15 minutes the master tape will be stopped 
until the conclusion of the executive session. 
b. ?The master tape will be placed back into record once the meeting is reconvened. 
c. ?If the executive session exceeds 15 minutes the following character-generated message 
will be edited into the master tape stating the following: 
Village of Westmont  
Board Meeting  
_____ 
Executive Session  
Month, Day, Year 
The Executive Session for this meeting lasted _______ minutes. The tape has been edited 
for playback purposes only. No discussion or decisions have been edited. 
In addition to the character-generated message, the break taken for the executive session 
would be reduced to two minutes in length on the recorded master tape. 
(Res. No. 98-76, §§ 1, 2, 7-20-1998) 


Sec. 2-64. - Electronic attendance at meetings rules. 
(a) ?Rules statement. It is the decision of the Village of Westmont that any member of the corporate 
authorities may attend via electronic means (such as by telephone, video or internet connection) any 
regular or special open meeting of the corporate authorities convened pursuant to properly published 
notice at which a quorum is present, including workshop meetings of the corporate authorities, but 
not including committee meetings, provided that such attendance is in compliance with these rules 
and any applicable laws. Electronic attendance at closed meetings by a member of the corporate 
authorities is not permitted. 
(b) ?Prerequisites. A member of the corporate authorities may attend a meeting electronically if the 
member meets the following conditions: 
(1) ?The member shall notify the village manager at least 48 hours in advance of the scheduled 
meeting so that necessary communications equipment can be arranged. Inability to make the 
necessary technical arrangements will result in denial of a request for remote attendance. The 
request for electronic attendance shall be made using the attached request written form, which 
should be submitted to the village manager at least 48 hours in advance of the scheduled 
meeting. In the event advanced transmission of the written request form is impossible, the 
request to attend a meeting remotely and electronically shall be otherwise communicated to the 
village manager at least 48 hours prior to the start of the meeting. Thereafter, within 48 hours 
following the meeting, such written request form shall be submitted to the village manager. 
(2) ?The member must assert one of the following three reasons why he or she is unable to 
physically attend the meeting: 
a. ?The member cannot attend because of personal illness or disability; or 
b. ?The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the business of the 
Village of Westmont; or 
c. ?The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency. 
(c) ?Authorization to participate. 
(1) ?The village manager, after receiving the electronic attendance request, shall inform the 
corporate authorities of the request for electronic attendance. 
(2) ?After establishing that there is a quorum is physically present at a meeting where a member of 
the corporate authorities desires to attend electronically, the presiding officer shall state that (i) 
a notice was received by a member of the corporate authorities in accordance with these rules, 
and (ii) the member will be deemed authorized to attend the meeting electronically unless a 
motion objecting to the member's electronic attendance is made, seconded, and approved by 
2/3 of the members of the corporate authorities who are physically present at the meeting. If no 
such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion fails to achieve the required vote by 
the members of the corporate authorities physically present at the meeting, then the request by 
the member to attend the meeting electronically shall be deemed approved and the presiding 
officer shall declare the requesting member present. After such declaration by the presiding 
officer, the question of a member's electronic attendance may not be reconsidered. 
(3) ?Only one member of the corporate authorities may attend a meeting electronically at any one 
time. In the event more than one member requests remote attendance at a specific meeting, 
selection shall be made by the village manager based upon the first request received by the 
village manager. 
(4) ?A trustee attending a meeting electronically shall be entitled to receive his or her regular 
compensation for that meeting. 
(d) ?Adequate equipment required. The member participating electronically and other members of the 
corporate authorities must be able to communicate effectively, and members of the audience must 
be able to hear all communications at the meeting site. Before allowing electronic attendance at any 
meeting, the village, by proper authorization, shall provide equipment adequate to accomplish this 
objective at the meeting site. 
(e) ?Minutes. Any member attending electronically shall be considered an off-site attendee and counted 
as present electronically for that meeting if the member is allowed to attend. The meeting minutes 
shall also reflect and state specifically whether each member is physically present or present by 
electronic means. 
(f) ?Rights of remote member. 
(1) ?A member permitted to attend electronically will be able to express his or her comments during 
the meeting and participate in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject 
to all general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted and adhered to. 
(2) ?The member attending electronically shall be heard, considered, and counted as to any vote 
taken. Accordingly, the name of any member attending electronically shall be called during any 
vote taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded by the clerk and placed in the minutes for 
the corresponding meeting. 
(3) ?A member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any 
member, provided the member attending electronically shall announce his or her leaving and 
returning. 
(4) ?A member of the corporate authorities is eligible to use this procedure and may attend 
electronically no more than three times per fiscal year. 
(g) ?Committees, boards and commissions. These rules shall not apply to any committees, boards and 
commissions established by authority of the Village of Westmont. 
(Ord. No. 09-113, § 2(Exh. A), 7-20-2009) 


Sec. 2-65. - Consent agenda. 
    The village manager shall direct the preparation of the consent agenda, which shall include such 
matters as the village manager shall determine are routine. All items listed on the consent agenda will be 
enacted by one motion and one vote, which shall be a roll call vote. No separate discussion of any item 
listed on the consent agenda will occur unless the mayor and/or one or more trustees requests removal 
from the consent agenda. Any item removed from the consent agenda shall be placed at the end of "new 
business" and shall be discussed and considered after all other items on the posted agenda are 
considered. 
(Ord. No. 12-108, § 1, 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 2-66. - Procedures for public participation at public meetings. 
(a) ?Members of the public may address public officials at meetings of the village board, its committees, 
commissions and other subsidiary bodies in accordance with Section 2.06(g) of the Illinois Open 
Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/2.06(g)). 
(b) ?Public comments are limited to three minutes per speaker. 
(c) ?The subject of public comments shall be reasonably related to matters identified on the meeting 
agenda and/or other village business. 
(d) ?Any person desiring to speak shall register their request with the public body prior to the meeting, if 
practical. 
(e) ?Any person desiring to speak on behalf of a group and not solely as an individual must register as a 
"group speaker" and any person speaking on behalf of a group is limited to six minutes. 
(f) ?Public comment shall be taken at one particular time within the meeting (e.g. at open forum at a 
village board meeting) and shall not be allowed at other times unless the chair of the meeting 
recognizes the participant speaker, or unless required pursuant to the public hearing process 
established by state law. 
(g) ?To ensure accurate record keeping, public members are encouraged to provide their full name and 
their home address prior to speaking, however, provision of an address is not required to speak. 
(h) ?A registered speaker cannot give their allotted minutes to another person. 
(i) ?Statements are to be directed to the village board/committee/commission or subsidiary body as a 
whole and not to an individual member. 
(j) ?Public comment is not intended to require board/committee/commission members to provide 
answers to the speaker. 
(k) ?Discussions between speakers and members of the audience are not allowed. 
(l) ?Repetitive public comments should be avoided, to the extent practical, through adoption of prior 
public comment (e.g. agreeing with a prior speaker). 
(m) ?The chair of the meeting may create and enforce reasonable additional rules to preserve order and 
decorum (e.g. prohibiting applause, cheering, booing, shouting, use of profanity, or the use of signs, 
banners and placards). 
(n) ?The chair may suspend the rules in order to provide more public comment, as he/she deems 
appropriate. 
(o) ?The following conduct is prohibited during public participation: 
(1) ?Acting or appearing in a lewd or disgraceful manner; 
(2) ?Using disparaging, obscene or insulting language; 
(3) ?Personal attacks impugning character and/or integrity; 
(4) ?Intimidation; 
(5) ?Disorderly conduct (as defined by state law); 
(p) ?Any speaker who engages the public body in a prohibited manner, as identified above, shall be 
called to order by the chair; 
(q) ?Any person who violates these rules or who otherwise disrupts the order and decorum of the 
meeting may be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2017-093, § 2(Exh. A), 6-8-2017) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2017-093, § 2(Exh. A), adopted June 8, 2017, adopted provisions 
pertaining to procedures for public participation at public meetings but did not specify a Code 
section; hence, its inclusion herein was at the discretion of the editor. 


Secs. 2-672-85. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference Officers, employees not liable to fine for failure to perform duties, § 1-9. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 2-86. - Application of division. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply alike to all officers and employees of the village regardless 
of the time of the creation of the office or position or the time of the appointment of the officer or 
employee. 
(Code 1972, § 2-18) 


Sec. 2-87. - Commencement of office; oath of office. 
    The inauguration of newly elected officers shall be fixed for the first regular or special meeting in the 
month of May following the election. Every officer of the village shall before entering upon his duties take 
the oath prescribed by state law. 
(Code 1972, § 2-20) 
State Law reference Oath of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25. 


Sec. 2-88. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all municipal officers, except trustees, 
shall execute a bond with security to be approved by the corporate authorities. The bond shall be payable 
to the village in the penal sum directed by resolution or ordinance, conditioned upon the faithful 
performance of the duties of the office and the payment of all money received by the officer, according to 
law and the ordinances of the village. The bond may provide that the obligation of the sureties shall not 
extend to any loss sustained by the insolvency, failure, or closing of any bank or savings and loan 
association organized and operating either under the laws of the state or the United States in which the 
officer has placed funds in the officer's custody, if the bank or savings and loan association has been 
approved by the corporate authorities as a depository for those funds. In no case, however, shall the 
mayor's bond be fixed at less than $3,000.00. Bonds shall be filed with the village clerk, except the bond 
of the clerk, which shall be filed with the village treasurer. 
(Code 1972, § 2-21) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 


Sec. 2-89. - Terms of office; vacancies. 
    Every appointive officer of the village shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified, 
unless it is otherwise provided by ordinance. In case of a vacancy in any such place, it shall be filled in 
the same manner in which appointments or selections are made, in the absence of provision to the 
contrary. 
(Code 1972, § 2-22) 


Sec. 2-90. - Salaries. 
    The salaries of all elected officials shall be established by ordinance. The salaries of all other officials 
and employees of the village shall be established by approval of the annual budget and appropriation 
ordinance. 
(Code 1972, § 2-23) 
State Law reference Salaries of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-5 et seq. 


Sec. 2-91. - Availability of records for inspection. 
(a) ?Village records shall be open for inspection and copying in accordance with the Freedom of 
Information Act. [5] No village official or employee shall disclose any village records or information 
contained therein to the public if such records would not be available pursuant to the Freedom of 
Information Act. With the exception of individual employee personnel records, documents shall be 
available to the village president and members of the board of trustees. 
(b) ?The village manager shall promulgate all needful rules and regulations to lawfully carry out the 
obligations of the village to disclose public records, including but not limited to: 
(1) ?The persons to whom requests for records shall be made, and the times and places at which 
such requests may be made; and 
(2) ?The times and places at which such records will be made available. 
(Code 1972, § 2-24) 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
(5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.) 


Sec. 2-92. - Accounting for money. 
    Every officer of the village shall at least once each week or more often turn over all money received 
by him in his official capacity to the village treasurer with a statement showing the source from which such 
moneys were received. 
(Code 1972, § 2-25) 


Sec. 2-93. - Arrest authority. 
    The village president, members of the board of trustees, and members of the police department are 
hereby declared to be conservators of the peace with such powers and authority to make arrests as are 
given to conservators of the peace by statute. 
(Code 1972, § 2-26) 
State Law reference Conservators of the peace, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-25. 


Sec. 2-94. - Surrender of effects of office. 
    Every officer and employee of the village, upon the expiration of his term for any cause whatsoever, 
shall deliver to his successor all books and records which may be the property of the village, and if no 
successor has been appointed within one week after the termination of office, such property shall be 
delivered to the village clerk or village treasurer. 
(Code 1972, § 2-27) 
State Law reference Duty of municipal officer to successor, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-35. 


Sec. 2-95. - Impersonating officers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be any village officer or employee. 
(Code 1972, § 2-28) 
State Law reference False personation of judicial or governmental officials, 720 ILCS 5/32-
5. 


Sec. 2-96. - Interference with officers. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of the village while engaged in 
the duties of his office or employment. 
(Code 1972, § 2-29) 
State Law reference Resisting or obstructing a peace officer or correctional institution 
employee, 720 ILCS 5/31-1. 


Sec. 2-97. - Participation in municipal retirement fundGenerally. 
    The village does hereby elect to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, effective 
January 1, 1973. 
(Code 1972, § 2-30) 
State Law reference Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, 40 ILCS 5/7-101 et seq. 


Sec. 2-98. - SameBy part-time elected officials. 
(a) ?Elected officials may become participating employees in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund if 
they are in positions normally requiring performance of duty during 1,000 hours or more per year. 
(b) ?The board shall determine from time to time which part-time elected officials normally require the 
performance of duty during 1,000 hours or more per year. 
(Code 1972, § 2-31(a), (c)) 


Sec. 2-98.5. - Municipal retirement fund credit for qualifying military service. 
    Pursuant to Public Act 90-0448, the village shall allow each of its employees to purchase Illinois 
Municipal Retirement Fund credit for military service if the employee qualifies under Public Act 90-0448, 
and the village hereby undertakes to contribute the funds necessary to promote and accomplish the 
purchase of additional Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund credit for such qualifying military service. No 
such purchase shall take place unless in full compliance with the federal and state laws governing this 
increase in participating member benefits. 
(Res. No. 98-149, 12-21-1998) 
Cross reference Personnel, ch. 62. 


Sec. 2-99. - Indemnification of certain officials. 
(a) ?To the fullest extent permitted by the constitution of the state and applicable law, including 735 ILCS 
10/2-302 and 10/9-102, each of the following officials and employees of the village, namely: The 
mayor; each trustee; the village manager and any and all assistant village managers; the village 
clerk and deputy village clerk; the village treasurer; the village collector; the village attorneys and 
village prosecutors; the director of each department of the village; the chief of police; the fire chief; 
and each member of any board or commission of the village established pursuant to applicable law 
or by ordinance of the village, shall be indemnified, defended and held harmless by the village from 
and against all liabilities for compensatory damages, expenses of investigation, judgments and 
amounts paid in settlement which may be imposed upon or reasonably incurred or paid by such 
official or employee in connection with or resulting from any claim made against him, or any action, 
suit, proceeding or investigation in which he may be involved, by reason of his being or having been 
such official or such employee of the city and acting within the scope of his employment or official 
duties, whether or not he continues to be such official or employee at the time of such claim, action, 
suit, proceeding or investigation; provided, however, that the foregoing indemnity shall not extend to 
any of the following: 
(1) ?Any liability or cost with respect to any matter as to which such official or employee is finally 
adjudged to be guilty of bad faith, or actual malice, or willful and wanton misconduct in the 
performance of his duties as such official or employee, such activity being outside of the scope 
of his employment or official duties; 
(2) ?Any payment, expense or cost arising out of a settlement of any claim, action, suit or 
proceeding, unless: 
a. ?Settlement shall be approved by the court having jurisdiction over such claim, action, suit 
or proceeding, with express knowledge of the existence of the indemnification provided 
hereby; or 
b. ?Such settlement shall have been made upon the written opinion of the city attorney to the 
effect that there is no reasonable grounds for any finding of bad faith, actual malice, willful 
and wanton misconduct or other acts outside the scope of official duties or employment on 
the part of such official or employee that proximately caused the damage complained of, 
and that the anticipated cost of such settlement will not substantially exceed the estimated 
cost and expense of defending such claim, action, suit or proceeding to a final conclusion; 
(3) ?Any liability, expense, judgment or amount paid in settlement in connection with or resulting 
from any claim, action, suit, or proceeding in which such official or employee and the village 
itself or officials of the village acting in their governmental capacities are adverse parties; or 
(4) ?The cost of independent legal representation in any such action, suit or proceeding, if the 
village offers or otherwise indicates its willingness to provide a legal defense with respect to 
such claim, action, suit, proceeding or investigation. 
(b) ?The rights of indemnification as provided in this section shall be in addition to any other rights to 
which such official or employee may otherwise be entitled as a matter of law. 
(c) ?Indemnification shall be provided by the village to police officers as provided by applicable law, 
including 65 ILCS 5/1-4-6. 
(Ord. No. 93-54, § 1, 11-1-1993) 


Secs. 2-1002-120. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - VILLAGE PRESIDENT 


Sec. 2-121. - Election; term of office. 
    The village president shall be elected for a term of four years, and shall be president of the board of 
trustees, as is provided by statute. 
(Code 1972, § 2-69) 
State Law reference Presiding officer, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-30. 


Sec. 2-122. - Oath of office. 
    The village president shall take the oath of office prescribed by state law. 
(Code 1972, § 2-70) 
State Law reference Oath of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25. 


Sec. 2-123. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the village president shall give a bond with sureties to 
be approved by the board of trustees conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties in a sum of 
not less than $3,000.00. 
(Code 1972, § 2-71) 
State Law reference Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 


Sec. 2-124. - Compensation. 
    The village president shall receive such compensation as may be set from time to time by the board 
of trustees. The compensation shall be established at least four months prior to the general election in 
which the president is elected. 
(Code 1972, § 2-72) 
State Law reference Compensation, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-5 et seq. 


Sec. 2-125. - Powers and duties. 
    The village president shall be the chief executive officer of the village, and shall perform all such 
duties as may be required of him by statute or ordinance. The village president shall have the power and 
authority to inspect all books and records kept by any village officer or employee at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1972, § 2-73) 
State Law reference Powers and duties of mayor or president, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-5 et seq. 


Sec. 2-126. - Mayor pro tem. 
    During the temporary absence or disability of the village mayor, the mayor pro tem shall be the most 
senior member of the board of trustees available to act in that capacity. Subject to the provisions of 
section 2-53, the mayor pro tem shall have all the powers of the mayor including, but not limited to, the 
declaration of emergencies. 
(Code 1972, § 2-74) 
State Law reference Mayor or president pro tem, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-35. 


Sec. 2-127. - Terms "president" and "mayor" to be interchangeable. 
    The village president may be referred to as mayor of the village. The term "village president" as used 
in any ordinance, resolution, motion or other action of the village authorities shall be construed as 
meaning the mayor, and the term "mayor" wherever so used shall be construed to mean the village 
president. The title "mayor" as used in the minutes of the meetings of the village authorities, or any other 
official document, shall be construed as meaning the village president. 
(Code 1972, § 2-75) 
State Law reference Village president may also be called a mayor, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2.1, 5/3.1-
15-10. 


Sec. 2-128. - Emergency powers of the president; proclamations; notice to public; penalty. 
(a) ?The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Civil emergency means: 
(1) ?A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to 
use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three or more persons acting 
together without authority of law. 
(2) ?Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, 
earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of the village, resulting in the death or injury 
of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be 
taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew means a prohibition against any persons walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring 
upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the 
village, except officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference 
to a civil emergency. 
(b) ?Whenever a civil emergency exists, the village president shall declare the existence by means of a 
written declaration setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency. 
(c) ?After proclamation of a civil emergency, the village president may order a general curfew applicable 
to such geographical areas of the village, or to the village as a whole, as he deems advisable, and 
applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of public 
safety and welfare. 
(d) ?After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the village president may also, in the interest of public 
safety and welfare, make any or all of the following orders: 
(1) ?Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns and private clubs or portions 
thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor and beer is permitted. 
(2) ?Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any wholesaler or retailer. 
(3) ?Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid 
flammable or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed 
to a motor vehicle. 
(4) ?Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or 
ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
(5) ?Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. 
(e) ?The proclamation authorized by this section shall be effective for a period of up to seven days, 
unless terminated by a proclamation of the village president indicating that the civil emergency no 
longer exists, or unless it is continued or renewed for an additional time period with the consent of 
the village board. 
(f) ?Upon issuing the proclamation authorized in this section, the chief of police shall notify the news 
media within the general area of the village, and shall cause three copies of the proclamation 
declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the following places within the village: 
(1) ?The village hall. 
(2) ?The police station. 
(3) ?The post office. 
(g) ?Any person violating the provisions of this section or executive order issued pursuant thereto shall 
be guilty of an offense and shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1972, § 2-76; Ord. No. 97-06, § 1, 1-6-1997) 
Cross reference Emergency services management, § 42-261 et seq.; mob action, § 58-6. 
State Law reference Mayor or president, calling out militia, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-25. 


Secs. 2-1292-150. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - VILLAGE MANAGER 


Sec. 2-151. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of village manager, an executive office of the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-107) 


Sec. 2-152. - Employment contract. 
    The village president and board of trustees are hereby authorized to enter into a contract of 
employment with the village manager. 
(Code 1972, § 2-108) 


Sec. 2-153. - Appointment; term. 
    The village manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term by the president and board of trustees 
of the village or in accordance with any contract entered into between the village manager and board of 
trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 2-109) 


Sec. 2-154. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon his duties of office, the village manager shall execute a bond in an amount of 
not less than $3,000.00, with such sureties as may be required by the board of trustees, conditioned upon 
the faithful performance of his duties. 
(Code 1972, § 2-110) 
State Law reference Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 


Sec. 2-155. - General duties. 
    The village manager shall have and exercise all powers and duties assigned to him by statute and 
such other authority as may be granted by the village board. The village manager shall be charged with 
the enforcement of all laws and ordinances within the village insofar as their enforcement is within the 
powers of the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-111) 


Sec. 2-156. - Duty to attend meetings, inform board of trustees of affairs of village and make 
recommendations. 
    The village manager shall attend all meetings of the village board of trustees, shall keep the board 
informed as to the affairs of the village, and shall recommend to the board such actions as may be 
necessary or expedient for the welfare of the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-112) 


Sec. 2-157. - Duties in regard to hiring and discharging employees. 
    The village manager shall hire and discharge all employees of the village, other than those under 
civil service or other tenure of office laws, authorized by the village board of trustees to be hired, at such 
compensation as may be set or authorized by the village board. All employees shall perform their duties 
subject to the direction of the village manager or the superior to whom the manager may assign such 
employee. The village manager may delegate to any other official or employee the authority to hire or 
discharge any employees so authorized. 
(Code 1972, § 2-113) 


Sec. 2-158. - Duty in regard to assignment of powers and duties of village officers and employees. 
    Whenever there is a question as to the respective powers or duties of any appointed officer of the 
village, the question shall be settled by the village manager. The village manager shall have the power to 
delegate to any appointed officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific officer has been 
directed to perform the duty. 
(Code 1972, § 2-114) 


Sec. 2-159. - Duties in regard to appointment and removal of village officers. 
    All appointive offices of the village shall be filled by appointment by the village manager, except 
where otherwise provided by law. The village manager shall report to the president and board of trustees 
such appointments, or any removal from office, made by him, as soon as possible after the appointment 
or removal. Every administrative department of the village shall be under the supervision and control of 
the village manager, who shall have the power to remove from office any officer appointed by the 
manager. 
(Code 1972, § 2-115) 


Sec. 2-160. - Duties in regard to contracts. 
    The village manager shall examine all proposed contracts to which the village may be a party and 
may sign on behalf of the village any contract authorized by the village board, except where the board 
directs that some other officer or officers shall do so. It shall be the duty of the village manager to see to it 
that all terms of any contract to which the village is a party are fully performed by all parties thereto. 
(Code 1972, § 2-116) 


Sec. 2-161. - Purchasing agent; powers and duties in regard to purchasing. 
    The village manager shall be or designate a general purchasing agent of the village, and except 
where specific provision to the contrary is made by law or by the board of trustees, he shall make all 
purchases of supplies, materials and equipment authorized by the board of trustees, in the manner 
prescribed by and subject to the limitations imposed by law. No purchase shall be made or obligation or 
expense incurred, except for the purpose for which no prior appropriation is required by law, if the amount 
thereof is not covered by an unexpended appropriation for the purpose. On all purchases of more than 
$20,000.00, the village manager shall first procure the approval of the village board before making such 
purchases, and in all cases he shall comply with the statutory provisions as to solicitation of bids. The 
village manager or his designee shall develop purchasing policies and procedures, in conformance with 
state and federal law, that will be modified from time to time in the discretion of the village manager and to 
maintain conformance with such laws. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117; Ord. No. 00-56B, § 1, 5-1-2001; Ord. No. 07-01, § 1, 1-2-2007; Ord. No. 
16-111, § 2, 6-23-2016) 
State Law reference Municipal purchasing agent, 65 ILCS 5/3-6-4. 


Sec. 2-162. - Duties in regard to appropriations and levies. 
    It shall be the duty of the village manager or his designee to cause to be prepared each year the 
annual budget resolution and appropriation ordinance in time for consideration and enactment by the 
village board during the first quarter of the fiscal year; and to prepare the tax levy ordinance for passage 
and file a certified copy thereof with the county clerk within the time required by law. He shall keep current 
accounts of the amounts appropriated and the amounts spent out of each appropriation, showing the 
unexpended appropriations at all times. 
(Code 1972, § 2-118) 


Sec. 2-163. - Duty to keep inventory and be custodian of village property. 
    The village manager or his designee shall keep a current inventory showing all real and personal 
property of the village and its location, and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all such 
property, including equipment, buildings, parks and all other village property, which is not by law assigned 
to some other officer or body for care and control. 
(Code 1972, § 2-120) 


Sec. 2-164. - Publication of notices; preparation of reports. 
    It shall be the duty of the village manager to see to the publication of all notices, ordinances or other 
documents required by law to be published, and to prepare or cause to be prepared all reports which the 
village or any of the officials thereof are required by law to prepare. 
(Code 1972, § 2-121) 


Sec. 2-165. - Duties in regard to elections. 
    The village manager shall prepare for the village clerk all notices, ballots and election supplies 
necessary in connection with village elections. 
(Code 1972, § 2-122) 


Sec. 2-166. - Recordkeeping; clerical assistance and certification of records and documents. 
(a) ?The village manager or his designee shall prepare and have custody of all village records required 
by law to be kept by the village and not by a specific officer thereof. 
(b) ?Where the law makes it the duty of a specific officer to keep or maintain records, the village 
manager or his designee shall make available to such officer all necessary clerical assistance for the 
preparation of such records and shall make available a place for the custody of such records. In 
compliance with this section, the village manager or his designee shall make available to the village 
clerk any stenographic or clerical assistance necessary for the preparation of the journal of village 
proceedings, the record of ordinances and all other documents which by law the village clerk is 
required to keep; and he shall perform similar service for the village treasurer in the maintenance of 
bond registers, and all other records or documents which by law the treasurer is required to keep or 
prepare. 
(c) ?Where the law requires or provides for certification of any records or documents by any officer of the 
village, the village manager or his designee shall cause such records or documents to be properly 
prepared and presented to such officer for his signature. 
(Code 1972, § 2-123) 


Sec. 2-167. - Ex officio collector and comptroller. 
    The village manager shall be ex officio village collector and village comptroller, unless such offices, 
or either of them, are duly filled by appointment; and the manager shall perform the duties of each such 
office in the absence of such appointment to either of them. 
(Code 1972, § 2-124) 
State Law reference Powers and duties of comptroller, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-100 et seq.; powers 
and duties of collector, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-125 et seq. 


Sec. 2-168. - Keeping of maps and plats. 
    The village manager or his designee shall cause to be kept a complete set of maps and plats 
showing the location of all village utilities and other village properties, all streets and other public places, 
and all lots or parcels of land subdivided according to law. 
(Code 1972, § 2-125) 


Sec. 2-169. - Duty to maintain office and devote required time to duties of office. 
    The village manager shall maintain an office in the village hall and shall spend such time in the 
performance of his duties as may be required by the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 2-126) 


Sec. 2-170. - Acting village manager. 
    If the village manager shall be absent from the village or incapacitated from performing the duties of 
his position, the assistant village manager shall act as village manager during such absence or 
incapacity. If the assistant village manager is unable to serve in this capacity, some other qualified officer 
of the village designated by the board of trustees shall act as village manager during such absence or 
incapacity. 
(Code 1972, § 2-127; Ord. No. 08-83, § 1, 5-19-2008) 


Secs. 2-1712-190. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 4. - VILLAGE CLERK[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference Village clerk to keep license and permit forms on file, § 22-34. 
State Law reference General duties of municipal clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 


Sec. 2-191. - Election; term. 
    The village clerk shall be elected and serve for a four-year term and until his successor is elected 
and qualified as provided by statute. 
(Code 1972, § 2-87) 
State Law reference Village clerk to be elected, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5, 5/3.1-25-90. 


Sec. 2-192. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon his duties of office, the village clerk shall execute a bond in an amount of not 
less than $3,000.00, with such sureties as may be required by the board of trustees, conditioned upon the 
faithful performance of his duties. 
(Code 1972, § 2-88) 
State Law reference Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 


Sec. 2-193. - Custody, use of seal. 
    The village clerk shall be the custodian of the village seal, and shall affix its impression on 
documents whenever this is required. 
(Code 1972, § 2-89) 
State Law reference Use of corporate seal, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 


Sec. 2-194. - Sealing and attesting documents. 
    The village clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the village and all licenses, permits and such 
other documents as shall require this formality. 
(Code 1972, § 2-90) 


Sec. 2-195. - Keeping of accounts. 
    The village clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by him and the source and 
disposition thereof; and such other accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1972, § 2-91) 


Sec. 2-196. - Disposition of moneys. 
    The village clerk shall turn over all money received by him on behalf of the village to the village 
treasurer promptly upon the receipt of such moneys, together with a statement as to the source of the 
moneys. 
(Code 1972, § 2-92) 


Sec. 2-197. - Recordkeeping; register of licenses. 
    In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the village clerk is required by statute 
to keep, he shall keep a register of all licenses and permits issued and the payments thereon; a record 
showing all of the officers and regular employees of the village; and such other records as may be 
required by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 2-93) 


Sec. 2-198. - Custody of documents. 
    The village clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the village which are not 
assigned to the custody of some other officer. 
(Code 1972, § 2-94) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 


Sec. 2-199. - Duty to index documents and records. 
    The village clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, 
so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. 
(Code 1972, § 2-95) 


Sec. 2-200. - Vacancy in office. 
    In the event the office of village clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the president and board of 
trustees shall appoint a successor as provided by statute. 
(Code 1972, § 2-96) 
State Law reference Filling vacancy of office of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3-5-9. 


Sec. 2-201. - Deputy village clerkOffice created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of deputy village clerk. The deputy clerk shall be appointed by the 
village clerk to serve for the term of such clerk's office, or until a successor deputy clerk shall be 
appointed. 
(Ord. No. 95-38, § 1(2-97), 6-5-1995) 


Sec. 2-202. - SameDuties. 
    In the event that the village clerk shall be absent from the village or otherwise incapacitated from 
performing the duties of the position, the deputy village clerk shall be authorized to perform any and all 
duties of the clerk as set forth in this division or pursuant to state law. 
(Ord. No. 95-38, § 1(2-98), 6-5-1995) 


Secs. 2-2032-220. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 5. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY 


Sec. 2-221. - Office created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of village attorney, an executive office of the village. The attorney 
shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees and shall serve until his successor is appointed. 
(Code 1972, § 2-157) 


Sec. 2-222. - Special counsel. 
    The village president with the consent of the board of trustees may from time to time retain an 
attorney to represent or advise the village on legal matters if no village attorney has been appointed; and 
he may likewise retain special counsel to advise or represent the village on special matters or to assist 
the village attorney. 
(Code 1972, § 2-158) 


Sec. 2-223. - Compensation. 
    The village attorney shall receive such compensation as may be decided from time to time by the 
village board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 2-159) 


Sec. 2-224. - Duty to render legal advice; written opinions. 
    The village attorney shall be the legal advisor of the village and shall render advice on all legal 
questions affecting it, whenever requested to do so by any village official. Upon request of the village 
president, any trustee or the village manager, the village attorney shall reduce any such opinion to writing. 
(Code 1972, § 2-160) 


Sec. 2-225. - Duty to prosecute and defend suits. 
    The village attorney shall prosecute or defend all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village 
may be a party or in which it may be interested or which may be brought against or by any officer of the 
village on behalf of the village or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-161) 


Sec. 2-226. - Duty to draft ordinances, contracts and other documents. 
    The village attorney shall, on direction of the president and board of trustees or village manager, 
draft or supervise the drafting of all ordinances and resolutions to be acted on, and all contracts or other 
documents in which the village is interested. 
(Code 1972, § 2-162) 


Secs. 2-2272-245. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 6. - RESERVED[7]

DIVISION 7. - FINANCE DIRECTOR 


Sec. 2-276. - Keeping of accounts; collection agent. 
    It shall be the duty of the finance director to keep current accounts showing at all times the fiscal 
condition of the village, including the current and anticipated expenses, appropriations, cash on hand and 
anticipated revenue of all village funds and accounts; and the finance director shall see to the collection of 
all monies due the village. The finance director shall receive all monies paid into the village coffers and 
shall pay out money on behalf of the village pursuant to the standards imposed by the village manager. 
The finance director shall perform all statutory duties prescribed of a village treasurer and shall perform 
such other duties as set forth in the job description approved by the village manager. 
(Code 1972, § 2-119; Ord. No. 08-187, § 2, 12-1-2008) 


Secs. 2-2772-280. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 8. - DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 03-162, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 2003, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 
2-277 and 2-278. At the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as §§ 2-281 and 2-282. 


Sec. 2-281. - Office created; appointment; compensation; term. 
    There is hereby created the office of director of public works. The director shall be appointed by the 
village manager, subject to approval of the village president and board of trustees. The director shall be 
compensated at such amount as shall be fixed by the president and board of trustees and shall serve 
until his successor has been appointed. 
(Ord. No. 03-162, § 1, 11-17-2003) 


Sec. 2-282. - Duties generally. 
    The director of public works shall supervise the street division, water division, public works 
department and economic development department, shall oversee all public works programs and 
operations, and shall perform such other duties as assigned by the village manager. The director shall 
report to the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 03-162, § 1, 11-17-2003; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, 6-4-
2007; Ord. No. 07-105, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)

ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS OF THE VILLAGE 


Sec. 2-301. - Creation of village departments. 
    The village government shall be administered, under the direction and control of the village manager, 
within the following departments of the village: 
(1) ?Administration department. 
(2) ?Economic development department. 
(3) ?Finance department. 
(4) ?Fire department. 
(5) ?Police department. 
(6) ?Public works department. 
(Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-107, § 1, 6-4-
2007) 


Sec. 2-302. - Control and supervision. 
    The village manager shall have control and supervision of all village departments, and any divisions 
thereof which he may designate from time to time. 


Sec. 2-303. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The village manager shall establish the duties and responsibilities of each department of the village. 


Sec. 2-304. - Commingling of funds. 
    The commingling of any funds earned by or appropriated for one department of the village with any 
funds earned by or appropriated for another department is expressly prohibited.

DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference Electrical commission, § 18-236 et seq.; board of trustees of police pension fund, § 
54-132. 
State Law reference Board of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 


Sec. 2-346. - Created; terms of members. 
    There is created a board of fire and police commissioners, the members of which shall be appointed 
by the village president, subject to approval of a majority of the board of trustees. The board shall consist 
of three members, whose terms of office shall be three years and until their respective successors are 
appointed and have qualified. All board members shall be electors in the village. No appointment shall be 
made by the village president within 30 days before the expiration of his term of office. All board members 
shall provide an affidavit to the village president, prior to approval by a majority of the board of trustees, 
with the following information: 
(1) ?A statement that the member holds no other office within the village; 
(2) ?A statement that the member has not been convicted of a felony under the laws of this state or 
comparable laws of any other state or the United States; 
(3) ?A statement that the member is not related by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin 
to any elected official of the village; and 
(4) ?A statement as to the member's political party affiliation existing within the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-210; Ord. No. 99-107, § 1, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 99-124, § 1(2-346), 9-7-1999) 


Sec. 2-347. - Qualifications of members; oath; bond; removal. 
    The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall possess the qualifications required 
of other officers of the village, shall take an oath or affirmation of office, and shall give a fidelity bond in 
the same manner as other appointive officers of the village, in an amount of not less than $3,000.00. The 
members shall be subject to removal from office as are other officers of the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-211) 
State Law reference Qualifications, oath, bond, removal, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-3. 


Sec. 2-348. - General powers; counsel. 
(a) ?The board of fire and police commissioners shall make such rules and make such appointments 
and removals except those reserved to the president and board of trustees of the village, and shall 
have such other powers as are provided by statute. 
(b) ?If the village attorney informs the board he can no longer advise the board due to a conflict, the 
board of fire and police commissioners may select its own special counsel from a list approved by 
the mayor with advice and consent of the trustees. The special counsel shall serve the board solely 
with regard to the issue on which the board requires assistance. Once the issue is resolved, the 
special counsel shall have no further obligations to or authority from the village. 
(Code 1972, § 2-212; Ord. No. 97-94, § 2, 10-20-1997) 


Sec. 2-349. - Appointment of members of police department. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all sworn officers of the police department 
of the village, except the chief of police and the deputy chief of police, which appointments shall be made 
as provided by statute and the rules, regulations and procedures adopted and amended from time to time 
by the board of fire and police commissioners and the village police department. 
(Code 1972, § 2-213; Ord. No. 10-96, § 1, 6-7-2010) 


Sec. 2-350. - Secretary. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own 
members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be 
custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations 
held by the board, and shall perform all other duties as the board shall prescribe. 
(Code 1972, § 2-214) 


Sec. 2-351. - Compensation of members. 
    All members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall receive compensation for their 
services as determined by the village board. If the village board deems advisable, the secretary to the 
commission may receive such compensation as may be fixed by the board from time to time and provided 
for in the annual appropriation ordinance. If the board shall deem it advisable to secure advice or services 
on technical matters, it may do so upon authority from the village board and appropriation of funds 
therefor by the board. 
(Ord. No. 94-53, § 2-215, 8-1-1994; Ord. No. 97-93, § 2, 10-20-1997) 


Secs. 2-3522-375. - Reserved.

    The library board of trustees shall have the power to make reasonable rules and regulations 
governing the use of the library, and may exclude from the library any person who wilfully violates such 
rules. 
(Code 1972, § 2-225)

--- (14) --- 
(5 ILCS 120/1.01 et seq.) 


Sec. 2-450. - Powers and duties. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1) ?To prepare and recommend to the village board for adoption, a comprehensive plan for the 
present and future development or redevelopment of the village and land contiguous to the 
village and within 1½ miles of its corporate limits. Such plan may establish reasonable 
standards of design for subdivisions and for resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas 
subject to redevelopment with respect to public improvements; may establish reasonable 
requirements governing the location, width, course, and surfacing of public streets and 
highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks, 
playgrounds, schoolgrounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater 
drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and sewage collection and treatment; 
and may designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the recommended zoning 
classification upon annexation. 
(2) ?To recommend changes from time to time in the official comprehensive plan. 
(3) ?To prepare and recommend to the village board, from time to time, plans for specific 
improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan. 
(4) ?To give aid to village officials charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced 
within the official comprehensive plan, to further the making of these projects, and, generally, to 
promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. 
(5) ?To examine all subdivision plats referred to it by the village board, and to approve or 
disapprove such plats in the manner described by this Code. The chairman and secretary shall 
execute final subdivision plats once approved by the village board. In the temporary absence of 
the chairman, the most senior commissioner other than the secretary shall sign plats on behalf 
of the chairman. In the temporary absence of the secretary, the second most senior 
commissioner other than the chairman shall sign plats on behalf of the secretary. 
(6) ?To review site plans and make recommendations to the village board for all development in 
zoning districts other than single-family residential. 
(7) ?To hear and decide appeals from and review any order, requirement, decision or determination 
made by a economic development director or building inspector charged with the enforcement 
of the zoning ordinance of the village, subject to the procedures for hearings established 
therein, and provided that a concurring vote of not less than four members of the planning and 
zoning commission shall be required to reverse any such administrative decision. 
(8) ?To hear applications for special uses or variations from the requirements of the zoning 
ordinance, subject to the standards set forth therein, and to make recommendations to the 
village board concerning such applications. 
(9) ?To consider proposed amendments to the zoning ordinance of the village, pursuant to the 
procedures established therein, and to make recommendations to the village board concerning 
such proposed amendments. 
(10) ?To consider applications for planned developments, pursuant to the standards and 
procedures of the zoning ordinance with respect thereto, and to make recommendations to the 
village board concerning such developments. 
(11) ?To carry out any and all other duties and responsibilities assigned to it pursuant to the 
village's zoning and land development ordinances, state law governing the functions of a plan 
commission or zoning board of appeals, and any other ordinances of the village. 
(12) ?To carry out any other duties or responsibilities which may, from time to time, be referred or 
assigned to it by the village board. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 2(2-235), 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 16-061, § 2, 
4-14-2016)
