ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 2-511. - Fiscal year established. 
    The fiscal year for the village shall begin on May 1 and end on April 30 of each year. 
(Code 1972, § 2-3) 
State Law reference "Fiscal year" defined, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2(5). 


Sec. 2-512. - Surety bonds. 
    Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the village is required as a prerequisite to exercising the duties 
of any office or position, or to the issuance of a license or permit, or for the exercise of any special 
privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in this 
state as a surety company, in the absence of specific provision to the contrary by ordinance. Whenever in 
its opinion additional sureties or an additional surety may be needed on any bond to indemnify the village 
against loss or liability because of the insolvency of the existing surety or for any other reason, the village 
may order a new surety to be secured for such bond. If such new surety is not procured within ten days 
from the time such order is transmitted to the principal on the bond, or his assignee, the board of trustees 
shall declare the bond to be void, and thereupon such principal or assignee shall be deemed to have 
surrendered the privilege or position as condition of which the bond was required. 
(Code 1972, § 2-4) 


Sec. 2-513. - Warrants to be signed by president and clerk; required contents. 
    All warrants drawn on the village treasury must be signed by the village president and countersigned 
by the village clerk, stating the particular fund or appropriation to which such warrant is chargeable, and 
the person to whom payable. No money shall be paid otherwise than upon such warrants so drawn, 
except as otherwise provided in this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 2-5) 
State Law reference Warrants, signing, countersigning, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-8. 


Secs. 2-5142-519. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - DOWNTOWN PARKING FUND 


Sec. 2-520. - Downtown parking fundEstablished. 
    There is hereby established and created within the village, a downtown parking fund which shall be 
established for the purposes set forth in section 2-252. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 10-5-2009) 


Sec. 2-251. - Revenues. 
    The downtown parking fund shall serve as a repository for the following sources of revenue: 
(1) ?Fines generated by parking citations issued for parking violations in the downtown central 
Business District; and 
(2) ?Assessments, fees, and charges associated with the granting of parking variances to 
businesses operating in the downtown B-1 Business District; and 
(3) ?Fees associated with various downtown parking permits. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 10-5-2009) 


Sec. 2-252. - Expenditures. 
    The proceeds of the downtown parking fund shall be expended for the following: 
(1) ?To purchase property for the purpose of creating a new parking lot or parking structure; 
(2) ?To expand or improve existing parking lots or structures; 
(3) ?To establish or expand landscaping, lighting, or signage associated with parking lots or 
structures; and 
(4) ?For any other purpose as determined by the village board of trustees to be related to the 
maintenance, expansion, establishment, or enhancement of parking in the downtown B-1 
Business District. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 10-5-2009) 


Secs. 2-5232-535. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VII. - CODE OF ETHICS[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference Pecuniary interest in contracts, 65 ILCS 5/4-8-6. 


Sec. 2-536. - Declaration of policy. 
    The proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials and employees be 
independent, impartial, and responsible to the people they serve; that government decisions and policies 
be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal 
gain or to advance the interest of a family or relatives; and that the public have confidence in the integrity 
of its government. In recognition of these goals there is established this code of ethics for all village public 
officials, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid, and for all village employees. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-300), 9-20-1999) 


Sec. 2-537. - Purposes. 
    The purpose of this code of ethics is to establish ethical standards of conduct for all village public 
officials and employees by setting forth those acts or actions which are incompatible with the best interest 
of the village and its inhabitants. This code of ethics is founded upon the principle that no individual 
should receive any financial or other gain beyond that legally defined by reason of serving as a public 
official or employee of the village, and that no private party or taxpayer, including public officials or 
employees or their family members, should receive any benefit from village action beyond that which is 
available to any other private party or taxpayer due to their relation to or as a result of privileged 
information or support provided by any public officials or employees. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-301), 9-20-1999) 


Sec. 2-538. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business entity means any business, proprietorship, firm, partnership, person in a representative or 
fiduciary capacity, association, venture, trust, or corporation. 
    Charity means any organization as defined by the Internal Revenue Code, 26 USC 501(c)(3), which 
is exempt from taxation. 
    Confidential or privileged information means public records and information exempt from inspection 
and copying under any provision of the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, [17] that are designated and 
labeled as confidential by the board of trustees or any committee thereof, and any matter or information 
properly the subject of a closed meeting or session pursuant to the Illinois Open Meetings Act. [18] 
    Ethics board means the board consisting of the village president, village clerk, and one village 
trustee as appointed by the village president. The village president may change the appointment of the 
village trustee from time to time in his or her discretion. The village president shall also appoint a separate 
village trustee as an alternate ethics board member who shall serve only in the event that a conflict of 
interest prevents an ethics board member from hearing a matter. The ethics board shall conduct hearings 
of purported violations of this ethics article and the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act, and shall 
impose disciplinary action and/or fines for violations as it deems appropriate. 
    Ethics officer. The village manager or designee shall serve as the village ethics officer, and shall 
receive and investigate all complaints of violations of this ethics article by public officials and employees 
and may recommend disciplinary measures to the ethics board. 
    Family member means a spouse; children and grandchildren and their spouses; parents and 
spouse's parents; and brothers and sisters and their spouses. 
    Gift means any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or 
intangible item having monetary value including but not limited to cash, food and drink, and honoria for 
speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of a 
public official or employee. 
    Interest means any material direct or indirect benefit accruing to a public official or employee or their 
family members, whether in the public official's or employee's own name or the name of any person, firm, 
corporation, association, or trust from which the official or employee is entitled to receive any financial 
benefit, as a result of a contract or transaction that is or that is known will become the subject of an official 
act or action by or with the village; provided, however, that the term "interest" shall not include: 
(1) ?Any such benefit accruing as a result of any such contracts or transactions that by their terms 
and substance confer on all other citizens of the village the opportunity and right to realize 
similar benefits. 
(2) ?Any such benefit accruing to a public official or employee solely by reason of ownership of less 
than one-half of one percent of the publicly traded stock of a business entity realizing such a 
benefit. 
(3) ?The employment of any family member of a public official in any temporary position or in any 
permanent part-time position, provided that such family member is otherwise qualified and 
meets all requirements for such employment and is not treated in any manner differently than 
any other employee in a comparable position for purposes of wages or benefits paid or work 
evaluations performed. 
    Official act or action means any legislative administrative, appointive, or discretionary act of any 
public official or employee of the village or any agency, board, committee, or commission thereof. 
    Public official or employee means any person, officer, or employee holding a position by election, 
appointment, or employment in the service of the village, whether paid or unpaid, including members of 
any agency, board, committee, or commission thereof; provided, however, that independent contractors 
shall not be considered public officials or employees. 
    Transaction means any matter, including but not limited to contracts, work, or business with the 
village, the sale or purchase of real estate by the village, or any request for zoning amendments, 
variations, planned development approval, or special use permits, involving or requiring any official act or 
action of the village. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-302), 9-20-1999; Ord. No. 04-93, § 3, 5-17-2004; Ord. No. 10-63, § 1, 
4-5-2010) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference (5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.) 
 
--- (18) --- 
State Law reference (5 ILCS 120/1.01 et seq.; 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.) 


Sec. 2-539. - Ethical standards. 
(a) ?Conflict of interest. No public official or employee shall perform or participate in an official act or 
action with regard to a transaction in which he has, or knows he will thereafter acquire, an interest; 
provided, however, that any interest permitted or prohibited under applicable state laws and 
regulations, as they may be amended from time to time, shall be permitted or prohibited under the 
same circumstances and conditions as therein set forth. 
(b) ?Reserved. 
(c) ?Reserved. 
(d) ?Preacquisition of interest. No public official or employee shall acquire an interest in or position 
himself to be beneficially affected by any transaction, or the subject matter thereof, at a time when 
the public official or employee believes or has reason to believe that such transaction will directly or 
indirectly be affected by an official act or action of such official or employee. 
(e) ?Unauthorized disclosure and use of confidential or privileged information. No public official or 
employee shall disclose, without proper legal authorization, confidential or privileged information 
concerning the property, government, or affairs of the village. Nor shall any public official or 
employee use any such confidential or privileged information to advance the interest of such public 
official or employee or his family members. Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the village 
manager, in his discretion, from disclosing to any village staff such confidential or privileged 
information as he may determine to be necessary to carry out his duties as chief administrative 
officer of the village, and to enable such staff members to carry out their respective duties and 
responsibilities. 
(f) ?Misrepresentation of village positions. No public official or employee shall state that the village has 
made a particular decision or adopted a position when such public official or employee knows that 
the village has in fact not duly made or adopted such decision or position. This subsection shall not 
be construed to prohibit any public official or employee from stating his personal views concerning 
any matter so long as such views are clearly identified as personal views and not as the official 
decision or position of the village. 
(g) ?Appearance. Except as otherwise provided by law, no public official or employee shall appear on 
behalf of any private person or business entity, other than himself or a family member: 
(1) ?Before any village agency, board, committee, or commission; or 
(2) ?Before any other agency, board, committee, commission, or court regarding the subject matter 
of any transaction that is pending before the village or in which an interest of the village is 
directly involved. 
Provided, however, that nothing in this subsection (g) shall be construed to prohibit an appearance 
without compensation by a public official on behalf of his constituents in the course of such public official's 
duties as a representative of such constituents, or in the discharge of such public official's public or civil 
obligations, or to prohibit an appearance by a public official or employee as a duly authorized 
representative of the village. 
(h) ?Public property. No public official or employee shall use or permit the use of village-owned vehicles, 
equipment, materials, or property for profit or for personal convenience except with an administrative 
order of the village. 
(i) ?Special treatment. No public official or employee shall grant any special consideration, treatment, or 
advantage to any person or business entity beyond that which is available to every other citizen. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-303), 9-20-1999; Ord. No. 04-93, § 2, 5-17-2004) 


Sec. 2-540. - Political activities and business transactions. 
(a) ?Appointments or employment. No appointment to or employment in any village position shall be 
dependent on any political activity or business transaction. 
(b) ?Condition of employment. No employee shall be required to engage in any political activity or 
business transaction as a condition of employment. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-304), 9-20-1999) 


Sec. 2-541. - Disclosure of interest. 
    Any public official or employee who has an interest in a contract or transaction that is or that is 
known will become the subject of an official act or action in which such public official or employee is 
involved shall disclose on the record of the agency, board, committee, or commission which performs 
such official act, or to the village manager in the case of employees, the nature and extent of such 
interest, and shall not participate in any manner in the official action of the village, agency, board, 
committee, or commission. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-305), 9-20-1999) 


Sec. 2-542. - Violations. 
(a) ?Jurisdictional authority. All complaints regarding a potential violation of any provision of this code of 
ethics shall be made, in writing, to the ethics officer. Upon the receipt of any complaint, the ethics 
officer shall immediately forward the complaint to the ethics board and may recommend disciplinary 
action to the ethics board. The ethics board shall thereafter schedule a special meeting convened to 
consider the alleged violation of this code of ethics pursuant to the procedures described in this 
section. The ethics board shall provide at least seven days' advance written notice to the alleged 
violator of the date and location of the special meeting. The ethics board shall convene this special 
meeting within 45 days after receiving a written complaint forwarded to it by the ethics officer. An 
emergency meeting of the ethics board may be called by the village president or by any three 
trustees. 
(b) ?Procedures for disciplinary action. The ethics board and the alleged violator shall each have the 
opportunity to present a case-in-chief, in which they may present evidence, call witnesses, cross 
examine witnesses and make opening and closing arguments. The state rules of evidence applicable 
to civil proceedings shall govern. The village president shall preside over the hearings. A written 
decision with a finding of facts and the imposition of disciplinary action, if any, shall be made by the 
ethics board within seven business days after the hearing, and shall be transmitted to the alleged 
violator via certified mail. 
(c) ?Disciplinary action. A finding by the ethics board that any public official or employee has violated 
any provision of this code of ethics shall, to the extent allowed by state law, constitute cause for 
reprimand, censure, suspension, removal, or other appropriate disciplinary action. 
(d) ?Fines. Any person prosecuted for and found guilty by the ethics board of violating any provision of 
this code of ethics may be fined not more than $5,000.00 for each such offense. In cases of a 
continuing violation, the village attorney is authorized to apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for 
a restraining order or injunction to abate such violation. If the ethics board finds after a full hearing 
that a complaint is frivolous, it may impose a fine against the person initiating the complaint up to 
$5,000.00. 
(e) ?Appeals. Any public official or employee found guilty by the ethics board of violating this code of 
ethics may appeal such decision to any court or tribunal of competent jurisdiction, or make any such 
other appeals as provided by state law and due process requirements. Any such appeal shall not 
stay any disciplinary action ordered by the ethics board unless so directed by a court or tribunal of 
competent jurisdiction. 
(f) ?Reconsideration of transaction. Any transaction that was the subject of an official act or action of the 
village in which any public official or employee has an interest prohibited by this code of ethics, or 
which involved the violation of a provision of the code of ethics, shall be officially reconsidered upon 
discovery, disclosure, or determination of such interest or violation. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-306), 9-20-1999) 


Sec. 2-543. - Distribution. 
    The village clerk shall cause a copy of this code of ethics to be distributed to every public official and 
employee of the village within 30 days after enactment of this code of ethics. Each public official and 
employee elected, appointed, or engaged thereafter shall be furnished a copy of this code of ethics 
before entering upon the duties of his office or employment. 
(Ord. No. 99-130, § 1(2-307), 9-20-1999) 


Sec. 2-544. - Adoption of the Illinois Whistleblower Act by reference. 
    The Illinois Whistleblower Act, 740 ILCS 174/1 et seq., as amended from time to time, is hereby 
adopted by reference to be applied within the corporate limits of the village to the extent permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 11-154, § 1, 9-19-2011) 


Sec. 2-545. - Adoption of the Illinois False Claims Act (Illinois Whistleblower Reward and Protection Act) 
by reference. 
    The Illinois False Claims Act (Illinois Whistleblower Reward and Protection Act), 740 ILCS 175/1 et 
seq., as amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference to be applied within the corporate 
limits of the village to the extent permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 11-154, § 1, 9-19-2011) 


Sec. 2-546. - Whistleblower reporting policy. 
(a) ?Purpose. The village has adopted, by reference, the Illinois Whistleblower Act and the False Claims 
Act which are comprehensive statutes designed to expose the fraudulent actions of employees, 
politicians and contractors in connection with government obligations, resources and employment by 
encouraging the reporting of such fraudulent behavior. The reporting of concerns of illegal or 
dishonest or fraudulent activity promotes open government, protects the health, safety and welfare 
and improves the community. However, it is understood that baseless allegations are subject to 
discipline, up to and including termination. 
(b) ?Policy. A whistleblower is an employee of the village who reports an activity that he/she considers to 
be illegal or dishonest or designed to deceive others, resulting in the village suffering a loss and/or 
the perpetrator achieving a gain. The whistleblower acts in good faith and has reasonable grounds 
for believing the information disclosed provides evidence of an improper transaction or a violation of 
the law or the policies and ordinances of the village. 
    Examples of illegal or dishonest activities are violations of federal, state or local laws, billing for 
services not performed or for goods not delivered and other fraudulent activity. 
(c) ?Procedure. If an employee has knowledge of or a concern of illegal or dishonest fraudulent activity, 
the employee may contact one of the following to discuss the situation and evidence: 
 ?His/her immediate supervisor. 
 ?Human resources administrator. 
 ?Village manager. 
 ?Illinois state police at (271) 785-4377. 
 ?Attorney General at (312) 814-3000. 
 ?Inspector General (from Attorney General's Office) at (888) 814-4646. 
    Alternatively, a written complaint may be submitted to any of the above. The reporting employee 
must exercise sound judgment to avoid baseless allegations. Making allegations maliciously, recklessly or 
with the foreknowledge that the allegations were false is a serious offense and may result in discipline 
and/or penalties as provided in Illinois law or in the policies of the village. 
    Once a complaint is made, the human resources administrator will gather information or conduct an 
investigation, unless the complaint is regarding the human resources administrator. The human resources 
administrator may enlist the assistance of police department personnel for investigative purposes. In the 
event that the human resources administrator is the target, then the chief of police or chief's designee 
may investigate the complaint. Either the chief/chief's designee or the human resources administrator 
may request assistance from an accountant or auditor, if deemed appropriate. 
    The complaint and information gathered pursuant to the complaint will be kept confidential except as 
needed to complete the investigation, resolve the complaint, comply with applicable law or otherwise 
properly inform and receive feedback from the board of trustees or legal counsel. 
    The investigation shall begin as soon as practicable after a complaint is lodged and shall conclude 
as expeditiously as possible. The village manager will make a report to the board of trustees within 14 
days of the complaint or at the next available village board meeting. Once the investigation is completed, 
the findings, along with a recommendation made in consultation between legal counsel and the village 
manager, will be reduced to writing and submitted to the board of trustees. 
    The finding may be placed in a personnel file and disseminated if it is determined to be appropriate 
to do so. The finding may lead to disciplinary action on the part of the village as defined the village's 
Personnel Code. 
    This complaint procedure shall not be construed to create any independent right to any specific 
remedy or to a hearing. 
(Ord. No. 11-154, § 1, 9-19-2011) 


Secs. 2-5472-560. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VIII. - STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 04-93, § 1, adopted May 17, 2004, repealed the former Art. VIII, §§ 2-5612-
565, and enacted a new Art. VIII, § 2-561, as set out herein. The former Art. VIII pertained to gift ban and 
derived from Ord. No. 99-65, § 1(A-101)(A-103), (A-105), (A-106), adopted June 21, 1999. 


Sec. 2-561. - Adoption of Act. 
(a) ?The regulations of Sections 5-15 (5 ILCS 430/5-15) and Article 10 (5 ILCS 430/10-10 through 10-
40) of the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act, 5 ILCS 430/1-1 et seq., (hereinafter referred to 
as the "Act" in this section) are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and 
employees of the village to the extent required by 5 ILCS 430/70-5. 
(b) ?The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the Act, by any 
officer or any employee of the village, is hereby prohibited. 
(c) ?The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the 
village under the Act, is hereby prohibited. 
(d) ?The participation in political activities prohibited under the Act, by any officer or employee of the 
village, is hereby prohibited. 
(e) ?For purpose of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 
ILCS 430/70-5(c). 
(f) ?The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 ILCS 
430/50-5 for similar violations of the Act. 
(g) ?This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies 
which regulate the conduct of village officers and employees. To the extent that any such existing 
ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section 
shall prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 ILCS 430/70-5(a). 
(h) ?Any amendment to the Act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be 
incorporated into this section by reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, 
offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that 
makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this section 
by reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(i) ?If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the Act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be 
repealed as of the date that the Illinois Supreme Court's decision becomes final and not subject to 
any further appeals or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by 
the corporate authorities of the village if the Act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois Supreme 
Court. 
(j) ?If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the Act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality 
of the remainder of the Act, or does not address the remainder of the Act, then the remainder of the 
Act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this section 
relating to the part of the Act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action 
by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 04-93, § 1, 5-17-2004) 


Secs. 2-5622-565. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IX. - CONFERENCE AND TRAVEL POLICY. 


Sec. 2-566. - Conference and travel policy. 
    There shall be a conference and travel policy which sets criteria for payment and reimbursement of 
travel expenses incurred by the village president, village board of trustees, village employees and 
members of all village boards and commissions in the performance of their official functions. This policy, 
which may be amended from time to time, shall be distributed to all elected officials, employees and 
board and commission members, and kept on file with the village manager and village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 03-32, § 2, 2-17-2003) 


ARTICLE X. - COMPETITIVE BIDDING 


Sec. 2-567. - Competitive bidding. 
    It is the policy of the village to engage in competitive bidding and to award contracts to the lowest 
responsible bidder for public improvement projects where the costs of said projects exceed the minimum 
amount established by state statute, 65 ILCS 5/8-9-1 (the "Act"), as amended from time to time. It is 
further the policy of the village to comply with the requirements of the Act, other applicable provisions of 
Illinois law, and any policies approved by the village, when awarding contracts for public improvement 
projects, except as limited by section 2-568. 
(Ord. No. 18-180, § 2, 12-6-2018) 


Sec. 2-568. - Exceptions to competitive bidding. 
    The village is not obligated to comply with the competitive bidding requirements of state statute 
under the following circumstances: (1) where the public improvement project involves renovations or 
improvements to existing village buildings which cost in excess of the minimum amount established by 
state statute, and competitive bidding is impractical for such work, (2) where competitive bidding is 
impractical because the public improvement project is capable of only being primarily performed by a 
single source, or (3) where an emergency exists rendering competitive bidding impractical. 
    When one of said exceptions to the competitive bidding requirements applies, the contract for the 
public improvement project shall only be awarded if approved by a vote of two-thirds of the village 
trustees then holding office, as required by state statute. Additionally, if the public improvement project 
involves renovations or improvements to existing village buildings, the village shall first make reasonable 
attempts to obtain three proposals for the work, and the contract shall be awarded based on the lowest 
responsible proposal. 
    Competitive bidding is not required for the purchase of materials, for the use of professional or 
unique services, or for contracts between the village and the federal government or any agency thereof. 
(Ord. No. 18-180, § 2, 12-6-2018)
