multiple-family structures containing three (3) or more living units; and all buildings with 
business, commercial and industrial uses, including mixed use buildings. The fire resistance 
rating of structural elements (including outside walls and floors) and tenant separation or party 
walls, shall be a minimum of two (2) hours, except that the required minimum fire resistance 
rating and tenant separation or party wall shall be a minimum of one (1) hour for business or 
commercial occupancies which are equipped with a fire suppression and fire alarm system 
throughout the structure. 
(21) ?Add subsection "Sec. 903.2.13 Sprinkler Protection of Glass Openings (in a rated wall): Any 
opening that has a glass panel, e.g., sidelights, windows, glass doors, and/or similar openings, 
shall be protected by a specifically designed automatic sprinkler system. The sprinkler system 
shall include automatic sprinkler heads installed no further than eighteen inches (18") from the 
surface of the glass, and installed at six feet (6') on center horizontally on both sides of the 
glass. The sprinkler system shall completely wet the entire surface of the glass when activated. 
(22) ?Add subsection "Sec. 903.3.1.3 Sprinkler System Supervision." All fire alarm systems and 
suppression systems supervision shall be transmitted wirelessly and the wireless signal shall 
terminate at the Westmont Emergency Communication Center, located at 500 North Cass 
Avenue, Westmont, IL. All fire alarm systems and suppression systems supervision shall 
comply with NFPA 72 and shall be approved by the Fire Official. Such fire alarm systems and 
suppression systems supervision are currently monitored at the Downers Grove/Westmont 
Dispatch Center. The following signals shall be supervised: 
(A) ?All flow signals from any fire suppression system in service; and 
(B) ?All system components which are normally supervised, including valves, pressures and 
levels which are critical to the system operation, and all signal components required under 
National Fire Protection Standards, and any other component deemed necessary of the 
proper operation of the system. 
(23) ?Add subsection "Sec. 903.2.13 Automatic Sprinkler Systems, Where Required: 
(A) ?Any new building over two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet, or over three (3) 
stories in height. 
(B) ?Any restaurant with an occupancy of over fifty (50) persons, or any place of assembly with 
occupancies over fifty (50) persons. 
(C) ?Any building which is added on to that will increase the building to more than two 
thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet. 
(D) ?Any building over two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet that has a change in use 
to a more hazardous use as determined by the Westmont Fire Department. Examples of 
more hazardous uses include but are not limited to: Change of use from an Office or Retail 
use to a hardware store or other use where paint, paint thinners, Lacquers, or other 
flammable materials are stored on the property. Change in use from office to retail or retail 
to office will not, in and of itself, trigger the requirement to install sprinklers. 
(E) ?Any new duplex which includes any dwelling attached, or semidetached unit, or any new 
two (2) family detached dwelling units. 
(F) ?Any new multiple family dwelling, which is a dwelling containing three (3) or more dwelling 
units. 
(G) ?Any, and all, building general contractors must also provide a signed memorandum that a 
sprinkler system, and one hundred percent (100%) brick veneer exterior wall construction, 
is available as an option for all new single family homes. 
(H) ?Any commercial building over 2,500 square feet which is the subject of remodeling 
including, but not limited to: removal of interior walls, relocation of interior walls, addition of 
interior walls, addition or removal of door or window openings, relocation of door or window 
openings, substantial changes, additions, or upgrades to building plumbing or electrical 
systems, addition of building square footage through building addition or number of stories, 
removal of building square footage, or any other such substantial renovation deemed by 
the Director if Economic Development to trigger the need for sprinklers. This section shall 
not include redecorating or maintenance efforts such as carpeting, wall coverings, 
countertops, or replacement with like kind and quality roofing, plumbing, heating, air 
conditioning, or lighting fixtures. Upgrades to electrical and plumbing service by itself shall 
not trigger the requirements for sprinklers. Further, any interior remodeling of an area 
representing less than 20% of the total building square footage, not to exceed 1,000 
square feet, shall be permitted without triggering the requirement for sprinklers. Such 
limited remodeling shall be permitted no more than once every three years, without 
triggering the sprinkler requirement. 
(I) ?Any remodeling which does not breach a "Building Separation/Fire Wall" shall not, in and 
of itself, trigger a requirement to install fire suppression sprinklers in an existing 
commercial building in the B-1 District. 
(J) ?A mixed use occupancy (i.e., commercial and residential) in any new building or 
redevelopment of an existing building shall trigger the sprinkler requirement. 
(24) ?Class III standpipe systems shall be installed throughout buildings three (3) stories or more in 
height above grade level, or where the floor level of the lowest story is located three (3) stories 
or more below grade. Grade level shall be measured from the grade level main entrance of the 
building and approved by the Fire Code Official. 
Exceptions: 
1. ?Class I standpipes are allowed in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic 
sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2. 
2. ?Class I manual standpipes are allowed in open parking garages where the highest floor is 
located not more than three (3) stories above grade. Approval is per the Fire Code Official. 
3. ?Class I manual dry standpipes are allowed in open parking garages that are subject to 
freezing temperatures, provided that the hose connections are located as required for 
Class II standpipes in accordance with Section 905.5. Approval is per the Fire Code 
Official. 
4. ?Class I standpipes are allowed in basements equipped throughout with an automatic 
sprinkler system. 
5. ?Buildings four (4) stories or less above grade level; the fire code official may approve: 
5.1 ?Operating pressures of less than 100 psi at the outlet of the hydraulically most 
remote 2-½ hose connection. The reduced outlet pressure shall not be less than 65 
psi. 
5.2 ?A Class I standpipe system in lieu of a Class III system. 
(25) ?Add the following to Sec. 907.2 Where Required. The following buildings shall have an "NFPA 
72" approved fire detection and alarm system installed: 
(A) ?Any new building. 
(B) ?All existing commercial properties or multi-family properties with three (3) or more living 
units. However, such non-compliant properties subject to this requirement shall be entitled 
to an alternative arrangement as follows: 
(i) ?Such properties shall be permitted to phase-in compliance in three (3) phases, with 
the first phase completed within six months of notice of violation, the second phase 
within nine months, the final phase within 12 months. 
(ii) ?Such properties shall be permitted phase-in compliance only if the property owner 
has a signed contract with a qualified fire alarm contractor to install a NFPA 72 
compliant fire alarm system by a specified date. 
(iii) ?such properties, through their property owner, have executed a memorandum of 
understanding with the village, on a form provided by the Village, acknowledging the 
phase-in compliance obligations; and 
(iv) ?Each day any part or portion of the phase-in compliance does not meet the 
obligations of this ordinance and/or the memorandum of understanding shall be 
considered a violation of this ordinance and that penalties may be assessed pursuant 
to Section 113.5. 
(C) ?Sprinkled buildings conforming to NFPA 13 are not required to have detection devices 
(i.e., smoke/heat detectors) unless otherwise required by adopted codes. Properties 
protected by a compliant sprinkler system are required to have manual pull stations, 
compliant notification devices, and compliant supervisory switches monitored by a 
compliant fire alarm control panel. 
(26) ?Add to Sec. 907 - Smoke detectors as part of system. Full detection, via complaint smoke 
detectors, is required in all Group E, I, R-1 and R-2 use groups. This requirement applies even if 
property has a compliant sprinkler system. 
(27) ?Add subsection: "Section 907.6.5.3 Fire Protection System Monitoring." All fire alarm systems 
and suppressions systems supervision shall be transmitted wirelessly and the wireless signal 
shall terminate at the Westmont Emergency Communication Center, located at 500 North Cass 
Avenue, Westmont, IL. All fire alarm systems and suppression systems supervision shall 
comply with NFPA 72 and shall be approved by the Fire Official. Such fire alarm systems and 
suppression systems supervision are currently monitored at the Downers Grove/Westmont 
Dispatch Center. 
Existing fire alarm and suppression systems that are monitored elsewhere or which do not have 
monitoring shall be transmitted wirelessly and the wireless signal shall terminate at the 
Westmont Emergency Communication Center, located at 500 North Cass Avenue, Westmont, 
IL. All fire alarm systems and suppression systems supervision shall comply with NFPA 72 and 
shall be approved by the Fire Official. Such fire alarm systems and suppression systems 
supervision are currently monitored at the Downers Grove/Westmont Dispatch Center. 
(28) ?Add subsection: Sec. 1403.1.1 Duplex, Townhomes, and Two-family dwellings. Any new 
duplex dwelling unit, townhome, or two-family dwelling, built must have fifty percent (50%) of all 
exterior walls, excluding window and door openings, constructed with a nominal four inch (4") 
face brick (wood frame, brick veneer) or a four inch (4") nominal natural stone.

Sec. 18-63. - Standards for residential tear downs for remodeling. 
    For the purpose of applying the codes of the village, a residential "remodeling" project is defined as a 
project which maintains a minimum of two adjoining exterior walls and foundation in place during such 
remodeling. Any project which fails to meet this minimum standard shall be classified as a "tear down." 
(Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 1-1-2015) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, amended various sections 
in Ch. 18, and in effect repealed and reenacted § 18-63, as set out herein. Former § 18-63 
pertained to additions, deletions and changes to building codes and derived from Ord. No. 12-
113, § 1(Attch. A), adopted June 18, 2012 and Ord. No. 13-42, § 1(Exh. A), adopted March 4, 
2013. Text pertaining to additions, deletions and changes is now set forth in § 18-62. 


Sec. 18-64. - Standards for exterior construction for duplex units. 
    Any new duplex unit constructed must have 50 percent of all exterior walls, excluding window and 
door openings, constructed with nominal 4 inch face brick (wood frame, brick veneer) or a 4 inch nominal 
natural stone B. 
(Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 1-1-2015) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, amended various sections 
in Ch. 18, and in effect repealed and reenacted § 18-64, as set out herein. Former § 18-64 
pertained to the Property Maintenance Code and derived from Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 
adopted June 18, 2012. Text pertaining to the Property Maintenance Code is now set forth in § 
18-62. 


Sec. 18-65. - Standards for construction types other than single-family homes and duplexes. 
    For all construction types other than single-family home and duplexes, exterior wall construction shall 
be masonry. Brick veneer construction shall not be permitted. All floors shall be of pre-cast concrete type, 
poured concrete type, or other type having at least a two-hour fire resistance rating. Upon approval of the 
required fire rating by the fire department, the community development director may administratively 
approve waivers to the masonry requirement if all other building and fire code requirements are met. 
    In addition, any new duplex dwelling unit build must have 50 percent of all exterior walls, excluding 
window and door openings, constructed with a nominal four-inch face brick (wood frame, brick veneer) or 
a four-inch nominal natural stone. 
(Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 1-1-2015; Ord. No. 17-135, § 1, 8-31-2017) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, amended various sections 
in Ch. 18, and in effect repealed and reenacted § 18-65, as set out herein. Former § 18-65 
pertained to the Mechanical Code and derived from Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), adopted 
June 18, 2012. Text pertaining to the Mechanical Code is now set forth in § 18-62.

ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 18-86. - Office of plumbing inspector created, appointment. 
    There is hereby created the position of plumbing inspector, who shall be appointed by the village 
manager subject to the approval of the village president with the consent of the village board. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-87. - Community development director to act as ex officio plumbing inspector. 
    The community development director shall act as ex officio plumbing inspector and shall have the 
powers and perform all the duties connected with that office. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-88. - Enforcement. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have the authority to enforce all provisions of this article and other 
ordinances of the village relating to plumbing. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-89. - Right of entry of plumbing inspector. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building in the 
discharge of his/her official duties, or for the purpose of making an inspection or test of the plumbing 
equipment therein. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-90. - Sewer connections, when required; independent connection required for each building. 
    Every building within the village shall be separately and independently connected by a separate 
house service sewer pipe with a public sewer where there is such a sewer adjoining the lot within 300 feet 
of the lot or parcel on which such building stands. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012, effective 1-1-2015) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, amended various sections 
in Ch. 18, and in so doing repealed § 18-90, which pertained to inspectionswork not to be 
covered prior to inspection, and renumbered § 18-93 as § 18-90, and derived Ord. No. 12-113, § 
1(Attch. A), adopted June 18, 2012. 


Sec. 18-91. - Connections to stormwater drainage system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or cause to be connected any drain carrying, or to 
carry, any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool, industrial waste, or any fixture or device 
discharging polluting substances to any stormwater drainage system constructed as part of the building 
improvement. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012, effective 1-1-2015) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, amended various sections 
in Ch. 18, and in so doing repealed § 18-91, which pertained to stop ordersissuance; 
resumption of work; and service, and renumbered § 18-91 as § 18-94, and derived Ord. No. 12-
113, § 1(Attch. A), adopted June 18, 2012. 


Sec. 18-92. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, effective Jan. 1, 2015, 
amended various sections in Ch. 18, and in so doing repealed § 18-92, which pertained to 
violation of stop orders and derived Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), adopted June 18, 2012. 


Secs. 18-9318-120. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - PLUMBING CODE 


Sec. 18-121. - Adoption. 
    There is hereby adopted by the village for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the 
construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location, and maintenance 
of the building structures, including permits and penalties, a plumbing code known as the Illinois Plumbing 
Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890), as required by the State of Illinois, Department of Public Health. The Illinois 
Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890) is adopted and incorporated by this reference as though fully set 
forth herein. From date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling 
the construction of the buildings and other structures therein contained within the corporate limits of the 
village. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-138, § 2, 8-7-2014; Ord. No. 16-113, § 
2, 6-23-2016)

ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICITY 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 18-186. - Scope; title. 
    This article establishes the minimum standards, specifications, rules and regulations for electrical 
installations, alterations and repairs, and shall be known and may be cited as the electrical code of the 
Village of Westmont. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-187. - Purpose of minimum standards. 
    The minimum standards and specifications adopted by this article are deemed to be those necessary 
to assure reasonable safety to life and property. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-188. - Adoption of electrical code; amendments. 
(a) ?Adoption . The standards and specifications of the National Electric Code, 2011 Edition, as may be 
amended from time to time and as amended below and forthcoming are hereby adopted as the 
standards and specifications and rules and regulations for the installations, alteration, repair, and use 
of electrical equipment, subject; however, to additional standards, rules and regulations set forth in 
this chapter and except where they are in conflict with other provisions of this Code. 
(b) ?Amendments . The following Amendments to the National Electric Code, 2011 Edition, are hereby 
adopted: 
Section 110.26(C) (1) add: all three (3) phase shall have the entrance and egress door swing 
outward with panic hardware. 
Section 210.8 Ground-Fault Circuit-Interrupter Protection for Personnel. Change this paragraph to 
read: "Self-diagnostic type ground-fault circuit-interrupter protection (LED) for personnel shall be 
provided as required in 210.8(A) through (C). The Self-diagnostic type ground-fault circuit-interrupter 
shall be installed in a readily accessible location." 
Section 210(A) Dwelling Units. Add as paragraph nine "(9) all floor receptacles shall have ground-
fault circuit-interrupter protection (breaker) as required." 
Section 210.12(B) Branch Circuit Extensions or Modifications - Dwelling Units. Add subsection as 
follows: "(3) Bedroom circuit shall not exit to common hallways." 
Section 210, Table 210.21(B) (3) Receptacle Ratings for Various Size Circuits. Line two (2) shall 
read: Circuit rating twenty (20) amp, receptacle rating of twenty (20) amp only. 
Article 230 - Services - Section 230.1 Scope. Add the following sentence at the end of the section: 
"All new services shall be underground." 
Article 250 - Grounding and Bonding. Section 250-1 Scope. Add the following Subsection: "(7) no 
electrical installation in the Village of Westmont shall rely on a ground rod, or rods, as means of 
grounding when a water utility system connection exists on the property." 
Section 250-62 Grounding Electrode Conductor Material. Place a period after the word "copper" in 
the first (1 st ) sentence and delete the remainder of the sentence. 
Section 250.64 Grounding Electrode Conductor Installation. Delete paragraph (A). 
Table 250-66 Table Grounding Electrode Conductor for Alternating Current Systems. Delete 
reference to aluminum or copper-clad aluminum. 
Section 314.27(A) Boxes or Lampholder Outlets. Add the following sentence at the end of the 
paragraph: "Fan rated boxes are required in all bedrooms." 
Section 410-16(A) Luminaire Types Permitted. Delete entire subsection and replace with "Only 
receded or fluorescent fixture may be used in clothes closets." 
Section 820.26 Spread of Fire or Products of Combustion. Add at the end of the paragraph the 
following: "The accessible portion of abandoned network powered broadband communications 
cables shall not be permitted to remain." 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 
1-1-2015) 


Sec. 18-189. - Additional standards and specifications. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to over fuse any conductor, motor, or apparatus in excess of the 
maximum allowed by the electrical regulations of this Code for such conductor, motor, or apparatus, 
or to install any substitute in lieu of an approved fuse or devise, so as to remove or reduce the factor 
of safety of the same. 
(b) ?Heavy wall rigid metal conduit, intermediate metal conduit, or PVC conduit shall only be used in all 
poured concrete.) 
(1) ?Conduit larger than one-half inch in four inches of concrete is not permitted. 
(2) ?EMT not permitted in concrete, or outdoors. 
(3) ?PVC #80, rigid galvanized or intermediate conduit may be used for underground service. 
(c) ?PVC shall not emerge from below grade level ground. PVC shall convert to galvanized rigid conduit 
prior to its emergence. 
(d) ?Minimum service size on commercial buildings shall be 100 single phase, or three phase. 
(e) ?Twin, or tandem, circuit breakers are not acceptable for new work. 
(f) ?Dry wall rings must be installed on all concealed ceiling openings on new work. 
(g) ?Over current protection shall be required in all underground conductors. 
(h) ?Prints involving hazardous areas must be approved prior to installation. 
(i) ?Only copper wire shall be permitted for use in the Village of Westmont. 
(j) ?All wiring shall be in metal conduit, except low voltage wiring. 
(k) ?Where new construction, or alteration work, involves electrical work of any type, the construction 
plans shall include a complete wiring plan that contains the following information: 
(1) ?Size of wire, insulation type, and conduit size. 
(2) ?Number of circuits and their ampere rating. 
(3) ?Location of all electrical panels and cabinets. 
(4) ?Size of all motors and power consuming equipment, and their ratings. 
(5) ?Specifications and locations for all exit lights and emergency lights. 
(6) ?Schedule on lighting and power panels. 
(7) ?Every electrical panel shall contain a panel circuit director card identifying all circuits. 
Commercial and industrial panels shall be typed or computer generated. 
(8) ?All commercial and industrial wiring shall be minimum 12 gauge wiring, except low voltage 
wiring. 
(9) ?An approved nonferrous metal tag shall be attached to the ground electrode clamp giving 
warning against its removal. 
(10) ?Thin wall (EMT) conduit shall not be used for electrical services. Aluminum rigid conduit, if 
used, shall be installed above grade only. 
(11) ?Underground electrical service permitted in PVC #80 at 32 inches below grade. 
(12) ?No PVC shall emerge from the ground or concrete slab or encasement. PVC shall convert to 
galvanized rigid conduit prior to its emergence. 
(13) ?All rooms with multiple entrance or exits, which are more than six feet apart shall utilize three-
way or four-way switches, unless an alternate arrangement is approved by electrical inspector. 
(14) ?Any secondary or sub feeder crossing under driveways, parking lots, or vehicle traffic ways 
shall be encased in heavy wall rigid conduit or intermediate metallic conduit; 30 inches depth 
required. 
(l) ?In all commercial restrooms (size does not apply), there shall be provided an emergency battery 
backup lighting system installed inside. 
(m) ?All single family units having living spaces less than 2,000 square feet shall utilize a minimum 100 
ampere service excluding the requirements of electrical heating, if any. All occupancies having living 
spaces greater than 2,000 square feet shall utilize a minimum of 200 ampere service exclusive of 
electrical heating. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 
1-1-2015) 


Sec. 18-190. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, effective Jan. 1, 2015, 
amended various sections in Ch. 18, and in so doing repealed § 18-190, which pertained to 
penalty for violation or noncompliance and derived Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), adopted 
June 18, 2012. 


Secs. 18-19118-210. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR 


Sec. 18-211. - Office created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the position of electrical inspector, who shall be appointed by the village 
manager with the approval of the village president and the board of trustees and who shall serve under 
the supervision of the community development director. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-212. - Designation of ex officio electrical inspector. 
    The community development director shall act as ex officio electrical inspector, and shall have the 
powers and perform all the duties connected with that office. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-213. - General powers. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building in the 
discharge of his or her official duties, or for the purpose of making an inspection or test of the electrical 
equipment therein; and he shall have the authority to enforce all the ordinances of the village relating to 
electrical wiring and equipment. The electrical inspector shall have the power to cause the current in any 
wire or conduit to be turned off whenever this is necessary in an emergency for the protection of life and 
property. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Secs. 18-21418-260. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION 


Sec. 18-466. - Registration certificate and bonding. 
    Applications for a certificate of registration shall be issued by the community development 
department for the following trades: 
(1) ?General. 
(2) ?Excavator. 
(3) ?Concrete. 
(4) ?Carpentry. 
(5) ?Masonry. 
(6) ?HVAC. 
(7) ?Lathing and plastering. 
(8) ?Glazing. 
(9) ?Iron work. 
(10) ?Paving. 
(11) ?Landscaping. 
(12) ?Underground utilities. 
(13) ?Drywallers. 
(14) ?Electricians. 
(15) ?Roofers. 
(16) ?Swimming pool and spa installers. 
(17) ?Sprinkler installers. 
    An annual registration fee of $50.00 per contractor is required. A bond in the penal sum or 
$10,000.00 shall also be required, the condition of the bond being compliant with all ordinances of the 
village. Contractor registration fees are nonrefundable. 
    Roofing contractors, in addition to the registration requirements, shall also produce a copy of a 
current and valid State of Illinois Roofers License. 
    Electrical contractors, in addition to the registration requirements, shall produce a copy of a current 
and valid license from another municipality which administers an acceptable electrical exam, as 
determined by the community development director. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 
1-1-2015) 


Secs. 18-46718-485. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VIII. - FEES AND BONDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, amended various sections in Ch. 18, 
and in so doing changed the title of Art. VIII from "Permit fees and bonds" to "Fees and Bonds," as set out 
herein. 


Sec. 18-486. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 17-025, § 2, 2-16-2017, repealed § 18-486, which pertained to plan 
review fees and derived from Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Dec. 2, 2014 and Ord. No. 
15-099, § 2, adopted June 11, 2015. 


Sec. 18-487. - Building permit fees. 
    The village will collect building permit fees as set forth in this section to cover the costs of performing 
building and zoning plan reviews, checking computations, determining estimates of cost, researching 
specifications and other similar activities in order to issue a building permit. Building permit fees are non-
refundable. If third party or outsourced professional services are used by the village to review plans or 
any other aspect of a project, the applicant shall reimburse the village for the costs of such services in 
addition to the building permit fees. If an applicant withdraws their building permit request prior to a permit 
being issued, the applicant is liable for any base fee, and third party or outsourced professional services 
cost rendered by the village up to and including the date of withdrawal. 
    The building permit fees set forth in this section do not include engineering plan review and 
inspection fees, fire department plan review or inspection fees, water connection and other water utility 
related fees, bonds, certificate of occupancy fees pursuant to section 18-489 of this Code, or other 
required inspection fees pursuant to section 18-490 of this Code. 
    Building permit fees shall be determined as follows: 
(1) ?Commercial : 
a. ?Scope : Commercial building permit fees shall apply to all buildings or structures in the 
commercial, business, manufacturing, office/research and multi-family use categories, as 
defined in the village zoning code, which are designed by an architect or structural 
engineer, including but not limited to, new construction, repair, renovation, addition and/or 
remodeling. Commercial building permit fees shall also apply to include all accessory 
buildings, structures and fences, including but not limited to new construction, repair, 
renovation, addition and/or remodeling. The types of uses in the commercial category, and 
their accompanying buildings or structures, are specified in appendix A - Zoning, article VII 
and VIII of this Code. 
b. ?Building permit fee calculation : The building permit fees for all uses listed in subsection a. 
above shall be calculated based on the market value of the construction or improvement to 
be completed. The market value shall be determined based upon the value stated in the 
publication entitled "Means Square Foot Costs," published by R.S. Means Company, Inc., 
Kingston. Massachusetts, as amended from time to time, which publication is hereby 
adopted by reference by the village. In lieu of using this publication, the village may, in its 
discretion, use the value listed on a signed contract between the applicant and its 
contractor(s). 
c. ?Building permit fee amounts : Except as provided in subsection d., below, the building 
permit for any commercial project shall be equal to a base fee of $100.00 or one and one-
half percent of the market value of the construction or improvement to be completed as 
determined in subsection b. Above, whichever is more. If the building permit includes 
electrical work, an additional fee of $75.00 shall be charged. If the building permit includes 
plumbing work, an additional fee of $75.00 shall be charged. The building permit fee 
amount does not include required inspection fees pursuant to section 18-490 of this Code. 
d. ?Flat fee commercial building permit fee amounts : The following projects shall be charged a 
flat fee of $150.00 (plus applicable inspection fees): 
1. ?Fences; 
2. ?Exterior concrete/asphalt flat work (i.e., driveways, patios, sidewalks); 
3. ?Window and door replacement (provided no structural alteration); 
4. ?Generators; 
5. ?HVAC and water heater installation and replacement; and 
6. ?Roofs (such as tear-offs or a second layer; as long as no structural work is involved). 
(2) ?Residential . 
a. ?Scope : Residential building permit fees shall apply to all one and two family dwellings, 
including but not limited to, new construction, repair, renovation, addition and/or 
remodeling. Residential building permit fees shall also apply to all accessory buildings, 
structures and fences, including but not limited to new construction, repair, renovation, 
addition and/or remodeling. 
b. ?Building permit fee calculation : The building permit fees for residential permits shall be 
calculated based on the estimated cost of the project. The estimated cost of the project 
shall be determined based upon the value stated in the publication entitled "Means Square 
Foot Costs," published by R.S. Means Company, Inc., Kingston, Massachusetts, as 
amended from time to time, which publication is hereby adopted by reference by the 
village. In lieu of using this publication, the village may, in its discretion, use the value listed 
on a signed contract between the applicant and its contractor(s). 
c. ?Building permit fee amounts : Except as provided in subsection d. below, the building 
permit fees for any residential project shall equal a base fee of $75.00 plus one and one-
half percent of the estimated cost of the construction or improvement to be completed as 
determined in subsection b. above, whichever is more. If the building permit includes 
electrical work, an additional fee of $75.00 shall be charged. If the building permit includes 
plumbing work, an additional fee of $75.00 shall be charged. The building permit fee 
amount does not include required inspection fees pursuant to section 18-490 of this Code. 
d. ?Flat fee residential building permit fee amount : The following projects shall be charged a 
flat fee of $100.00 (includes one inspection): 
1. ?Fences. 
2. ?Roofs (provided no structural work is involved; tear off or second layer only). 
3. ?Exterior concrete/asphalt flat work (i.e., driveways, patios, sidewalks). 
4. ?Window and door replacement (provided no structural alteration). 
5. ?Generators. 
6. ?HVAC and water heater installation and replacement. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § l(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 
1-1-2015; Ord. No. 15-017, § 1, 1-22-2015; Ord. No. 15-099, § 2, 6-11-2015; Ord. No. 17-025, § 
2, 2-16-2017; Ord. No. 18-174, § 2, 12-6-2018) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 17-025, § 2, adopted Feb. 16, 2017, amended § 18-487 and in so doing 
changed the title of said section from "Permit fees" to "Building permit fees," as set out herein. 


Sec. 18-488. - Bonds. 
(a) ?Bond amounts required . Cash bonds to ensure the completion of building construction and the 
proper installation of building materials in accordance with approved site plans, building plans, 
special use permits, sign permits, landscaping plans, engineering plans, temporary occupancies, and 
approved specifications, shall be made in accordance with the following schedule. Irrevocable letters 
of credit, or surety bonds may be submitted in lieu of cash bond upon approval by the community 
development director: 
(1) ?New one- and two-family dwelling . One percent of total cost of project (not to exceed 
$10,000.00). 
(2) ?New multi-family dwelling building (under 50 living units) . One percent of total cost of project 
(not to exceed $15,000.00). 
(3) ?New multi-family dwelling building (50 to 100 living units) . One percent of total cost of project 
(not to exceed $50,000.00). 
(4) ?New multi-family dwelling building (over 100 living units) . One percent of total cost of project 
(not to exceed $100,000.00). 
(5) ?New nonresidential building . Five percent of total cost of project (not to exceed $50,000.00). 
(6) ?Nonresidential building alteration, renovation, addition, or build-out . Two percent of total cost 
of project (not to exceed $25,000.00). 
(7) ?Residential building alteration, renovation, addition, or build-out . One percent of total cost of 
project (not to exceed $5,000.00). 
(8) ?Site work (multiple-family/nonresidential) . Five percent of total cost of project (not to exceed 
$25,000.00). 
(9) ?Engineering . See section 34-112 of this Code for engineering bond amounts. 
(b) ?Increase in required bond amounts. The bond sums required by this section shall be increased in an 
appropriate amount if, in the opinion of the director of public works or village engineer, the amount 
required therein would not be sufficient to construct required improvements or repair damages to 
sidewalks, pavements, trees or any other village property which is already damaged or will most 
likely be damaged in the course of construction. 
(c) ?Deposit . The deposit required by this section shall be in addition to any plan review fee, inspection 
fees, and building or engineering permit fees. 
(d) ?Refunds . Cash bonds deposits made pursuant to this section shall be refunded to the permittee 
upon the following: 
(1) ?Return of the cash bond receipt from the village; 
(2) ?After it has been documented and verified by the village that the permittee is in compliance with 
this Code and all other applicable ordinances of the village; 
(3) ?After issuance of a certificate of occupancy or temporary certificate of occupancy by the village; 
and 
(4) ?After any deductions are calculated by the community development department and approved 
by the finance department; for: 
a. ?Unpaid re-inspection fees, 
b. ?Required improvements or repairs to sidewalks, trees, pavements or other village property. 
(e) ?Forfeiture . Any deposit made as required by this section which is not redeemed within two years 
after completion of the work (except as provided in subsection (g) below), shall be forfeited to the 
village. Upon a determination that there is no outstanding work to be completed, or that any 
outstanding work to be completed is minor in nature and, if not completed, will not adversely impact 
the property, surrounding properties or the public health and safety, then the forfeited deposit shall 
be transferred to the village's general fund to be used to fund general village operations. Upon a 
determination that outstanding work does adversely affect the property, surrounding properties or the 
public health and safety, then the village may utilize the deposit to have the outstanding work 
completed. 
(f) ?Central business district completion bond . Redevelopment projects in the central business district, 
excluding new construction projects, shall post a separate central business district completion bond 
(the "completion bond"), in addition to meeting the other requirements of this section. The completion 
bond of $3,000.00 is payable as a cash bond or approved letter of credit, and is due to the village 
prior to the issuance of building permits. The completion bond shall be forfeited to the village as a 
penalty in the event that a redevelopment project is not completed and open for business/occupancy 
within 12 months after approval of the project by the village board. The village board may grant 
extensions of this 12-month period upon a timely written request by the developer. 
(g) ?Waiver of bonds . 
(1) ?The bonds required by subsections 18-487 (1) d. and (2) d. for flat fee permits may be waived 
in total at the discretion of the director. 
(2) ?The bonds required by subsections 18-487 (1) c. and (2) c. for permits which fee amounts 
calculate to be less than $100.00 may be waived in total at the discretion of the director. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014; Ord. No. 
15-135, § 2, 8-6-2015; Ord. No. 18-174, § 2, 12-6-2018) 


Sec. 18-489. - Certificate of occupancy fee. 
    The fee for a certificate of occupancy shall be as follows: 
(1) ?Residential, including: Alterations/remodeling, garages, accessory buildings: $100.00. 
(2) ?Commercial structures, including: Common spaces, each tenant space, alterations/remodeling: 
$100.00. 
(3) ?Existing buildings: $100.00. 
(4) ?Changes in use and occupancy (associated with issuance of a business license): $100.00. 
(5) ?A multi-family dwelling unit, including individual rental units, duplexes, townhomes and 
condominiums: $50.00 per dwelling unit. For purposes of this requirement, a nursing home, 
senior or youth institution, or other congregant care facility are considered to be a commercial 
structure. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 13-51, § 4, 3-18-2013; Ord. No. 14-170, § 
1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014; Ord. No. 18-174, § 2, 12-6-2018) 


Sec. 18-490. - Inspection fees. 
(a) ?There is no charge for an initial inspection for construction, improvement, repair and/or alteration of 
one and two family residences, individual units of multi-unit townhouses or individual condominium 
units as one inspection (i.e., footing inspection) is included at no charge as part of the building permit 
fee. Inspection and re-inspection fees for residential construction, improvement, repair and/or 
alteration are $50.00 per inspection, following the first included (no-charge) inspection. 
(b) ?Inspection and re-inspection fees for commercial construction, improvement, repair and/or alteration 
are $100.00 per inspection. 
(c) ?Payment for all inspections and re-inspections is required prior to the inspection being performed or 
it may be paid out of the applicant's bond, in the discretion of the community development director. 
(d) ?Specialized inspections : Additional specialized inspections as defined by the adopted codes of the 
village may be required by the community development director or an authorized designee, when 
special circumstances warrant. The specialized inspection fee shall be $100.00 per inspection or the 
cost of the third party or outsourced professional service fee for such inspection, whichever is 
greater. Payment for specialized inspections is required prior to the inspection being performed. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 15-099, § 2, 6-11-2015; Ord. No. 17-025, 
§ 2, 2-16-2017; Ord. No. 18-174, § 2, 12-6-2018) 


Secs. 18-49118-510. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IX. - INSPECTIONS 


Sec. 18-511. - Required. 
    The director shall prescribe on-site inspections necessary for determination of compliance with 
building plans. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-512. - Notice to be given. 
    The director shall be given at least 24 hours' notice of the starting of work or before one of the 
inspections prescribed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-513. - Right of entry. 
    The director shall have the power to make or cause to be made an entry into any building or 
premises where the work of altering, repairing or constructing of any building or structure is going on for 
the purpose of making inspections, at any reasonable hour. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-514. - Accessibility. 
    On all inspections required by this article, all covers must be left open. All necessary equipment, 
including ladders and hose, must be available for use of the director. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-515. - Permittee to give notice. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the permittee to notify the director when the building for which a permit 
under this chapter has been granted is ready for inspection. The director shall be given at least 24 
business hours' notice of said inspection. The director or his/her designee has at least three days to 
complete requested inspection. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-516. - Failure to call for inspection. 
    Failure to call for an inspection as required by this article will mean forfeiting of cash bond and permit 
and will be considered a violation of the building code. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-517. - Re-inspections. 
    If an inspection is called for before the feature to be inspected is ready or if the feature fails 
inspection, a reinspection charge of $50.00 for residential, and $100.00 for commercial, will be assessed 
and is payable prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or final inspection. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 
1-1-2015) 


Sec. 18-518. - Survey stakes. 
    Permanent survey points will be provided for all lots prior to construction and such identifying 
property line markers shall be maintained during the course of construction and will be accessible upon 
completion of construction. In the case of permits for additions and accessory structures, such as fences, 
sheds, etc., it shall be the responsibility of the property owner to insure they know where their property 
lines are in the absence of survey stakes. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-519. - Plat of survey. 
    A plat of survey prepared by a state registered land surveyor will be provided for each building after 
the foundations and footings have been constructed and prior to any further construction. All dimensions, 
elevations, and other information pertinent to proper evaluation will be provided and accepted by the 
Director prior to any further construction. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Secs. 18-52018-550. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE X. - CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY 


Sec. 18-551. - General. 
    No building or structure shall be used or occupied, and no change in the existing occupancy 
classification of a building or structure or portion thereof shall be made until the director has issued a 
certificate of occupancy therefor as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-552. - Certificate issued. 
    After the building official inspects a building or structure and finds no violations of the provisions of 
the village codes, ordinances or other laws that are enforced by the village, shall issue a certificate of 
occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-553. - Temporary certificate of occupancy. 
(a) ?A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued by the director, provided the following 
conditions apply: 
(1) ?The holder of the building permit(s) shall have completed all interior construction of the 
building, exterior construction of the building and site work including site grading and any/all 
stormwater management; and 
(2) ?A cash bond of not less than $10.000.00 shall be posted payable to the Village of Westmont. 
(b) ?No temporary certificate of occupancy shall be issued during the months of May through November. 
A temporary certificate of occupancy may otherwise be considered for incomplete landscape 
restoration or any site improvements not attainable during the winter season. A temporary certificate 
of occupancy shall be valid for a period not to exceed 60 days from the date of issuance. Relief from 
this deadline may be made in writing to the community development director, who shall assess the 
situation on a case by case basis and determine if a particular hardship exists to grant an extension 
beyond the 60-day deadline. 
(c) ?Once a final certificate of occupancy is issued, the cash bond shall be released to the individual who 
posted it. If the temporary certificate of occupancy expires and a final inspection is not called for, the 
bond shall be forfeited and the matter may be turned over for legal proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-134, § 2, 8-7-2014) 


Sec. 18-554. - Revocation. 
    The director shall, in writing, suspend or revoke a certificate of occupancy issued under the 
provisions of this chapter where the certificate is issued in error, or on the basis of incorrect information 
supplied, or where it is determined that the building or structure or portion thereof is in violation of any 
ordinance or regulation of the Village of Westmont. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Secs. 18-55518-575. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE XI. - BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION SITE OPERATIONS 


Sec. 18-576. - Night operations. 
    No construction or alteration operations shall be carried on between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 
a.m. if such activities are accompanied by loud or annoying noises. Provided, that emergency repairs 
may be undertaken if the conditions so dictate. See appendix A, section 8.02, subsection (B)(1) for noise 
control standards. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-577. - Obstruction and removal of sidewalks. 
    No sidewalk shall be obstructed in the course of building operations without a special permit from the 
public works director, and whenever a removal of a sidewalk is required such work shall not be done until 
a permit is secured in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-578. - Maintenance and restoration of public alley adjoining construction site. 
    It shall be the duty of the builder, contractor, owner, and person holding the permit authorizing the 
construction of any work within the village to maintain any public alley adjoining the construction site 
during the period of construction so that the ingress and egress of the alley shall not be impaired. The 
person holding such construction permit shall be responsible, upon completion of the construction for 
which the permit was issued, to restore such alley to the same condition as it was prior to his undertaking 
the construction. Upon the failure of such person to comply with this section, after notice so to do from the 
community development director or the public works director, the village may cause such repair work to 
be undertaken at the cost of the person to whom the permit was issued and such cost may be deducted 
from the bond provided for in section 18-488. Such repair by the village shall not relieve such person from 
any penalty imposed for the failure to comply with this section. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-579. - Safeguards; barricades; lights. 
(a) ?It shall be the duty of a person doing any constructing, altering, or wrecking to do such work with 
proper care for the safety of persons and property. 
(b) ?Warning barricades and lights shall be maintained whenever necessary for the protection of 
pedestrians or traffic; and temporary roofs over sidewalks shall be constructed whenever there is 
danger from falling articles or materials to pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-580. - Storage of building materials and equipment on streets or sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to store tools, equipment or building materials in the streets or 
upon sidewalks in the village for a period of more than 24 hours without special permission from the 
public works director or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-581. - Container required during building operation. 
    It shall be the duty of the building, contractor, owner and person holding the permit to place on the 
construction site a commercial type container adequate to hold all surplus building materials and debris 
from the work site. It shall be the obligation of the person obtaining the commercial container to see that 
accumulated rubbish is properly removed and to keep the area free from building debris and other 
materials connected with the building operation. Upon the failure of such person to comply with this 
section and after due notice from the community development director or the public works director, the 
village may cause such building material and debris to be removed and the cost of such removal shall be 
deducted from the building bond. Such removal by the village shall not relieve the person from any 
penalty imposed for the violation of this section. Waste/dumpster containers shall not be placed on any 
public right-of-way. In cases where the placement on private property is not feasible, relief from this 
requirement may be made in writing to the director of public works, who shall assess the situation on a 
case by case basis and determine if a particular hardship exists to grant the placement. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 
1-1-2015) 


Sec. 18-582. - Removal of material and debris after building operations. 
    Upon the completion of any work for which a permit is required by this chapter, it shall be the duty of 
the builder, contractor, owner and person holding the permit to remove all surplus building materials, 
supplies and equipment and all debris from the work site and adjacent streets, sidewalks, alleys and lots, 
and dispose of the same in accord with the provisions of this chapter. Upon the failure of such person to 
comply with this section, after notice so to do from the community development director or the public 
works director, the village may cause such supplies, material, equipment or debris to be removed and the 
cost of such removal shall be deducted from the deposit provided for in section 18-488. Such removal by 
the village shall not relieve such person from any penalty imposed for the violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-583. - Toilet facilities to be provided for building operations. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for the owner of any building or any person employing or in charge of any 
workers to begin the construction, alteration or repair of any building, or the construction of any 
public or private works, without having provided proper and sufficient toilet facilities, consisting of 
water closets, chemical closets, or privies of a type approved by the director, for the use of all 
employees engaged in such work. There shall be at least one such water closet, chemical closet, or 
privy for every 30 employees or fraction thereof. 
(b) ?A chemical closet shall be construed, for the purposes of this section, to be any closet or privy in 
which human excreta and urine are deposited in a receptacle containing a solution of caustic 
hydrates. The receptacle in such closet shall be watertight. The capacity of such receptacle shall be 
as follows: 
(1) ?For ten persons or less 60 gallons. 
(2) ?For 20 persons or less 100 gallons. 
(3) ?For 40 persons or less 300 gallons. 
A solution of at least 16.42 percent of crude caustic hydrates (1 1/3 pounds to one gallon of water) shall 
be used in such receptacles, and such chemical closets shall not be used until properly charged with 
such solution. Every such closet shall be cleaned before being removed from one building or premises to 
another, and as often otherwise as may be deemed necessary by the director. 
(c) ?All toilet facilities required by this section shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and each closet 
shall be properly enclosed to secure privacy and tissue toilet paper must be provided. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-584. - Use of fire hydrants. 
    The use of fire hydrants in connection with building operations is prohibited except with permission of 
the public works director or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-585. - Erosion control measures required prior to commencement of excavations. 
    Excavation under any issued permit shall not commence until adequate erosion control has been 
established pursuant to the requirements of chapter 34, article III, of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-586. - Perimeter safety fence. 
    Prior to commencement of any new construction, demolition, or excavation, the permittee shall install 
a protective six-foot chain link safety fence with locking gate around the perimeter of the property for 
which the permit is covered, during the duration of construction and until fine grading is complete. Also 
see chapter 80 of the Westmont Municipal Code for additional tree protection standards. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012; Ord. No. 14-28, § 1, 2-20-2014; Ord. No. 14-170, § 
1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 1-1-2015; Ord. No. 14-156, § 1, 9-4-2014) 


Secs. 18-58718-610. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE XII. - MOVING BUILDINGS 


Sec. 18-611. - PermitRequired. 
    No person shall move any building on, through or over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public 
place in the village without having obtained a permit thereof after requesting permission from and 
approval given from the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-612. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for permits required by section 18-611 shall be made in writing to the community 
development department and shall state thereon the proposed route and the number of days it is 
intended that the building shall occupy any portion of any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place. 
The community development director shall review and prepare said request for placement of said matter 
on the next available village board committee of the whole meeting for review. The matter shall then be 
placed on the next available village board meeting for formal action. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-613. - SameFee; issuance. 
    Upon approval of the intended route by the board of trustees, a fee of $50.00 for each day or fraction 
thereof that it is intended that the building shall occupy any portion of any public place shall be paid to the 
village clerk and the permit issued. An additional payment of $25.00 for each day or fraction thereof over 
and above the time stated on the permit during or on which any building shall occupy such public place 
shall be paid by the permittee. This fee shall be in addition to any other costs that would be incurred by 
the village for other services rendered, such as, but not limited to, traffic control by police department, 
plan review fees, building permit fees, inspection fees, etc. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-614. - Bond or insurance required. 
    Each applicant for a permit issued under sections 18-611 through 18-613 shall file a bond or 
certificate of insurance coverage as follows: One hundred thousand dollars for each person injured, 
$300,000.00 for each accident and $50,000.00 for property damages, with sureties or insurers to be 
approved by the village president and board of trustees, conditioned to indemnify the village from any loss 
or damage resulting from the work undertaken or the manner of doing such work. Such bond or certificate 
of insurance is to be filed with the village clerk in conjunction with the application for permit. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-615. - Lights and warnings. 
    Whenever a street or alley is blocked by a house or structure which is being moved, warnings to that 
effect shall be placed by the police department so as to warn vehicles and persons from entering that 
portion of the street so blocked. The person moving any building through the streets shall keep warning 
signs and lanterns or lights at night on the building so as to guard against any person or vehicle from 
colliding with it. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-616. - Cutting wires and cables; bond. 
    Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere with wires or cables of a public utility in moving a 
building, the terms of any special or franchise ordinances governing shall apply and the bond therein 
specified shall be given. If no such terms apply, then the village manager, or his/her designee, shall 
estimate the expense of fixing the wires and the bond to be given to cover the expense. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-617. - Duty when structure approaches fire alarm wires and poles. 
    When any moving building approaches any fire alarm wire or pole which shall be endangered by the 
removal of such building or structure, it shall be the duty of the mover to notify the fire chief at least six 
hours before reaching such wire or pole so that they may be removed or cared for by the village 
authorities. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-618. - Moving wooden buildings into and within fire limits prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to move into the fire limits any wooden building which could not be constructed in 
the fire limits within the provisions of this chapter; and it shall be unlawful to move any such building from 
one location or lot in the fire limits to another location or lot within the fire limits. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-619. - Contractor registrationRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of house moving, raising or shoring without having first 
secured a contractor's registration therefor. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-620. - SameApplication. 
    Application for a contractor registration required by section 18-619 shall be made in accordance with 
article VII. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Sec. 18-621. - SameFees. 
    The annual fee for a contractor registration required by section 18-619 shall be in accordance with 
article VII. 
(Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), 6-18-2012) 


Secs. 18-62218-799. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE XIII. - ELEVATOR STANDARDS 


Sec. 18-800. - Permits for elevators and other conveyances. 
(a) ?Permit applications for the construction, operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration, 
repair, and removal of elevators and conveyances, shall comply with the Elevator Safety and 
Regulation Act (225 ILCS 312/1, et seq. )(the "Act"). Applicants shall apply for elevator and 
conveyance permits and all other applicable and related permits through the community 
development department. 
(b) ?Applicants for the construction, installation, alteration, replacement, repair, and removal of private 
residence conveyances, as defined in the Illinois Elevator Safety Rules ("Rules") (41 IL. Admin. 
Code 1000.30), shall obtain all applicable permits from the community development department. 
(c) ?The fire prevention bureau may take one or more of the following actions regarding elevators and 
other conveyances in compliance with the requirements of the Act: 
(1) ?Issue construction and alteration permits through the community development department. 
(2) ?Issue certificates of operation. 
(3) ?Require that all elevators and conveyances shall be registered with the office of the state fire 
marshal ("OSFM"). Application for the required registration may be obtained on the OSFM 
website (www2.illinois.gov/sites/sfm) or from the fire prevention bureau. 
(4) ?Consider requests to extend the time frame for construction or alteration permits. Such 
requests may be granted for up to an additional 12 months, for good cause shown, if the 
request is received by the fire prevention bureau prior to expiration of the existing permit. 
Extension requests received after the expiration of the existing permit shall be denied, requiring 
a new application that must be accompanied by payment of the current permit fee charged by 
the village. 
(5) ?Provide for inspection of elevators and conveyances, including temporary operation 
inspections, through a village-designated third-party elevator contractor certified by the OSFM. 
(6) ?Grant exceptions and variances from the literal requirements of applicable state codes, 
standards and regulations, in cases in which such variances would not jeopardize the public 
safety and welfare. The fire prevention bureau shall notify the OSFM by mail of any exception or 
variance granted. 
a. ?The OSFM may object to such exception or variance within seven business days of receipt 
of the notice. 
b. ?Should the OSFM and the fire prevention bureau fail to reach an agreement on the 
exception or variance, the matter shall be directed to the elevator safety review board 
("Board") to hear and decide. 
(7) ?Enforce the applicable provisions of the Act, and levy fines in accordance with the Illinois 
Municipal Code and the village's code of ordinances. 
(8) ?Maintain for inspection by the OSFM the following documentation and information, all of which 
shall be maintained for a two-year period: 
a. ?All elevator and conveyance permit applications; 
b. ?All elevator and conveyance permits issued; 
c. ?All exceptions or variances granted or denied in reference to elevators and conveyances; 
d. ?All inspection reports for elevators and conveyances; and 
e. ?Proper records demonstrating the number of certificates of operation issued by the village. 
(9) ?Ensure that all inspections are performed by personnel properly licensed by the state and notify 
the OSFM of any instances of non-compliance with the Act and/or rules of which it becomes 
aware. 
(10) ?Amend its elevator and conveyance program within 90 days of receipt of notice from the 
OSFM informing it of changes to any form, document, standards and/or rules that affect the 
village's program. 
(11) ?Notify the OSFM at least 90 days in advance of the date the village elects to discontinue its 
elevator and conveyance program under this article. 
(12) ?Place out-of-service and report to the OSFM the names of the owners of those elevators and 
conveyances that fail to register within 30 days of the determination that the elevator or 
conveyance is not registered. 
(13) ?Make itself available, upon reasonable notice, to meet with the OSFM administrator or its 
representatives, to ensure compliance with the Act and rules. 
(14) ?Ensure that the fees and procedures for applications, permits, inspection and enforcement of 
elevators and conveyances remain the jurisdiction of the village (except for the registration and 
fee requirement to the OSFM, and ensure that such fees and procedures shall take precedence 
over the procedures adopted by the OSFM. 
(15) ?Make necessary amendments to its elevator and conveyance program should the OSFM 
determine, upon notice to the village, that the program does not meet the requirements of the 
Act and/or the rules. 
(Ord. No. 15-017, § 2, 1-22-2015; Ord. No. 18-010, § 2, 1-18-2018) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 15-017, § 2, adopted Jan. 22, 2015, amended § 18-800 in effect 
repealing and reenacting said section as set out herein. Former § 18-800 pertained to codes 
adopted and derived from Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), adopted June 18, 2012 and Ord. No. 
14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014. Provisions pertained to adopted codes are now set 
forth in § 18-801. Later, Ord. No. 18-010, § 2, adopted Jan. 18, 2018, amended § 18-800 and in 
so doing changed the title of said section from "Permits" to "Permits for elevators and other 
conveyances," as set out herein. 


Sec. 18-801. - Codes adopted. 
(a) ?American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME): 
(1) ?Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators (ASME A17.1-2010/CSA B44-10), and Performance 
Based Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators (ASME A17.7 2007/CSA B44.7-07); 
(2) ?Safety Code for Existing Elevators and Escalators (ASME 17.3-2005); 
(3) ?Safety Standard for Platform Lifts and Stairway Chairlifts (ASME A18.1-2008); 
(4) ?Standard for the Qualification of Elevator Inspectors (ASME QEI-1-2010); 
(b) ?American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE): 
(1) ?Automated People Mover Standards (ASCE 21, Part 1-2005/2006, ASCE 21, Parts 2 through 
4-2008). 
(Ord. No. 15-017, § 2, 1-22-2015) 


Sec. 18-802. - Permit fees. 
    The permit fees for the construction, operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration, repair, 
and removal of an elevator or conveyance are as follows: 
(1) ?Plan reviews of elevators, escalators, dumbwaiters and lift equipment ..... $150.00. 
(2) ?Permit inspections and re-inspections of elevators, escalators, dumbwaiters and lift equipment 
..... $150.00. 
(3) ?Annual inspections and re-inspections (certifications) of elevators, escalators, dumbwaiters and 
lift equipment  
(this fee includes issuance of elevator certificate) ..... $80.00. 
    The applicant shall pay such other permit fees as required by the village for any related work. 
(Ord. No. 18-010, § 2, 1-18-2018) 


Sec. 18-803. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 2, 2014, effective Jan. 1, 2015, 
amended various sections in Ch. 18, and in so doing repealed § 18-803, which pertained to 
conflict and derived Ord. No. 12-113, § 1(Attch. A), adopted June 18, 2012. 


Chapter 19 - CONDOMINIUM CONVERSIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; zoning, App. A; land development, App. B. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 19-1. - General purpose and intent. 
    It is concluded that equity ownership of multiple-family dwellings and office units is a positive 
development for the Village of Westmont (the "village") and, within certain limits, such ownership should 
be encouraged. Because of the unique nature of condominium ownership and the age of the existing 
multiple-family dwelling and office unit stock in the village, it is further concluded that the quality of 
housing and office units and the rights of the condominium purchaser should be protected to a greater 
extent than the protections provided under existing laws. To this end, the village has the authority to 
introduce regulation into the condominium process, as provided in the Condominium Property Act, 765 
ILCS 605/1 et seq. 
    Based on the foregoing, the purpose and intent of this chapter is to introduce regulatory elements 
into the condominium conversion process that protect the rights of condominium purchasers and preserve 
and improve the quality of housing and office units in an effort to encourage orderly development of the 
condominium concept within the village. Further, this chapter is intended to facilitate code inspections by 
the village and, thus, to reduce the possibility of a condominium containing material defects that would 
have an adverse effect on the health, safety and welfare of its occupants or neighboring property, or 
would place unexpected burdens on condominium unit buyers. 
(Ord. No. 06-204, § 1, 12-4-2006) 


Sec. 19-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them by this section. To the extent not set forth in this section, the definitions set forth in Appendix A, 
Article XIV of this Code or the Condominium Property Act (765 ILCS 605/1 et seq.) shall apply for 
purposes of this chapter: 
    Agent: Any person, firm corporation, association, joint venture or any other entity or any combination 
thereof who represents or acts for or on behalf of an owner and/or developer on the sale or offer for sale 
of any condominium unit, excepting an escrow officer acting for a title company. 
    Association or unit owners' association: The association of all the condominium unit owners, acting 
pursuant to bylaws through its duly elected board of managers/directors. 
    Building: All structures, attached or unattached, containing one or more dwelling units. 
    Certificate of code compliance (full): A written instrument issued by the village as evidence of a 
condominium project's compliance with the requirements of this chapter. 
    Certificate of code compliance (partial): A written instrument issued by the village, as evidence that 
common elements or a individual condominium units are in compliance with this chapter. 
    Closing: The act of transferring ownership of a condominium unit to the purchaser from the owner 
and/or developer. 
    Code inspection report: A written report issued by the village as evidence that all condominium units 
and common elements in a condominium project have been inspected for compliance with all applicable 
zoning, building and/or other life safety code standards of the village. 
    Common elements or common areas: All portions of the property except the condominium units, 
including limited common elements unless otherwise specified. 
    Condominium: A form of property ownership established pursuant to the Condominium Property Act. 
    Condominium conversion compliance schedule: The schedule referenced in subsection 19-11(c)(1) 
below. 
    Condominium project: The sale of or plan by an owner and/or developer to sell or offer for sale 
residential condominium units, commercial condominium units, or business condominium units, or any 
combination thereof, in an existing building or any modification or reconstruction of an existing building. 
    Condominium Property Act: The Illinois Condominium Property Act (765 ILCS 605/1 et seq.). 
    Condominium unit or unit: A part of the property designed and intended for any type of independent 
use. 
    Conversion, convert or like words: The offering for sale by an owner and/or developer or their agent 
of a condominium unit in a "conversion condominium", as defined in the Condominium Property Act. 
    Developer: Any person or entity who/which undertakes to develop a condominium unit or building by 
conversion, as further defined in the Condominium Property Act. 
    Director: The director of economic development or authorized representative. 
    Limited common elements: A portion of the common elements so designated in the declaration as 
being reserved for the use of a certain condominium unit or units to the exclusion of other condominium 
units, including, but not limited to, balconies, terraces, patios and parking spaces or facilities. 
    Offering: Any inducement, solicitation, advertisement or announcement to encourage the purchase 
of a condominium unit in a condominium project or prospective condominium project. 
    Owner: The title holder of property being converted to a condominium. 
    Parking space: A space dedicated exclusively to the location or storage of a motor vehicle which 
meets the requirements of Appendix A, Article X of this Code. 
    Person: A natural individual, corporation, partnership, trustee or other legal entity capable of holding 
title to real property. 
    Property: All the land, property and space comprising the parcel, all improvements and structures 
erected, constructed or contained therein or thereon, including the building and all easements, rights and 
appurtenances belonging thereto, and all fixtures and equipment intended for the mutual use, benefit or 
enjoyment of the condominium unit owners, submitted to the provisions of the Condominium Property Act. 
    Prospective purchaser: A person who investigates the condominium project site for the purpose of 
the possible purchase of one or more condominium units. 
(Ord. No. 06-204, § 1, 12-4-2006) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Secs. 19-319-10. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS AND PROCEDURES 


Sec. 19-11. - Certification and code inspections. 
(a) ?No existing building, or part thereof, shall be submitted to the provisions of the Condominium 
Property Act nor shall an existing apartment or office unit be offered for sale or sold as a proposed 
condominium unit or occupied as a condominium unit without the prior issuance of a full or partial 
certificate of code compliance pursuant to this chapter. 
(b) ?A developer intending to submit a property to the provisions of the Condominium Property Act 
and/or offering an existing apartment or office unit for sale as a proposed condominium unit shall file 
a written notice of intent to convert with the economic development department. The notice shall 
include a current survey of the property, the address, a description of the subject dwelling units, and 
the names and telephone numbers of existing occupants, current property owner, and developer. 
The developer shall provide other information regarding the condition of the proposed development 
as the director shall reasonably request in a timely manner. A code inspection of the property, 
including all projected condominium units and common elements and facilities, shall be scheduled by 
agreement between the developer and the director when the notice of intent to convert is received, 
but not less than 60 days prior to the anticipated conversion date. The inspection shall be made to 
determine the property's compliance with all applicable zoning, building and/or other life safety 
codes. The economic development department shall issue a written code inspection report after any 
inspection or re-inspection. The fee for each inspection or any re-inspection shall be $200.00 per 
proposed condominium unit. 
(c) ?No certificate of code compliance shall be issued until: 
(1) ?The subject property is in compliance with those Village Code provisions as set forth on the 
village's condominium conversion compliance schedule. The director shall establish a 
condominium conversion compliance schedule setting forth those zoning, building and life 
safety codes which must be complied with prior to converting an apartment or office building 
into a condominium building. Said condominium conversion compliance schedule shall be 
approved by the village board and made available to the public. 
(2) ?a. ?The subject property has two and one-half parking spaces provided per condominium 
dwelling unit, or such total number of parking spaces as required by any variation, special 
use permit or planned development approval providing for a modified parking quantity. 
b. ?Office condominium units provide parking in accordance with Appendix A, section 10.06(K) 
or such total number of parking spaces as required by any variation, special use permit, or 
planned development approval providing for a modified parking quantity. 
c. ?The developer shall submit a plan to provide any required parking spaces not present on 
the property, together with any guarantees necessary to ensure its provision. 
(3) ?That the subject property is in compliance with the Village of Westmont landscaping 
requirements unless said compliance would result in the loss of parking or the need to relocate 
or alter an existing building as determined by the director of economic development. 
(d) ?The director may issue a partial certificate of code compliance as to individual condominium units 
and/or common elements and facilities that are in compliance with subsection (c) of this section. Any 
condominium unit and/or common elements and facilities issued a partial certificate of occupancy 
shall be deemed habitable. No partial certificate of code compliance shall be granted for a
