condominium unit until the common areas and elements have also been issued a partial certificate of 
code compliance. 
(e) ?A developer shall be required to provide a prospective purchaser with a copy of any code inspection 
report, and any full or partial certificates of code compliance prior to the closing on a condominium 
unit sales contract. All condominium unit sales contracts shall contain the following provision: 
"The Village of Westmont Condominium Ordinance requires that the condominium property and your 
unit be inspected for conformity with Village Codes. It also requires that the person contracting to 
purchase has the opportunity to review the code inspection report and the applicable code 
compliance certificate issued by the Village." 
(f) ?Tenant consent for inspections: 
(1) ?A tenant shall not unreasonably withhold consent for the developer or village to enter a unit in 
order to comply with or enforce the provisions of this chapter. Except in case of emergency, or 
unless otherwise provided in the lease, a tenant shall be given at least two days' notice by the 
developer of intent to enter. Unless the tenant consents, or the lease otherwise provides, a 
developer shall not undertake construction for conversion of a unit while it is occupied by a 
tenant, or create any unreasonable disruption of the common areas, including, but not limited to, 
restricting access thereto, or interfere with the quiet use and enjoyment of the premises. 
(2) ?If consent is withheld in violation of this section, the village may seek an administrative search 
warrant from the circuit court for the limited purpose of enforcing this chapter. 
(g) ?No certification or other approval shall issue if property is submitted to the provisions of the 
Condominium Property Act in violation of this chapter. No full or partial certificate of code compliance 
shall be issued unless all water bills and village liens outstanding with respect to any building, or any 
part thereof, subject to conversion are paid or adequate surety is provided. 
(h) ?Issuance of certificates of code compliance: 
(1) ?The issuance of a full or partial certificate of code compliance by the village shall not be 
deemed a finding that the village has in any way passed upon the merits or given approval to 
the condominium project. It shall be unlawful to make, or cause to be made, any representation 
contrary to the foregoing to a prospective purchaser. 
(2) ?The following provision shall be reprinted on every full or partial certificate of code compliance 
issued by the village pursuant to this chapter: 
"By virtue of the issuance of this certificate of code compliance, the Village of Westmont does 
not guarantee the condition of the subject property, or its suitability or fitness for the purpose for 
which it is being sold or transferred, and the Village of Westmont shall not be responsible or 
liable for any claims arising out of the condition of the property or any defects or deficiencies 
therein." 
(Ord. No. 06-204, § 1, 12-4-2006) 


Sec. 19-12. - Penalties for violation and noncompliance. 
(a) ?Any person or entity violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be 
fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. Each violation of the provisions 
of this chapter and each day such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct 
offense. 
(b) ?The remedies provided in this chapter shall be cumulative and in addition to provisions and 
remedies provided elsewhere in this Code regarding zoning, building and life safety regulations. 
(c) ?The developer and the condominium unit owner shall be liable for violations occurring in a 
condominium unit or proposed condominium unit and each may be cited for any individual violation. 
The developer shall be liable for violations occurring in common areas and may be cited for any 
individual violation. 
(d) ?In addition to the imposition of a fine, the village may seek injunctive relief to prevent a violation of 
this chapter, including, but not limited to, enjoining the occupancy and/or sale of any building or unit. 
(Ord. No. 06-204, § 1, 12-4-2006) 


Sec. 19-13. - Appeals. 
    All reports and decisions of the director made pursuant to this chapter shall be made in writing in a 
timely manner. Any decision of the director may be appealed to the planning and zoning commission 
pursuant to Appendix A, section 13.08 of this Code and may include a request for a variation pursuant to 
Appendix A, section 13.07 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 06-204, § 1, 12-4-2006) 


Sec. 19-14. - Other Code provisions and statutes. 
    This chapter shall become effective immediately upon approval. This chapter shall not be construed 
to prevent, limit or modify any other provisions of this Code regarding zoning, building and/or life safety. 
This chapter shall not limit or modify the application of other provisions of this Code with respect to 
properties submitted to the provisions of the Condominium Property Act prior to its effective date. 
(Ord. No. 06-204, § 1, 12-4-2006) 


Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Advertising, ch. 6; alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; license required for sale of alcoholic 
liquor, § 10-31; animals, ch. 14; electrical permit required, § 18-261; registration of electrical contractors 
required, § 18-287; license required for sound amplifying devices, § 38-52; health and sanitation, ch. 46; 
food dealer's license, § 46-32; milk dealers, § 46-101 et seq.; license required for food deliveries, § 46-
126; permit for street food vendor required, § 46-146; license required for refrigeration locker plant, § 46-
167; tattooing and body piercing establishments, § 46-200 et seq.; housing, ch. 50; prohibition of drug 
paraphernalia and related transactions, § 58-210 et seq.; taxation, ch. 74; telecommunications systems, 
ch. 76; telecommunications infrastructure maintenance fee, ch. 77; permit required for water connection, 
§ 82-32; permit required for planting or removing tree or shrub in public place, § 86-31; vehicles for hire, 
ch. 90; license required to operate taxicab business, § 90-32; zoning, app. A; land development, app. B; 
schedule of fees, taxes and charges, app. C. 
State Law reference Municipal powers over certain businesses, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq.; issuance 
and revocation of municipal licenses, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 22-1. - Offensive and nuisance businesses prohibited. 
    No business shall be conducted or operated in the village or within one mile thereof which is 
unwholesome, offensive or nauseous or which amounts to a nuisance in fact. 
(Code 1972, § 16-15) 
Cross reference Nuisances, § 38-81 et seq. 
State Law reference Authority of village to prohibit unwholesome businesses, 65 ILCS 5/11-
42-9. 


Sec. 22-2. - Sale of firearms prohibited. 
    No business or retail establishment within the village limits shall be permitted to sell pistols, 
revolvers, handguns or other firearms of a size which may be concealed upon the person. 
(Code 1972, § 16-19) 


Sec. 22-3. - Pawnshops prohibited. 
    No person or entity shall operate as a pawnbroker or operate a pawnbrokerage or pawnshop within 
the corporate limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 99-19, § 1(A), 2-1-1999) 
Cross reference Operation of pawnshops prohibited, § 58-31. 


Secs. 22-422-30. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - LICENSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference Dog license, § 14-37; license for master plumber, § 18-155; license for journeyman 
plumber, § 18-156. 


Sec. 22-31. - When license required. 
    Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of the village a license is required for the 
maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or establishment or for doing business or engaging in 
any activity or occupation, any person shall be subject to the requirement if, by himself or through an 
agent, employee or partner, he holds himself out as being engaged in the business or occupation; or 
solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any part of such 
business or occupation in the village. 
(Code 1972, § 16-1) 


Sec. 22-32. - Applications; contents. 
    Applications for all licenses and permits required by this Code or other ordinance shall be made in 
writing to the village clerk in the absence of provision to the contrary. Each application shall state the 
name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and 
the fee to be paid; and each application shall contain such additional information as may be needed for 
the proper guidance of the village officials in the issuing of the permit or license applied for. 
(Code 1972, § 16-2) 


Sec. 22-33. - Temporary permits and licenses to be approved by village president and board. 
    An application for a temporary permit or license shall be referred to the president and board of 
trustees of the village for approval before the permit or license shall be issued. 
(Code 1972, § 16-3) 


Sec. 22-34. - License forms, keeping of. 
    Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor, shall be prepared and kept on file by 
the village clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 16-4) 
Cross reference Village clerk, § 2-191 et seq. 


Sec. 22-35. - Signature of president and clerk required. 
    Each license or permit issued by the village shall bear the signature of the president and village clerk 
in the absence of any provision to the contrary. 
(Code 1972, § 16-5) 


Sec. 22-36. - Procedure for investigations. 
    Upon the receipt of any application for a license or permit where this Code or any other ordinance of 
the village necessitates an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such permit or license, the 
village clerk shall refer such application to the proper officer for making such investigation within 48 hours 
of the time of such receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making an investigation or inspection shall 
make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten days after receiving the application or a copy 
thereof. The economic development director shall make or cause to be made any such inspections 
relative to the construction of buildings or other structures. All other investigations, except where 
otherwise provided, shall be made by the chief of police or some other officer designated by the 
president. 
(Code 1972, § 16-6; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 22-37. - Fees to be paid in advance; prorating; disposition. 
    In the absence of provision to the contrary, all fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid 
in advance at the time application therefor is made to the village clerk. When an applicant has not 
engaged in the business until after the expiration of part of the current license year, the license fee shall 
be prorated by half years, and the fee paid for each six months or fraction thereof during which the 
business has been or will be pursued. Except as otherwise provided, all license fees shall become a part 
of the corporate fund. 
(Code 1972, § 16-7) 


Sec. 22-38. - Expiration; notice; late fee. 
(a) ?All annual village licenses shall terminate on the last day of the calendar year where no provision to 
the contrary is made. 
(b) ?The village clerk shall mail to all licensees of the village a statement three weeks prior to the 
expiration of the license held by the licensee. A failure to send out such notice, or the failure of the 
licensee to receive it, shall not excuse a licensee from a failure to secure a new license or a renewal 
thereof, nor shall it be a defense in action for operation without a license. 
(c) ?If a licensee fails to renew its license on or before the last day of the calendar year, the licensee 
shall be charged a late fee equal to ten percent of the annual fee for such license, or $10.00, 
whichever is greater. 
(Code 1972, § 16-8; Ord. No. 96-97, § 1, 12-2-1996) 


Sec. 22-39. - Building and premises to comply with Code and ordinances. 
    No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business and no permit shall be issued for any 
thing or act if the premises and building to be used for the purpose do not fully comply with the 
requirements of this Code and other ordinances of the village. No such license or permit shall be issued 
for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning 
ordinance of the village. 
(Code 1972, § 16-9) 
Cross reference Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 


Sec. 22-40. - Change of location or operations. 
    In the absence of any provision to the contrary, the location of any licensed business or occupation 
or of any permitted act may be changed, provided ten days' notice thereof is given to the village clerk, if a 
license could initially be issued for such location under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 16-10) 


Sec. 22-41. - Duty to permit inspections and tests and to furnish samples; violations. 
(a) ?Whenever inspection of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed 
business or occupation are provided for or required, or are reasonably necessary thereto to secure 
compliance with any provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee or the 
person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the 
inspection any officer or employee of the village who is authorized or directed to make such 
inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(b) ?Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure 
conformance with any provision of this Code or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the 
licensee of the village whose business is governed by the provision to give any authorized officer or 
employee of the village requesting it, sufficient samples of such material or commodity for such 
analysis upon request. 
(c) ?In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the village president and board of trustees 
may revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the village who refuses 
to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make an inspection or take a sample to 
make the inspection or take an adequate sample of the commodity, or who interferes with such 
officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making an inspection. Provided, that no 
license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon the licensee or person 
in charge of the premises in the name of the village, stating that such inspection or sample is desired 
at the time it is sought to make the inspection or to obtain the sample. 
(Code 1972, § 16-14) 


Sec. 22-42. - Revocation of licenses, permits authorized. 
    Any license or permit issued by the village may, for a limited time, be revoked by the village 
president and board of trustees during the life of the license or permit for the violation by the licensee or 
permittee of any provision relating to the license or permit, the subject of the license or permit, or the 
premises occupied. Such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. 
(Code 1972, § 16-16) 


Sec. 22-43. - Posting license required. 
    It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the village to keep his license 
posted at all times in a prominent place on the premises used for such business. 
(Code 1972, § 16-17) 


Sec. 22-44. - Issuance of vehicle stickers or tags; affixing to vehicle. 
    Whenever the number of vehicles used is a basis of a license fee, the village clerk shall furnish each 
licensee with a tag or sticker for each vehicle covered by the license and such tag or sticker shall be 
affixed in a conspicuous place on each such vehicle while it is in use. 
(Code 1972, § 16-18) 


Secs. 22-4522-65. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - MERCHANDISING 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Secs. 22-6622-80. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - JUNK DEALERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license, tax, locate and regulate all dealers in junk and 
secondhand articles, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 


Sec. 22-81. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business of junk dealer or to keep any junk shop, store 
or place for the purchase or sale of junk, rags, old rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper, empty 
bottles or any secondhand articles whatsoever without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-39) 


Sec. 22-82. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license for junk dealers or secondhand dealers shall be $25.00 where the total 
area of the business, including exterior areas utilized for business purposes, is between zero square feet 
to 2,500 square feet; $50.00 per year where the total area of the business is between 2,501 square feet 
and 5,000 square feet; $75.00 per year where the total area of the business is between 5,001 square feet 
and 10,000 square feet; and $100.00 where the total area of the business is 10,001 square feet or more. 
(Code 1972, § 16-40; Ord. No. 02-146, § 1, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-83. - Stolen and lost goods; examination by police. 
    Every person operating a junk shop who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or 
things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall upon demand produce the article or thing to any 
member of the police department for examination. 
(Code 1972, § 16-41) 


Sec. 22-84. - Vehicles to be marked. 
    Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible 
characters the name and address of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 16-42) 


Secs. 22-8522-100. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - LUMBERYARDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license, tax and regulate lumberyards and lumber 
storehouses, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 


Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Lumberyard means any place used for the storage of lumber, wooden containers or wood in an 
amount exceeding 5,000 board feet. 
(Code 1972, § 16-48) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-102. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall establish, conduct or maintain a lumberyard in the village without first obtaining a 
license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-49) 


Sec. 22-103. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall 
state thereon the location and size of the lumberyard for which the license is intended. 
(Code 1972, § 16-50) 


Sec. 22-104. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license for lumberyards shall be $25.00 where the total area of the business, 
including exterior areas utilized for business purposes, is between zero square feet to 2,500 square feet; 
$50.00 per year where the total area of the business is between 2,501 square feet and 5,000 square feet; 
$75.00 per year where the total area of the business is between 5,001 square feet and 10,000 square 
feet; and $100.00 where the total area of the business is 10,001 square feet or more. 
(Code 1972, § 16-51; Ord. No. 02-146, § 2, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-105. - Lumber not to be piled in dangerous manner. 
    It shall be unlawful to pile any lumber in a lumberyard in such a way that the lumber is hanging over 
or in danger of falling onto any adjoining property, street, alley or public way. 
(Code 1972, § 16-52) 


Sec. 22-106. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect or cause to be inspected every lumberyard in the village 
to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 16-53) 


Secs. 22-10722-130. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 4. - PAINT STORES 


Sec. 22-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Paint store means any premises or establishment where soda, sal soda, caustic soda, essential oils, 
coal tar chemicals, inks, dyes, disinfectants, cleaning compounds, photographic chemicals, glycerine, 
kerosene, turpentine, paints, linseed oil, shellac, varnish, enamels, or other chemicals or preparations 
containing any of the foregoing are made, mixed, compounded, purified, prepared or offered for sale or 
are used for commercial or industrial use. 
(Code 1972, § 16-59) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-132. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a paint store without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-60) 


Sec. 22-133. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall state whether or not a certificate of occupancy 
has been issued covering the premises and use contemplated. 
(Code 1972, § 16-61) 


Sec. 22-134. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license for paint stores shall be $25.00 where the total area of the business, 
including exterior areas utilized for business purposes, is between zero square feet to 2,500 square feet; 
$50.00 per year where the total area of the business is between 2,501 square feet and 5,000 square feet; 
$75.00 per year where the total area of the business is between 5,001 square feet and 10,000 square 
feet; and $100.00 where the total area of the business is 10,001 square feet or more. 
(Code 1972, § 16-62; Ord. No. 02-146, § 3, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-135. - Cleanliness; removal of refuse, dust and fumes; toilet facilities. 
    All paint stores shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned of all 
dirt, refuse and debris at least once every 24 hours. Each building, or part thereof, used for such 
purposes shall be adequately equipped with devices to remove and eliminate all fumes, odors and dust. 
Adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities for employees shall be provided. 
(Code 1972, § 16-63) 


Sec. 22-136. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be 
necessary to enforce the provisions of this division and the provisions of this Code relating to fire and 
health hazards applicable to paint stores. 
(Code 1972, § 16-64) 


Secs. 22-13722-180. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 5. - PARAPHERNALIA SALES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference Possession of cannabis, § 58-28. 
State Law reference Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, 720 ILCS 600/1 et seq. 


Sec. 22-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cannabis means marijuana, hashish and other substances recited in the Cannabis Control Act. [6] 
    Cocaine spoon means a spoon with a bowl so small that the primary use for which it is reasonably 
adapted or designed is to hold or administer cocaine, and which is so small as to be unsuited for the 
typical, lawful use of a spoon. A cocaine spoon may or may not be merchandised on a chain and may or 
may not be labeled as a cocaine spoon or coke spoon. 
    Controlled substance means any drug or substance recited in the Illinois Controlled Substances Act. 
[7] 
    Marijuana or hashish pipe means a pipe characterized by a bowl which is so small that the primary 
use for which it is reasonably adapted or designed is the smoking of marijuana or hashish, rather than 
lawful smoking tobacco, and which may or may not be equipped with a screen. 
    Minor means any male or female person who has not yet attained the age of 18 years. 
    Paraphernalia means any empty gelatin capsule, vial, hypodermic syringe or needle, cocaine spoon, 
marijuana pipe, hashish pipe, cigarette paper of colorful design, named and oriented for use with illegal 
cannabis or drugs, roach clips, or any other instrument, implement or device which is primarily adapted or 
designed for the administration or use of any controlled substance. 
(Code 1972, § 16-75) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
(720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.) 
 
--- (7) --- 
(720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.) 


Sec. 22-182. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person as principal, clerk or agent to sell any items, effects, 
paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs, as 
defined by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, without obtaining a license therefor from the village. Such 
licenses shall be in addition to any or all other licenses held by the applicant. 
(Code 1972, § 16-76) 


Sec. 22-183. - SameApplication. 
    Application to sell any item, effects, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed 
for use with illegal cannabis or drugs shall be in a form prescribed by the chief of police of the village 
police department. Every application shall be filed with the police department and shall be accompanied 
by affidavits by the license applicant and each and every employee of such applicant authorized to sell 
such items, that such person has never been convicted of a drug related offense. 
(Code 1972, § 16-77) 


Sec. 22-184. - Recordkeeping. 
    Every licensee under this division must keep a record of every item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory 
or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs which is sold by such 
licensee. This record shall be open to the inspection of any police officer at any time during the normal 
hours of business. Such record shall contain the following: 
(1) ?Name and address of the purchaser; 
(2) ?Name and quantity of the product; 
(3) ?Date and time of the purchase, and the form of identification used; and 
(4) ?The licensee or agent's signature. 
Such records shall be retained for not less than two years. 
(Code 1972, § 16-78) 


Sec. 22-185. - Display of items; proximity to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful to publicly display any items, effects, paraphernalia, accessories or things 
designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs as defined in this division in any business 
establishment within the village that permits or allows persons under the age of 18 years to enter into and 
upon its place of business. 
(Code 1972, § 16-79) 


Sec. 22-186. - Revocation of license. 
    The village president and board of trustees shall have the authority to revoke all licenses and permits 
issued to any licensee who violates any provision of this division. For the purpose of this section, a 
violation of this division by any agent or employee of the licensee shall be deemed a violation by the 
licensee. The village president and board of trustees shall establish rules and regulations to provide a fair 
hearing prior to the revocation of any license issued under this division. The revocation of a license or 
permit shall not bar the imposition of a fine or other penalty. 
(Code 1972, § 16-80) 


Sec. 22-187. - Compliance with other regulations. 
    The license under this division shall comply with all applicable regulations of all departments, boards, 
and commissions and the village police department. 
(Code 1972, § 16-81) 


Sec. 22-188. - Fee schedule. 
    The annual license fee for licenses issued under this division shall be $150.00 per annum. Every 
such license shall be effective and valid from the first day of the calendar year and shall expire on the last 
day of the particular calendar year for which it was granted. There shall be no prorations of any annual 
license fee. 
(Code 1972, § 16-82) 


Sec. 22-189. - Sale or delivery to minors prohibited. 
    The sale, barter, gift or exchange of all types of smoking paraphernalia, and items, effects, 
paraphernalia, accessories, or things designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs, is 
hereby prohibited to persons under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1972, § 16-83) 


Sec. 22-190. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating any section of this division may be fined no less than $10.00 nor more than 
$100.00 for the conviction of a first offense. Any person convicted of a second or subsequent offense 
shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00. A violation of this division on a 
continuing basis for a period of time in excess of 24 hours shall be deemed a separate offense for each 
day that the continuing violation continues. 
(Code 1972, § 16-84) 


Secs. 22-19122-199. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 6. - HARDWARE STORES 


Sec. 22-200. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply: 
    Graffiti implements. "Graffiti implements" shall mean any paint in an aerosol spray paint can or any 
marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble and has a point, brush, applicator or other writing 
surface of 3/8 of an inch or greater. 
    Hardware store. "Hardware store" shall include any retail commercial establishment that sells, offers 
for sale, delivers or displays any paint in an aerosol spray paint can or any marker containing a fluid 
which is not water soluble and has a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface of 3/8 of an inch or 
greater. 
(Ord. No. 11-159, § 2, 10-3-2011) 


Sec. 22-201. - Display of graffiti implements. 
    Every hardware store offering graffiti implements for sale shall either (1) restrict access to those 
items from the public by placing them behind a locked counter, cabinet or other storage facility so that 
access to them cannot be gained without employee assistance, or (2) display those items in an area 
continuously observable, through direct observation or video surveillance equipment, by employees of the 
hardware store during the regular course of business. 
(Ord. No. 11-159, § 2, 10-3-2011) 


Sec. 22-202. - Signage. 
(a) ?Every hardware store shall: 
(1) ?Place a sign in clear public view at or near the display of such products stating: 
Graffiti is against the law. Any person who defaces real or personal property with paint or any 
other liquid or device is guilty of a crime. 
(2) ?Place a sign in the direct view of such persons responsible for accepting customer payment for 
paint in an aerosol spray paint can or any marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble 
and has a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface of 3/8 of an inch or greater stating: 
Selling spray paint, paint sticks or broad-tipped markers to persons under eighteen (18) years of 
age is against the law. 
(Ord. No. 11-159, § 2, 10-3-2011) 


Sec. 22-203. - Identification required. 
    Every hardware store owner, employee or agent shall require a photographic form of identification to 
be produced by each person purchasing graffiti implements establishing that such person is 18 years or 
older. 
(Ord. No. 11-159, § 2, 10-3-2011) 


Sec. 22-204. - Violations. 
    Any person or business violating the provisions of this article shall be fined in an amount not less 
than $25.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. Each day a violation continues constitutes a 
separate violation. Each section of this article violated constitutes a separate offense. These penalty 
provisions do not preclude the village from filing any civil liability claim, licensing violation claim or 
pursuing any other available legal remedy. 
(Ord. No. 11-159, § 2, 10-3-2011) 


Secs. 22-20522-220. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - PEDDLERS, HAWKERS AND SOLICITORS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license, tax, regulate or prohibit peddlers, itinerant 
merchants and transient vendors, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Secs. 22-22122-250. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - PEDDLERS AND HAWKERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference Street food vendors, § 46-146 et seq. 


Sec. 22-251. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of hawker or peddler of any 
merchandise, article or thing without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-95) 


Sec. 22-252. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made to the village clerk and shall state 
thereon the number of vehicles, if any, intended to be operated, the kind of merchandise to be peddled or 
hawked and the permanent address of the applicant. 
(Code 1972, § 16-96) 


Sec. 22-253. - SameFee. 
    The license fee for peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants and transient vendors, except those 
selling food and beverages, shall be $50.00 for an annual license and $20.00 for a daily license. For 
those engaged in the selling of foods and beverages, the provisions of section 46-146 et seq. shall apply. 
(Code 1972, § 16-97) 


Sec. 22-254. - SameDuty to carry and exhibit. 
    Each peddler who has been issued a license pursuant to this division shall at all times while peddling 
within the village carry upon his person a copy of the license, and shall exhibit such license upon request 
to any police officer or to any person upon whom such peddler calls in the course of business. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1(16-100), 6-19-1995) 


Sec. 22-255. - Fraud and misrepresentation; revocation of license. 
    Any peddler or hawker who shall be guilty of any fraud, cheating or misrepresentation, whether 
through himself or through an employee, while acting as a peddler in the village or who shall barter, sell 
or peddle any goods or merchandise or wares other than those specified in his application for a license 
shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall in addition to any penalty be subject to revocation of his 
license by the village president. 
(Code 1972, § 16-98) 


Sec. 22-256. - Consent of occupants; no peddlers or solicitors sign. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any peddler to enter any residential premises, or to remain therein, for the 
purpose of hawking or peddling any merchandise, article or thing, without the express or implied 
consent of the occupant of the premises. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling upon any premises or at any residence 
located thereon if such premises or residence is posted against peddling or solicitation by means of 
a notice, prominently displayed, upon which either of the following legends is printed: "No solicitors" 
or "No peddlers or solicitors." 
For the purpose of this subsection, a dwelling house, apartment or other place of residence shall be 
deemed to be posted against peddling or solicitation if there is exhibited on or near the main entrance to 
the premises or on or near the main door to any residence located thereon, a sign at least three inches by 
four inches in size, and with letters at least one-third inch in height, which bears either of the above 
legends. Signs complying with the requirements of this section shall be made available at cost at the 
office of the village manager to persons requesting such sign. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1(16-99), 6-19-1995) 


Secs. 22-25722-275. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - SOLICITORS GENERALLY 


Sec. 22-276. - Permit required. 
    No person shall solicit any products or services house to house or within any business establishment 
without first having registered with the village clerk and obtained a permit therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-104) 


Sec. 22-277. - Registration forms; contents. 
    The registration required by this division shall be on forms provided by the village and shall contain 
the following: 
(1) ?The solicitor's signature; 
(2) ?The name of his employer; 
(3) ?The nature of the products or services in which he is interested and the name of the 
manufacturer of the products he intends to sell and his proposed method of operation in the 
village. 
(Code 1972, § 16-105) 


Sec. 22-278. - Bond required. 
    No permit shall be issued under the terms of this division until a cash bond in the amount of $50.00 
is first deposited with the village clerk, conditioned upon the solicitor not committing any offense or 
causing any disturbance while soliciting in the village. 
(Code 1972, § 16-106) 


Sec. 22-279. - Moral character of applicant. 
    No permit required by this division shall be given to any person not of good moral character. 
(Code 1972, § 16-108) 


Sec. 22-280. - Duty to carry and exhibit permit. 
    Each solicitor who has been issued a permit pursuant to this division shall at all times while soliciting 
or canvassing within the village carry upon his person the permit and shall exhibit such permit upon 
request to any police officer or to any person upon whom he calls in the course of his business. 
(Code 1972, § 16-109) 


Sec. 22-281. - Consent of occupants; no solicitors sign. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any solicitor to enter any residential premises, or to remain therein, for the 
purpose of selling or taking orders for any commodity or service or for soliciting contributions or 
memberships of any nature, without the express or implied consent of the occupant of the premises. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in solicitation upon any premises or residence located 
thereon if such premises or residence is posted against solicitation by means of a notice, prominently 
displayed, upon which is printed the legend: "No solicitors." 
For purposes of this subsection, a dwelling house, apartment or other place of residence shall be deemed 
to be posted against solicitation if there is exhibited, on or near the main entrance to the premises, or on 
or near the main door to any residence located thereon, a sign at least three inches by four inches in size, 
with letters at least one-third inch in height, which bears the above legend. Signs complying with the 
requirements of this section shall be made available at cost at the office of the village manager to persons 
requesting such sign. 
(Code 1972, § 16-110) 


Secs. 22-28222-300. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 4. - SOLICITATIONS FOR CHARITABLE PURPOSES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 


Sec. 22-301. - PermitRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to go from house to house soliciting funds or subscriptions or to 
publicly solicit, either in person or by agent, upon the public streets, sidewalks or other public places in 
the village, subscriptions for charitable or religious or educational or other organizations or purposes, 
whether present gifts of money or promises are sought, without having first secured a permit therefor. 
There shall be no registration or permit requirement for any person or organization who is spreading 
information only regarding religious, political or other non-commercial purposes, provided such person or 
organization is not soliciting funds or peddling or hawking any goods or services. 
(Code 1972, § 16-116; Ord. No. 02-146, § 4, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-302. - SameApplication; issuance. 
    Application for a permit required by this division shall be made to the village clerk who shall approve 
and issue the permit upon compliance with all requirements of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 16-117; Ord. No. 16-045, § 2, 3-17-2016) 


Sec. 22-303. - Statewide fundraising drivesApplication for permit to solicit contributions at 
intersections. 
    Any charitable organization registered with the attorney general in the manner provided by law may 
stand upon the streets or highways within the village at any intersection where all traffic is required to 
come to a full stop, for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupants of any vehicle as part of 
a statewide fundraising activity. The charitable organization is limited to one such charitable solicitation 
per year upon village streets or highways. The charitable organization shall be liable for any injuries to 
any person or property during the solicitation which is casually related to any act of ordinary negligence of 
the soliciting agency. Any person engaged in the act of solicitation shall be at least 16 years of age and 
shall wear a high visibility vest. Any charitable organization wishing to engage in such solicitation for 
contributions shall apply to the village clerk for a permit. The application shall state the following facts, 
along with such other facts as may be required by the village clerk: 
(1) ?The name, address and telephone number of the organization. 
(2) ?The name, address and telephone number of a local representative of the organization or that 
person making the application. 
(3) ?Proof that the organization is registered with the attorney general. 
(4) ?A statement of the statewide fundraising activity of which the local solicitation effort is a part. 
(5) ?A certificate of insurance showing whether the organization is insured against any claims for 
injuries or damage to property which is causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the 
soliciting agent acting on behalf of the organization. The village shall be named as an additional 
insured on such certificate of insurance. 
(6) ?The location or locations at which approval to solicit is being sought. 
(7) ?The days and times of days at which such solicitation is proposed to take place. 
(8) ?The number of persons proposed to solicit at each location. 
(Code 1972, § 16-118; Ord. No. 15-111, § 2, 6-25-2015; Ord. No. 16-045, § 2, 3-17-2016) 
State Law reference Solicitation of charitable contributions upon highways within 
municipalities, 625 ILCS 5/11-1006. 


Sec. 22-304. - SameDuties of police chief in issuance of solicitation permit. 
    The village clerk shall issue a permit for solicitation as provided in section 22-303 if he/she finds that 
the applicant has complied with all of the provisions of state law regarding such solicitation and the 
provisions of section 22-303. The village clerk must also find that the locations, times and durations of the 
proposed solicitation and number of proposed solicitors shall not result in an interference with the flow of 
vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1972, § 16-119; Ord. No. 16-045, § 2, 3-17-2016) 


Sec. 22-305. - SameViolation; penalty. 
    Any person, corporation, unincorporated association or other entity violating any provision of section 
22-303 or 22-304 shall, upon a judicial finding of such violation, be fined not less than $50.00 nor more 
than $500.00 for each separate violation. 
(Code 1972, § 16-120) 


DIVISION 5. - PANHANDLING 


Sec. 22-306. - Definitions. 
    As used in this section, the following terms will have the following meanings: 
    "Automated teller machine" means any automated teller machine as defined by the Automated Teller 
Machine Security Act, 205 ILCS 695, as amended. 
    "Bank" means any bank or financial institution as defined by the Illinois Banking Act, 205 ILCS 5, as 
amended. 
    "Currency exchange" means any currency exchange as defined by the Currency Exchange Act, 205 
ILCS 405, as amended. 
    "Panhandling" means any solicitation made in person upon any street, public place or park in the 
village, in which a person requests an immediate donation of money or other gratuity from another 
person, and includes but is not limited to seeking donations: 
(1) ?By vocal appeal; and 
(2) ?Where the person being solicited receives an item of little or no monetary value in exchange for 
a donation, under circumstances where a reasonable person would understand that the 
transaction is in substance a donation. 
    However, "panhandling" shall not include the act of passively standing or sitting nor performing 
music, singing or other street performance with a sign or other indication that a donation is being sought, 
without any vocal request other than in response to an inquiry by another person. 
    "Public place" shall mean any area to which the public is invited or permitted, and includes the public 
way. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 2-17-2009) 


Sec. 22-307. - Panhandling generally. 
    Panhandling within the Village of Westmont is permitted subject to the time, place and manner 
restrictions set forth in this Division 5. Except as permitted in section 22-311(a), panhandling requires a 
permit issued by the village. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 2-17-2009) 


Sec. 22-308. - Prohibitions. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful to engage in an act of panhandling on any day after sunset or before sunrise. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful to engage in an act of panhandling when either the panhandler is located at or 
within 30 feet in any direction of the following locations, or the person being solicited is located at or 
within 30 feet any of the following locations: 
(1) ?At a bus stop; 
(2) ?In any public transportation vehicle or in or upon the grounds of any public transportation 
facility; 
(3) ?In a vehicle which is parked or stopped on a public street or alley; 
(4) ?In a sidewalk cafe; 
(5) ?In a gasoline service station; 
(6) ?At an automated teller machine; 
(7) ?At an entrance to a bank or currency exchange, church or place of worship, 
(8) ?At a residential living facility where persons over the age of 65 or persons with physical or 
developmental disabilities are the primary residence population; 
(9) ?At a funeral home that is open for business; 
(10) ?At a school that is in session or while students are present on the school campus; and 
(11) ?Any Village of Westmont organized or sponsored event, including but not limited to the Taste 
of Westmont, Holly Days Parade, Pumpkin Harvest Festival, 4 th of July Fireworks event, 
Memorial Day event, Patriot's Day event, Concerts in the Park, Celebrate Westmont Festival, 
the Red, White & Bar-B-Q Festival or Crusin' Nights event. 
(c) ?It shall be unlawful to engage in an act of panhandling in an aggressive manner, including any of the 
following actions: 
(1) ?Touching the solicited person without the solicited person's consent; 
(2) ?Panhandling a person while such person is standing in line and waiting to be admitted to a 
commercial establishment; 
(3) ?Blocking the path of a person being solicited, or the entrance to any building or vehicle; 
(4) ?Following behind, ahead or alongside a person who walks away from the panhandler after 
being solicited; 
(5) ?Using profane or abusive language, either during the solicitation or following a refusal to make 
a donation, or making any statement, gesture, or other communication which would cause a 
reasonable person to be fearful or feel compelled; or 
(6) ?Panhandling in a group of two or more persons. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 2-17-2009) 


Sec. 22-309. - Penalties. 
    Each act of panhandling prohibited by this section shall constitute a public nuisance and a separate 
violation of this Code. Each violation shall be punishable as provided in chapter 1, section 8, and the 
court shall enjoin any such violator from committing further violations of this section. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 2-17-2009) 


Sec. 22-310. - Exclusions. 
    This ordinance expressly excludes from enforcement any activity by any person, organization or 
entity being conducted pursuant to any validly issued permits by the village clerk under chapter 22 of the 
Westmont Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 2-17-2009) 


Sec. 22-311. - Panhandling permits. 
(a) ?No person shall panhandle on five or more days in a revolving calendar year without a permit issued 
by the village clerk's office. A person who has been issued a permit shall keep it displayed on his/her 
person at all times while panhandling and show it to any peace officer upon request. No person 
whose permit has been revoked shall panhandle for a period of two years following the revocation. 
Any person found to be panhandling in violation of the permit issued hereunder shall be charged with 
an ordinance violation, or any other proper action or proceeding to enjoin, restrain, correct or abate 
any violation of the foregoing as deemed appropriate by the village attorney. 
(b) ?The village clerk's office shall issue the permit, without fee, to any eligible person who presents 
himself at the village clerk's office, states his true name, presents photo identification or signs a 
declaration under penalty of perjury that he has no such identification, and permits himself to be 
photographed and fingerprinted. 
(c) ?A person is ineligible for a permit if and only if within the past five years he/she: 
(1) ?Has been convicted of two or more violations of this chapter or similar local or state law; 
(2) ?Has had a permit revoked pursuant to subdivisions (e) or (f), below, of this section; or 
(3) ?Has been convicted of two or more offenses under the law of any jurisdiction which involve 
aggressive or intimidating behavior while panhandling or false or misleading representations 
while panhandling. 
(d) ?If the village clerk's office is unable to determine eligibility within 24 hours of the application, the 
department shall issue a permit good for 30 days and determine eligibility for a regular permit before 
the temporary permit expires. The regular permit shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
Along with the permit, the village clerk's office shall give the applicant a copy of this division 5. 
(e) ?Any person or organization that makes any false or misleading representation while applying for a 
permit under this section is guilty of a violation of this division 5 and may be charged accordingly. 
Upon conviction of violation of this subsection, the village clerk's office shall revoke any permit 
issued to the defendant under this section. 
(f) ?If a permit is issued to a person under this section and that person subsequently commits and is 
convicted of a violation of any provision of this division 5, the village clerk's office shall revoke the 
permit. 
(Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 2-17-2009) 


Secs. 22-31222-330. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE V. - SERVICES[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference Registration of electrical contractors, § 18-286 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 46. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Secs. 22-33122-350. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - BARBERSHOPS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license, tax and regulate barbers and barbershops, 65 ILCS 
5/11-42-1; Barber, Cosmetology, Esthetics and Nail Technology Act of 1985, 225 ILCS 410/1-1 et seq. 


Sec. 22-351. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a barbershop in the village without having 
first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-147) 


Sec. 22-352. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall 
state thereon the number of chairs to be used in the barbershop. 
(Code 1972, § 16-148) 


Sec. 22-353. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $50.00, and no licenses shall be issued 
except upon payment of the fee. 
(Code 1972, § 16-149; Ord. No. 02-146, § 5, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-354. - Sanitation; diseased persons. 
    Premises used for a barbershop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and it shall be 
unlawful to permit waste material of any kind to accumulate therein. It shall be unlawful to employ in such 
establishments any person afflicted with a contagious disease. 
(Code 1972, § 16-150) 


Sec. 22-355. - Sterilization of tools, towels. 
    It shall be unlawful to use in any establishment used as a barbershop any implement or tool upon 
any person after the same has been used upon a person afflicted with any skin disease or any scalp 
disease without first sterilizing the implement or tool. It shall be unlawful to use any towel on any 
customer after such towel has been used before without having such towel sterilized and cleaned prior to 
such second usage. 
(Code 1972, § 16-151) 


Sec. 22-356. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of an official designated by the village president and board of trustees to inspect 
every establishment licensed under this division as often as necessary to ensure compliance with this 
division. 
(Code 1972, § 16-152) 


Secs. 22-35722-375. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENTS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference Health and sanitation, ch. 46. 


Sec. 22-376. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dry cleaning establishment means any place where the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a 
process incidental to dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting, or finishing any cloth fabric is rendered as a business. 
(Code 1972, § 16-158) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-377. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall conduct, operate or maintain any dry cleaning establishment in the village without 
first securing a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-159) 


Sec. 22-378. - SameFee. 
    The annual license fee for a dry cleaning establishment shall be $50.00. 
(Code 1972, § 16-160; Ord. No. 02-146, § 6, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-379. - Sanitation; diseased persons. 
    All dry cleaning establishments must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be kept free 
from rats, mice and vermin. No person afflicted with a contagious disease shall be employed in any dry 
cleaners. 
(Code 1972, § 16-161) 


Sec. 22-380. - Fire prevention regulations. 
    No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in a frame building. Such establishment shall be 
kept free from inflammable wastes as far as possible, and it shall be unlawful to maintain or permit a 
stove or open flame of any kind in the premises. Smoking in such premises is hereby prohibited, and 
appropriate signs to that effect shall be posted in conspicuous places in the establishment. 
(Code 1972, § 16-162) 
Cross reference Fire prevention, fire protection and emergency services, ch. 42; fire 
prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Sec. 22-381. - Inspections; report of violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other official designated by the village president and board 
of trustees to inspect or cause to be inspected every establishment licensed under this division at least 
once every six months. Any violations of this division or any other ordinance relating to dry cleaners, the 
premises or flammable liquids, shall be reported to the village president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 16-163) 
Cross reference Fire prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Secs. 22-38222-400. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 4. - LAUNDRIES[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Cross reference Health and sanitation, ch. 46. 
State Law reference Authority of village to regulate laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 


Sec. 22-401. - LicenseRequired; exception. 
(a) ?No person shall operate or conduct a laundry in the village without having first secured a license 
therefor. 
(b) ?Establishments licensed as dry cleaning establishments need not obtain a laundry license in 
addition to the dry cleaning license. 
(Code 1972, § 16-169) 


Sec. 22-402. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk, and 
shall state thereon the location intended to be occupied for use as a laundry. 
(Code 1972, § 16-170) 


Sec. 22-403. - SameFee. 
    The annual license fee for a laundry shall be $50.00. 
(Code 1972, § 16-171; Ord. No. 02-146, § 7, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-404. - Sanitation; diseased persons. 
    Premises used for laundries must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. No refuse of any kind 
shall be permitted to accumulate on such premises and the premises must be kept free from rats, mice 
and vermin. It shall be unlawful to employ any person afflicted with a contagious disease in a laundry. 
(Code 1972, § 16-172) 


Sec. 22-405. - Inspections; report of violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other official designated by the village president and board 
of trustees to inspect or cause to be inspected every establishment licensed under this division at least 
once every six months. Any violations of this division which are discovered shall be reported to the 
president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 16-173) 


Secs. 22-40622-420. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 5. - MOTELS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference Hotel-motel tax, § 74-246 et seq. 
State Law reference Authority of village to regulate public sleeping accommodations, 65 ILCS 5/11-
30-5. 


Sec. 22-421. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motel means every building, structure or any part thereof used or held out to the public to be a place 
where sleeping accommodations are furnished or maintained for 20 or more persons for a period of one 
day or more. 
(Code 1972, § 16-179) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-422. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a motel in the village without having first obtained a license 
therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-180) 


Sec. 22-423. - SameApplication; plans required. 
    Each application for a motel license shall be filed with the village clerk, and shall state thereon the 
name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the owner or manager thereof, the location 
of the motel, and the maximum number of persons and vehicles to be accommodated. The application 
shall be accompanied by plans of the motel, showing the toilet, bath and washbasin facilities, slop sinks, 
water faucets, sewer connections, driveways and other improvements. 
(Code 1972, § 16-181) 


Sec. 22-424. - SameFee. 
    The annual license fee required for motels shall be $60.00. 
(Code 1972, § 16-182) 


Sec. 22-425. - Fire protection for buildings near parking spaces. 
    No parking space shall be provided for motor vehicles within ten feet of any building or structure 
used for housing accommodations in a motel unless the wall facing the parking space is constructed of 
fireproof materials and unless the windows in such wall, if any, are equipped with reinforced fire resistant 
glass. 
(Code 1972, § 16-183) 
Cross reference Fire prevention, fire protection and emergency services, ch. 42. 


Sec. 22-426. - Sanitary facilities. 
    No premises shall be operated as a motel unless each unit of occupancy is equipped with adequate 
toilet and other sanitary facilities to serve the persons accommodated therein. All such sanitary facilities 
shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewer system of the village if the premises are located on a 
street served by such sewer. 
(Code 1972, § 16-184) 
Cross reference Health and sanitation, ch. 46. 


Sec. 22-427. - General cleanliness; removal of waste. 
    All motel premises must be kept clean and sanitary at all times, and all waste material must be 
removed therefrom at least once every 24 hours. 
(Code 1972, § 16-185) 


Sec. 22-428. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of an official designated by the village president and board of trustees to inspect 
or cause to be inspected each motel to see to the compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 16-186) 


Sec. 22-429. - Lighting requirements. 
    Any area or premises of a motel open to use by the public or by all persons staying in or being 
accommodated in the motel shall be kept adequately lighted at nighttime; provided, that such lights must 
be so shaded or otherwise regulated so as to prevent them from shining upon any adjacent premises. 
(Code 1972, § 16-187) 


Sec. 22-430. - House trailers prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of a motel parking lot or garage for the accommodation 
of a house trailer. 
(Code 1972, § 16-188) 


Secs. 22-43122-450. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 6. - NURSING HOMES AND HOMES FOR THE AGED[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference Powers and duties of municipalities as to nursing homes, 210 ILCS 45/3-104 et 
seq. 


Sec. 22-451. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any person making application for a license required by this division. 
    Department means the county health department. 
    Fire chief means the fire chief of the city or his authorized representative. 
    Home for the aged means any home operated not for profit under the auspices of a religious, 
fraternal, charitable or other nonprofit organization or operated not for profit under an endowment, which 
through its ownership or management, as its principal objective, provides maintenance, personal care, 
nursing, or sheltered care to aged persons, and in the conduct of which provides such services to not less 
than three persons over 60 years of age who are not related to the applicant by blood or marriage. 
    Maintenance means food, shelter and laundry. 
    Nursing means professional nursing or practical nursing as these terms are defined by state law, for 
sick or infirm persons who are under the care and supervision of licensed medical practitioners. 
    Nursing home means a private home, institution, building, residence or other place whether operated 
for profit or not or a county home for the infirm and chronically ill operated pursuant to state law or any 
similar institution operated by a political subdivision of the state which provides, through its ownership or 
management, maintenance, personal care, or nursing for three or more persons, not related to the 
applicant or owner by blood or marriage, who by reason of illness or physical infirmity are receiving such 
care. 
    Owner means the licensee. 
    Personal care means assistance with meals, dressing, transportation and movement and such other 
general overseeing of the physical well-being of the residents of a home subject to this division, exclusive 
of nursing, as may be required by their condition. 
    Sheltered care means maintenance and personal care. 
    Sheltered care home means a private boarding home, institution, building, residence or other place 
operated for profit which, through its ownership or management, provides sheltered care to three or more 
adults who are not related to the applicant or owner by blood or marriage. 
(Code 1972, § 16-194) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-452. - Certain institutions exempt from division. 
    The institutions set out in this section are not subject to this division: 
(1) ?A home, institution or other place operated by the federal government or agency thereof, or by 
the state. 
(2) ?A hospital, sanitarium or other institution whose principal activity or business is the care and 
treatment of persons suffering from mental or nervous disease, which is required to be licensed 
by the state, or a hospital, home, sanitarium or other institution duly licensed or approved by the 
department of public welfare under state law. 
(3) ?A hospital, sanitarium or other institution whose principal activity or business is the diagnosis, 
care and treatment of human illness through the maintenance and operation of organized 
facilities therefor, which is required to be licensed by the state. 
(4) ?Any child welfare agency, or child welfare institution required to be licensed by the state under 
state acts. 
(Code 1972, § 16-195) 


Sec. 22-453. - License required. 
    No person shall open, conduct, manage or maintain a nursing home, sheltered care home or home 
for the aged, or advertise as such, without first obtaining a license therefor from the village. 
(Code 1972, § 16-196) 


Sec. 22-454. - Inspections prerequisite to license issuance. 
    No license required by this division shall be issued for the operation of a nursing home, sheltered 
care home or home for the aged until an inspection shall first have been made by the economic 
development director, plumbing inspector, electrical inspector, the fire chief and the county health 
department and approval is granted by the director of the county health department. 
(Code 1972, § 16-197; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 22-455. - Denial of license; grounds. 
    An application for a license required by this division may be denied for any of the following reasons: 
(1) ?Failure to meet any of the minimum standards prescribed by the state department of public 
health. 
(2) ?Conviction of a felony, as shown by a certified copy of the record of the court of conviction, of 
the applicant or if the applicant is a firm or corporation, of any of its members or officers or of 
the person designated to manage or supervise the home; or other satisfactory evidence that the 
moral character of the applicant or the manager or supervisor of the home is not reputable. 
(3) ?Nursing personnel insufficient in number or unqualified by training or experience to properly 
care for the proposed number and type of residents. 
(4) ?Financial inability to operate and conduct the home in accordance with the requirements of this 
division and the minimum standards, rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Code 1972, § 16-198) 


Sec. 22-456. - License fee; license year. 
    The annual license fee for operating a nursing home or sheltered care home shall be $100.00. For 
the purpose of this division, the annual license period shall run from January 1 to December 31, and the 
license fee as set forth in this section shall be submitted together with the application for a license. When 
an application for a license is submitted during a given year for the balance of the year the license fee 
shall be prorated in accordance with the number of full months remaining in that year. 
(Code 1972, § 16-199) 


Sec. 22-457. - Institutions exempt from license fee; to comply with standards. 
    Nursing homes or sheltered care homes operating on a nonprofit basis and all homes for the aged 
shall not be required to pay a license fee, but a license shall be applied for and used without charge. 
However, nonprofit nursing homes, sheltered care homes and homes for the aged shall be operated in 
accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 16-200) 


Sec. 22-458. - Renewal of license. 
    No application for the annual renewal of a license required by this division shall be granted unless 
authorized by the county health department and the application is accompanied with the required renewal 
fee. 
(Code 1972, § 16-201) 


Sec. 22-459. - Inspections and approvals prerequisite to renewal of license. 
    Before any license issued pursuant to this division can be renewed, the premises to be licensed shall 
be inspected and approved by the following persons: 
(1) ?The fire inspector. 
(2) ?The economic development director. 
(3) ?The plumbing inspector. 
(4) ?The electrical inspector. 
(Code 1972, § 16-202; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 22-460. - Revocation of license. 
    Licenses issued under the provisions of this division may be revoked by the village manager for 
violation of any of the provisions of this division. In the event of a revocation, the license shall become null 
and void and the original license and renewal certificates shall be surrendered to the village clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 16-203) 


Sec. 22-461. - License void upon sale or change of location of institution. 
    When a licensed nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged is sold, leased, 
discontinued or moved to a new location, the annual renewal certificate as well as the original license 
shall immediately become void and shall be returned to the county health department. 
(Code 1972, § 16-204) 


Sec. 22-462. - Minimum standards. 
    All nursing homes, sheltered care homes, and homes for the aged must comply with the minimum 
requirements established by the state department of public health under the Nursing Home Care Act, [17] 
which are hereby adopted by reference; three copies of such requirements shall be on file in the office of 
the village clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 16-205) 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference (210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.) 


Sec. 22-463. - Quarterly inspections by fire chief. 
    The fire chief shall make quarterly inspections of each home licensed under this division to 
determine that no fire hazards exist in the building or on the premises, that suitable firefighting equipment 
has been provided and that all the provisions of the fire prevention regulations of the village and the 
minimum standards relating to fire protection have been complied with. 
(Code 1972, § 16-206) 


Secs. 22-46422-485. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 7. - PARKING LOTS[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference Sale of food for consumption on parking lots, § 46-43; sidewalks and driveways, § 70-
71 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78. 
State Law reference Authority of village to regulate parking lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 


Sec. 22-486. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking lot means any place maintained for the outdoor parking of cars, except on a street, alley or 
other public place, where such parking is permitted upon the payment of compensation or is made 
available to patrons or customers of any places of business. 
(Code 1972, § 16-212) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-487. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a parking lot in the village without first having obtained a license 
therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-213) 


Sec. 22-488. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall 
contain all necessary information to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division, including a 
description of the location, size, number of cars to be accommodated, and a statement of any services, 
other than parking, or of any commodities for sale offered to patrons of the parking lot. 
(Code 1972, § 16-214) 


Sec. 22-489. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $50.00 for 50 parking spaces or less, 
and $75.00 for 51 parking spaces or more. 
(Code 1972, § 16-215; Ord. No. 02-146, § 8, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-490. - Lots not to be established or operated in violation of ordinances. 
    No parking lot shall be established or operated in any place where the lot or operation would be in 
violation of the village zoning ordinance or any other ordinance. 
(Code 1972, § 16-216) 


Sec. 22-491. - Surfacing of lot. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a parking lot in the village unless the surface is covered with concrete, 
asphalt, macadam or similar paving. 
(Code 1972, § 16-217) 


Sec. 22-492. - Construction and repair of driveways. 
    No driveway to a parking lot shall be constructed except in full compliance with the provisions of this 
Code relative to the issuance of permits for driveways. It shall be the duty of the operator of each parking 
lot to maintain the sidewalk and parkway over which any driveway passes in good condition. 
(Code 1972, § 16-218) 


Sec. 22-493. - Minimum parking space requirements. 
    Minimum parking space dimensions, aisle widths, and parking configurations shall comply with the 
provisions of the Village of Westmont Parking Standards, published by the Westmont Public Works 
Department, and which is hereby adopted by reference. Copies of such publication shall remain on file 
and be made available at both the office of the village clerk and at the village public works department. 
(Code 1972, § 16-219; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 22-494. - Marking of parking spaces; sufficiency of exits. 
    Each parking lot shall be marked so as to show the parking place allotted for each vehicle, and shall 
have sufficient entrances and exits to permit the entrance and egress of vehicles without obstruction to 
traffic. 
(Code 1972, § 16-220) 


Sec. 22-495. - Buildings on lot. 
    Any buildings constructed on a parking lot shall be constructed in full compliance with this Code and 
other ordinances pertaining thereto, and shall have exterior walls of nonflammable materials. Any 
structure used or to be used for office purposes only may have less than the minimum area requirements 
prescribed for residences or commercial buildings. 
(Code 1972, § 16-221) 


Sec. 22-496. - General cleanliness. 
    All parking lots shall be kept clean and free from dust and refuse at all times. 
(Code 1972, § 16-222) 


Sec. 22-497. - Fire extinguishers required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any parking lot unless there are available on the premises adequate 
fire extinguishers and personnel competent to use such fire extinguishers. There shall be maintained on 
each parking lot at least one handheld chemical fire extinguisher having a capacity of one quart of liquid 
or 2½ pounds of carbon dioxide for each ten cars for which accommodations are offered, which 
extinguishers shall always be maintained in good order and in accessible places. Where accommodations 
are provided for more than 100 cars, there shall be maintained in addition to the handheld extinguishers 
required, at least one portable chemical fire extinguisher having a capacity of 2½ gallons of liquid or 15 
pounds of carbon dioxide. 
(Code 1972, § 16-223) 


Sec. 22-498. - Attendant to be present. 
    There shall be at least one attendant on the premises at all times during which the parking lot is open 
for business. 
(Code 1972, § 16-224) 


Sec. 22-499. - Posting of rates and closing hours. 
    At the entrance of each parking lot there shall be posted in words and figures large enough to be 
read by prospective patrons a statement of the rates to be charged and of the closing hours of the parking 
lot. 
(Code 1972, § 16-225) 


Sec. 22-500. - Operation of business in conjunction with parking lot. 
    If any business other than that of operating a parking lot is conducted on the same premises with a 
parking lot, such business shall be conducted in full compliance with all ordinances pertinent thereto, and 
any license required for the operation of such business must be procured and the fee therefor required 
must be paid. 
(Code 1972, § 16-226) 


Sec. 22-501. - Use of alcoholic liquor prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to serve alcoholic liquor for consumption in any vehicle parked in a parking lot, 
and it shall be unlawful for any person in a vehicle parked in a parking lot to drink any intoxicating liquor 
while in such vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 16-227) 
Cross reference Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10. 


Sec. 22-502. - Abandoned vehicles; display of vehicles; use as repair shop. 
    It shall be unlawful to park or store, in any parking lot, any vehicle which is not in a condition ready 
for use, or to permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially disabled vehicle in any such lot. It 
shall be unlawful to use any parking lot for storage or parking of any vehicle for the purpose of displaying 
such vehicle for sale, or to use any parking lot or portion thereof as an automobile repair shop. 
(Code 1972, § 16-228) 


Secs. 22-50322-525. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 8. - PUBLIC GARAGES[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Cross reference Traffic and vehicles, ch. 78. 
State Law reference Authority of village to regulate garages, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 


Sec. 22-526. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall operate or maintain a public garage in the village without having first obtained a 
license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-234) 


Sec. 22-527. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made to the village clerk in writing, and 
shall state the location of the garage and the number of cars which can be accommodated therein. 
(Code 1972, § 16-235) 


Sec. 22-528. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $50.00 for 50 parking spaces or less, 
and $75.00 for 51 parking spaces or more. 
(Code 1972, § 16-236; Ord. No. 02-146, § 9, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-529. - Certain buildings not to be used as public garages. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage in a frame building, or in any building or 
structure used for school, church or theater purposes, or in any building which does not conform to the 
requirements of the village building code. 
(Code 1972, § 16-237) 


Sec. 22-530. - Location of driveways. 
    No driveway for a public garage or auto repair shop shall be within 250 feet of the external boundary 
of any premises used for a church, school, place of public assembly, village hall or fire station. 
(Code 1972, § 16-239) 


Sec. 22-531. - Cleanliness; flammable wastes. 
    Every public garage in the village shall be kept clean and free from flammable wastes. 
(Code 1972, § 16-240) 


Sec. 22-532. - Smoking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or light a cigarette, pipe or cigar in any public garage. 
(Code 1972, § 16-241) 


Sec. 22-533. - Changing identification on vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change the identification marks on any vehicle in any public 
garage. It shall be unlawful to change the license tags on any such vehicle, excepting in accordance with 
the register of motor vehicles kept by the secretary of state. 
(Code 1972, § 16-242) 


Sec. 22-534. - Inspection of garage and vehicles.
