    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire chief to make or cause to be made such 
inspections of public garages as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this 
division. Any police officer may be permitted at any reasonable time to view any vehicle stored or kept in 
any public garage, and it shall be unlawful to hinder any such inspection or to conceal any vehicle from 
inspection. 
(Code 1972, § 16-243) 


Secs. 22-53522-555. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 9. - SCAVENGERS[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Editor's note Section 1 of Ord. No. 97-16, adopted on March 3, 1997, repealed former div. 9, §§ 22-
55622-560, which pertained to scavengers and catchbasin cleaners, and enacted a new div. 9, §§ 22-
55622-560, to read as herein set out. The repealed sections derived from §§ 16-24916-253 of the 
1972 Code. 
Cross reference Health and sanitation, ch. 46; solid waste, ch. 66. 


Sec. 22-556. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial service means solid waste collection service provided to commercial and industrial 
businesses, for which such service is provided from standard commercial containers, commonly known 
as dumpsters, and for which billing is made directly by the village's exclusive provider, or, in the case of 
recyclable materials collection service, by the village's exclusive provider or other licensed provider. 
    Recyclables and recyclable materials mean and include materials which have a useful second life in 
the economic cycle if they are successfully collected, separated, and marketed for return to the economic 
mainstream. Recyclable materials shall include any and all materials which are to be recycled pursuant to 
the village's exclusive contract for residential recycling, a list of which may be obtained from the office of 
the village clerk. 
    Refuse means and includes such terms as "garbage," "debris," and "solid waste," and includes 
discarded items other than recyclables and yard waste. 
    Residential/commercial service means solid waste collection service provided to multiple-family 
dwellings, including rental units and owner-occupied units, for which such service is provided from 
standard commercial containers, commonly known as dumpsters, and for which billing is made directly by 
the village's exclusive provider. 
    Residential service means solid waste collection service provided to detached or attached single-
family dwellings, and to certain townhome or condominium units, for which such service is provided by 
standard residential containers from each dwelling unit, and for which billing is not made by the village's 
exclusive provider, except for yard waste or other special collections as provided in the village's contract 
with its exclusive provider. 
    Yard waste means and includes grass and garden clippings, leaves, weeds, plant materials, brown-
stemmed branches and shrub prunings. 
(Ord. No. 97-16, § 1, 3-3-1997) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-557. - Collection of solid waste by persons other than village's exclusive provider. 
(a) ?The village has granted a contract to an exclusive provider for all solid waste collection services, 
except for the collection of recyclable materials from commercial and industrial businesses. 
(b) ?Except for the village's exclusive provider of solid waste collection services, no person shall provide 
residential service, as defined in this division, regardless of how such service is billed, no person 
shall provide residential/commercial or commercial service, as defined in this division, and no person 
shall engage in the business of providing such services, except for the collection of recyclable 
materials from commercial and industrial businesses. 
(Ord. No. 97-16, § 1, 3-3-1997) 


Sec. 22-558. - Recycling scavenger license required. 
    Except for the village's exclusive provider, it shall be unlawful for any person to collect or dispose of 
recyclable materials or to engage in the business of collecting and disposing of recyclable materials in the 
village without obtaining a recycling scavenger license. 
(Ord. No. 97-16, § 1, 3-3-1997) 


Sec. 22-559. - Application for recycling scavenger license; issuance; insurance; fee. 
(a) ?Application for a recycling scavenger license shall be made to the village clerk on a form to be 
provided by the clerk's office. 
(b) ?All applications for recycling scavenger licenses shall be referred to the village board, which shall 
either approve or disapprove the issuance of a license. 
(c) ?Prior to issuance of any recycling scavenger license under this division, the applicant shall procure 
comprehensive general liability insurance and comprehensive automobile liability insurance, with 
limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 for property damage, $1,000,000.00 for bodily injury or death of 
any one person and $2,000,000.00 per occurrence. A certificate of insurance shall be provided to the 
village clerk attesting to the required coverages for the full term of the license, and such certificate 
shall state that the insurer is required to provide written notice to the village of any cancellation or 
reduction in coverage on any insurance policy not less than 90 days prior to the effective date of 
such cancellation or reduction. 
(d) ?The annual fee for a recycling scavenger license shall be $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 97-16, § 1, 3-3-1997; Ord. No. 98-135, § 1, 11-16-1998) 


Sec. 22-560. - Standards for operation as recycling scavenger. 
(a) ?Any vehicle used by a recycling scavenger in the village shall be kept in a clean and sanitary 
condition, shall be fully enclosed and leakproof, and shall be maintained and operated in such 
manner that recyclables cannot leak, spill or blow off the vehicle. The vehicle operator shall be 
responsible for the immediate collection and cleanup of any litter. 
(b) ?The licensee shall undertake to perform all collection and disposal services in a clean, orderly and 
efficient manner. 
(c) ?All vehicle operators shall be properly licensed and shall obey all traffic regulations, including weight 
and speed limits. 
(d) ?No recyclables shall be deposited, stored or disposed of in any place in the village, except with the 
proper zoning and the express permission of the village board. 
(Ord. No. 97-16, § 1, 3-3-1997) 


Secs. 22-56122-580. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 10. - FUNERAL DIRECTORS[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
State Law reference Funeral Directors and Embalmers Licensing Code, 225 ILCS 41/1-1 et seq. 


Sec. 22-581. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain an undertaking establishment or to operate as a 
funeral director in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 16-259) 


Sec. 22-582. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $50.00. 
(Code 1972, § 16-260; Ord. No. 02-146, § 10, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-583. - Duty to notify police of all corpses. 
    It shall be the duty of every funeral director to notify the police whenever a corpse is brought in to 
him or turned over to him for his services. 
(Code 1972, § 16-262) 


Sec. 22-584. - Exhibition of deceased person. 
    It shall be unlawful for any funeral director to permit his establishment to be used for the exhibition to 
the public of the body of any deceased person. This section shall not be construed to prevent the display 
of a body to relatives and friends of the deceased. 
(Code 1972, § 16-263) 


Secs. 22-58522-610. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VI. - FACTORIES AND MACHINE SHOPS[22] 
Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to regulate blacksmith shops, foundries and machine shops, 
65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 22-611. - License required for operation of blacksmith shops and foundries; fee. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain any blacksmith shop or foundry within the village without 
first having secured a license therefor. 
(b) ?The annual fee for a license required by this section shall be $25.00. 
(Code 1972, § 16-274) 


Sec. 22-612. - Zoning ordinance to control. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be construed to permit the establishment of any factory or 
place of business in any location where the factory or place of business is prohibited by the village zoning 
ordinance (appendix A). 
(Code 1972, § 16-275) 


Secs. 22-61322-635. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - MACHINE SHOPS 


Sec. 22-636. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Machine shop means every workshop in which machines are made or metal parts thereof are 
repaired, or where parts of machines or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws, or other metal articles are 
cut, filed, shaped or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery. 
(Code 1972, § 16-281) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-637. - LicenseRequired; exception. 
(a) ?No person shall conduct, operate or manage a machine shop in the village without first securing a 
license therefor. 
(b) ?No additional license shall be required under this section for any machine shop which is specifically 
licensed under any other provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 16-282) 


Sec. 22-638. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $50.00. 
(Code 1972, § 16-283; Ord. No. 02-146, § 11, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-639. - Night operation in residential areas. 
    No machine shop shall be operated between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. in any place in 
which a majority of the buildings within a radius of 400 feet are used exclusively for residential purposes. 
(Code 1972, § 16-284) 


Sec. 22-640. - General health and safety. 
    No building, structure, or part thereof used for or in connection with any machine shop shall be used 
in any way so as to endanger the health or property of the employees or of the public. 
(Code 1972, § 16-285) 


Sec. 22-641. - General maintenance; cleanliness. 
    The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or manager of any machine shop shall cause all floors or other 
surfaces around or beneath any machine or workbench to be kept in good order and repair and shall 
have suitable and convenient sanitary receptacles for receiving wastes and cloths used in and about the 
machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or which are intended for any other 
necessary use. 
(Code 1972, § 16-286) 


Sec. 22-642. - Diseased persons not to be employed where cutting compound or fluid is used; preventing 
infection. 
    No person suffering from any actively contagious or infectious disease shall be employed in or about 
any machine shop where cutting compound or fluid is used. All cutting compound or fluid shall be kept 
free from infectious or harmful matter. 
(Code 1972, § 16-287) 


Sec. 22-643. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of an official designated by the village president and board of trustees to make or 
cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this 
division. 
(Code 1972, § 16-288) 


Secs. 22-64422-665. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VII. - VENDING MACHINES 


Sec. 22-666. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Vending machine means any machine which dispenses for monetary consideration above $0.10, by 
package, can, carton or directly into any receptacle, any tobacco products, foods, drinks, or other goods 
by mechanical means. 
(Code 1972, § 16-301) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-667. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate, use, maintain or dispense goods by means of a vending machine 
without having first obtained a license authorizing the sale and dispensing of goods through a vending 
machine. 
(Code 1972, § 16-300) 


Sec. 22-668. - SameApplication. 
    Any person desiring to operate, dispense or maintain a vending machine shall make written 
application for a license on forms to be provided by the village clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 16-302) 


Sec. 22-669. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a vending machine license for products other than tobacco products shall be 
$25.00 for each vending machine. The annual fee for a vending machine license for tobacco products 
shall be $40.00 for each vending machine. The fee for a daily license for any vending machine shall be 
$12.50. 
(Code 1972, § 16-303; Ord. No. 02-146, § 12, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-670. - SameDisplay. 
    Each vending machine shall display the vending license issued by the village. 
(Code 1972, § 16-304) 


Sec. 22-671. - Certain vending machines prohibited outdoors. 
    Any vending machine dispensing goods or products which minors are prohibited to purchase shall be 
enclosed within a building and shall not be permitted outdoors. 
(Code 1972, § 16-305) 


Secs. 22-67222-700. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VIII. - GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS[23] 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
Cross reference Fire prevention, fire protection and emergency services, ch. 42. 


Sec. 22-701. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Service station means any place of business where gasoline or any highly volatile fuels for motor 
vehicles or internal combustion engines are sold or offered for sale. 
(Code 1972, § 14-1) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-702. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a service station in the village without first obtaining a 
license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 14-2) 


Sec. 22-703. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license for a service station shall be $10.00 per customer fuel service pump. 
(Code 1972, § 14-3; Ord. No. 02-146, § 13, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-704. - Private storage tanks. 
    Any person maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for his own use or the use of his 
employees or agents shall comply with all of the provisions of this article other than the requirement for 
the payment of a license fee. 
(Code 1972, § 14-4) 


Sec. 22-705. - Distance requirement from church, school, certain other places. 
    No driveway for a service station shall be within 200 feet of the external boundary of any premises 
used for a church, school, place of public assembly, village hall or fire station. 
(Code 1972, § 14-5(b)) 


Sec. 22-706. - Approval of plans for alterations and construction; contents of plans. 
    Drawings or blueprints made to scale shall be submitted in triplicate to the village president and 
board of trustees and shall be approved by them before any new construction, addition or remodeling is 
undertaken on any service station. Drawings shall carry the name of the person proposing the installation, 
the location of the service station and shall in addition show the following: 
(1) ?The plot to be utilized and its immediate surroundings on all sides; all property lines shall be 
designated and adjacent streets and highways shall be named. 
(2) ?The complete installation as proposed, including tanks and their capacity, pumps, buildings, 
drives and all equipment shall be shown. 
(3) ?Clearance from tanks to property lines shall be shown. 
(4) ?The type of construction of the filling station building or buildings, with a clear showing that 
there will be no basement, cellar or excavation under any portion of the building. 
(5) ?The location of basements, cellars or pits of any other buildings on the property or on adjacent 
property, and the location of tanks with reference thereto. If a building has no basement, cellar 
or pit a notation shall be made to that effect. 
(6) ?The location of sewers, manholes, catchbasins, cesspools, septic tanks, wells or cisterns, 
whether on the property or adjacent to the property or in adjoining streets, highways or alleys, 
and the location of tanks with reference thereto. If there is no sewer, manhole or catchbasin in a 
street or alley or no sewer, manhole, cesspool, septic tank, well or cistern on the property a 
notation to that effect shall be made. 
(7) ?The location of vent pipe outlets and the location of the fill pipe shall be shown. 
(8) ?The ventilation of the greasing pit if a greasing pit is located within a building or enclosure shall 
be shown. 
(9) ?The drawings shall be accompanied by an application for approval made out in triplicate on 
blanks furnished by the village clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 14-6) 
Cross reference Fire prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Sec. 22-707. - Bulk sales prohibited. 
    No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except into fuel tanks connected with the 
carburetion system of motor vehicles; however, individual sales of up to five gallons per person may be 
made in metal receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with state law. 
(Code 1972, § 14-7) 


Sec. 22-708. - Self-service sales, application; safety inspection. 
(a) ?It shall be permissible for a service station owner to provide wholly or partially for self-service 
gasoline sales. 
(b) ?For the purposes of this section, "self-service" is defined as the operation by persons other than the 
service station owner or authorized employee of motor fuel dispensing equipment at any gasoline 
service station, provided that such operation by any other person is for consumption of such motor 
fuel in a motor vehicle, or that such motor fuel is placed into a properly marked container for the 
storage of such motor fuels. 
(c) ?Any service station owner who desires to provide wholly or partially for self-service gasoline sales 
shall file an application stating such desire with the village fire department. No such application shall 
be approved until the fire chief of the village has conducted a safety inspection. Such a safety 
inspection shall also be required upon the happening of any one of the following: 
(1) ?A new service station owner takes possession of a service station which wholly or partially 
provides for self-service gasoline sales; and 
(2) ?There are repeated complaints by residents of the village that a self-service gasoline service 
station is being conducted in a manner which may constitute a fire hazard. 
(d) ?The fee for the inspection required by this section shall be $15.00. 
(Code 1972, § 14-8) 


Sec. 22-709. - Fire prevention requirements generally. 
(a) ?No gasoline shall be placed in any motor vehicle until the motor and ignition have been shut off. 
(b) ?No smoking shall be permitted on the premises of any service station at any time. 
(c) ?No open lights or flames shall be permitted except within a stove located within the service station 
building. 
(d) ?Cleaning with gasoline, naphtha or other highly flammable liquids of classes I and II as defined in 
the fire prevention code adopted in section 42-186 shall not be permitted in or around any service 
station. 
(Code 1972, § 14-9) 


Sec. 22-710. - Fire extinguishers required. 
    Every service station shall be equipped with fire extinguishers required by the fire prevention code 
adopted in section 42-186. 
(Code 1972, § 14-10) 


Sec. 22-711. - Cleanliness of premises. 
    All service stations shall be kept neat and clean and free of rubbish and trash. 
(Code 1972, § 14-11) 


Sec. 22-712. - Construction and use of greasing pits. 
(a) ?Every greasing pit installed in a building or enclosed by three or more walls shall be ventilated by a 
vent duct not less than six inches in diameter or an equivalent cross-sectional area if a noncircular 
duct is used. The duct shall start within four inches of the floor and shall extend on an upward 
diagonal or by an easy bend over to the side wall, thence straight up through the roof to a height 
sufficient to draw off gasoline vapors which may accumulate at the bottom of the pit. Abrupt bends 
must be avoided and all joints must be tight. The floor of the pit should slope slightly toward the 
corner where the duct is located to facilitate the flow of gases to the duct. 
(b) ?Gasoline or naphtha shall never be used to clean out any greasing pit, whether the pit is located 
within a building or enclosure or in the open. 
(c) ?No sewer connection shall be permitted from any greasing pit. 
(d) ?If the greasing pit is electrically lighted, the globes shall be of vaporproof construction and the wiring 
shall be in a conduit. 
(Code 1972, § 14-12) 


Sec. 22-713. - Grease traps, when required; cleaning. 
    If a sewer connection is made to any service station, an adequate grease trap shall be provided to 
intercept grease and oils. The trap shall be cleaned out at least every 30 days. 
(Code 1972, § 14-13) 


Sec. 22-714. - Basements; floors. 
(a) ?No basement or excavation shall be permitted under any service station building. 
(b) ?The floor level of the service station building shall be abovegrade so as to prevent the flow of liquids 
or vapors into the building. 
(c) ?The floor of the service station building shall be on concrete. 
(Code 1972, § 14-14) 


Sec. 22-715. - Storage of inflammable liquids prohibited; exceptions. 
(a) ?No gasoline, naphtha or other liquids of class I type, as defined in the fire prevention code adopted 
by section 42-186, shall be kept inside of any service station. 
(b) ?No alcohol or other flammable antifreeze solution shall be kept inside of any service station except 
in original sealed containers. No transfer of such liquids from these receptacles shall be made inside 
of any service station. 
(Code 1972, § 14-15) 
Cross reference Fire prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Sec. 22-716. - Storage of gasoline and other flammable liquids. 
    The storage of gasoline and other flammable liquids and the construction and location of tanks 
therefor shall be in accordance with the fire prevention code adopted in section 42-186. 
(Code 1972, § 14-16) 
Cross reference Fire prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Sec. 22-717. - Inspection fee for installation and/or testing of tanks. 
    The annual inspection fee for tanks used to store gasoline or other flammable liquids on any service 
station premises shall be $50.00 per tank. 
(Code 1972, § 14-17; Ord. No. 00-57, § 1, 6-19-2000; Ord. No. 02-146, § 14, 12-16-2002) 
Cross reference Fire prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Secs. 22-71822-750. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IX. - GARAGE SALES 


Sec. 22-751. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage sale means the sale or offering for sale of personal or household goods, by the advertising 
and/or display of such goods on a lot or within a building located within any residential district. 
(Code 1972, § 16-290(a)) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-752. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not more than $100.00 for each 
offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation 
occurs or continues. 
(Code 1972, § 16-295) 


Sec. 22-753. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to hold or conduct a garage sale within the corporate limits of the village without 
first obtaining a permit authorizing such sale. 
(Code 1972, § 16-289) 


Sec. 22-754. - Deposit required for certain garage sales. 
    For garage sales held by other than individuals for personal goods, a deposit of $25.00 will be 
required, to be returned within 30 days if there has been no violation of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 16-290(b)) 


Sec. 22-755. - Application procedure; restrictions; permit fee. 
    Any person desiring to hold or conduct a garage sale shall make written application on forms to be 
provided by the village clerk. No garage sale shall be held or conducted between the hours of 8:00 p.m. 
and 8:00 a.m. nor for a period exceeding three consecutive days. No more than two such permits will be 
issued within any 12-month period unless the applicant is in the process of moving from one residence to 
another residence. A fee of $5.00 shall be charged for the issuance of any garage sale permit. The permit 
will be prominently displayed throughout the time of the sale on the property where the sale is being held. 
(Code 1972, § 16-291; Ord. No. 02-146, § 15, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-756. - Untrue statements on application prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person applying for a permit to hold or conduct a garage sale to make any 
fraudulent or untrue statements concerning the ownership of the goods to be sold or offered for sale. 
(Code 1972, § 16-294) 


Sec. 22-757. - Prohibition on sale of goods acquired for resale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person holding or conducting a garage sale within the village to sell or 
offer for sale any goods acquired by the owner for purposes of sale or resale. 
(Code 1972, § 16-293) 


Sec. 22-758. - Posting of signs. 
    No direction or advertising signs will be posted on any pole, tree, or other public property within the 
village limits except on the property of the person conducting the garage sale. 
(Code 1972, § 16-292) 


Secs. 22-75922-780. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE X. - ADULT USES[24] 
Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Editor's note Section 1 of Ord. No. 99-20, adopted February 1, 1999, incorporated therein by 
reference thereto the introductory recitals of such ordinance. Since § 1 of the ordinance did not 
specifically amend this Code, the introductory clauses are set forth herein for the convenience of the 
Code user: 
"WHEREAS, the Mayor and Board of Trustees believe and hereby declare that it is in the best interest of 
the Village of Westmont and its residents to amend the provisions of Chapter 22, Article X of the Village 
Code to incorporate regulations governing the sale and distribution of certain articles and more perfectly 
clarifying the sale, rental or transfer of these items for any consideration as adult uses, as hereinafter set 
forth; and 
"WHEREAS, the Village recently entered into a debate with a prospective business owner as to whether 
the sale of sexual devices or marital aids such as prostheses, vibrators, waxes, sexually exploitive lingerie 
and undergarments, and other items were governed by the Village's adult use ordinance governing 
bookstores; and 
"WHEREAS, the Village merely hopes to make perfectly explicit in its ordinances that the sale of the 
above-noted items constitutes an adult use; and 
"WHEREAS, the effort to amend the adult use ordinance will not change the Village's present 
interpretation of Section 22-781 as it pertains to adult bookstores such as the one which was the subject 
of the debate noted above; and 
"WHEREAS, the Mayor and Village Board have acted jointly to respond to the allegations of the 
prospective business owner and they are continuing to act Jointly based upon the evidence presented to 
the Zoning and Planning Commission and other relevant hearings; and 
"WHEREAS, the Mayor and Village Board understand that there is a place in the Village for adult uses 
and that place is not within any district other than a manufacturing district where the business can meet 
appropriate space and distance restrictions; and 
"WHEREAS, the regulation of adult use establishments is essential for the protection of public health, 
safety, and welfare. 
"NOW THEREFORE, be in [it] ordained by the Mayor and Board of Trustees of the Village of Westmont, 
DuPage County, Illinois as follows:" 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 22-781. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult bookstore means an establishment having, as a substantial portion of its stock in trade, books, 
magazines, films or videotapes for sale or viewing on the premises by use of motion picture devices or 
other coin-operated means, and other periodicals which are distinguished by their emphasis on matter 
depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as such terms 
are defined in this section, or an establishment with a segment or section devoted to the sale or display of 
such material. Adult bookstores may alternatively or in conjunction with the above stock in trade sell 
undergarments and other clothing designed for the display of specified anatomical areas or for the 
enhancement of specified sexual activities. Further, an adult bookstore may alternatively or in conjunction 
with the above stock in trade sell prosthetic devices, dolls, candles, vibrators and other objects for sexual 
gratification which take the form of specified anatomical areas and for the purpose of enhancing specified 
sexual activities. 
    Adult entertainment cabaret means an establishment offering to its patrons, as entertainment, any 
exhibition or display or any theatrical or other live performances which include topless or go-go dancers, 
exotic dancers, strippers, male or female impersonators, or similar entertainers, or any persons singing, 
reading, posing, modeling, or serving food or beverages, where the exhibition, performance, display or 
dance is intended to sexually arouse the entertainer or the patrons, or where the attire of persons 
involved is such as to expose specified anatomical areas, as defined in this section. 
    Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building, regardless of its seating capacity, which is 
used to present for public view on the premises, films, movies, previews, trailers or advertisements which 
are distinguished by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual 
activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this section. 
    Adult use means and includes adult bookstores, adult entertainment cabarets, and adult motion 
picture theaters, as defined in this section. 
    Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1) ?Less than completely and opaquely covered human or animal genitals, pubic region, or pubic 
hair, buttocks; and female breasts below a point immediately above the top of the areola; and 
(2) ?Genitals of humans or animals in a discernible turgid state, even if completely opaquely 
covered. 
    Specified sexual activities means: 
(1) ?Human or animal genitals in the state of sexual stimulation or arousal. 
(2) ?Acts or representations of acts of human or animal masturbation, sexual intercourse or 
sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation or flagellation. 
(3) ?Fondling or erotic touching of human or animal genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breast. 
(4) ?Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any activities set forth in subsections (1) 
through (3) of this definition. 
(Ord. No. 94-15, § 1(16-312), 2-21-1994; Ord. No. 99-20, § 2, 2-1-1999) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-782. - Conditions and regulations governing operation; violation; penalty. 
(a) ?The following regulations shall govern and control the business of operating an adult use in the 
village: 
(1) ?No person under 21 years of age shall be allowed on the licensed premises. 
(2) ?At all times during the hours of operation there shall be present a manager or other employee 
of the licensee who shall be not less than 21 years of age. 
(3) ?Upon a change of any manager conducting business for the licensee, the licensee shall, within 
ten regular business days, give the village clerk written notice of such change by actual delivery 
or by registered or certified mail. The licensee shall, thereafter, as promptly as practicable, but 
in any event within five regular business days, provide the information concerning the new 
manager which is required in section 22-802(a). 
(4) ?No adult use shall be located on premises for which a license to sell alcoholic liquor has been 
issued, and no alcoholic liquor shall be permitted on such premises. 
(5) ?No adult use shall be permitted unless the premises on which such business is located 
complies with the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(6) ?No licensee or manager under the provisions of this article shall knowingly permit any person 
to remain in or upon licensed premises who commits any act of public indecency or obscenity 
as defined in sections 58-10 and 58-11, respectively, of this Code. 
(7) ?No licensee or manager under the provisions of this article shall permit any act of prostitution, 
solicitation for prostitution or patronization of a prostitute on the licensed premises. 
(8) ?No sign shall be posted on the licensed premises which depicts, displays or refers to specified 
anatomical areas or specified sexual activities, as defined in this article. 
(b) ?In addition to the requirements established in subsection (a) of this section, the following regulations 
shall govern and control the operation of an adult bookstore which offers any films or videotapes for 
viewing on premises by use of motion picture devices or other such operations means: 
(1) ?All viewing areas, which shall be defined as the area where a patron or customer would 
ordinarily be positioned while watching a film or viewing device, shall be visible from a 
continuous main aisle or public room and shall not be obscured by any curtain, door, wall or 
other enclosure. 
(2) ?There shall be no aperture whatsoever in any wall or partition between viewing areas. 
(3) ?Each viewing area shall be lighted at a minimum level of ten footcandles in all parts thereof. 
(c) ?In addition to the requirements established in subsection (a) of this section, the following regulations 
shall govern and control the operation of an adult entertainment cabaret: 
(1) ?All performers shall be at least 21 years of age. 
(2) ?All performances, exhibitions or displays shall take place on a platform raised at least two feet 
from the level of the floor, and located at least ten feet from any patron. 
(3) ?No performer shall fondle or caress any patron or other performer, and no patron shall fondle 
or caress any performer. 
(4) ?No patron shall be permitted to pay or give any gratuity to any performer, and no performer 
shall solicit any pay or gratuity from any patron. 
(d) ?It shall be unlawful for any person licensed to engage in the business of operating an adult use 
within the village to fail to comply with the conditions and regulations set forth in subsection (a), (b) or 
(c) of this section as they are applicable to the licensed business, or to suffer or permit 
noncompliance with such conditions and regulations on or within the licensed premises. In this 
regard, any act or omission of an employee shall be deemed the act or omission of the owner if such 
act or omission occurred either with the authorization, knowledge or approval of the owner or as a 
result of the owner's negligent failure to supervise the employee's conduct. All conduct occurring 
while on the premises shall be presumed to be the responsibility of the owner. 
(e) ?Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be subject to a fine pursuant to section 1-8 
of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 94-15, § 1(16-315), 2-21-1994) 


Sec. 22-783. - Tattooing and body piercing. 
    No adult use shall include in its services or provide in any way for the sale of tattoos, the sale of 
jewelry which may be utilized in connection with body piercing, or the provision of tattoo or body piercing 
services. 
(Ord. No. 99-20, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Secs. 22-78422-800. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 


Sec. 22-801. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating an adult use in the village 
without first having obtained a license therefor from the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 94-15, § 1(16-311), 2-21-1994) 


Sec. 22-802. - Application; standards for issuance. 
(a) ?Application for an adult use license shall be made in writing and shall state the following: 
(1) ?The name, address, telephone number and age of the applicant and the registered agent of the 
applicant if the applicant is a corporation. 
(2) ?The location of the adult use business. 
(3) ?The exact nature of the adult use to be conducted and of the proposed place of business and 
the facilities related thereto. 
(4) ?A statement by the applicant that he is familiar with the provisions of this article and is in 
compliance with them. 
(5) ?A statement of whether the business will be conducted by a manager and, if so, the name, 
address, telephone number and age of each such manager. 
(6) ?A statement that no manager or principal operating the business has been convicted of any 
offense of prostitution, soliciting for prostitution, or obscenity or public indecency as defined in 
sections 58-10 and 58-11 of this Code within the last two years, and that the applicant has not 
had any license for an adult use in any other community revoked within the last two years. 
(b) ?Within 15 days after receipt of an application for an adult use license, the village shall investigate 
the information contained in the application and shall determine the following: 
(1) ?That the premises designated by the applicant as the location of the business are in full 
compliance with all applicable ordinances of the village, including zoning ordinances. 
(2) ?That the premises and each manager and employee comply with the provisions of section 22-
782 as such provisions apply to them. 
(3) ?That the applicant, each manager and each employee are over 21 years of age. 
(4) ?That no manager or principal operator of the business has been convicted of any offense of 
prostitution, solicitation for prostitution, or obscenity or public indecency, as defined in sections 
58-10 and 58-11 of this Code, within the last two years, and that the applicant has not had any 
license for an adult use revoked within the last two years. 
(c) ?If the investigation shows the compliance of the applicant for an adult use license, the premises 
upon which the business is to be conducted, and each manager and employee, if applicable, with 
each of the requirements established in subsection (b) of this section, and with the conditions and 
regulations set forth in section 22-782, within 15 days after completion of such investigation, the 
village clerk shall issue a license, and upon payment by the applicant of the license fee required 
under this article, the license shall be issued. 
(d) ?If the investigation shows that the applicant for an adult use license, the premises on which the 
business is to be conducted, or the managers and employees, if applicable, do not comply with each 
of the requirements established in subsection (b) of this section, and with the conditions and 
regulations set forth in section 22-782, within 15 days after completion of such investigation, the 
village clerk shall notify the applicant in writing that the license has been denied. Such denial shall be 
the final administrative action of the village with respect to the license application, and shall be 
subject to the immediate appeal by the applicant to the circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 94-15, § 1(16-313), 2-21-1994) 


Sec. 22-803. - Fee; term; renewal; transferability. 
(a) ?The fee for the license required by section 22-801 shall be $500.00 per year, and such license shall 
be valid from January 1 to December 31. 
(b) ?Any license issued under this article shall be renewable under the same terms and conditions 
established in this article for initial issuance of a license. 
(c) ?Any license issued pursuant to this article shall be applicable only to the specific licensee and 
location designated, and may not be sold, transferred, or otherwise assigned. 
(Ord. No. 94-15, § 1(16-314), 2-21-1994) 


Sec. 22-804. - Suspension or revocation. 
    Nothing in the terms of this article shall preclude the right of the mayor to suspend or revoke the 
license of the licensee, as follows: 
(1) ?The mayor may temporarily suspend any license issued under the terms of this article when he 
has reason to believe that the continued operation of a particular licensed premises will 
immediately threaten the welfare of the community or create an imminent danger of violation of 
applicable law. In such case, he may, upon the issuance of a written order stating the reason for 
such determination, and without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises closed for not 
more than seven days; provided, that the licensee shall be given an opportunity to be heard in a 
public hearing during the seven-day period, and further provided that if such licensee shall also 
be engaged in the conduct of other business on the licensed premises, such order shall not be 
applicable to such other businesses. 
(2) ?The mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under the terms of this article upon ten 
days' notice to the licensee of the time and place of a public hearing, and a public hearing at 
which the licensee may appear and present evidence, if the mayor determines upon such 
hearing that the licensee has failed or refused to comply with the terms of this article, has failed 
or refused to comply with other law applicable to the business of operating an adult use, has 
knowingly permitted the failure of any manager or employee on the premises to comply with the 
terms of this article or with other law applicable to the business of operating an adult use, has 
knowingly furnished false or misleading information on any application required for any license 
under this article or has suffered or caused another to furnish or withhold such information on 
his behalf, or has been convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of a violation of any 
provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-15, § 1(16-316), 2-21-1994) 


Sec. 22-805. - Penalty. 
    In addition to license suspension or revocation as provided in this division, any person, firm or 
corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $75.00 and not more 
than $750.00, and a separate offense shall be determined to have been committed each day during 
which or on which the violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 99-20, § 2, 2-1-1999) 
Editor's note Section 2 of Ord. No. 99-20, adopted February 1, 1999, amended ch. 22, art. X, 
by adding thereto provisions designated as § 22-810. Such provisions have been included as § 
22-805 at the discretion of the editor. 


Secs. 22-80622-830. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE XI. - TEMPORARY USES 


Sec. 22-831. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Temporary use means a use proposed to exist only for temporary period of time, and for no more 
than three such periods of time in any calendar year, provided such use is permitted in the village and in 
the zoning district for which such use is proposed. 
(Ord. No. 93-47, § 1(16-306), 9-20-1993; Ord. No. 03-142, § 1, 10-20-2003) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-832. - PermitRequired; application. 
    No person shall conduct any temporary use without first having obtained a permit therefor from the 
village manager. Application for such permit shall be made on a form as provided by the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 93-47, § 1(16-307), 9-20-1993) 


Sec. 22-833. - SameStandards for issuance. 
    The following standards shall govern the issuance of a temporary use permit: 
(1) ?The applicant shall provide sufficient information to show that it has such experience in the 
proposed temporary use or such understanding of the nature thereof that it can conduct such 
temporary use in full compliance with all ordinances of the village, including the zoning 
ordinance, and applicable law, except for such ordinances as would effectively prohibit the 
business or activity itself. 
(2) ?The applicant is of good character and adequate fitness so that he might conduct such 
temporary use in full compliance with all ordinances of the village, including the zoning 
ordinance, and applicable law, except for such ordinances as would effectively prohibit the 
business or activity itself. 
(3) ?The temporary use will not create an unreasonable danger of nuisance to the neighborhood in 
which it is located, nor will it create a danger of substantial breach of the peace, riot or similar 
disorder. 
(4) ?The temporary use will not be conducted for an unlawful purpose. 
(5) ?The temporary use will not interfere with the safe and orderly movement of traffic and persons 
in the public ways of the village. 
(6) ?The temporary use will not create a hazard to the health or safety of the residents of the village, 
nor to the health of domestic or wild plants and animals in the village. 
(7) ?There is adequate parking space available to serve such temporary use. 
(Ord. No. 93-47, § 1(16-308), 9-20-1993) 


Sec. 22-834. - SameIssuance by village manager; notice to council. 
    The village manager shall review the application pursuant to the standards established in section 22-
833, and shall determine whether a temporary use permit should be issued. If he determines that 
issuance of such permit is appropriate, he shall give written notice to the village board at least 48 hours 
prior to a regularly scheduled board meeting, and at such meeting the village board may, in its discretion, 
raise any objections to such issuance and by majority vote direct the village manager to deny a temporary 
use permit to the applicant therefor. In the absence of such vote, the village manager shall issue such 
permit. 
(Ord. No. 93-47, § 1(16-309), 9-20-1993) 


Sec. 22-835. - SameFee; term; renewal. 
    The permit fee for a temporary use permit shall be $25.00 for each application. Such permit shall be 
for a fixed term established at the time of issuance and shall not be renewable under any circumstances. 
No person shall be granted more than three temporary use permits in any calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 93-47, § 1(16-310), 9-20-1993) 


Sec. 22-836. - Block party permits. 
    A block party involving the temporary closure of a public street or other public right-of-way shall be 
considered a temporary use. No person shall hold or conduct a block party without first obtaining a permit 
from the village clerk and paying any applicable block party permit fee. The village clerk may develop 
guidelines governing block parties. The village clerk may refer any block party permit request to the 
village board for approval in the event of questions or concerns related to the permit. 
(Ord. No. 08-88, § 1, 6-2-2008) 


Secs. 22-83722-855. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE XII. - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[25] 
Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
State Law reference Municipal regulation of amusements, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5; carnivals, 65 ILCS 5/11-
54.1-1 et seq. and 225 ILCS 205/0.01 et seq. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 22-856. - Application of division. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other 
amusements in the village whether or not specifically licensed in another division of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 5-1) 


Sec. 22-857. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement regulated by this article without having first 
secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-2) 


Sec. 22-858. - Application for license. 
    All applications for licenses required by this article shall be made to the village clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 5-3) 


Sec. 22-859. - License fees. 
(a) ?The license fees for amusements shall be in accordance with the division of this article which 
governs the particular amusement. 
(b) ?Where no license fee is specifically provided for in this article, the fee shall be as follows: 

Per 
day 
 
(1) ?Menageries ..... $?10.00 
(2) ?Exhibitions of inanimate objects ..... 5.00 
(3) ?Amusement parks, including miniature railroads, and merry-go-rounds ..... 20.00 
(4) ?Other amusements ..... 10.00 
(Code 1972, § 5-4) 


Secs. 22-86022-880. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES[26] 

Footnotes: 
--- (26) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license and regulate pinball machines and other similar 
implements, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2; authority of village to license, tax or regulate coin-operated amusement 
devices, 65 ILCS 5/11-55-1 et seq. 


Sec. 22-881. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall place, install, maintain or operate in any building or place within the village any 
mechanical coin-controlled amusement devices for use by the public and for which a fee is charged, 
without first having obtained a license for each place or location where such automatic coin-controlled 
amusement device shall be installed, maintained or operated. 
(Code 1972, § 5-17) 


Sec. 22-882. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Any person desiring the license required by this division shall make application for such license to 
the village clerk, which application shall set forth the full name of the applicant and his address, the 
location and character of the building or place where such mechanical coin-controlled amusement 
devices are to be located, maintained and operated, the number of such devices to be located, 
maintained and operated in such building or place, the type of machine to be located, maintained and 
operated and the charge to be made to the customer for operating each such device. 
(Code 1972, § 5-18) 


Sec. 22-883. - SameFee. 
    The annual license fee for each electrical or mechanical amusement device shall be $25.00 per year 
per device. When more than five electrical or mechanical amusement devices are located within a certain 
establishment, the annual license fee shall be $100.00 per year per device. 
(Code 1972, § 5-19) 


Sec. 22-884. - Hours of operation. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful to allow any person under 17 years of age to operate any automatic coin-
operated amusement device prior to 3:00 p.m. and after 10:30 p.m. on any school day unless such 
person is accompanied by a parent or guardian or other person having custody of such minor. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful to allow any person under 17 years of age to operate an automatic coin-
operated amusement device after 11:00 p.m. on nonschool days unless such person is accompanied 
by a parent or guardian or other person having custody of such minor. 
(c) ?To ensure compliance with the provisions of this section, it shall be required that an attendant over 
21 years of age shall be present and supervising the activities of all establishments which have one 
or more automatic coin-operated amusement devices on the premises. 
(Code 1972, § 5-20) 


Secs. 22-88522-900. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - AUTOMATIC MUSICAL DEVICES 


Sec. 22-901. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automatic musical device means any phonograph, piano player, music box, jukebox, or other 
instrument or device capable of producing or reproducing any vocal or instrumental sounds, other than a 
motion picture sound machine, which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a coin or token. 
(Code 1972, § 5-32) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-902. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall keep or permit to be kept, for gain or profit from operating within the village, any 
automatic musical instrument without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-33) 


Sec. 22-903. - SameApplication. 
    The application for a license required by this division shall be made to the village clerk, in conformity 
with this chapter, except as otherwise provided in this division. In addition, the applicant shall set forth the 
description of the automatic musical instrument or instruments intended to be kept for use on his 
premises. 
(Code 1972, § 5-34) 


Sec. 22-904. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $35.00 for each automatic musical 
device kept or installed on the licensee's premises. 
(Code 1972, § 5-35) 


Sec. 22-905. - Transferability. 
    No license issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1972, § 5-36) 


Sec. 22-906. - License not to permit loud or obscene use. 
    No license issued pursuant to this division shall permit the operation of any automatic musical 
instrument at any place or in any manner which will disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside the 
licensed premises. No selections which would be obscene, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20, shall be 
played on any such instrument. 
(Code 1972, § 5-37) 
Cross reference Sound amplifying devices, § 38-51 et seq. 


Secs. 22-90722-930. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 4. - SHOOTING GALLERIES 


Sec. 22-931. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Shooting gallery means any place wherein persons shall use firearms for the purpose of sport or 
amusement or any purpose other than military or police training, or wherein a charge, fee or dues are 
made for the privilege of the use of firearms. 
(Code 1972, § 5-48) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-932. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct any shooting gallery in the village without 
first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-49) 


Sec. 22-933. - SameFee. 
    The fee for a license for a shooting gallery shall be $50.00 for an annual license or $10.00 for one 
day or less. 
(Code 1972, § 5-50) 


Sec. 22-934. - Hours of operation. 
    Shooting galleries shall not be open to the public or to members or users thereof except from 9:00 
a.m. to 9:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and from 1:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. on Sunday. 
(Code 1972, § 5-51) 


Sec. 22-935. - Safety requirementsBuildings. 
    Any building used for the purpose of operating a shooting gallery shall be constructed and fashioned 
in such a way that the public will not be exposed to danger or hazard. All targets shall be placed before a 
backstop of steel, sufficiently thick to prevent any bullet from piercing it, and shall be arranged so that 
there shall be no danger from ricocheting bullets or deflected pieces of bullets or other metal. 
(Code 1972, § 5-52) 


Sec. 22-936. - SameUse of firearms. 
    Persons using any shooting gallery in the village shall follow the following safety requirements: 
(1) ?No firearms will be loaded until ready to fire. 
(2) ?All firearms will be encased in a container when outside of the firing range. 
(3) ?All firearms will be inspected before being allowed on the firing line. 
(4) ?Any person 17 years of age or under who desires to use the firing line must first show evidence 
of having received basic firearms instruction at a regular class. 
(Code 1972, § 5-53) 


Sec. 22-937. - Sanitary requirements. 
    Premises used for shooting galleries shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1972, § 5-54) 


Sec. 22-938. - Persons under 18 years of age prohibited from using; exceptions. 
    No person shall inhabit or utilize the facilities of any shooting gallery who is under the age of 18 
years unless such person is with a parent or guardian, or, if a member of a duly constituted group or club, 
with the regular leader of such organization. 
(Code 1972, § 5-55) 


Sec. 22-939. - Persons under 17 years of age prohibited from removing ammunition. 
    Ammunition used by persons 17 years of age or under shall be used on the firing line only and shall 
not be removed from the building. 
(Code 1972, § 5-56) 


Sec. 22-940. - Persons using alcohol, drugs or suffering from illness prohibited on firing line. 
    No person who has imbibed alcoholic beverages or who is in the possession of such beverages or 
who is under the influence of any drug, narcotic or illness shall be allowed upon the firing line of any 
shooting gallery. 
(Code 1972, § 5-57) 


Sec. 22-941. - Violations; revocation of privilege to use gallery. 
    Any customer, member or person using the facilities of a shooting gallery who violates any of the 
provisions of this division shall not be allowed to use the facilities thereafter except by special permission 
of the management, who shall cooperate with the police department in determining whether or not the 
facilities shall be reoffered to such violator. 
(Code 1972, § 5-58) 


Secs. 22-94222-960. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 5. - BILLIARD AND POOL HALLS[27] 

Footnotes: 
--- (27) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license and regulate billiard, pool and other similar tables, 
65 ILCS 5/11-42-2; minors under the age of 16 years of age prohibited from working in pool rooms and 
billiard rooms, 820 ILCS 205/7. 


Sec. 22-961. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard or pool table open to the public without having 
first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-69) 


Sec. 22-962. - SameApplication; contents. 
    The application for a license required by the division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and 
shall state the intended location of the place of business and the number of billiard and pool tables to be 
used therein. 
(Code 1972, § 5-70) 


Sec. 22-963. - SameFee. 
    The annual license fee for billiard and pool halls shall be $40.00 for the first four tables and $5.00 for 
each additional table. 
(Code 1972, § 5-71) 


Sec. 22-964. - Presence of certain minors restricted. 
    Minors under the age of 17 years shall under no circumstances frequent, loiter, go or remain in any 
hall licensed under this division, unless it is upon some lawful errand under the direction and with the 
consent and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having the lawful custody of the minor. It 
shall be unlawful for the proprietor of any hall licensed under this division to permit any such minor to 
frequent, loiter or remain within the hall in violation of this section. 
(Code 1972, § 5-72) 


Secs. 22-96522-985. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 6. - BOWLING ALLEYS[28] 

Footnotes: 
--- (28) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license and regulate bowling alleys, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2; 
"bowling alley" defined for liquor control purposes, 235 ILCS 5/1-3.26; minors under the age of 16 years 
prohibited from working in bowling alleys, 820 ILCS 205/7. 


Sec. 22-986. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall operate or maintain a bowling alley open to the public without having first obtained a 
license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-83) 


Sec. 22-987. - SameApplication. 
    The application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and 
shall state the intended location of the place of business and the number of bowling lanes to be used 
therein. 
(Code 1972, § 5-84) 


Sec. 22-988. - SameFee. 
    The annual license fee for bowling alleys shall be $100.00. 
(Code 1972, § 5-85; Ord. No. 02-146, § 16, 12-16-2002) 


Secs. 22-98922-1010. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 7. - SKATING RINKS[29] 

Footnotes: 
--- (29) --- 
State Law reference Civil rights in places of public accommodation, 775 ILCS 5/5-101 et seq.; minors 
under age of 16 years prohibited from working in skating rinks, 820 ILCS 205/7. 


Sec. 22-1011. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain a public skating rink in the village without first having 
obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-96) 


Sec. 22-1012. - SameApplication; contents. 
    The application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and 
shall specify the location of the proposed skating rink and the person or organization sponsoring such 
skating rink. 
(Code 1972, § 5-97) 


Sec. 22-1013. - License not to issue unless applicant is of good moral character. 
    No license required by this division shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character 
nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the village by a person of good moral 
character. 
(Code 1972, § 5-98) 


Sec. 22-1014. - Investigation of applicant. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make an investigation into the character of each applicant 
for a license required by this division and report the results of such investigation to the president and 
board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 5-99) 


Sec. 22-1015. - License fees. 
    The fees for a license for skating rinks shall be $150.00 for an annual license or $15.00 for a monthly 
license. 
(Code 1972, § 5-100) 


Sec. 22-1016. - Requirements for exits. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct a public skating rink in any hall or building not equipped with at least 
two sufficient and adequate exits being at least four feet or more in width. 
(Code 1972, § 5-101) 


Sec. 22-1017. - Music after certain hour prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit music at any public skating rink after 10:00 p.m. on weekdays and after 
10:30 p.m. on Saturdays and Sundays. 
(Code 1972, § 5-102) 


Secs. 22-101822-1035. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 8. - PUBLIC GATHERINGS 


Subdivision I. - In General 


Sec. 22-1036. - Compliance with Code. 
    It shall be unlawful to hold, manage or conduct any meeting or entertainment of any kind in the 
village, in any premises other than a building constructed in full compliance with the provisions of this 
Code, other ordinances of the village and state law relating to auditoriums, theaters and lodge rooms, 
except in compliance with the other provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 5-113) 
Cross reference Fire prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Sec. 22-1037. - Board of trustees to authorize issuance of license when public place is used. 
    No license shall be granted for any carnival, exhibition, show or other amusement to be given on any 
public street or sidewalk or in any place where the main accommodation for the audience will be in a 
public place except on order of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 5-114) 


Sec. 22-1038. - Permits and licenses issued subject to requirements of division. 
    Any permit or license issued for any public gathering shall be subject to the condition that this 
division be fully complied with, whether or not such condition is embodied in the permit. 
(Code 1972, § 5-115) 


Sec. 22-1039. - Inspection required for certain buildings. 
    No public gathering or entertainment shall be held or presented in any premises other than a building 
as described in section 22-1036, unless such premises have been examined by the fire chief or economic 
development director not more than three days before the date of such gathering and found to be free 
from any fire hazard and found to be suitable for the purpose for which it is to be used. 
(Code 1972, § 5-116; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 22-1040. - Notice to village clerk prior to inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of any person conducting, calling for or managing any gathering in any premises 
other than a theater, lodge room or auditorium building constructed as provided in section 22-1036 to 
notify the village clerk of the date of such intended performance at least ten days before the meeting is to 
take place; upon such notice, the fire chief or economic development director shall inspect the premises 
to determine whether or not such premises comply with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 5-117; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 22-1041. - Duty of village officials to inspect. 
    It shall be the duty of the economic development director, the chief of police and the fire chief to see 
that every exhibition, amusement, show, theatrical or other public performance is inspected by a member 
of the police and fire departments, and to ensure conformity with the provisions of this article concerning 
such amusements. 
(Code 1972, § 5-118; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 22-1042. - Order and crowd control generally. 
(a) ?The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical performance must be orderly and quiet at all 
times and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such amusement, show or theatrical 
performance to create a disturbance in the audience. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful to permit such a crowd to witness any amusement, show or theatrical 
performance as to create a dangerous condition because of fire and other risks. 
(Code 1972, § 5-119) 


Sec. 22-1043. - Persons admitted not to exceed number of available seats. 
    It shall be unlawful to admit to any premises regulated by this division a number of persons to 
exceed the actual number of seats maintained for their accommodation. 
(Code 1972, § 5-120) 


Sec. 22-1044. - Strength of seats. 
    Any stands or rows of seats used in any premises regulated by this division shall be so constructed 
as to be safe for the use designed, and shall be sufficiently strong to carry the same weight and stress as 
is required for the construction of the auditorium floors of theater buildings, and shall in no event be less 
than one pound per square foot. 
(Code 1972, § 5-121) 


Sec. 22-1045. - Fire prevention code applicable. 
    The fire prevention code adopted by section 42-186 shall apply to the construction and use of all 
buildings used pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1972, § 5-122) 
Cross reference Fire prevention code, § 42-186 et seq. 


Sec. 22-1046. - Smoking; signs to be posted. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe on or beneath any stage or in 
a dressing room of any building used as an assembly hall with seating accommodations for more 
than 100 persons or in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other entertainments are 
offered, operated, presented or exhibited. 
(b) ?It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any premises where smoking is prohibited to provide 
and place printed signs in conspicuous places on which the words "no smoking" shall appear in 
letters at least four inches high. At least two such signs are to be placed upon the stage or in the 
wings of the premises and one in each dressing room. 
(Code 1972, § 5-123) 
State Law reference Illinois Clean Indoor Air Act, 410 ILCS 80/1 et seq. 


Sec. 22-1047. - Exhibition of criminals. 
    It shall be unlawful to exhibit any criminal or the body of any criminal or any person who shall have 
become notorious because of the commission of a crime, in any theatrical, exhibit, carnival or other public 
place. 
(Code 1972, § 5-124) 


Sec. 22-1048. - Amusements and shows which promote riots. 
    It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of any kind which tends to or is 
calculated to cause or promote any riot or disturbance. 
(Code 1972, § 5-125) 


Secs. 22-104922-1070. - Reserved. 


Subdivision II. - Motion Pictures and Theatricals[30] 

Footnotes: 
--- (30) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to license, tax, regulate or prohibit theatricals and other 
shows, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 


Sec. 22-1071. - LicenseRequired; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture or theatrical for which a fee is 
charged for admission without first obtaining a license therefor. No license shall be required if the 
performance is given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious, educational or 
charitable organization. 
(Code 1972, § 5-131) 


Sec. 22-1072. - SameApplication; contents. 
    The application for a license required by this subdivision shall be made in writing to the village clerk 
and shall state in addition to the other information required the place of the intended performances and 
the seating capacity thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 5-132) 


Sec. 22-1073. - SameFee. 
    The fee for a license for motion pictures and theatricals shall be $150.00 per year or $5.00 per day. 
(Code 1972, § 5-133) 


Sec. 22-1074. - Unlimited performances permitted under annual license. 
    Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures or theatricals naming a specific place or 
building where the performances are to be presented may present therein any number of performances 
during the year for which the license was secured without having to pay any additional fee. 
(Code 1972, § 5-134) 


Sec. 22-1075. - Scenery to be nonflammable. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any scenery in any theater other than nonflammable 
scenery or such as shall have been rendered nonflammable by the application of fire preventive coatings. 
(Code 1972, § 5-135) 


Sec. 22-1076. - Exhibition of obscene motion pictures. 
(a) ?Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for a licensee under this subdivision to exhibit any obscene motion 
pictures within the village. 
(b) ?Obscene defined. Any material or performance is obscene if: 
(1) ?The average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find that, taken 
as a whole, it appeals to the prurient interest; 
(2) ?The average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find that it 
depicts or describes, in a patently offensive way, ultimate sexual acts or sadomasochistic 
sexual acts, whether normal or perverted, actual or simulated, or masturbation, excretory 
functions or lewd exhibition of the genitals; and 
(3) ?Taken as a whole, it lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(c) ?Interpretation of evidence. 
(1) ?Obscenity shall be judged with reference to ordinary adults, except that it shall be judged with 
reference to children or other specially susceptible audiences if it appears from the character of 
the material or the circumstances of its dissemination to be specially designed for or directed to 
such an audience. 
(2) ?Where circumstances of production, presentation, sale, dissemination, distribution, or publicity 
indicate that material is being commercially exploited for the sake of its prurient appeal, such 
evidence is probative with respect to the nature of the matter and can justify the conclusion that 
the matter is lacking in serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(3) ?In any prosecution for an offense under this section evidence shall be admissible to show: 
a. ?The character of the audience for which the material was designed or to which it was 
directed; 
b. ?What the predominant appeal of the material would be for ordinary adults or a special 
audience, and what effect, if any, it would probably have on the behavior of such people; 
c. ?The artistic, literary, scientific, educational or other merits of the material, or absence 
thereof; 
d. ?The degree, if any, of public acceptance of the material in this state; 
e. ?Appeal to prurient interest, or absence thereof, in advertising or other promotion of the 
material; 
f. ?Purpose of the author, creator, publisher or disseminator. 
(d) ?Examples of obscene acts and exhibitions. Examples of the types of matters deemed obscene for 
the purposes of this subdivision shall include the following specifically proscribed acts: 
(1) ?Patently offensive descriptions, representations, or exhibitions of ultimate sexual acts, 
including, but not limited to, such acts as sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio or other similar 
acts, whether depicted in a normal or perverted fashion, real or simulated. 
(2) ?Patently offensive descriptions, representations, or exhibitions of acts such as masturbation, 
excretory functions, or any other lewd exhibition involving the genitals, whether depicted in a 
normal or perverted fashion, real or simulated. 
(3) ?Any other patently offensive description, representation or exhibition which appeals to the 
prurient interest; that is, a shameful or morbid interest in nudity, sexual matters or excretory 
functions, or simulations thereof, and further, where the description, representation or exhibition 
goes beyond the customary limits of candor commonly associated with such matters. 
(Code 1972, § 5-136(1), (2)) 
Cross reference Previews of certain types of motion pictures with respect to juvenile 
audiences, § 58-12. 
State Law reference Obscenity, 720 ILCS 5/11-20. 


Secs. 22-107722-1095. - Reserved. 


Subdivision III. - Circuses and Carnivals[31] 

Footnotes: 
--- (31) --- 
State Law reference Carnival Regulation Act, 225 ILCS 205/0.01 et seq.; Aerial Exhibitors Safety Act, 
720 ILCS 530/0.01 et seq. 


Sec. 22-1096. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carnival means and includes an aggregation of attractions, whether shows, acts, games, vending 
devices or amusement devices, and whether conducted under one or more managements or 
independently, which are temporarily set up or conducted in a public place or upon any private premises 
accessible to the public, with or without charging an admission fee, and which, from the nature of the 
aggregation, attracts attendance and causes promiscuous intermingling of persons in the spirit of 
merrymaking and revelry. 
(Code 1972, § 5-141) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 22-1097. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall conduct or operate a circus or carnival in the village without first having obtained a 
license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-142) 


Sec. 22-1098. - SameApplication; contents. 
    The application for a license required by this subdivision shall be made in writing to the village clerk 
and shall specify the place in or upon which the circus or carnival is to be conducted. 
(Code 1972, § 5-143) 


Sec. 22-1099. - SameFees. 
    The fee for a license to operate a circus or carnival shall be $50.00 per day. 
(Code 1972, § 5-144; Ord. No. 02-146, § 17, 12-16-2002) 


Sec. 22-1100. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire chief to see that inspections provided for in 
section 22-1039 shall be made of all circuses and carnivals and of the premises used for circuses and 
carnivals. 
(Code 1972, § 5-145) 


Sec. 22-1101. - Cheating and fraud. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cheat, shortchange or otherwise defraud any person attending 
or about to attend a circus performance or carnival within the village. 
(Code 1972, § 5-146) 


Sec. 22-1102. - Parades in connection with circus; permit required; bond. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct any parade connected with a circus or carnival on any public street, 
alley or other public way or place in the village unless a permit therefor is first obtained from the board of 
trustees. The permit shall specify the route to be followed, and shall be accompanied by a bond in the 
sum of $10,000.00, conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss, damage or liability incurred or 
caused by the conduct of such exhibition or such parade. 
(Code 1972, § 5-147) 
Cross reference Parades and open air meetings, § 70-181 et seq. 


Sec. 22-1103. - Closing hours; security; power to close down. 
(a) ?A circus or carnival shall close not later than 11:00 p.m. on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday 
and Thursday and not later than 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
(b) ?No person shall conduct or operate a circus or carnival without making arrangements to employ one 
or more off-duty police officers for the purpose of maintaining order and assisting in traffic control. 
(c) ?The chief of police is empowered to temporarily or permanently close down a circus or carnival if, in 
his discretion, just cause exists for doing so. Just cause for purposes of this section is an occurrence 
or event that tends to endanger the health, safety, morals or welfare of those attending or in 
proximity to a circus or carnival. 
(Code 1972, § 5-148) 


Sec. 22-1104. - Insurance. 
    Any circus or carnival for which a license is to be issued shall provide the village with a policy of 
insurance for bodily injury and property damage in a form and by an approved insurance company 
satisfactory to the village president. The amount of such insurance shall be not less than $1,000,000.00 
per occurrence of bodily injury and not less than $500,000.00 per occurrence for property damage and 
shall cover all events set forth in the license issued pursuant to section 22-1097. Each policy of insurance 
shall include the village as an additional assured and the applicant shall submit a certificate of such 
policy, together with the application for license, no later than 15 days prior to the event or events for which 
such license is to be issued. 
(Code 1972, § 5-149) 


Secs. 22-110522-1125. - Reserved. 


Subdivision IV. - Public Dances 


Sec. 22-1126. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the village without first having obtained a 
license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 5-153) 


Sec. 22-1127. - SameApplication; contents. 
    The application for a license required by this subdivision shall be made in writing to the village clerk 
and shall specify the location of the proposed dances and the person or organization sponsoring such 
dances. 
(Code 1972, § 5-154) 


Sec. 22-1128. - License not to issue unless applicant is of good moral character.
