(c) ?No earthmoving operations shall take place until engineering plans have been approved by the 
public works director and erosion control, including functional sediment and erosion control devices, 
are in place. 
(Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 34-81. - Control measures required for stockpiles. 
    If a stockpile is to remain in place for more than three days, sediment and erosion control shall be 
provided for such stockpile. 


Sec. 34-82. - Required protection for storm sewer inlets. 
    All storm sewer inlets shall be protected with sediment trapping or filter control devices during 
construction. 


Sec. 34-83. - Required protection for stripped areas. 
    Temporary sediment and erosion control measures shall be maintained continuously in stripped 
areas until permanent cover is established. The surface of stripped areas shall be permanently protected 
from soil erosion within 15 days after final grade is reached. 


Sec. 34-84. - Requirements for water pumping. 
    Water which is pumped or otherwise discharged from the site during construction shall be filtered in 
a manner approved by the public works director so that no sediment is discharged from the site. 
(Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 34-85. - Required cleanup of soil deposits. 
    Gravel areas shall be provided to prevent deposits of soil from being carried onto public or private 
roadways. Any such soil deposits shall be removed periodically or as required by the village, and at least 
at the end of each workday. 


Sec. 34-86. - Maintenance of temporary measures. 
    All control measures necessary to meet the requirements of this article shall be maintained and 
operational continuously throughout the period of time during which there are land disturbances on the 
site, and until permanent sediment and erosion control measures are operational. 


Sec. 34-87. - Enforcement; stop orders. 
(a) ?The enforcement officer for this article shall be the public works director. If the requirements of this 
article are not being met, the public works director shall issue a stop order, and the developer and 
owner shall not be permitted to continue with construction until compliance with this article is 
achieved. 
(b) ?The developer or owner shall have a right to appeal a stop order issued by the public works director 
to the president and board of trustees within five days of the issuance of such order, by filing written 
notice of such appeal to the village manager on forms provided by the village. Upon receiving a 
notice of appeal, the village manager shall meet with the developer or owner prior to the meeting of 
the board for the purpose of preparing an agreed statement of facts and issues to be submitted to 
the board prior to the hearing on appeal. The hearing shall be conducted by the president and board 
of trustees in accordance with the board's rules and procedures and with the requirements for 
providing the developer or owner with reasonable due process. 
(Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 34-88. - Financial obligation of developer. 
    An irrevocable letter of credit, issued by a responsible financial institution and covering the approved 
construction project, shall be submitted to the village by the developer. To ensure that the developer is in 
compliance with this article, the letter of credit required by the land development code (appendix B) 
should include the improvements required by this article and should not be released until these 
requirements have been satisfactorily fulfilled. 
(Code 1972, § 24-9) 


Sec. 34-89. - Violations; penalties and other remedies. 
(a) ?Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the 
enforcement of any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less 
than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each and every offense. A separate offense shall be deemed 
committed on each day a violation occurs or continues. 
(b) ?In addition to the penalties established in subsection (a) of this section, the village attorney, at the 
request of the village manager, may institute, in the name of the village, any proper action or 
proceeding to enjoin, restrain, correct, or abate any violation of this article. 


Secs. 34-9034-109. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - ENGINEERING FEES AND BONDS 


Sec. 34-110. - Definitions. 
    Approved engineer's estimate (AEE): The total estimated construction costs for a project, including 
public and private site improvements as part of a subdivision, or off-site public or private improvements as 
part of a project, but not necessarily part of a subdivision, such as parking lots, storm sewers, 
retention/detention ponds, water mains, pavements, curbs and gutters, etc. 
(Ord. No. 18-174, § 3, 12-6-2018) 


Sec. 34-111. - Review and inspection fees. 
    The village shall charge for reviewing plans, checking computations, determining estimates, 
researching specifications, inspecting improvements, and like activities, a fee approximating the time 
necessary to accomplish the task. If professional services are used, even if they exceed the permit fees 
presented, the village shall be entitled to reimbursement for the costs for such services from the 
permittee. Before the village will initiate any review of a permit application or related documentation, the 
applicant shall submit a non-refundable filing fee as outlined below. This filing fee will be credited towards 
the total fee of a permit at the time of its issuance. Minimum fees shall be as follows: 
(1) ?Individual lot. 
a. ?New single-family residence (includes up to four review submissions; if additional reviews 
are needed, the village's cost for the additional review(s) will be added): 
Filing fee: $1,200.00. 
Estimated total fee: $2,200.00, which includes the filing fee. 
b. ?New multiple-family residence, commercial or industrial building residence (includes up to 
four review submissions; if additional reviews are needed, the village's cost for the 
additional review(s) will be added): 
Filing fee: $2,000.00. 
Estimated total fee: $3,200.00, (which includes the filing fee) + $2,500.00 per acre. 
(2) ?Subdivisions . 
Filing fee: $2,500.00. 
Estimated total fee: $3,200.00, (which includes the filing fee) + 4% of AEE. 
(3) ?Separate construction projects (off-site improvements not part of new subdivision 
improvements, or certain on-site improvements), such as parking lots, storm sewers, water 
mains, pavements, curbs and gutters, etc. 
Filing fee: $500.00. 
Estimated total fee: $600.00 (which includes the filing fee). 
(4) ?Special management areas (flood plains, wetlands, riparian environments)Reviewed by 
DuPage County. 
Filing fee: As designated by DuPage County. 
(5) ?Excavation and grading (when done as a separate project). 
Flat fee: $80.00. 
(6) ?Right-of-way excavation. 
Flat fee: $80.00. 
(7) ?Re-inspections (where initial inspection of work identifies deficiencies). 
Flat fee: $50.00. 
(8) ?Other projects (where site development review and/or inspection is required). 
Fee: $100.00 per hour. 
(Code 1972, § 7-72; Ord. No. 93-28, § 7-72(b), 5-17-1993; Ord. No. 05-254, § 4, 11-7-2005; 
Ord. No. 18-174, § 3, 12-6-2018) 


Sec. 34-112. - Bonds. 
(a) ?Bonds to ensure completion of work in accordance with approved site plans, landscaping plans, 
village specifications and details, and engineering plans and specifications shall be made in 
accordance with the following: 
(1) ?Individual lot. 
a. ?New single-family or duplex residence. 
Cash bond: $1,500.00. 
b. ?New multiple-family residence, commercial or industrial building. 
Cash bond: Five percent of the AEE, up to a maximum of $10,000.00 and not less than 
$3,000.00. 
(2) ?Subdivisions. Letter-of-credit, using standard village wording, and for a minimum two-year 
term, in an amount equal to least 110 percent of the AEE for the public improvements in the 
subdivision. 
(3) ?Separate construction projects (off-site improvements not part of new subdivision 
improvements, or certain on-site improvements), such as parking lots, storm sewers, water 
mains, pavements, curbs and gutters, etc.; 
a. ?Private improvements. 
Cash bond: Five percent of the AEE, up to a maximum of $10,000.00, but where a site 
plan has been approved by the village board not less than $1,000.00. 
b. ?Public improvements. 
Bond: Cash or letter-of-credit in an amount equal to 110 percent of the AEE, minimum 
$1,000.00. 
(4) ?Right-of-way excavation. 
Cash bond: 110 percent of the approved restoration costs, minimum $300.00. 
(b) ?The bond amounts required by this section shall be increased by an appropriate amount if, in the 
opinion of the public works director or village engineer, the amount required therein would not be 
sufficient to construct required improvements, or repair damages to sidewalks, pavements, trees, or 
any other village property that might result due to the construction of the proposed improvement. 
(c) ?Forfeiture . Any deposits made as required by this section which are not redeemed within two years 
after completion of the work, shall be forfeited to the village. Upon a determination that there is no 
outstanding work to be completed, or that any outstanding work to be completed is minor in nature 
and, if not completed, will not adversely impact the property, surrounding properties or the public 
health and safety, then the forfeited deposit shall be transferred to the village's stormwater 
management fund to be used to fund general stormwater improvements. Upon a determination that 
outstanding work does adversely affect the property, surrounding properties or the public health and 
safety, then the village may utilize the deposit to have the outstanding work completed. 
(Ord. No. 05-254, § 4, 11-7-2005; Ord. No. 18-174, § 3, 12-6-2018)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 38-1. - Brush collection program. 
(a) ?The village's brush collection program is available to all single-family detached and attached 
residential properties. 
(b) ?The brush collection program is offered as part of the village's solid waste collection program as 
provided by an independent contractor (the "solid waste collection contract"). The guidelines and 
provisions of the brush collection program are contained in the solid waste collection contract, which 
are incorporated into this section by this reference, and said guidelines and provisions are accessible 
on the village's website. 
(c) ?The following additional criteria shall be observed by eligible residents to qualify for the brush pick-
up program services: 
(1) ?All qualifying brush shall be generated from the property where the brush is placed for 
collection. Importing of brush from anywhere other than the property on which the brush is 
placed for collection is not permitted and constitutes a violation of this section. Brush for 
collection must also be placed by the resident and not be generated by a professional tree or 
landscape service. 
(2) ?All brush shall be placed in the parkway in front of the residence in conjunction with the regular 
or rescheduled residential solid waste collection day as specified by the guidelines and 
provisions of the solid waste collection contract. 
(3) ?Brush shall be bundled with twine or string and limited in size as specified by the guidelines 
and provisions of the solid waste collection contract. 
(4) ?Brush bundles shall be limited in weight as specified in the guidelines and provisions of the 
solid waste collection contract. 
(5) ?No stumps, building materials, fence posts, wire, rocks, plastic tubing or products, weeds, 
garden vegetation or other foreign material shall be placed in the brush pile. Treated lumber is 
not considered brush and will not be picked up. 
(6) ?All small brush debris and leaves shall be properly bagged and separated from the brush 
bundles and disposed of by the property owner as specified by the guidelines and provisions of 
the solid waste collection contract. 
(7) ?Brush pick-up requirements must be followed or items will not be picked up, will be considered 
a nuisance, and shall subject the property owner or occupant to enforcement action for a 
violation of this section. 
(8) ?Brush placed on the parkway at times other than during the scheduled pick-up time will also be 
considered a nuisance, and shall subject the property owner or occupant to enforcement action 
for a violation of this section. 
(Res. No. R05-51, § 1(Exh. A), 3-7-2005; Ord. No. 18-152, § 2, 9-27-2018) 
Editor's note Res. No. R05-51, § 1(Exh. A), adopted 3-7-2005, added provisions that were 
not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions have been included herein 
as § 38-1. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 18-152, § 2, adopted Sept. 27, 2018, amended § 38-1 and in so doing 
changed the title of said section from "Brush pick up program" to "Brush collection program," as 
set out herein. 


Secs. 38-238-30. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - NOISE 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - SOUND AMPLIFYING DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference Loud automatic musical instruments, § 22-906. 


Sec. 38-51. - Certain activities exempted from division. 
    This division shall not apply to radios in homes or in private pleasure vehicles, when such radios are 
operated in such manner as not to be audible at a distance of 50 feet from such vehicle, nor to noise 
devices, bands, or other musical devices used in any public parade or procession which is operated 
under a license or permit issued by the village. 
(Code 1972, § 3-44) 


Sec. 38-52. - LicenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any loudspeaker or amplifier connected with any radio, 
phonograph, microphone, or other device by which sounds are magnified and made heard over any 
public street or public place without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 3-45) 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22. 


Sec. 38-53. - SameApplication; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made to the village clerk, upon a form 
provided by him, setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the name of the owner of the 
device, the date upon which it is intended to be used, and such other information as may be required by 
the village clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 3-46) 


Sec. 38-54. - SameConditions. 
    A license issued pursuant to this division shall permit the use of the device subject to the terms and 
conditions of this division, and only upon the date specified on the application for the license. 
(Code 1972, § 3-47) 


Sec. 38-55. - Hours of use. 
    No licensee shall use or employ any device licensed by this division within the village on Sunday, or 
between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. of any other day. 
(Code 1972, § 3-48) 


Sec. 38-56. - Restrictions on place of use. 
    No person shall use or employ any device regulated by this division within a radius of two blocks of 
any hospital or any church while services are being held in the church. 
(Code 1972, § 3-49) 


Sec. 38-57. - Indecent language; false advertising. 
    No person shall cause to be emitted from any such device regulated by this division any language or 
sounds which are obscene as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20, or make any false representation of any 
matter, product, or project or advertise the sale of any product which is prohibited by this Code or by 
statute. 
(Code 1972, § 3-50) 


Secs. 38-5838-80. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - NUISANCES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference Offensive and nuisance businesses prohibited, § 22-1; maintenance of bypass 
channels and stormwater storage areas, § 34-61 et seq.; premises in violation of drug paraphernalia 
regulations declared nuisance, § 58-214; certain weeds declared nuisances, § 86-1. 
State Law reference Authority of village to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2; 
Lewdness Public Nuisance Act, 740 ILCS 105/0.01 et seq. 


Sec. 38-81. - Prohibited; abatement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or maintain the existence of any nuisance on any 
property under his control. The chief of police and the health officer of the village are each authorized to 
abate any nuisance existing in the village, whether such nuisance is specifically recognized by this Code 
or not. 
(Code 1972, § 17-26) 
Cross reference Dog or cat going on premises of another as nuisance, § 14-3. 


Sec. 38-82. - What constitutes. 
    It is hereby declared to be a nuisance: 
(1) ?To place, cause or permit any tangible thing to be placed upon or permitted to remain upon any 
parkway within the village, except for the purpose of being picked up by a regularly scheduled 
scavenger service; to allow or permit the placement of items for pickup by scavenger service 
upon any parkway sooner than six hours before the regularly scheduled day for pickup; to allow 
or permit containers or tangible items to remain upon any parkway longer than six hours 
following the regularly scheduled day for pickup. 
(2) ?To use or occupy any part of a street, parkway, alley or sidewalk of the village for the purpose 
of carrying on, soliciting or promoting any trade, business or other enterprise which impedes, 
interferes with, or makes dangerous, travel thereon; also to cause or permit the storage of any 
product, supplies for or equipment incidental to the operations of such business or enterprises, 
upon any street, parkway, alley or sidewalk within the village. 
(3) ?To create or permit to be created or remain upon any premises within the village for a period of 
more than 30 days the storing, piling, scattering, accumulating, heaping, amassing or collecting 
of bricks, concrete blocks, straw, lumber, structural iron, pipe, roofing materials or any building 
materials where the same is in public view and where the same may or does constitute a safety 
hazard to children playing in the area or that the same may or does become an attraction to or 
haven for vermin or rodents. 
Building material stored outdoors on any site for construction authorized by a building permit 
shall be used or incorporated into the proposed building within 30 days of arrival upon the site. 
(4) ?To allow, cause or permit garbage, rubbish, or waste materials to be set out in containers 
which are not covered or which permit or allow the contents of such containers to be accessible 
to rodents or animals or that permit the contents thereof to be scattered or blown about. 
(5) ?For any person to dump, deposit, store or place any garbage, rubbish, trash or refuse upon 
property within the village, except in covered containers. 
(6) ?To keep, cause or permit to be kept livestock upon any residentially zoned premises within the 
village or any structure or place for the retaining, care or shelter of any animals or fowl in an 
unclean, insanitary or filthy condition so as to produce and give offensive or disgusting, harmful, 
injurious or noxious odors. To cause or permit body wastes from animals or fowl to lay in the 
open upon any premises when the same may or does give off objectionable odors. 
(7) ?To store, cause to be stored or permit to remain in public view on any premises within the 
village junk cars, or vehicles not in active use, or other machinery or parts thereof; to dismantle, 
repair, paint or assemble any motor vehicle or major part thereof on any premises, unless it is 
done within a structure or building which shields such activity from the public view. 
To deposit upon any public or private roadway, alley, driveway, parking area or other place 
within the village limits, any inoperable motor vehicle or part thereof, without first obtaining 
permission of the owner, occupant or agent of private property or the police department of the 
village for public property. 
(8) ?To cause or permit the carcass of any dead animal or vegetable matter, slops, swill, suds, 
garbage, filth, stable droppings or other offal or noisome substance of any kind to be collected, 
deposited, or remain in any place, except in approved covered containers and then only long 
enough to be properly disposed of. 
(9) ?To keep or permit to be kept upon any premises within the village any dog or other animal or 
fowl emitting loud, frequent and continuous offensive noises. 
(10) ?To cause or permit any premises within the village to become or remain littered with tin cans, 
glass jars, bottles, scrap glass, paper cartons, scraps of paper, boxes, ashes, iron, old hot water 
tanks, oil storage tanks, tin or other metal materials, refuse, rubbish, junk, waste, manure, 
straw, piles of grass clippings, lumber, old bricks, concrete blocks, chunks of broken concrete, 
plasterboard, discarded furniture, household appliances, mattresses, bedsprings, portable 
swimming pools in disrepair, or other like matter or things. 
(11) ?To corrupt or permit to be corrupted any water stream or body of water thereof. 
(12) ?To obstruct any water source, ravine, or gutter so as to cause water to stagnate therein, or to 
permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any premises. 
(13) ?To place or spread poisons upon any real estate for the purpose of killing vermin except in 
accordance with the provisions of a written permit to be issued by an official designated by the 
village president and board of trustees. 
(14) ?To allow or permit the grazing or riding of animals, bicycles and motorcycles upon the village 
parkways, or on private property without the permission of the owner thereof, nor in such a 
manner as to interfere with anyone walking upon the public sidewalks, or so as to cause 
damage to ornamental plantings. To cause, allow or permit anywhere within the village limits 
any dogs or other animals to excrete bodily wastes upon the premises of others. 
(15) ?To cause or permit the parking or storage of any commercial vehicle over one ton in capacity 
or construction equipment on residential premises except when making a delivery or rendering 
a service at such premises. 
(16) ?To utilize or occupy, or allow or permit to be utilized or occupied, any portion of any premises 
within the village for the purposes of operating an automated teller machine or bank automated 
teller machine in violation of any federal, state or local law which, by a preponderance of the 
evidence, may place at risk any member of the public, village officials or staff, or the automated 
teller machine or bank automated teller machine itself. 
(Code 1972, § 17-27; Ord. No. 99-16, § 2, 2-1-1999) 
Cross reference Parking, stopping and standing, § 78-301 et seq. 


Sec. 38-83. - Unlawful to create, maintain or fail to abate. 
    It is unlawful for any person to create, maintain, or permit to be created or maintained, or fail or 
refuse to abate promptly and without delay, any nuisance as defined in section 38-82. Every person who 
creates or maintains or permits to be created or maintained any such nuisance, and every owner, 
occupant, agent or trustee of any premises whereupon such nuisance exists, who fails or refuses to abate 
such nuisance as provided in this article shall be deemed guilty of violating sections 38-82 and 38-83. 
Each day that such nuisance exists unabated shall constitute and be a separate and distinct violation 
thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 17-28) 


Sec. 38-84. - Stagnant pools. 
    Any stagnant pool of water in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful 
for any person to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his control. 
(Code 1972, § 17-15) 


Chapter 42 - FIRE PREVENTION, FIRE PROTECTION AND EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes:

et seq.; fire prevention in dry cleaning establishments, § 22-380; fire protection for motels near parking 
spaces, § 22-425; gasoline service stations, § 22-701 et seq.; environment, ch. 38; health and sanitation, 
ch. 46; housing, ch. 50; personnel, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 66; foreign fire insurance companies, § 74-276 
et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; directing traffic at fires, § 78-6; utilities, ch. 82; schedule of fees, taxes

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 42-1. - Definition of authorized emergency vehicle. 
    The term "authorized emergency vehicle" as used in this chapter shall be restricted to those vehicles 
which are defined and authorized as such under the laws of the state. 
(Code 1972, § 11-33) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference "Authorized emergency vehicle" defined, 625 ILCS 5/1-105. 


Sec. 42-2. - Mutual fire and ambulance aid program. 
(a) ?Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide for a program of mutual fire and ambulance aid 
between this village and other municipalities and fire protection districts, whereby each such 
municipality and district will be obligated to come to the assistance of a neighboring municipality or 
district in the event of a fire or other disaster therein of such magnitude that the local firefighting 
equipment and personnel cannot effectively cope with it. 
(b) ?Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the 
meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different 
meaning: 
    Aiding municipality means a municipality furnishing fire equipment to a stricken municipality, or to 
another aiding municipality. 
    Municipality means a city, village or incorporated fire protection district. 
    Mutual aid area means the territory occupied by the municipalities lying between Riverside and 
Downers Grove, inclusive, through which the Burlington Northern Railroad passes, the villages of 
LaGrange, LaGrange Park, Lyons, North Riverside, Brookfield, Clarendon Hills, Western Springs, 
Hinsdale, and McCook, and the following fire protection districts: Clarendon Heights, Pleasantview, Tri-
State, Belmont, and Downers Grove Estates. 
    Mutual fire and ambulance aid program means a plan or program as provided for in this section 
whereby the municipalities participating in the program agree to come to one another's assistance in case 
of fire or other disaster too large for local equipment and personnel to handle. 
    Participating municipality means a municipality in the mutual aid area that participates in the mutual 
fire and ambulance aid program by adopting an ordinance authorizing or approving a program and 
entering into an appropriate agreement, substantially as provided in this section, with other participating 
municipalities for rendering and receiving aid in case of fire or other disaster. 
    Stricken municipality means a participating municipality in which a fire or other disaster occurs that is 
of such magnitude that it cannot be adequately coped with by local firefighting equipment and personnel. 
(c) ?Agreement to effectuate mutual fire and ambulance aid program. The president and board of 
trustees, upon recommendation by the fire chief and public works director, are authorized, on behalf 
of this village, to enter into, and from time to time to alter and amend, an agreement with any or all of 
the municipalities in the mutual aid area defining and putting into effect a mutual fire and ambulance 
aid program providing generally as follows: 
(1) ?If, in the judgment of the officer in charge of the fire department of a stricken municipality, the 
available firefighting equipment of that municipality is inadequate to effectively cope with a fire 
or other disaster therein, such officer may call on a neighboring participating municipality to 
furnish firefighting equipment and personnel, to the extent specified in the agreement, to the 
stricken municipality, for use either: 
a. ?In combating the fire or other casualty; or 
b. ?As a standby reserve to meet other calls that may occur before the local firefighting 
equipment is free to take care of them. 
(2) ?Each aiding municipality furnishing firefighting equipment to a stricken municipality shall have 
the right to call on another participating municipality for firefighting equipment and personnel, to 
the extent specified in the agreement, as a standby reserve to take the place, in part, of the 
equipment furnished to the stricken municipality until such equipment shall be returned. 
(3) ?Upon receipt of a call under subsection (c)(1) or (c)(2) of this section, the aiding municipality 
called upon shall, to the extent provided in the agreement, furnish the equipment and personnel 
called for by the stricken municipality, or by the first aiding municipality; except that each aiding 
municipality may always be permitted to retain sufficient firefighting equipment and personnel to 
fight any fire or to meet any emergency within its own boundaries that may reasonably be 
anticipated. 
(d) ?Tentative mutual fire and ambulance aid program. Subject to approval of the respective corporate 
authorities, a tentative mutual fire and ambulance aid program conforming to the provisions of 
subsection (c) of this section has been agreed to by the chiefs of the fire departments of the villages 
of Riverside, LaGrange, LaGrange Park, Lyons, North Riverside, Brookfield, Clarendon Hills, 
Western Springs, Hinsdale, McCook, and of the Clarendon Heights, Pleasantview, Tri-State, 
Belmont and Downers Grove Estates Fire Protection Districts, and has been submitted to the 
authorities of this village. This tentative mutual fire and ambulance aid program is set forth in a chart 
on file in the office of the clerk of this village, and is subject to change or abrogation by action of the 
chief of the fire department pursuant to subsection (c) of this section. Unless and until so changed or 
abrogated, the tentative mutual fire and ambulance aid program as set forth in such chart is ratified 
as a binding agreement between this village and all other municipalities who shall have adopted 
such program and shall have assumed the obligations thereby imposed upon them. 
(e) ?Obligation of village under program. The village shall furnish firefighting equipment and personnel 
for use outside its boundaries, as provided in the tentative mutual fire and ambulance aid program 
referred to in subsection (d) of this section, or in any mutual fire and ambulance aid program agreed 
to as provided in subsection (c) of this section, to any municipality or fire protection district that has 
agreed to conform to such program and has assumed the obligations imposed upon it thereby. 
(Code 1972, § 2-8; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007) 
State Law reference Mutual fire aid, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1. 


Secs. 42-342-30. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Authority of village to create a fire department, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 42-31. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a fire department in the village, consisting of a full time fire chief, a full time 
deputy chief, full time administration staff, part-time paid on call, contract and volunteer members of the 
fire department as may from time to time be determined and appointed by the fire chief and confirmed by 
the village manager. The department's personnel shall not exceed 130 members consisting of up to 80 
members for the fire department and up to 50 members for the emergency management agency, all of 
various ranks, positions, and duties appointed by the fire chief and confirmed by the village manager. The 
fire chief shall promote the first deputy chief and thereafter, the hiring, promotion and discipline of the 
deputy chief shall be made by the fire and police commission. 
(Code 1972, § 11-1; Ord. No. 06-99, § 1, 6-5-2006; Ord. No. 13-96, § 1, 5-6-2013; Ord. No. 15-
054, § 2, 4-2-2015) 


Sec. 42-32. - Duties generally. 
    It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and every member thereof, excluding the fire 
chief, full-time administrative staff and emergency management agency personnel, to control and 
extinguish fires, to prevent occurrence of such fires, to protect life and property and, if assigned to an 
EMT or paramedic function, to deal with medical and trauma emergencies. 
(Code 1972, § 11-2; Ord. No. 13-96, § 1, 5-6-2013) 


Sec. 42-33. - Fire inspectors. 
    The fire chief may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to 
time be necessary. Such inspector(s) shall be in addition to the fire inspector in the building and public 
works department. 
(Code 1972, § 11-3; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Secs. 42-3442-60. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - FIRE CHIEF 


Sec. 42-61. - Appointment; term; removal. 
    The fire chief shall be appointed by the village manager, subject to the approval of the president and 
board of trustees of the village. The fire chief's appointment shall continue during good behavior and 
satisfactory service, and he shall be removed from office only in accordance with this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 11-4) 


Sec. 42-62. - Duties and responsibilities generally. 
    The fire chief shall have the control, subject to the orders and direction of the village manager, of the 
fire department and all fire apparatus belonging to the village. Whenever any fire apparatus needs 
repairing the fire chief shall cause such repairs to be done without delay. The fire chief shall also be 
responsible for any emergency medical transportation service provided by the village whether EMT or 
paramedic service. 
(Code 1972, § 11-5) 


Sec. 42-63. - Recordkeeping. 
    The fire chief shall keep a record of all meetings, drills, fire and ambulance calls and the attendance 
of members thereto. 
(Code 1972, § 11-7) 


Secs. 42-6442-85. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - PERSONNEL 


Sec. 42-86. - Qualifications; training; probationary period. 
    Fire department applicants must pass the physical examination as specified by the village. Training 
drills will be conducted at such frequency and schedule as determined by the fire chief. The probationary 
period shall be of such length that the firefighter can obtain the certifications required by the fire chief. 
(Code 1972, § 11-8) 


Sec. 42-87. - Compensation. 
    Members of the fire department shall receive such compensation as may be set from time to time by 
the village board. 
(Code 1972, § 11-9) 


Secs. 42-8842-100. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 4. - FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES 


Sec. 42-101. - Created; established. 
    That there is hereby created and established a firefighters' pension fund and firefighters' pension 
board in and for the Village of Westmont, DuPage County, Illinois, in accordance with 40 ILCS 5/4-101, et 
al. (Article 4 of the Illinois Pension Code.) 
(Ord. No. 15-043, § 1, 3-5-2015) 


Sec. 42-102. - Purpose. 
    That for the purpose of this division the term "firefighter" and "board" or "board of trustees" are 
defined, respectively, as full-time firefighter or full-time firefighters entitled to participate in the benefits of 
said pension fund as provided by said Article 4 of said Illinois Pension Code and the board of trustees of 
said pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 15-043, § 2, 3-5-2015) 


Sec. 42-103. - Duties. 
    That the rights, powers, duties and functions of said board and the members thereof, as such, and 
the rights and benefits of the various beneficiaries of the pension fund shall be and are hereby declared to 
be in accordance with the law and particularly of Article 4 of the Illinois Pension Code and all 
amendments thereof. 
(Ord. No. 15-043, § 3, 3-5-2015) 


Sec. 42-104. - Operation. 
    Such board shall be appointed and elected therein provided; shall exercise such powers and perform 
such duties that shall be required of them by law. All monies and securities belonging to said fund shall 
be held by the municipal treasurer subject to the order of the board of trustees of the pension fund. An 
annual list of beneficiaries and report of funds shall be made as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 15-043, § 4, 3-5-2015) 


Secs. 42-10542-110. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - FIRE SUPPRESSION 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 42-111. - Authority at fires and other emergencies. 
(a) ?The fire official, or duly authorized representatives, as may be in charge at the scene of a fire or 
other emergency involving the protection of life and/or property, is empowered to direct such 
operations as may be necessary to extinguish or control any suspected or reported fires, gas leaks, 
or other hazardous conditions or situations or of taking any other action necessary in the reasonable 
performance of their duty. The fire official may prohibit any person, vehicle or object from 
approaching the scene and may remove or cause to be removed from the scene any person, vehicle 
or object which may impede or interfere with the operations of the fire department. The fire official 
may remove or cause to be removed any person, vehicle or object from hazardous areas. All 
persons ordered to leave a hazardous area shall do so immediately and shall not reenter the area 
until authorized to do so by the fire official. 
(b) ?In case of a fire or medical emergency, the fire chief and his assistants shall rank in the order 
named, and the officer of the highest rank at the emergency shall take command of the fire or 
medical emergency in the best manner possible; and when it may be necessary for the protection of 
other property and to prevent the spread of the conflagration, the officer in command may cause 
buildings to be removed, torn down or destroyed in the best manner possible. 
(Code 1972, §§ 11-6, 11-21) 


Secs. 42-11242-137. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - FIRE CONTROL MEASURES 


Sec. 42-138. - Public water supply. 
    The fire chief shall recommend to the village manager or fire protection district, as the case might be, 
the location or relocation of new or existing fire hydrants and the placement or replacement of inadequate 
water mains located upon public property and deemed necessary to provide an adequate fire flow and 
distribution pattern. A fire hydrant shall not be placed into or removed from service until approved by the 
fire chief. 
(Code 1972, § 11-38) 


Sec. 42-139. - Hydrant locations. 
    All new and existing oil storage plants, lumberyards, amusement or exhibition parks, and educational 
or institutional complexes and other occupancies and uses involving high fire or life hazards, and which 
are located more than 150 feet from a public street or which require quantities of water beyond the 
capabilities of the public water distribution system shall be provided with properly placed fire hydrants. 
Such fire hydrants shall be capable of supplying fire flows as required by the fire chief and shall be 
connected to a water system in accordance with accepted engineering practices. The fire chief shall 
designate and approve the number and location of fire hydrants. The fire chief may require the installation 
of sufficient fire hose and equipment housed in accordance with approved rules and may require the 
establishment of a trained fire brigade when the hazard involved requires such measures. Private 
hydrants shall not be placed into or removed from service until approved by the fire chief. 
(Code 1972, § 11-39) 


Secs. 42-14042-145. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - PROHIBITED ACTS 


Sec. 42-146. - Interference with fire department operations. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or 
restrict the mobility of, or block the path of travel of any fire department emergency vehicle in any way, or 
to interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or hamper any fire 
department operation. 
(Code 1972, § 11-31) 


Sec. 42-147. - Compliance with orders of fire official. 
    A person shall not willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of the fire chief or 
the fire official on the scene or to interfere with the compliance attempts of another individual. 
(Code 1972, § 11-32) 


Sec. 42-148. - Unlawful boarding or tampering with fire department emergency equipment. 
    A person shall not, without proper authorization from the fire official in charge of such fire department 
emergency equipment, cling to, attach himself to, climb upon or into, board or swing upon any fire 
department emergency vehicle, whether such vehicle is in motion or at rest, or sound the siren, horn, bell 
or other sound producing device thereon, or to manipulate or tamper with, or attempt to manipulate or 
tamper with, any levers, valves, switches, starting devices, brakes, pumps, or any equipment or protective 
clothing on, or a part of, any fire department emergency vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 11-34) 


Sec. 42-149. - Damage or injury to fire department equipment or personnel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface, or attempt or conspire to damage or deface, 
any fire department emergency apparatus or equipment at any time, or to injure, attempt to injure, or 
conspire to injure, fire department personnel while performing departmental duties. 
(Code 1972, § 11-35) 


Sec. 42-150. - Entering fire station or places where firefighting apparatus kept. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the fire department quarters or any place where the 
equipment and apparatus of the fire department is stored at any time except on village business. 
(Code 1972, § 11-22) 


Sec. 42-151. - Private use of apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to use any fire engine or any other apparatus 
belonging to the village for any private purpose. 
(Code 1972, § 11-23) 


Sec. 42-152. - Burning combustible material. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any combustible material at any time, at any place, outside 
of any building within the village, unless in accordance with the adopted 2012 International Codes, as 
amended. 
(Code 1972, § 11-24; Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 1-1-2015) 


Sec. 42-153. - Blocking fire hydrants and fire department connections. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful to obscure from view, damage, deface, obstruct or restrict the access to any fire 
hydrant or any fire department connection for the pressurization of fire suppression systems, 
including fire hydrants and fire department connections that are located on public or private streets 
and access lanes or on private property. 
(b) ?If upon the expiration of the time mentioned in a notice of violation issued pursuant to this section, 
obstructions or encroachments are not removed, the fire official shall proceed to remove the same. 
Costs incurred in the performance of necessary work shall be paid by the village on the certificate of 
the fire official and with the approval of the village manager. The village shall institute appropriate 
action for the recovery of such costs in circuit court. 
(Code 1972, § 11-36) 


Sec. 42-154. - Hydrant use. 
    A person shall not use or operate any fire hydrant intended for use of the fire department for fire 
suppression purposes unless such person first secures a permit for such use from the fire chief and the 
water utility having jurisdiction over such hydrants. This section shall not apply to the use of such 
hydrants by a person employed by, and authorized to make such use by, the water utility having 
jurisdiction. 
(Code 1972, § 11-37) 


Sec. 42-155. - Tampering with hydrants or appliances. 
    A person shall not obstruct, remove, tamper with or otherwise disturb any fire hydrant or fire 
appliance required to be installed or maintained under the provisions of the fire prevention code except 
for the purpose of extinguishing fires, training or testing purposes, recharging, or making necessary 
repairs, or when permitted by the fire chief. Whenever a fire appliance is removed as permitted under this 
chapter, it shall be replaced or reinstalled as soon as the purpose for which it was removed has been 
accomplished. Defective and nonapproved fire appliances or equipment shall be replaced or repaired as 
directed by the fire chief. 
(Code 1972, § 11-40) 


Sec. 42-156. - Sale of defective fire extinguishers. 
    A person shall not sell, trade, loan or give away any form, type or kind of fire extinguisher which is 
not approved by the National Fire Protection Association (NFIPA) or which is not in proper working order, 
or the contents of which do not meet the requirements of the NFIPA. The requirements of this section 
shall not apply to the sale, trade or exchange of obsolete or damaged equipment for junk when such units 
are permanently disfigured or marked with a permanent sign identifying the unit as junk. 
(Code 1972, § 11-41) 


Sec. 42-157. - Street obstructions. 
    No person shall erect, construct, place or maintain any bumps, fences, gates, chains, bars, pipes, 
wood or metal horses or any other type of obstruction in or on any street within the boundaries of the 
village. The word "street," as used in this chapter, shall mean any roadway accessible to the public for 
vehicular traffic, including, but not limited to, private streets or access lanes, as well as all public streets 
and highways within the boundaries of the village. 
(Code 1972, § 11-42) 


Secs. 42-15842-165. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - FIRE PREVENTION 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Secs. 42-16642-185. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference Fire prevention in dry cleaning establishments, §§ 22-380, 22-381; fire prevention 
requirements for gasoline service stations, §§ 22-706, 22-717; application of fire prevention code to 
storage of gasoline and other flammable liquids in service stations, §§ 22-715, 22-716; application of fire 
prevention code to buildings used for public entertainment, §§ 22-1036, 22-1045. 


Sec. 42-186. - Codes adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing 
conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain codes known as: 
(1) ?The International Fire Code/2012 Edition, save and except such portions as are hereinafter 
deleted, modified or amended by section 42-189(a) of this article, of which code not less than 
three copies have been and now are filed in the office of the clerk of the village and the same 
are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if Westmont and the same are hereby adopted 
and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this article 
shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the 
Village of Westmont, DuPage County, Illinois. These codes, amendments thereto and other 
provisions shall be known as the Westmont Fire Prevention Code. 
(2) ?The Life Safety Code, NFPA 101, 2012 edition, compiled by the National Fire Protection 
Association, One Batterymarch Park, Quincy, Massachusetts 02269, save and except such 
portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended by section 42-189(b) of this article, of 
which code not less than three copies have been and now are filed in the office of the clerk of 
the village and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if Westmont set out at 
length herein, and from the date on which this article shall take effect, the provisions thereof 
shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the Village of Westmont, DuPage County, 
Illinois. These codes and amendments thereto and other provisions shall be known as the 
Westmont Fire Prevention Code. 
(Code 1972, § 11-51; Ord. No. 98-143, § 1, 12-7-1998; Ord. No. 05-63, § 1(Exh. A), 3-7-2005; 
Ord. No. 14-170, § 1(Exh. A), 10-2-2014, effective 1-1-2015) 
State Law reference Authority of village to adopt fire prevention code, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et 
seq. 


Sec. 42-187. - Enforcement. 
    The fire official charged with the enforcement of this code shall be under the supervision of the fire 
chief. The fire chief shall provide technical jurisdiction for matters not within the fire official's (inspector's) 
authority to enforce. 
(Code 1972, § 11-52; Ord. No. 98-143, § 1, 12-7-1998; Ord. No. 05-63, § 1(Exh. A), 3-7-2005) 


Sec. 42-188. - Citations. 
    The fire chief shall designate and permit certain fire officials (inspectors), in the performance of their 
duties, to issue citations for court appearance to building owners or their designated managers for 
violations of the Fire Prevention Code. 
(Code 1972, § 11-53; Ord. No. 98-143, § 1, 12-7-1998; Ord. No. 05-63, § 1(Exh. A), 3-7-2005)

notices, and final decisions by the Board of Trustees shall be as outlined in Chapter 29, Article XIII of the 
village Code. 
    Section 109.4 . Add: 
    ...shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $750.00 or by 
imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
    Section 113.1.3 . Add: Other Fees; 
Where in the judgment of the fire official an outside fire protection consultant is required because of 
the uniqueness or complexity of a requested installation, the consultant's time will be charged at the 
prevailing rate with the minimum rate of two hundred dollars ($200) per hour. 
One (1) free re-inspection will be given within thirty (30) days, and if current violations are not 
corrected, the owner or his authorized agent will be issued a warning notice to have these violations 
corrected within a time period specified on the notice and signed by the Authority having jurisdiction. 
A second free re-inspection will be given within thirty (30) days of the first re-inspection, and if 
current violations are not corrected, the owner or his authorized agent will again be issued a warning 
notice to have these violations corrected within a time period specified on the notice and signed by 
the Authority having jurisdiction. 
Once a second re-inspection has been conducted, if there is a need for more re-inspections, there 
will be an re-inspection fee of one-hundred dollars ($100) per re-inspection, and/or at the discretion 
of the Fire Prevention Bureau, there may be a citation for court appearance issued, with possible 
fines not to exceed Seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750/day) per day per violation. 
Each person having an approved alarm, automatic protection device or signaling device shall be 
responsible for any false "true" or "trouble" alarm transmitted by the device that he operates or 
maintains. Transmission of false alarms constitutes a deterrent to the overall effective operation of 
the system. A person owning or leasing an alarm device shall be charged a fee of One Hundred 
Dollars ($100) for each false alarm in excess of two (2), in one six-(6) month period transmitted by 
any automatic protection device or signaling device. This charge shall be remitted to the Village upon 
receipt of a statement for such charge. 
Failure to comply with notice to repair. The failure of any person to comply with the requirements 
contained in a written notice of a malfunction of equipment within three (3) days of receipt of such 
notice shall constitute an offense punishable by a fine of not more than One Hundred Dollars ($100). 
Such notice shall continue in force and effect until full compliance with the requirements stated 
therein and each and every failure to comply with such notice within twenty-four (24) hours after the 
three (3) days allowed for compliance constitute a separate offense. 
    Section 319 . Add: Motel and Hotel Cooking and Heating Appliances. 
The use of any cooking or heating appliances other than what has been provided for in the guest 
room by hotel or motel management shall be prohibited. 
    Section 503.2.4.1 . Add: Fire Apparatus Turning Radius. 
Public or private fire department access roads and roadways shall be, in all weather, properly 
maintained and accessible at all times. They shall be designed to accommodate fire apparatus and 
have a turning radius of 32 degrees or 45' 2" curb-to-curb clearance. Alterations and construction of 
fire department access roads shall be APPROVED by the Westmont Fire Chief, or designee. 
    Section 506.3 . Add: Fire Department Personnel access to Protected Premises 506.3.1 General; 
rapid entry key box - "Knox Box" 
The fire official shall require all new and existing structures that are required to be equipped with an 
approved fire alarm system and all buildings required to be equipped with a complete fire 
suppression system, to have an approved rapid entry key box system, a "Knox Box". Knox Box is 
only key box device approved for use in Village of Westmont. The Fire Code Official shall make 
available an order form to acquire required Knox Box. 
    506.3.2 Purpose . 
The purpose of the rapid entry key box system is to allow the fire department to gain immediate 
access to buildings in emergency situations without forcible entry. 
    506.3.3 Location . 
The installation location of the approved key box shall be approved by the Fire Official. 
    506.3.4 Contents . 
The approved key box shall contain keys to gain necessary access as required by the Fire Official. 
Keys shall be provided by Building Owner, Management, or tenant. 
    Section 511 . Add: Emergency Contact information 
It shall be the responsibility of every property owner and/or manager to provide current telephone 
numbers and contact persons, to be notified in case of any emergency involving their property and/or 
building. 
    Section 609.4 . Add: Kitchen Hood/Duct Suppression System, U.L. 300 Requirement 
All hood and duct extinguishing systems shall comply with the U.L. Standard 300. 
    Section 903.7 . Add: Exterior Access to Sprinkler Control Room 
In all new construction, an exterior access door shall be provided to the sprinkler riser room. This 
provision shall not apply to sprinkler systems installed in existing buildings 
    Section 907.6.5.3 . Add: Fire Alarm System Monitoring. 
All fire alarm systems and suppressions systems supervision shall be transmitted wirelessly and the 
wireless signal shall terminate at the Westmont Emergency Communication Center, located at 500 
North Cass Avenue, Westmont, IL. All fire alarm systems and suppression systems supervision shall 
comply with NFPA 72 and shall be approved by the Fire Official. Such fire alarm systems and 
suppression systems supervision are currently monitored at the Downers Grove/Westmont Dispatch 
Center. 
    Section 907.6.5.4 . Add: Elevator Emergency Telephones. 
Elevator emergency telephones shall not automatically be connected to Westmont 911 Dispatch. An 
emergency phone number, shall be provided by the Fire Code Official. 
    Section 907.10 . Add: Manual Pull Stations Required 
Manual pull stations shall be required in all buildings equipped with an automatic sprinkler system or 
NFPA 72 compliant fire alarm system. Location to be determined by Fire Code Official. 
    Delete Section 2306.2.3 Above Ground Storage tanks located outside, above grade 
Above-ground storage tanks for flammable and combustible liquids not permitted within Village of 
Westmont; except as follows: 
(1) ?Above ground storage tanks may not be approved by Westmont Fire Department for 
emergency situations. All installations in this instance shall conform to all state and local codes. 
(2) ?Above ground storage tanks may be approved by the Westmont Fire Department for storage of 
new and used cooking oil per the following specifications: 
a. ?Above ground storage tank must be approved by the Illinois State Fire Marshall; 
b. ?Above ground storage tank shall not exceed 600 gallons in total volume; 
c. ?Only Class IIIB flammables (cooking oils only) shall be stored in approved tanks; 
d. ?All installations shall conform with state and local codes. 
    Section 5610 . Add: Prohibited Fireworks 
The manufacture, display and sale of fireworks and/or explosives are prohibited. This includes both: 
1.3G and 1.4G per IFC Chapter 56. The discharge of fireworks shall comply with the provisions of 
this chapter. Only "professional" fireworks displays are permitted, and require a Fire Department 
Permit. This Section supersedes all Exceptions noted in Section 5601.1.3 
    Section 5608.11 . Add: Financial Responsibility, Bond Amount for commercial fireworks display. 
A Bond for Five Million Dollars ($5,000,000) per accident liability insurance policy shall be required 
prior to approval. 
    Section 5608.12 . Add: Fire Department Supervision of Displays. 
All outside, public "display" type fireworks displays (1.3G) are required to have a fire department 
standby, to be determined by the Fire Chief. Fire department expenses related to this standby to be 
billed to the host of the display. Local governmental agencies may be exempt from this fee. 
    Section 5608.13 . Add: Consumer fireworks. 
For the purpose of this Code, "consumer" fireworks (1.4G) are those intended for use in other than 
"display" (1.3G) fireworks. The use of, storage of, or manufacture of "consumer" type fireworks 
(1.4G) is not permitted within the Village of Westmont. 
Fireworks prohibited shall include blank cartridges, toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes and toy guns 
in which explosives are utilized; balloons requiring fire underneath to propel the balloon; firecrackers 
of any size, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, sparklers of any size and other devices of 
similar construction and use; any device containing any explosive or flammable compound; and any 
tablets and other devices containing explosive substance. 
The term "fireworks" shall NOT include automobile flares, paper caps containing not more than an 
average of 0.25 grain (16 mg) of explosive content per cap, and toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes, 
and other devices utilizing such caps. These types of devices shall be permitted under this section. 
    Delete Section 5604 in entirety and add: 
The storage of explosive materials or parking of vehicle(s) containing explosives is prohibited, within 
the corporate limits of the Village of Westmont, except by special permit, and only when applied for 
and approved by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
    Section 5604.1 . Add: Approved Transport Routes of Explosives The only approved routes for 
transporting explosives within the Village of Westmont shall be U.S. Route 34 (Ogden Avenue) and 
Illinois Route 83 (Kingery Highway). 
    Delete Section 5605 Manufacture, assembly and testing of explosives, explosive materials and 
fireworks 
    Add: Manufacturing of explosives is not permitted within Village of Westmont. 
    Section 6101.4 LP-gas capacities . Change to read: 
The aggregate capacity of LP-gas permitted at one installation shall not exceed a water capacity of 
1,000 gallons, and shall comply with NFPA 58, applicable edition.
