Sec. 42-190. - Prescribed burns. 
    Section 307 "Open Burning, Recreational Fire and Portable Outdoor Fireplaces" of the International 
Fire Code/2012 Edition is hereby amended through the addition of a new subsection 307.3 entitled 
"Prescribed Burns" as follows: 
    307.3 Prescribed Burns . 
A. ?Definitions: 
1. ?Prescribed Burns - Also termed as; Open Controlled Burns are the act of burning 
undisturbed vegetation, such as grasses, flowers, brush, shrubs and small trees in an open 
landscape. Prescribed burning is performed for the management and preservation of 
grasslands and savannas. 
2. ?Outdoor Burning - Also termed as silvicultural burning is the burning of landscape or land-
clearing waste. Outdoor burning, of this type, shall not be permitted in the Village of 
Westmont. 
3. ?Recreational Outdoor Burning - Includes recreational fire pits, decorative outdoor burning 
devices, and recreational bonfires for recreation or ceremonial purposes. Each of these 
burning activities are specifically regulated by the International Fire Code, which is the 
adopted fire code of the Village of Westmont. This Prescribed Burn Ordinance does not 
apply. 
4. ?Outdoor Open Flame Cooking Devices - Including charcoal or wood burning grills and 
barbeques and fuel fired (LPG or natural gas) grills or barbeques are specifically regulated 
by the International Fire Code, which is the adopted fire code of the Village of Westmont. 
This Prescribed Burn Ordinance does not apply. 
B. ?Permit required: 
1. ?A permit shall be required for all prescribed burns. This is referred to as the Prescribed 
Burn Permit (PBP). 
2. ?Prescribed Burn Permit applications shall be applied for a minimum of fourteen (14) 
business days prior to the start of any requested prescribed burn period. 
3. ?Request for PBP shall be made directly to the Westmont Fire Prevention Bureau at 6015 S. 
Cass Ave, Westmont, IL, 60515. 
4. ?Permit duration: Upon approval, Prescribed Burn Permits are valid for 180 days from the 
date of permit approval. 
5. ?Prescribed Burn Permit revocation: Prescribed Burn Permits may be revoked, at any time, 
by the Westmont Fire Chief, or designee(s), without advanced notice. 
1. ?Revocation of PBP may be made via telephone, e-mail, or letter. 
6. ?Extension: Prescribed Burn Permits may be extended up to an additional 30 days at the 
discretion of the Westmont Fire Chief or designee(s). 
1. ?Requests for extension of PBP shall be in writing and submitted to the Westmont FPB, 
6015 S. Cass Ave, Westmont, IL 60515. 
C. ?Prescribed Burn Permit request submittal requirements: Permit requests shall include all of the 
following information and details: 
1. ?A copy of valid Illinois EPA (IEPA) prescribed burn permit. 
2. ?A copy of Certificate of Insurance: 
1. ?A minimum of $5,000,000 liability insurance is required. 
2. ?Certificate of Insurance shall name Village of Westmont as co-insured. 
3. ?A letter of scope, on company letterhead, shall be submitted to the Westmont FPB: 
1. ?The letter of scope shall describe area of prescribed burns and requested date range 
that prescribed burns may occur. 
2. ?Letter of scope shall describe a fire control plan: 
1. ?The Fire Control Plan will describe what the prescribed burn contractor will do in 
the event a prescribed burn needs to be extinguished. 
3. ?A map showing location of the prescribed burn shall be included in letter of scope 
packet. 
4. ?Contact information shall be provided: 
1. ?Owner (or designee) of prescribed burn contractor. This is the primary contact 
person which provides a 24 hour contact number. 
2. ?On-site responsible parties - any managers that will be on-site during prescribed 
burns, provide contact phone numbers. 
D. ?Fees; Prescribed Burn Permit fees shall be a minimum of $150 which the prescribed burn 
contractor will be invoiced for directly by the Village of Westmont: 
1. ?Failure to remit permit fees within prescribed remittal period will result in the revocation of 
prescribed burn permits. 
E. ?Prescribed Burn Permit approval: 
1. ?Once a request for a Prescribed Burn Permit is made, the Westmont Fire Prevention 
Bureau, or designee(s) will review all submitted material and respond to permit request 
within 5 business days of receiving the permit request. 
2. ?Upon approval of Prescribed Burn Permit, notice will be sent via e-mail or postal to the 
Primary Contact designated in the Letter of Scope. 
3. ?If Prescribed Burn Permit is not approved, notice will be sent, via e-mail or postal, to the 
Primary Contact informing of what additional information or material is needed to approve 
permit request. 
F. ?Prescribed Burn required notification: 
1. ?24 - 48 hours prior to any prescribed burn, prescribed burn contractor shall notify, via 
telephone, the Westmont FPB. 
2. ?2 hours prior to any prescribed burn, prescribed burn contractor shall notify; The Westmont 
FD and Westmont Fire Dispatch Center. 
3. ?Failure to properly inform the Westmont FD of any prescribed burn activity may result in 
permit revocation and/or ceasing of prescribed burns. 
G. ?Allowable prescribed burn times: 
1. ?Prescribed burns shall only occur between 0800 and 1700 on any weekday. Legal holidays 
excluded. 
H. ?Authority of the Westmont Fire Department: 
1. ?The Westmont FD Fire Chief or designee(s) shall have the authority to immediately cease 
any prescribed burns. 
2. ?Upon instruction to extinguish prescribed burns, the prescribed burn contractor shall 
extinguish any fires and cease operations immediately. 
3. ?The Westmont FD has the authority to extinguish prescribed burns, with or without the 
permission of the prescribed burn contractor. 
4. ?The Westmont FD Fire Chief or designee(s) have the authority to delay or cancel 
prescribed burns, without notice, for any of the following reasons: 
- ?Weather conditions make the prescribed burn scenario potentially dangerous. 
- ?Community activities which may be adversely affected by the prescribed burn. 
- ?Any unforeseen hazards or issues. 
(Ord. No. 15-163, § 2, 10-15-2015) 


Secs. 42-19142-210. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE V. - AMBULANCE SERVICE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference Ambulances in municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-7 et seq. 


Sec. 42-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Any person not a resident of the village or of North and South Westmont Fire Protection Districts 
means any person residing outside these limits. 
    Emergency medical service means any medical service provided by the village fire department, 
except the transporting of any persons to a medical facility. 
    Emergency medical transportation service means the transporting of any persons by the village fire 
department to any medical facility. 
    Resident of the village means any person residing within the corporate limits of the Village of 
Westmont or North and South Westmont Fire Protection Districts. 
(Code 1972, § 2-9(a)) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 42-212. - Service established. 
    There is hereby established an emergency ambulance service to be maintained and operated by the 
village. 
(Code 1972, § 11-71) 


Sec. 42-213. - Service area. 
    The area to be served by the village ambulance service includes the village and such contract 
service areas as the North Westmont Fire District and the South Westmont Fire District. 
(Code 1972, § 11-72) 


Sec. 42-214. - Services rendered. 
    The village ambulance service shall provide emergency medical transportation and emergency 
medical service. This service shall be for the purpose of transporting any persons by the village fire 
department to any adjacent medical facility. Emergency medical service shall be provided within the limit 
of the training and certification of assigned personnel. 
(Code 1972, § 11-73) 


Sec. 42-215. - Fees. 
    Residents. A $1,550.00 fee shall be charged for transport of Basic Life Support (BLS) service 
rendered to residents within the service area. A $1,550.00 fee shall be charged for transport of Advanced 
Life Support (ALS) service rendered to residents within the service area. In addition, a fee of $18.00 per 
mile will be charged to residents on all transports calculated from the central point of Westmont to the 
receiving hospital. Such fees shall be charged for each use of the service provided. 
    Nonresidents. A $1,550.00 fee shall be charged for transport of Basic Life Support (BLS) service 
rendered to nonresidents within the service area. An $1,550.00 fee shall be charged for transport of 
Advanced Life Support (ALS) service rendered to nonresidents within the service area. In addition, a fee 
of $18.00 per mile will be charged to nonresidents on all transports calculated from the central point of 
Westmont to the receiving hospital. Such fees shall be charged for each use of the service provided. 
    Emergency medical services. The following fees shall be charged for identified emergency medical 
services provided by the village fire department: 
(1) ?Response to callResident (treat/non-transport) ..... 350.00 
(2) ?Response to callNonresident (treat/non-transport) ..... 750.00 
(3) ?Patient assist fee ..... 100.00 
(4) ?Vehicle accident fee (fire vehicle response; fee per fire department vehicle responding) ..... 
250.00 
(Code 1972, §§ 2-9(b)(d), 11-74; Ord. No. 93-59, § 1, 12-6-1993; Ord. No. 00-156, § 1, 12-
18-2000; Ord. No. 05-179, § 1, 7-18-2005; Ord. No. 08-139, § 1, 7-18-2008; Ord. No. 10-51, § 
1, 3-15-2010; Ord. No. 13-51, § 2, 3-18-2013; Ord. No. 15-124, § 2, 7-9-2015; Ord. No. 17-184, 
§ 2, 12-21-2017) 


Secs. 42-21642-235. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VI. - CLEANUP OR ABATEMENT OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference Hazardous Material Emergency Response Reimbursement Act, 430 ILCS 55/1 et 
seq. 


Sec. 42-236. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Combustible means any substance having a flashpoint above 100 degrees Fahrenheit to and 
including 200 degrees Fahrenheit as determined by the Tagliabue Open Cup Tester, except the 
flammability of solids and of the contents of self-pressurized containers shall be determined by methods 
generally applicable to such materials or containers, respectively. 
    Corrosive means any substance which when coming in contact with living tissue causes destruction 
of tissue by chemical action, but does not refer to action of inanimate surfaces. 
    Emergency action means any action taken at or near the scene of a hazardous materials emergency 
incident to prevent or minimize harm to human health, to property, or to the environment from the 
unintentional release of hazardous materials, by the cleanup or abatement of such materials. 
    Etiologic agent means a living microorganism that may cause human disease. 
    Flammable means any substance which has a flashpoint below 100 degrees Fahrenheit as 
determined by the Tagliabue Open Cup Tester, except the flammability of solids and of the contents of 
self-pressurized containers shall be determined by methods generally applicable to such materials or 
containers, respectively. 
    Hazardous material means any substance or material or mixture of substances which is toxic, 
corrosive, an irritant, a strong sensitizer, radioactive, flammable, combustible, or which generates 
pressure through decomposition, heat or other means, and which is in a quantity or form which, in the 
determination of the fire chief or his authorized representative, poses an unreasonable and imminent risk 
to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the environment, or as defined by the Illinois 
Environmental Protection Act [6] or any federal law. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, 
such substances as explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, 
poisons, etiologic (biologic) agents, flammables or corrosives. 
    Hazardous materials incident means an incident which threatens public health or safety involving the 
actual or potential release of a hazardous substance or hazardous materials. 
    Irritant means any substance, not corrosive, which on immediate, prolonged or repeated contact with 
normal living tissue will induce local inflammatory reaction. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, trust, firm, company, estate, association or 
other legal entity. 
    Poison means any substance that is known to be dangerous to life or toxic if released. 
    Radioactive means any substance which emits ionizing radiation. 
    Responsible party means a person who: 
(1) ?Owns or has custody of hazardous materials that are involved in an incident requiring 
emergency action; or 
(2) ?Owns or has custody of bulk or nonbulk packaging or a transport vehicle that contains 
hazardous materials and that is involved in an incident requiring emergency action; and 
(3) ?Causes or substantially contributes to the cause of the incident, whether intentionally or 
negligently. 
    Strong sensitizer means any substance which will cause on normal living tissue, through an allergic 
or photodynamic process, a hypersensitivity which becomes evident on reapplication of the same 
substance. 
    Toxic means any substance other than a radioactive substance which has the capacity to produce 
bodily injury or illness to man through ingestion, inhalation, or absorption through any body surface. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1(11-75), 8-16-1993) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
(415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.) 


Sec. 42-237. - Cost of cleanup or abatement. 
(a) ?Any responsible person shall have the duty to reimburse the village for and shall be liable for the 
payment of all costs incurred as a result of any cleanup or abatement resulting from any emergency 
action taken by the village or any agency at the direction of the village, including, but not limited to: 
actual labor costs of the village personnel (including workmen's compensation benefits, fringe 
benefits, and administrative overhead), costs of equipment, operation and materials obtained directly 
by the village, replacement of expended supplies, and other costs incurred. Costs incurred under this 
section shall not include costs of actual fire suppression services which are normally or usually 
provided by the fire department. 
(b) ?The village shall prepare and forward to the responsible person a bill for the total costs and 
expenses incurred for which such person is responsible pursuant to this section; provided, however, 
any cost in connection with any independent cleanup contractor may be billed directly by such 
contractor. Payment of the total bill from the village shall be made within 30 days of receipt. Any bill 
or portion of a bill remaining unpaid after 30 days of receipt shall incur a late charge of 10 percent of 
the invoice amount, along with interest on the unpaid balance in the amount of 1.5 percent per 
month, as well as the actual costs of collection. 
(c) ?The village shall charge the following costs for cleanup or abatement: 
Level 1: Basic response - $700.00 per hour. Includes engine response, first responder assignment, 
perimeter establishment, evacuations, set-up and command. 
Level 2: Intermediate response - $2,500.00 per hour. Includes engine response, first responder 
assignment, hazmat certified team and appropriate equipment, perimeter establishment, 
evacuations, set-up and command, Level A or B suit donning, breathing air and detection equipment, 
set-up and removal of decon center. 
Level 3: Advanced response - $5,900.00 per hour. Includes engine response, first responder 
assignment, HAZMAT certified team and appropriate equipment, perimeter establishment, 
evacuations, first responder set-up and command, level A or B suit donning, breathing air and 
detection equipment and robot deployment, set-up and removal of decon center, detection 
equipment, recovery and identification of material, disposal and environment clean-up. Includes 
three hours of on-scene time; each additional hour billed at $300.00 per hour per HAZMAT team. 
Additional costs billed for disposal rates of material and contaminated equipment and material used 
at scene. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1(11-76), 8-16-1993; Ord. No. 16-095, § 3, 5-26-2016) 


Sec. 42-238. - Penalties. 
    The remedy provided by this article shall be in addition to any other remedies or penalties provided 
by law. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1(11-77), 8-16-1993) 


Sec. 42-239. - Reimbursement of costs through state emergency response reimbursement panel. 
(a) ?When deemed necessary, the village and the fire department may solicit the assistance of the office 
of the state fire marshal, hazardous materials emergency response reimbursement panel for 
assistance in recovering the costs of emergency actions taken by the village in response to 
hazardous materials incidents from responsible parties. 
(b) ?The village and the fire department may file an application to the hazardous materials emergency 
response reimbursement panel, office of the state fire marshal, to obtain reimbursement for materials 
and equipment expended or rendered unserviceable due to chemical contamination after a 
reasonable but unsuccessful effort has been made to recover any such expended costs from the 
responsible parties. 
(c) ?If materials or equipment are expended or rendered unserviceable because of their use at a 
hazardous materials incident which occurs outside the village, while village personnel are operating 
under existing or future mutual aid/response agreements, a summary of costs expended shall be 
presented to the governmental agency or authority having jurisdiction over the hazardous materials 
incident where the costs were incurred, so that such agency can bill the responsible party and 
reimburse the village for such costs. If the governmental agency or authority having jurisdiction lacks 
the means to collect the village's costs from the responsible party, then the village and the fire 
department shall utilize the means set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section to obtain 
reimbursement or assistance in collection of such costs. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1(11-78), 8-16-1993) 


Sec. 42-240. - Village not liable. 
    The village, the village fire department, their officers, agents and employees shall not have any 
liability or responsibility for any claim, injury or damage of any kind resulting from emergency action taken 
in response to a hazardous materials incident to which they respond. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1(11-79), 8-16-1993) 


Secs. 42-24142-260. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VII. - EMERGENCY SERVICES MANAGEMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference Emergency powers of president, § 2-128. 
State Law reference Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq. 


Sec. 42-261. - Generally; purpose. 
    In accordance with Illinois Emergency Management Act, the emergency services management 
agency of the village (the "ESDA"), as established on July 7, 1980, shall serve to prepare for the 
possibility of and respond to the occurrence of disasters of unprecedented size and destructiveness 
resulting from the explosion in this or neighboring states of atomic or other means from without or by 
means of sabotage or other disloyal actions from within, or from fire, flood, earthquake, 
telecommunications failure, power failure, airline disaster, passenger or commercial rail accident, or other 
natural or technological causes. The ESDA shall take such steps as it and the village deem necessary 
and appropriate to ensure that this village will be prepared to and will adequately plan, manage, and deal 
with any disasters, preserve the lives and property of the residents of the village and protect the public 
peace, health, and safety in the event of disaster. This chapter 42, article VII, the Illinois Emergency 
Management Act, [8] as amended from time to time, and the rules, orders, and regulations promulgated by 
the village or any governing state agency shall govern the operations of the ESDA. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-74), 4-18-1994; Ord. No. 98-65, § 1, 6-15-1998) 
State Law reference Emergency services and disaster agencies, 20 ILCS 3305/1, 20 ILCS 
3305/10. 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
(20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.) 


Sec. 42-262. - Appointment of coordinator; training; function as liaison. 
(a) ?The coordinator of the ESDA shall be appointed by the same person and in the same manner 
provided in chapter 2 for other regular department heads. 
(b) ?The coordinator appointed pursuant to this section shall have primary responsibility for the 
organization, administration, training, and operation of the ESDA, subject to the ultimate direction 
and control of the village president as provided by statute, and subject to the ongoing and regular 
direction and supervision of the fire chief. 
(c) ?Any coordinator appointed under this section shall, within two years of the appointment, take 
necessary training courses to qualify as coordinator, as required by the regulations of the office of 
emergency management of the county. 
(d) ?In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability of any appointed ESDA coordinator, the 
village president, or any person designated by him, shall be and act as coordinator until a new 
appointment is made as provided in this article. 
(e) ?Upon appointment, the ESDA coordinator shall act as liaison between the village's ESDA and the 
office of emergency management of the county and any ESDA officials of the state. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-75), 4-18-1994; Ord. No. 98-65, § 2, 6-15-1998) 
State Law reference Persons responsible for emergency services and disaster agency, 20 
ILCS 3305/10(f), (i). 


Sec. 42-263. - Oath of office; personnel regulations. 
(a) ?Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the ESDA, including any appointed coordinator 
and all volunteers, shall, before entering upon any duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall 
be kept on file with the coordinator: 
I, ___________, do solemnly swear that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance 
to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, 
institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; 
that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will 
well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear that I 
do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that 
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; 
and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Village of Westmont ESDA organization, I will not 
advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of 
the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence. 
(b) ?All persons serving the ESDA, whether paid or volunteer, shall be governed by the personnel code 
of the village and subject to the primary supervision of the fire chief. The village discourages any 
form of discrimination and harassment. Persons serving the ESDA are subject to discipline for 
violations of federal, state, and local laws and regulations. Persons serving the ESDA shall be 
special part-time employees of the village and shall receive the benefit of workers' compensation 
coverage as permitted by the village's insurer. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-78), 4-18-1994; Ord. No. 98-65, § 3, 6-15-1998) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 20 ILCS 3305/20. 


Sec. 42-264. - Functions of ESDA. 
(a) ?The ESDA shall perform such functions within the village as prescribed in and by the state 
emergency management agency, any comparable ESDA plan and program promulgated by the 
governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor from time 
to time. 
(b) ?The ESDA shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits of the village as may be required 
pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or 
quasimunicipality entered into as provided by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, [9] as 
amended. 
(c) ?The ESDA may perform those duties within and without the corporate limits of the village which 
promote the purposes set forth in section 42-261, and which the ESDA is empowered to do under 
state law, the rules and regulations of various state agencies, including the state emergency 
management agency, and any mutual aid agreement entered into pursuant to the Illinois Emergency 
Management Act. [10] 
(d) ?The ESDA shall function routinely in the fields of hazards mitigation and preparation during non-
emergency periods and in the fields of response and recovery during a state of emergency or 
disaster. The ESDA shall plan, train, and equip the village so that the village can respond to and 
recover from a variety of emergencies, declared or undeclared. 
(e) ?In addition to the calls to action provided for by state law and any intergovernmental agreements, 
the ESDA may be summoned and called to action by the mayor, the village manager, or any 
department head who makes the determination that assistance from the ESDA will serve the health, 
safety and welfare of the village and its residents. 
(f) ?During emergencies, the ESDA shall have all the duties and powers delegated to it by statute and 
intergovernmental agreement. In addition, the ESDA shall manage the emergency operations center, 
emergency communications center, and shelters. The ESDA shall also oversee and manage 
emergency resources and volunteer manpower as specified in the village's emergency operation 
plan. 
(g) ?The ESDA shall have joint responsibility with the police and fire departments for communicating with 
the village and its residents during emergencies and disasters, providing advance warnings, severe 
weather reporting, controlling traffic and crowds, search and rescue during emergencies and 
disasters, providing emergency power and lighting, disseminating public information, downed power 
line/electric wirewatching, and participating in, managing and coordinating mobile command and 
communications and other public service activities. 
(h) ?Prior to functioning in any manner not required or permitted by this article, by the state emergency 
operations plan, or by programs, rules, and regulations of the state emergency management agency, 
or by any mutual aid agreement, the ESDA shall promulgate it own rules and regulations regarding 
emergency management functions. Such rules and regulations should specify the functions and 
duties within subsection (c) of this section in such a manner as to identify, in general terms, the 
functions to be performed. Prior to functioning pursuant to the ESDA's rules and regulations, the 
ESDA shall present its rules and regulations to the board of trustees for approval by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-77), 4-18-1994; Ord. No. 98-65, § 4, 6-15-1998) 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
(20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.) 
 
--- (10) --- 
(20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.) 


Sec. 42-265. - Mobile support team. 
(a) ?Any mobile support team shall be created by the director of the state emergency management 
agency, as provided by law. 
(b) ?Any member of the mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to 
duty by the governor or the state director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, 
duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a 
paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall receive from the state the reasonable 
compensation as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-78), 4-18-1994) 
State Law reference Mobile support teams, 20 ILCS 3305/8. 


Sec. 42-266. - Agreements with other political subdivisions. 
    The coordinator of the ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other villages, cities, or 
political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by 
the village president and board of trustees and by the director of the state ESDA. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-79), 4-18-1994) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 20 ILCS 3305/13. 


Sec. 42-267. - Emergency action. 
    If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon 
the United States or the occurrence within the state of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or 
other hostile action, or from any manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the ESDA to 
cooperate fully with the state ESDA and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as 
provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-80), 4-18-1994) 
State Law reference State emergency management agency, 20 ILCS 3305/5; emergency 
powers of governor, 20 ILCS 3305/7. 


Sec. 42-268. - Compensation of members for training. 
    Members of the ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the 
director of the state ESDA, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as 
attached to the position held; members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for 
such training time such compensation as may be established by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-81), 4-18-1994) 


Sec. 42-269. - Reimbursement to village by the state. 
    The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any reimbursement by the 
state to the village for expenses incident to training members of the ESDA as prescribed by the director of 
the state ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of any member of a mobile support team while 
serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or director of the state ESDA, as provided 
by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-82), 4-18-1994) 


Sec. 42-270. - Purchases and expenditures. 
    The village president and board of trustees may, on the recommendation of the coordinator of the 
ESDA, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the village in a position to combat 
effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, or from any 
manmade or natural disaster, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide 
emergency assistance to victims in the case of any such disaster. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-83), 4-18-1994) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 20 ILCS 3305/10(j). 


Sec. 42-271. - Appropriation; levy of taxes. 
    The village board may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner provided by law, 
and may levy in addition for ESDA purposes only, a tax not to exceed $0.05 per $100.00 of the assessed 
value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by the Illinois Emergency 
Management Agency Act, [11] as amended; however, any amount collectable under such levy shall in no 
event exceed $0.25 per capita. The annual tax shall be in addition to the amount authorized to be levied 
for general corporate purposes. 
(Ord. No. 94-26, § 1(11-84), 4-18-1994; Ord. No. 98-65, § 5, 6-15-1998) 
Cross reference Taxation, ch. 74. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/8-3-16. 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
(20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.) 


Sec. 42-272. - Conflicts of interest. 
    Neither the ESDA, nor any person working in the ESDA's behalf, shall be employed directly or 
indirectly by any person for political purposes. 
(Ord. No. 98-65, § 6, 6-15-1998)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Secs. 46-146-30. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - FOOD AND FOOD HANDLERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference Collection of garbage and refuse from hotels and food establishments, § 66-4.5. 
State Law reference Regulation of food in municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-1 et seq.; Sanitary Food 
Preparation Act, 410 ILCS 650/0.01 et seq. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 46-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Food shall include beverages as well as food. 
    Food dealer means and includes every person engaged in any of the following businesses: 
(1) ?Fruit stores or establishments for the retail sale of fresh fruit. 
(2) ?Grocery stores or establishments for the sale at retail of butter, cheese, vegetables or other 
provisions. 
(3) ?Ice cream parlors. 
(4) ?Meat markets or establishments for the retail sale of fresh meat, poultry and fish. 
(5) ?Bakeries or any establishment for the mixing, compounding or baking for sale of any bread or 
breadstuffs or any food product of which flour or meal is the principal ingredient; however, 
places where such foodstuffs are baked in restaurant kitchens for consumption in such 
restaurant only or in dwellings where such foodstuffs are baked on ordinary ranges or stoves for 
consumption on the premises only shall not be considered as bakeries. 
(6) ?Any other business specifically regulated by this article. 
(Code 1972, § 12-1) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 46-32. - Food dealer's license. 
(a) ?Required. It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the village without 
having first secured a license therefor. 
(b) ?Application; contents. Application for a food dealer's license shall state the kind of food intended to 
be sold or handled. 
(c) ?Investigation of applications. All applications for licenses to do business connected with the storage, 
handling, sale or preparation of food or drink intended for human consumption shall be referred to 
the chief of police, who shall make an investigation of the premises to be used. He shall report his 
findings and make a recommendation as to whether or not the license should be issued. 
(d) ?License fees. Unless another license fee is specifically provided for in this article, the license fee for 
food dealers shall be as follows: 
(1) ?For all food dealers, including but not limited to grocery stores, ice cream parlors, bakeries, 
dealers in nonalcoholic beverages (except that for those dealers with alcoholic beverage 
licenses the license fee shall be waived), meat markets or establishments for the retail sale of 
fresh meat, poultry or fish, and fruit or vegetable stands, the annual fee shall be $50.00 for the 
first 10,000 square feet of floor area, $75.00 for 10,000 to 25,000 square feet of floor area, 
$100.00 for 25,000 to 50,000 square feet of floor area and $125.00 for all grocery stores with 
over 50,000 square feet of floor area. 
(2) ?For ice sales in cubes or blocks for use in food and drink the fee shall be $10.00 per year. This 
shall include coin operated machines.. 
(Code 1972, §§ 12-212-5; Ord. No. 02-146, § 20, 12-16-2002) 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22. 


Sec. 46-33. - Licensing of more than one business. 
    Any person licensed under this article, to sell any foods or beverages may conduct on the same 
premises and in connection with the licensed business any other business mentioned in this article 
without paying any additional fee therefor if the fee paid for the licensed business is at least as great in 
amount as the fee required for the other business so conducted. This section shall not be construed to 
relieve any such applicant from the regulatory requirements of any business. 
(Code 1972, § 12-6) 


Sec. 46-34. - Revocation of food dealer's licenses; grounds. 
    Any food dealer's license may be revoked by the village president and board of trustees for repeated 
violation of the provisions of this article, or for any violation of any other ordinance relating to the conduct 
of the business, the condition of the premises, the articles sold, or to the license required. 
(Code 1972, § 12-8) 


Sec. 46-35. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of an official designated by the president and board of trustees to make or cause 
to be made such reasonable inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions 
of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 12-7) 


Sec. 46-36. - Adulterated food. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale or keep for such purpose, any food or drink intended for 
human consumption which has been adulterated by any material harmful in any way or which does not 
comply with the state law governing such food or drink. 
(Code 1972, § 12-9) 


Sec. 46-37. - Examination and condemnation of unwholesome or adulterated food or drink. 
    Samples of food, drink and other substances may be taken and examined as often as may be 
necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. Any food or drink which is unwholesome 
or adulterated may be removed or destroyed. 
(Code 1972, § 12-10) 


Sec. 46-38. - Unwholesome or spoiled foods. 
    No person shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food or drink 
of any kind intended for human consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for 
human consumption for any reason. 
(Code 1972, § 12-11) 


Sec. 46-39. - Premises to be sanitary; unlawful accumulations of waste. 
    Premises used for the sale or storage of food or drink intended for human consumption must be kept 
in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit any accumulation of refuse or waste of any 
kind to remain therein for more than 24 hours, and it shall be unlawful to permit any decaying matter or 
decaying animal or plant material to remain on such premises. The premises shall be kept free of flies 
and vermin of all kinds. 
(Code 1972, § 12-12) 


Sec. 46-40. - Common drinking cups prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup, dipper or other similar utensil for the use of 
more than one person in any public hall, theater, store or other place frequented by the public. 
(Code 1972, § 12-13) 


Sec. 46-41. - Utensils to be cleaned and sterilized. 
    Utensils for personal use in all places serving food or drink to the public shall be thoroughly cleaned 
and sterilized after each usage. 
(Code 1972, § 12-14) 


Sec. 46-42. - Employees to be clean, free from disease. 
(a) ?All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food intended for sale for human 
consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to person and clothing. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any infectious or contagious 
disease to handle or be engaged in the care or preparation of any food. It shall be unlawful to permit 
any such person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared, sold or 
delivered. 
(Code 1972, § 12-15) 


Sec. 46-43. - Sale of food for consumption on parking lots. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful, except as set forth in division 5 of this article, to serve food or drinks for 
consumption on any parking lot unless the parking lot is operated in connection with an 
establishment licensed to serve food for consumption on the premises. 
(b) ?If a parking lot is maintained in connection with an establishment licensed to serve food for 
consumption on the premises, and food or drinks are served to the occupants of cars, sufficient and 
adequate containers must be maintained for all trash and refuse, and the premises must be kept 
thoroughly clean by the proprietor. 
(Code 1972, § 12-16) 
Cross reference Parking lot license, § 22-486 et seq. 


Sec. 46-44. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more 
than $500.00 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on 
which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1972, § 12-88) 


Secs. 46-4546-65. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - RESTAURANTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10. 


Sec. 46-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Food shall include nonalcoholic beverages as well as food. 
    Restaurant means any place where food or drink is prepared or served to the public for consumption 
on the premises. 
(Code 1972, § 12-27) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 46-67. - Periodic inspections; posting of inspection report. 
(a) ?At least once every six months every restaurant located within the village shall be inspected. In case 
any violation of this article is discovered, a second inspection shall be made after such lapse of time 
as is necessary for the defect to be remedied. The second inspection shall be used in determining 
compliance with the requirements of this article. A violation of any requirement of this article on such 
second inspection shall call for immediate revocation of the permit issued under this article. 
(b) ?One copy of the inspection report shall be posted upon an inside wall of the restaurant, and such 
inspection report shall not be defaced or removed by any person. Another copy of the inspection 
report shall be filed with the records of the county health department. 
(c) ?The person operating the restaurant shall permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall 
permit copying of all records of food purchased. 
(Code 1972, § 12-28) 


Sec. 46-68. - Toilet facilities. 
    Every restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its 
employees and patrons. In restaurants constructed after December 3, 1956, toilet rooms shall not open 
directly into any room in which food, drink, or utensils are handled or stored. The doors of all toilet rooms 
shall be self-closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair and well lighted and 
ventilated. Handwashing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees. 
(Code 1972, § 12-29) 


Sec. 46-69. - Premises to be free of litter and rubbish. 
    The premises of all restaurants shall be kept clean and free of litter or rubbish. 
(Code 1972, § 12-30) 


Sec. 46-70. - Required lavatory facilities; use by employees. 
    In all restaurants in the village, adequate and convenient handwashing facilities shall be provided, 
including hot and cold running water, soap, and approved sanitary towels. The use of a common towel is 
prohibited. No employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without first washing his hands. 
(Code 1972, § 12-31) 


Sec. 46-71. - Water supply. 
    In all restaurants in the village running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in 
which food is prepared or utensils are washed, and the water supply shall be adequate and of a safe, 
sanitary quality. 
(Code 1972, § 12-32) 
Cross reference Utilities, ch. 82. 


Sec. 46-72. - Construction of utensils and equipment. 
    All multiuse utensils and all show and display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, 
refrigerating equipment, sinks and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of a 
restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair. Utensils 
containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used; however solder containing lead may be used 
for jointing. 
(Code 1972, § 12-33) 


Sec. 46-73. - Cleaning and bactericidal treatment of utensils and equipment. 
(a) ?All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, 
hoods, and sinks, shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects, and other contaminating 
material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be clean. Single-service 
containers shall be used only once. 
(b) ?All multiuse eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an 
approved bactericidal process after each usage. All multiuse utensils used in the preparation or 
serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved 
bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean 
and used for no other purpose. 
(c) ?No article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous material 
shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils. 
(Code 1972, § 12-34) 


Sec. 46-74. - Storage and handling of utensils and equipment. 
    After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust 
and other contamination, and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as 
practicable. Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers, and shall be stored 
therein in a clean, dry place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. 
(Code 1972, § 12-35) 


Sec. 46-75. - Disposal of wastes. 
    All wastes in a restaurant shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage and trash shall be kept in 
suitable receptacles, in such manner as not to become a nuisance. 
(Code 1972, § 12-36) 
Cross reference Solid waste, ch. 66. 


Sec. 46-76. - Refrigeration; disposal of refrigeration wastewater. 
    All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at or below 50 degrees Fahrenheit, except when 
being prepared or served. Wastewater from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of. 
(Code 1972, § 12-37) 


Sec. 46-77. - Storage, display and serving of food. 
    All food and drink shall be so stored, displayed and served as to be protected from dust, flies, 
vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage, 
and other contamination. No animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is 
prepared or stored. All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches, and rodents shall be used. 
(Code 1972, § 12-38) 


Sec. 46-78. - Requirements for milk products. 
    All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream and other frozen desserts served shall be from approved 
sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual original containers in which they 
were received from the distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device; 
however, this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from the original bottle or from a 
dispenser approved for such service. 
(Code 1972, § 12-39) 


Sec. 46-79. - Requirements for oysters, clams and mussels. 
    All oysters, clams and mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked shall be kept until 
used in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant. 
(Code 1972, § 12-40) 


Sec. 46-80. - Use of premises as living or sleeping quarters prohibited. 
    None of the operations connected with a restaurant shall be conducted in any room used as living or 
sleeping quarters. 
(Code 1972, § 12-41) 


Sec. 46-81. - Employees' lockers or dressing rooms. 
    Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees' clothing and shall be kept 
clean. 
(Code 1972, § 12-42) 


Sec. 46-82. - Storage of soiled linens. 
    Soiled linens, coats and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for such purpose. 
(Code 1972, § 12-43) 


Sec. 46-83. - Drive-in restaurants. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, or offer for sale, any food or drink at drive-in restaurants located on 
property adjacent to a residential district within the village between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. It 
shall be unlawful to permit the public to remain upon such premises during the hours within which the sale 
of such foodstuffs is prohibited. 
(Code 1972, § 12-44) 


Secs. 46-8446-100. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 3. - MILK DEALERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22. 
State Law reference Grade A Pasteurized Milk and Milk Products Act, 410 ILCS 635/1 et seq.; Illinois 
Milk Promotion Act, 505 ILCS 95/1 et seq. 


Sec. 46-101. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for a milk dealer's license shall be $10.00 per year. 
(Code 1972, § 12-54) 


Sec. 46-102. - Compliance with state law. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, distribute, process or handle any dairy products in violation 
of state law. 
(Code 1972, § 12-55) 


Sec. 46-103. - Delivery vehicles, marking and sanitation. 
    Every vehicle used for the delivery of milk or cream to the consumer shall have marked plainly 
thereon the name of the vendor of such milk with his address. All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean 
and sanitary manner and condition. 
(Code 1972, § 12-57) 


Sec. 46-104. - Deliveries to quarantined premises. 
(a) ?Milk may be delivered to quarantined premises, provided that there is no contact of any kind 
between the inmates and contents of the quarantined premises and the delivery agent. 
(b) ?No milk receptacles shall be taken from any quarantined premises during the period of quarantine 
and before being taken away for use such receptacles shall be thoroughly scalded and sterilized. 
(Code 1972, § 12-56) 


Sec. 46-105. - Periodic inspections; costs. 
    Periodic inspections shall be conducted of all milk distribution plants, dairies, vehicles and equipment 
used in the sale or distribution of milk as well as of the milk itself. Such inspections shall be made at least 
every quarter and as often as may be deemed necessary. In lieu of inspection the certificate of inspection 
of the county or any other municipality having equal or more rigid requirements than provided by this 
article may be accepted. The licensee shall pay the cost of all bacteriological inspections and tests 
necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 12-58) 


Secs. 46-10646-125. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 4. - FOOD DELIVERIES 


Sec. 46-126. - Vehicle licenseRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any vehicle, including wagons, motor vehicles and 
vehicles propelled by human power for the storage or delivery of foodstuffs intended for human 
consumption in the village or for resale in the village unless a license for the vehicle is first secured in 
accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 12-69) 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22. 


Sec. 46-127. - SameExemptions. 
    No license shall be required for any vehicle used to deliver foodstuffs from any establishment which 
is otherwise licensed and inspected as a food dealing establishment within the village; however, all of the 
other provisions of this division shall be complied with in connection with such vehicles. 
(Code 1972, § 12-70) 


Sec. 46-128. - SameFee; term. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $15.00 per vehicle and such license 
shall be in effect for one year beginning on January 1 of each calendar year. 
(Code 1972, § 12-71) 


Sec. 46-129. - Unwrapped foods to be screened and protected. 
    If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any vehicle coming within the terms of this division, such 
unwrapped foodstuffs shall be carried in a portion of the vehicle which is screened and protected against 
dust and insects. 
(Code 1972, § 12-72) 


Sec. 46-130. - Vehicles to be clean and sanitary. 
    All vehicles used in transporting food shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be 
thoroughly cleaned after each day's use. It shall be unlawful to permit stale food, decaying matter or other 
waste material to accumulate in or on such vehicle while it is so used. 
(Code 1972, § 12-73) 


Secs. 46-13146-145. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 5. - STREET FOOD VENDORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference Peddlers and hawkers, § 22-251 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, 
ch. 70. 


Sec. 46-146. - PermitRequired. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or offer to sell or to peddle any food or beverage for human consumption 
from any vehicle, including motor and nonmotorized vehicles or otherwise, in or about the village without 
such person having first obtained a permit therefor in accordance with the terms of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 12-84) 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22. 


Sec. 46-147. - SameApplication and fee; display; transfer. 
(a) ?The fee for a permit under this division shall be $200.00 per year. All permit fees shall be payable in 
advance and shall be nonrefundable, provided a permit is issued. 
(b) ?Application for a permit under this division shall be filed in writing with the village clerk, on a form to 
be provided by the village, and shall specify: 
(1) ?The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm, corporation, partnership or association, 
the principal officers thereof and their addresses. 
(2) ?The address of the premises wherefrom the vehicles are to be operated, together with the 
character of the business as carried on at such place and proof of compliance with all applicable 
laws, codes and ordinances. 
(3) ?The trade name and general description of the firm or person to be permitted, the name of the 
owner or owners thereof, and the number of vehicles to be permitted. Provided, however, that a 
permit shall entitle only one vehicle to conduct business on the assigned premises at any one 
time. 
(4) ?The name and address of the operator or operators of the vehicle, if other than the owner, and 
such other information as may be reasonably requested by the village. 
(c) ?The proper permit fee shall accompany each application for a permit under this division. Permits 
shall be displayed on a conspicuous place on the vehicle of the licensee. Permits shall be 
nonassignable and nontransferable. 
(Code 1972, § 12-85) 


Sec. 46-148. - SameDenial; revocation. 
    The village clerk shall have the right, for good cause, to deny issuance of or to revoke any permit 
issued under this division for the violation of any of the provisions of this article or any health code subject 
to notice and hearing to be held by the village president. 
(Code 1972, § 12-86) 


Sec. 46-149. - Standards for concessionaires. 
    The following shall be prohibitions and requirements concerning the operating of concessionaires in 
the premises described in this division: 
(1) ?It shall be unlawful to permit stale foods, decaying matter, or other waste material or product to 
accumulate in, on or about, or around such vehicle while it is so used or to fail to maintain all 
such vehicles in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(2) ?The area of operation per permittee shall not exceed the equivalent of one assigned parking 
area or space which shall be designated by the village clerk. 
(3) ?The operator of the vehicle must comply with all other ordinances, regulations and rules that 
apply to the parking and operating of vehicles in the defined premises. 
(4) ?The vehicle and vehicle operator must be licensed by the state for operation of the vehicle. 
(5) ?The permittee must be certified and in compliance with all the rules and regulations of the 
county department of health. 
(6) ?Prior to commencing business, the licensee shall execute and provide to the village, in a form 
to be supplied and approved by the village, a document indemnifying and insuring the village 
against any and all risks, liabilities, claims, demands, losses and judgments arising from or 
growing out of or related in any way to the work performed or to be performed by such licensee, 
whether or not due to or arising from the acts or negligence of the village, its agents and 
employees or the licensee, its agents, employees, subcontractors, and their agents and 
employees. The scope and limits of the insurance requirements shall be as follows: The 
licensee shall, prior to commencing business at the described premises, provide the village with 
proof of insurance as follows: Workers' compensation insurance up to the statutory limits and 
public liability and vehicle liability insurance of limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 for injury 
and death, per occurrence, and property damage liability providing for a limit of not less than 
$1,000,000.00 for damages to or destruction of property, per occurrence. 
(7) ?Hours of operation of vending services by mobile concessionaires shall be limited to between 
4:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(8) ?If wrapped foodstuffs are transported in any such vehicle, such foods shall be carried in a 
portion or compartment of the vehicle which is screened and protected against dust and insects. 
(9) ?Readily perishable foods or beverages while in transit shall maintain the temperature of not 
less than 35 degrees Fahrenheit and not more than 50 degrees Fahrenheit. The temperature for 
hot liquid foods or beverages shall be maintained at not less than 150 degrees Fahrenheit and 
for frozen foods at no more than 32 degrees Fahrenheit. The compartments in vehicles used for 
carrying such foods shall be so constructed, equipped and maintained as to preserve the 
temperature as above indicated with respect to types of food. 
(10) ?Disposal of liquids and solids, including wrappers, stale foods, excess coffee, etc., must be 
properly executed outside the village limits, preferably at the site of the franchisee's business. 
(Code 1972, § 12-87) 


Secs. 46-15046-165. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 6. - REFRIGERATION LOCKER PLANTS 


Sec. 46-166. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings 
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Food means and includes any edible substance or any beverage used or intended for human 
consumption. 
    Refrigeration locker plant means any establishment wherein compartments are rented, leased, or 
made available to any person other than the owner of the establishment for the refrigerated storage of 
food. 
(Code 1972, § 12-97) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference "Locker plant" defined, 225 ILCS 650/2.29. 


Sec. 46-167. - LicenseRequired. 
    No person shall operate a food refrigeration locker plant in the village without having first secured a 
license therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 12-98) 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22. 


Sec. 46-168. - SameApplication; contents. 
    The application for a license required by this division shall be made to the village clerk and shall 
state the number of units maintained on the premises, the size of each unit, and whether a unit is 
maintained in which food will be stored belonging to more than one individual in addition to separate 
units. 
(Code 1972, § 12-99) 


Sec. 46-169. - SameCompliance with state law prerequisite to issuance. 
    No license shall be issued for any food refrigeration locker plant which does not comply with the laws 
of the state pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1972, § 12-100) 


Sec. 46-170. - SameFee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $50.00. 
(Code 1972, § 12-101) 


Sec. 46-171. - Building requirements. 
    No refrigeration locker plant shall be operated or conducted in a building which is not constructed in 
full compliance with this Code and other ordinances of the village, and no such plant shall be operated in 
a frame building, nor in any building other than one where the floors are so constructed as to bear a live 
load of 100 pounds per square foot. 
(Code 1972, § 12-102) 
Cross reference Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 


Sec. 46-172. - Refrigeration requirements. 
    No food shall be stored in any refrigeration locker plant unless the food has been frozen to a 
temperature of zero degrees Fahrenheit or below before being so stored. The lockers or compartments 
used for the refrigerated storage of food must be kept at all times at a temperature below 15 degrees 
Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1972, § 12-103) 


Sec. 46-173. - Electrical wiring. 
    The electrical wiring in all refrigeration locker plants shall conform to the provisions of this Code 
relative to electric wiring and to the installation of refrigeration units. 
(Code 1972, § 12-104) 
Cross reference Electricity, § 18-186 et seq. 


Sec. 46-174. - Sanitation requirements; storing unwholesome food. 
    All premises used for the operation of a refrigeration locker plant shall be kept in a clean and sanitary 
condition, and shall be thoroughly cleaned of all refuse, dust, and debris at least once every 24 hours. It 
shall be unlawful to store or keep in such plant unwholesome, spoiled, contaminated or adulterated food. 
(Code 1972, § 12-105) 


Secs. 46-17546-199. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - TATTOO AND BODY PIERCING ESTABLISHMENTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22; zoning, app. A. 


Sec. 46-200. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the words and terms defined below shall have the following meanings: 
    Body piercing means any procedure whereby a part of the human body is pierced by a sharp 
instrument in order to allow insertion of a piece of jewelry, a ring or other commercial device through the 
orifice thus created. 
    Microblading is a semi-permanent makeup procedure using a microblade and pigment to enhance, 
reshape or create a natural looking appearance on the eyebrows. It is also known as microfeathering, 
microshading, eyebrow embroidery and other names. 
    Operator means any individual, firm, company, corporation or association that owns or operates an 
establishment where tattooing is performed, and any individual who performs or practices the art of 
tattooing other human beings. 
    Permanent makeup is a cosmetic technique which uses permanent pigment as a means of 
producing designs that resemble makeup, such as eyelining and other permanent enhancements to the 
skin of the face, lips, eyelids, and eyebrows. It is also known as permanent cosmetics, 
dermapigmentation, micropigmentation and cosmetic tattooing. 
    Tattoo, tattooed, and tattooing mean any method of placing designs, letters, scrolls, figures, symbols 
or any other marks upon or under the skin by the aid of needles or other instruments designed to touch or 
puncture the skin. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999; Ord. No. 18-085, § 1, 6-21-2018) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2. 


Sec. 46-201. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and operate a tattoo establishment, with or without 
body piercing, without first having obtained a license as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-202. - Application for license; investigation. 
    Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate or conduct a tattoo establishment shall file an 
application upon a form provided by the village clerk and pay a nonrefundable filing fee of $100.00 to the 
village clerk. The village clerk shall, within 15 days thereafter, refer copies of such application and all 
additional information to the police department, economic development department and mayor. The 
village departments shall, within 45 days, inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a tattoo 
establishment, and make recommendations to the clerk concerning compliance with the codes of the 
village. Upon receipt of the recommendations of the respective village departments, the clerk shall notify 
the applicant as to whether his application has been granted, denied or held for further investigation. The 
period of such additional investigation shall not exceed an additional 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 46-203. - Expiration and renewal of license. 
    A license as provided for in this article shall expire upon the expiration of each calendar year. 
Applications for renewal shall be made no later than October 1. The renewal fee shall be $75.00. There 
shall be a $25.00 late filing fee for applications for renewal filed prior to October 31. No application for 
renewal shall be granted if filed on or subsequent to November 1. An application for renewal shall be 
processed in the same manner as the initial application noted in section 46-202. The failure to renew any 
license required by this section 46-203 shall result in a cessation of use on the premises, and any special 
use permit granted for the use under section 8.03 of the zoning ordinance (appendix A to this Code) shall 
automatically terminate. No new license shall be granted until the operator has obtained proper village 
board approval of the special use. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-204. - Standards for premises; operation generally. 
    No tattoo establishment shall receive a license or be operated, established or maintained unless the 
establishment shall comply with each of the following minimum regulations: 
(1) ?The establishment shall have a certificate of compliance with or inspection by the county health 
department, if available. 
(2) ?The room in which tattooing is done shall have an enclosed area of not less than 500 square 
feet. The walls, floors and ceiling shall have an impervious, smooth and washable surface. 
(3) ?Toilet facilities shall be provided within the establishment. When five or more employees or 
patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the same time, separate toilet facilities shall be 
provided. Lavatories shall be provided with both hot and cold running water and shall be 
installed in the toilet room. Lavatories shall be provided with soap and a dispenser with sanitary 
towels. 
(4) ?All tables and other equipment shall be constructed of easily cleanable material, shall be 
painted or finished in a light color, with a smooth washable finish, and shall be separated from 
waiting customers or observers by a solid wall or door totally eliminating any view into the 
tattooing room. 
(5) ?Closed cabinets shall be provided for use in the storage of clean linens, towels, needles, and 
other materials and instruments used in tattooing. All used linens, towels, equipment, 
instruments, and other materials shall be kept in properly covered containers or cabinets which 
shall be kept separate from the clean storage areas. 
(6) ?The entire premises and equipment shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary condition and in 
good repair. 
(7) ?No tattoo establishment shall be open to the public for business between the hours of 8:00 p.m. 
and 8:00 a.m. 
(8) ?The main entrance door of any tattoo establishment shall be visible from a public street and 
shall remain unlocked during business hours. 
(9) ?The business shall also comply with all of the terms and conditions set forth in this Code with 
respect to business licenses. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-205. - Standards for tattooing; operators; alcoholic beverages. 
(a) ?The operator shall wash his hands thoroughly with antiseptic soap and water before starting any 
tattoo. The hands shall be dried with individual, single-use towels. 
(b) ?The area on the patron to be tattooed shall first be thoroughly washed with a sterile, single-use 
sponge with warm water containing an antiseptic liquid soap. The area should be shaved with a 
safety razor, using single-service blades for each customer or patron, followed by a solution of 70 
percent alcohol, to be applied to the area before tattooing is begun. 
(c) ?Only petroleum jelly in collapsible metal or plastic tubes shall be used on the area to be tattooed, 
and it shall be applied with sterile gauze. 
(d) ?Single-service or individual containers of dye or ink shall be used for each patron, and the container 
therefor shall be discarded immediately after completing work on each patron. Any dye in which the 
needles are dipped shall not be used on another person. All needles, pigments, dyes, colors and any 
other material used in tattooing and all bandages and surgical dressings used in connection with 
tattooing shall be sterile and free from bacteria, virus particles and noxious agents and substances. 
After completing work on any person, the tattooed area shall be washed with sterile gauze and 70 
percent alcohol solution and allowed to dry. A sterile gauze dressing shall be fastened to the tattooed 
area. 
(e) ?Operators shall at all times while in the performance of their services wear uniforms or garments 
which cover the torso, and such garments shall be kept clean and in a sanitary condition. 
(f) ?No person, while on the premises of any tattoo establishment, shall possess, sell, dispense, provide, 
give, keep or maintain any alcoholic beverage. 
(g) ?No intoxicated person shall be tattooed by an operator on the licensed premises. 
(h) ?Operators shall at all times comply with the regulations of the Department of Labor's Occupational 
Safety and Health Administration (29 CFR 1910.1030), as presently existing or hereafter amended, 
with respect to occupational exposure to blood, bloodborne pathogens or other potentially infectious 
materials, which regulations are incorporated by reference in this section. 
(i) ?Tattooing may be performed within such licensed tattoo establishments but shall be done only by a 
physician or osteopath or in the physical presence and under the direct supervision of a physician or 
osteopath authorized to practice medicine or osteopathic medicine in the state as set forth in the 
Illinois Medical Practice Act of 1987 (225 ILCS 60/1 et seq.), or any amendment thereof. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-206. - Inspections. 
    Any village department or agency may make an inspection of each establishment granted a license 
under the provisions of this article for the purposes of determining compliance with the provisions of this 
article. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-207. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    It shall be cause for revocation or suspension that a licensee has violated the provisions of this 
article or any code or ordinance of the village relative to operation of the business or use of the premises, 
or has made a false statement on any application for license under this article, or if the licensee shall 
refuse to permit any authorized police officer or authorized member of the police department or economic 
development department of the village to inspect the premises or the operations thereof at reasonable 
times. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007) 


Sec. 46-208. - Transfer of license. 
    No license for the operation of a tattoo establishment shall be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-209. - Display of license. 
    Each licensee shall display a valid current license in a conspicuous place within the licensed 
establishment so that the license may be readily seen by persons entering the establishment. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-210. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to licensed medical doctors or doctors of osteopathic 
medicine who perform body piercing or tattoo individuals while in the course of their medical practice, or 
to those performing microblading and permanent makeup as an accessory use to a licensed beauty salon 
establishment. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999; Ord. No. 18-085, § 1, 6-21-2018) 


Sec. 46-211. - Body piercing. 
    Body piercing may be performed within such licensed tattoo establishment, but shall be done only by 
a physician or osteopath or in the physical presence and under the direct supervision of a physician or 
osteopath authorized to practice medicine or osteopathic medicine in the state as set forth in the Illinois 
Medical Practice Act of 1987 (225 ILCS 60/1 et seq.), or any amendment thereof. The piercing of ears 
shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. No operator shall pierce any portion of any specified 
anatomical area, human genitals, pubic regions, buttock, or female breast as defined in section 22-781. 
The piercing of any portion of a specified anatomical area, human genitals, pubic regions, buttock, or 
female breast is hereby declared a specified sexual activity as defined by section 22-781. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-212. - Tattooing of persons under 21 years of age. 
    In accordance with 720 ILCS 5/12-10, no person under the age of 21 may be tattooed except by a 
person authorized to practice medicine or osteopathic medicine as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-213. - Penalty. 
    In addition to license suspension or revocation as provided in this article, any person violating any of 
the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $75.00 and not more than $750.00, and a 
separate offense shall be determined to have been committed each day during which or on which the 
violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 2, 2-1-1999) 


Sec. 46-214. - Microblading and permanent makeup. 
    Persons performing microblading and permanent makeup as defined herein are exempt from the 
licensing requirements of this article, provided that the microblading and/or permanent makeup is 
performed as an accessory use to a licensed beauty salon. All person performing microblading and 
permanent makeup shall possess all necessary state licenses and shall display such licenses in the 
establishment where the microblading and/or permanent makeup is performed. All persons performing 
microblading and permanent makeup shall obtain a business license from the village. Microblading and 
permanent makeup as an accessory use to a licensed beauty salon are allowed in all zoning districts 
where beauty salons are allowed. 
(Ord. No. 18-085, § 1, 6-21-2018) 


Secs. 46-21546-299. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - SMOKE FREE WESTMONT 


Sec. 46-300. - Adoption of the Smoke Free Illinois Act by reference. 
(a) ?The regulations of the Smoke Free Illinois Act, 410 ILCS 82/1 et seq., as amended from time to 
time, are hereby adopted by reference in their entirety, save and except such portions as are herein 
modified or amended, and are, together with such amendments, incorporated as fully as if set out at 
length herein, and shall control in the village to the extent permitted by law. Said ordinance, as 
modified and amended, shall be referred to as the "Smoke Free Westmont" ordinance. 
(b) ?In lieu of using any section, or in addition to any section of this chapter, the officer issuing a citation 
may issue it by using any of the sections of the Smoke Free Illinois Act, 410 ILCS 82/1 et seq. and 
as amended from time to time, which are hereby incorporated and adopted by reference as part of 
this chapter. All citations issued for these violations shall be in the name of the Village of Westmont 
and shall refer to the numbered sections in the Smoke Free Illinois Act, but shall also be referred to 
as an ordinance violation. References to a state employee or official may be to a corresponding 
village employee or official where such reference is applicable or necessary. 
(c) ?The burden of proof shall be by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(Ord. No. 13-191, § 1, 10-3-2013) 


Sec. 46-301. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of the Smoke Free Westmont ordinance, the following words and phrases shall have 
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Enforcing agency. The Village of Westmont. 
(Ord. No. 13-191, § 1, 10-3-2013) 


Sec. 46-302. - Amendments. 
    The modifications and amendments to the Smoke Free Illinois Act which are applicable to the Smoke 
Free Westmont ordinance are as follows: None. 
(Ord. No. 13-191, § 1, 10-3-2013) 


Sec. 46-303. - Penalties. 
(a) ?Any person served with a citation for violation of the Smoke Free Westmont ordinance may settle 
and compromise the matter in respect of such ordinance violation by ceasing and abating said 
violation and paying the sum as defined in Section 45 of the Smoke Free Illinois Act (410 ILCS 
82/45) to the Village of Westmont within 15 days from the date appearing on the citation. 
(b) ?Payment of a citation issued under this article shall be made in accordance with the instructions 
contained in the aforesaid citation, at the office of the village clerk, who shall issue a receipt for the 
money so received and promptly remit such amount to the village treasurer to be credited to the 
proper municipal fund. 
(c) ?In the event the payment is not made within the time prescribed and a complaint has been field in 
the Circuit Court of DuPage County, any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this 
article shall be punishable by a fine no less than $250.00. 
(Ord. No. 13-191, § 1, 10-3-2013) 


Chapter 50 - HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; economic development director, § 18-3; 
businesses, ch. 22; engineering and flood control, ch. 34; fire prevention, fire protection and emergency 
services, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 46; planning and development, ch. 63; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Law reference Municipal Housing Finance Law, 65 ILCS 5/11-74.5-1 et seq.; housing generally, 
310 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 50-1. - Title; purpose. 
    This chapter shall be known as the Housing Code of the Village of Westmont. It shall be the purpose 
of this chapter to establish minimum standards of dwelling space, facility requirements and structural 
adequacy for dwellings within the village; to establish fair housing practices and prohibit discrimination in 
real estate transactions; to provide for administration of this chapter and to specify the authority and 
procedures to be followed in executing the powers established in this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 15½-1; Ord. No. 93-37, § 1, 8-2-1993) 


Secs. 50-250-30. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - STANDARDS FOR DWELLINGS
