Sec. 58-10. - Public indecency. 
(a)  Any person of the age of 17 years and upwards who performs any of the following acts in a public place, as defined herein, commits a public indecency, which is prohibited: 
(1)  An act of sexual penetration or sexual conduct; or 
(2)  A lewd exposure of the body done with intent to arouse or to satisfy the sexual desire of the person. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
Public place means any place where the conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. 
Sexual conduct means any intentional or knowing touching or fondling by the victim or the accused, either directly or through clothing, of the sex organs, anus or breast of the victim or the accused, or any part of the body of a child under 13 years of age, for the purpose of sexual gratification or arousal of the victim or the accused. 
Sexual penetration means any contact, however slight, between the sex organ of one person and the sex organ, mouth or anus of another person, or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of the body of one person or of any animal or object into the sex organ or anus of another person, including but not limited to cunnilingus, fellatio or anal penetration. Evidence of emission of semen is not required to prove sexual penetration. 
(Code 1972, § 17-10; Ord. No. 94-4, § 1, 1-3-1994) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/11-9.  
Sec. 58-11. - Obscenity. 
(a)  Elements of the offense. A person commits obscenity, which is prohibited, when, with knowledge of the nature or content thereof, or recklessly failing to exercise reasonable inspection which would have disclosed the nature or content thereof, he: 
(1)  Sells, delivers or provides, or offers or agrees to sell, deliver or provide any obscene writing, picture, record or other representation or embodiment of the obscene; 
(2)  Presents or directs an obscene play, dance or other performance or participates directly in that portion thereof which makes it obscene; 
(3)  Publishes, exhibits or otherwise makes available anything obscene; 
(4)  Performs an obscene act or otherwise presents an obscene exhibition of his body for gain; 
(5)  Creates, buys, procures or possesses obscene matter or material with intent to disseminate it in violation of this section, or of the penal laws or regulations of any other jurisdiction; or 
(6)  Advertises or otherwise promotes the sale of material represented or held out by him to be obscene, whether or not it is obscene. 
(b)  Obscene defined. Any material or performance is obscene if: 
(1)  The average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find that, taken as a whole, it appeals to the prurient interest; and 
(2)  The average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find that it depicts or describes, in a patently offensive way, ultimate sexual acts or sadomasochistic sexual acts, whether normal or perverted, actual or simulated, or masturbation, excretory functions or lewd exhibition of the genitals; and 
(3)  Taken as a whole, it lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(c)  Interpretation of evidence. 
(1)  Obscenity shall be judged with reference to ordinary adults, except that it shall be judged with reference to children or other specially susceptible audiences if it appears from the character of the material or the circumstances of its dissemination to be specially designed for or directed to such an audience. 
(2)  Where circumstances of production, presentation, sale, dissemination, distribution, or publicity indicate that material is being commercially exploited for the sake of its prurient appeal, such evidence is probative with respect to the nature of the matter and can justify the conclusion that the matter is lacking in serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(3)  In any prosecution for an offense under this section evidence shall be admissible to show: 
a.  The character of the audience for which the material was designed or to which it was directed; 
b.  What the predominant appeal of the material would be for ordinary adults or a special audience, and what effects, if any, it would probably have on the behavior of such people; 
c.  The artistic, literary, scientific, educational or other merits of the material, or absence thereof; 
d.  The degree, if any, of public acceptance of the material in this state; 
e.  Appeal to prurient interest, or absence thereof, in advertising or other promotion of the material; 
f.  Purpose of the author, creator, publisher or disseminator. 
(d)  Forfeiture of property. 
(1)  Obscenity is a far-reaching and extremely profitable crime, which persists despite the threat of prosecution and successful prosecution because existing sanctions do not effectively reach the money and other assets generated by it. The state has, therefore, determined it to be necessary to supplement existing sanctions by mandating forfeiture of money and other assets generated by such crime, to diminish the financial incentives which encourage and sustain obscenity and secure for the state, local government and prosecutors a resource for prosecuting obscenity crimes. 
(2)  The village shall assist the county state's attorney and the attorney general of the state in investigating and prosecuting crimes of obscenity and in obtaining forfeiture of property pursuant to state law, and specifically pursuant to the procedures set forth in 720 ILCS 5/11-20. 
(e)  Prima facie evidence of intent to disseminate. The creation, purchase, procurement or possession of a mold, engraved plate or other embodiment of obscenity specially adapted for reproducing multiple copies, or the possession of more than three copies of obscene material, shall be prima facie evidence of an intent to disseminate. 
(f)  Affirmative defense. It shall be an affirmative defense to obscenity that the dissemination: 
(1)  Was not for gain and was made to personal associates other than children under 18 years of age; or 
(2)  Was to institutions or individuals having scientific or other special justification for possession of such material. 
(Code 1972, § 17-12; Ord. No. 94-4, § 2, 1-3-1994) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/11-20.  
Sec. 58-12. - Limitation on previews of certain types of motion pictures with respect to juvenile audiences. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to show or display on a motion picture screen for which an admission price is charged, any preview, trailer or advertisement which is intended solely for audiences 18 years of age or over or requiring or recommending parental permission, where the feature attraction that accompanies such preview, trailer or advertisement is advertised for general audiences. It is the intent of this section to protect children 17 years of age or under from exposure to harmful materials intended solely for audiences 18 years of age or over or requiring or recommending parental permission. This section in no way is intended to limit or restrict materials presented to adult audiences. 
(Code 1972, § 17-12.1) 
Cross reference Exhibition of obscene motion picture, § 22-1076.  
Sec. 58-13. - Acts constituting deceptive trade practice. 
(a)  A person engages in a deceptive trade practice, which is unlawful, when, in the course of his business, vocation or occupation, he: 
(1)  Passes off goods or services as those of another; 
(2)  Causes a likelihood of confusion or of misunderstanding as to the source, sponsorship, approval or certification of goods or services; 
(3)  Causes a likelihood of confusion or of misunderstanding as to affiliation, connection or association with or certification by another; 
(4)  Uses deceptive representations or designations of geographic origin in connection with goods or services; 
(5)  Represents that goods or services have sponsorship, approval, characteristics, ingredients, uses, benefits or quantities that they do not have or that a person has a sponsorship, approval, status, affiliation or connection that he does not have; 
(6)  Represents that goods are original or new if they are deteriorated, altered, reconditioned, reclaimed, used or secondhand; 
(7)  Represents that goods or services are a particular standard, quality or grade or that goods are a particular style or model, if they are of another; 
(8)  Disparages the goods, services or business of another by false or misleading representation of fact; 
(9)  Advertises goods or services with intent not to sell them as advertised; 
(10)  Advertises goods or services with intent not to supply reasonably expectable public demand, unless the advertisement discloses a limitation of quantity; 
(11)  Makes false or misleading statements of fact concerning the reasons for, existence of or amounts of price reductions; 
(12)  Engages in any other conduct which similarly creates a likelihood of confusion or of misunderstanding. 
(b)  In order to prevail in an action under this section, a plaintiff need not prove competition between the parties or actual confusion or misunderstanding. 
(c)  This section does not affect unfair trade practices otherwise actionable at common law or under other statutes of this state. 
(Code 1972, § 17-13) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 815 ILCS 510/2.  
Sec. 58-14. - Damage to property. 
Whoever commits any of the following acts shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(1)  Damages any property of another without his consent; 
(2)  By means of fire or explosive damages property of another; 
(3)  Starts a fire on the land of another without his consent; 
(4)  Injures a domestic animal of another without his consent; 
(5)  Deposits on the land or in the building of another, without his consent, any stink bomb or any offensive smelling compound and thereby intends to interfere with the use by another of the land or building; 
(6)  Damages any property, other than property specifically excluded by state law with intent to defraud an insurer; 
(7)  Knowingly shoots a firearm at any portion of a railroad train; or 
(8)  Knowingly damages any property owned or maintained by the village or any other public entity, including but not limited to street signs, guardrails, traffic lights, fire hydrants, parkways, trees, shrubs and any other kinds of property, both real and personal. 
(Code 1972, § 17-14; Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 9-18-1995) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/21-1.  
Sec. 58-15. - Criminal trespass to vehicles and land. 
Whoever commits any of the following acts shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(1)  Knowingly and without authority enters any vehicle, aircraft or watercraft, or any part thereof, of another without the owner's consent. 
(2)  Enters upon the land, or any part thereof, of another after receiving, immediately prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden, or remains upon the land of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart. For purposes of this section, "notice" shall include written notice, including but not limited to no trespass signs, and the posting of such signs shall constitute constructive notice of the owner's intent to forbid entry to such land. 
(Code 1972, § 17-14.1) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/21-2, 5/21-3.  
Sec. 58-16. - Throwing missiles; depositing glass, nails and other articles on street or public place. 
It shall be unlawful to cast, throw, or propel any missile on any street, alley or public place. It shall be unlawful to throw or deposit any glass, nails, tacks, or other similar articles on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place in the village. 
(Code 1972, § 17-16)  
Sec. 58-17. - Dense smoke emissions; testing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or any other agency in the village so as to cause annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof. 
(b)  For the purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke, the Ringelmann smoke chart as published and used by the United States Geological Survey shall be and is hereby adopted as a standard for such grading. Smoke shall be determined to be dense when it is of a degree of number 3 or greater on such chart, for more than six minutes in any one hour, whether such period of time is consecutive or not. 
(Code 1972, § 17-17)  
Sec. 58-18. - Establishment of cemeteries; burials. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish a cemetery or to bury any person within the village limits or within a mile of the village limits except in an established cemetery. 
(Code 1972, § 17-18)  
Sec. 58-19. - Leaking gas pipes. 
Any person maintaining any gas pipe in the village shall, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such pipes free from leaks. 
(Code 1972, § 17-19)  
Sec. 58-20. - Discharge of firearms. 
It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearm or airgun in the village; however, any officer of the law may discharge a firearm in the performance of his duties and any citizen may discharge a firearm when lawfully defending his person or property. 
(Code 1972, § 17-20) 
State Law reference Deadly weapons, 720 ILCS 5/24-1 et seq.  
Sec. 58-21. - Certain persons prohibited from purchasing firearms or ammunition. 
(a)  No person under 21 years of age shall purchase any ammunition of any type. 
(b)  No person under 18 years of age shall purchase a firearm of a size that may be concealed upon the person. 
(c)  No person under 21 years of age who has been convicted of a misdemeanor, other than a traffic offense, or adjudged delinquent shall purchase a firearm. 
(Code 1972, § 17-21) 
State Law reference Unlawful sale of firearms, 720 ILCS 5/24-3.  
Sec. 58-22. - Sale of firearms to be reported to police department. 
The sale of all firearms shall be reported to the police department and shall include the make, serial number and vital data regarding the firearm and the name and address to whom such firearms have been sold. 
(Code 1972, § 17-22)  
Sec. 58-23. - Electrically charged and barbed wire fences. 
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain anywhere in the village a fence equipped with, or having, barbed wire, spikes, or any similar device, or any electric charge sufficient to cause a shock, within seven feet of the ground level. 
(Code 1972, § 17-23) 
Cross reference Electricity, § 18-186 et seq.  
Sec. 58-24. - Height of fences. 
It shall be unlawful to construct any fence, in an area zoned for residence purposes only, to a height greater than six feet above the ground level, or to construct, in such areas, a fence to a height greater than three feet between the building line, where set by ordinance, and the street. 
(Code 1972, § 17-24)  
Sec. 58-25. - Use of steam whistles and engines. 
It shall be unlawful to blow or cause to be blown or sounded any steam whistle of any stationary or steam engine except as a signal for starting or stopping work or in emergencies to avoid injury to persons or property. 
(Code 1972, § 17-25)  
Sec. 58-26. - Theft. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person shall commit theft. A person commits theft when he knowingly: 
(1)  Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; 
(2)  Obtains, by deception, control over property of the owner; 
(3)  Obtains, by threat, control over property of the owner; or 
(4)  Obtains control of stolen property, knowing the property to have been stolen by another under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him to believe that the property was stolen; and: 
a.  Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property; 
b.  Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or 
c.  Uses, conceals or abandons the property knowing such use, concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00 and not more than $500.00 for each such violation.  
Sec. 58-27. - Retail theft. 
A person commits the offense of retail theft when he knowingly: 
(1)  Takes possession of, carries away, transfers or causes to be carried away or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; 
(2)  Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of value or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or in consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; 
(3)  Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which such merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; 
(4)  Under-registers the price with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of the merchandise; 
(5)  Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such cart; 
(6)  Represents to a merchant that he or another is the lawful owner of property, knowing that such representation is false, and conveys or attempts to convey that property to a merchant who is the owner of the property in exchange for money, merchandise, credit or other property of the merchant; 
(7)  Uses or possesses any theft detection shielding device or theft detection device remover with the intention of using such device to deprive the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or 
(8)  Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner and thereby intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property when a lessee of the personal property of another fails to return it to the owner, or if the lessee fails to pay the full retail value of such property to the lessor in satisfaction of any contractual provision requiring such, within 30 days after written demand from the owner for its return. A notice in writing, given after the expiration of the leasing agreement, by registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by the lessee and shown on the leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand. 
(Code 1972, § 17-32) 
State Law reference Offense of retail theft, 720 ILCS 5/16A-3; sentence for retail theft, 720 ILCS 5/16A-10.  
Sec. 58-28. - Possession of cannabis. 
It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to possess cannabis. As used in this section, "cannabis" includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant cannabis sativa, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis, or by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis. 
(Code 1972, § 17-33) 
Cross reference Paraphernalia sales, § 22-181 et seq. 
State Law reference Possession of cannabis, violations, punishment, 720 ILCS 550/4.  
Sec. 58-29. - False alarms. 
(a)  Responsibility for false alarms. Each person having an approved alarm, automatic protection device or signaling device, to include burglar alarms, shall be responsible for any false alarm transmitted by the device which he operates or maintains. 
(b)  "Police false alarm" defined. The term "police false alarm" shall mean the activation of any police alarm device by other than a forced entry, attempted forced entry, unlawful entry, or actual hold-up or attempted robbery on the premises which results in a response from the police department. A police response shall be defined as the actual dispatch of an on-duty police officer. Examples of a false alarm include, but are not limited to the following: activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, failure to properly maintain an alarm system or the negligence of the owners or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or agents. Such terminology does not include for example, alarms cause by tornados, storms, lightning or other violent conditions. 
(c)  Records; fees. Transmission of police false alarms constitutes a deterrent to the overall effective operation of the village's policing system. The chief of police shall maintain a record of all police false alarms occurring every six-month period, on a calendar-year basis, beginning January 1 and July 1. Any person owning the device, alarm device, telephone, or other medium which transmits a police false alarm to the village police department, directly or indirectly, shall pay the following fees: 
  First false alarm$0.00. 
  Second and third false alarm$25.00 per false alarm. 
  Fourth and fifth false alarm$50.00 per false alarm. 
  Sixth through tenth false alarm$100.00 per false alarm. 
  After the tenth false alarm, the fee shall be $500.00 per false alarm. 
Payment of fees for police false alarms shall be made to the office of the village clerk immediately upon receipt of a statement for such charges. 
(Code 1972, § 17-34; Ord. No. 98-100, §§ 1, 2, 9-21-1998; Ord. No. 09-66, § 1, 5-18-2009; Ord. No. 12-192, § 1, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 58-30. - Skateboards, rollerskates and scooters. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Central business district means the area bounded by Naperville Road on the north, Lincoln on the west, Dallas on the south, and Linden on the east. 
Rollerskates means devices worn on the feet with a combination of wheels which are propelled by human power. 
Scooter means a device with two or more wheels connected by a platform with a steering handle or wheel which is designed for standing and which is propelled by human power. 
Skateboard means a device with a combination of wheels connected by a platform designed for standing and which is propelled by human power. 
(b)  Prohibited uses. No skateboards, rollerskates or scooters shall be used, operated or propelled upon any sidewalk, street or public way in the central business district of the village. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $10.00 for the first offense, and not less than $20.00 for the second or subsequent offense. 
(Code 1972, § 17-35)  
Sec. 58-31. - Operation of pawnshops. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a pawnbrokerage or pawnshop, as defined in the Illinois Compiled Statutes, within the corporate limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 99-19, § 1(B), 2-1-1999) 
Cross reference Pawnshops prohibited, § 22-3.  
Sec. 58-32. - Fireworks. 
(a)  Definition: The term "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive composition, or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons, in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, sky rockets, Roman candles, bombs or other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any explosive compounds; or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects. The term "fireworks" shall not include snake or glow worm pellets, smoke devices, sparklers (except as limited herein), trick noisemakers, "trick matches," "cigarette loads," "autoburglar alarms," toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns; or other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing twenty-five one hundredths (0.25) grains or less of explosive compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper or plastic cups which contain less than twenty-five hundredths (0.25) grains of explosive mixture; the sale, possession and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
(b)  Possession, use or sale: 
(1)  Explosives or explosive or incendiary devices: It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, or transport any explosive compound, timing or detonating device in the village for use with any explosive compound or incendiary device when such person either intends to use said explosive or device to commit any criminal offense against the person or property of another or knows that another intends to use such explosive or device to commit any criminal offense against the person or property of another. 
(2)  Fireworks: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly possess, offer for sale, expose for sale, sell, use or explode any fireworks within the village except for professional fireworks displays as authorized by state statute and authorized by the village pursuant to the issuance of a permit pursuant to village ordinances. 
(3)  Sparklers: It shall be unlawful for any person to use sparklers on public property within the village. 
(4)  Enforcement: The prohibitions set forth in this section shall be enforced by the Westmont Police Department, and these prohibitions shall be in addition to any regulations and prohibitions as set forth in the Fire Prevention Code, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 08-84, § 1, 5-19-2008)  
Sec. 58-33. - Urinating in public. 
It shall be unlawful to urinate or defecate upon any public way or public place. For purposes of this section, the term "public way" shall mean any and all streets, roads, alleys, sidewalks, boulevards, rights-of-way, and parkways. The term "public place" shall mean all publicly owned buildings, grounds and parking lots and privately owned buildings, grounds and parking lots which are actually or customarily open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 11-137, § 1, 8-11-2011)  
Sec. 58-34. - No firearms or weapons inside village buildings. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person may possess, bring or cause any concealed or unconcealed firearm or weapon to be present in or upon any village owned, occupied or controlled building, structure or vehicle at any time. 
(1)  The prohibitions set forth in subsection (a), above, shall not apply to any active sworn law enforcement officers or arson investigators who are required to possess a handgun pursuant to enumerated job duties. 
(b)  Definitions. The following terms used in subsection (a) of this section shall have the following meanings: 
Building shall have the meaning set forth in this Code, specifically Appendix A (Zoning), Article XIV (Definitions) which includes the terms "structure" and "accessory building" as amended from time to time, to wit: "(a) structure designed or built for the support, enclosure, shelter, or protection of person, animals, chattel or property of any kind, and which is permanently affixed to the land. When any portion thereof is completely separated from every other portion by a party wall, then such portion shall be deemed to be a separate building." 
Law enforcement officer shall mean and include "police officer" and shall have the same meaning in Chapter 78 of this Code, specifically section 78-1 (Definitions) to wit: "every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic, or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations" as well as those sworn officers who are charged with the apprehension of criminals and the prevention and detection of crime and maintenance of public order including village police officers, village arson investigators, DuPage County Sheriff police officers, state patrol officers, other sworn state law enforcement officers, and sworn federal law enforcement agents. 
Structure shall have the meaning set forth in this Code, specifically Appendix A (Zoning), Article XIV (Definitions), as amended from time to time, to wit: "(a)nything constructed or erected, the use of which requires more or less permanent location on the ground or attached to something having a permanent location on the ground." 
Village shall mean the Village of Westmont, Illinois. 
(c)  Violations; penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall forfeit and pay to the village a penalty of not more than $75.00 and not to exceed $750.00 per weapon per incident, together with the costs of prosecution for each offense, and in default of the payment of such penalties, the violator shall be subject to the remedies available to a court of law for failure to pay imposed fines and penalties. In addition, the offending firearm(s) and/or weapon(s) shall be seized by the village police department and forever forfeited to the state. 
(Ord. No. 14-45, § 1, 3-6-2014)  
Secs. 58-3558-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH 
 
Sec. 58-51. - Heating of apartments. 
(a)  Any person who shall lease by oral or written agreement any building, apartment or room for business purposes, and who shall undertake in and by such agreement to furnish heat for the tenant or occupant, shall be subject to the terms of this section unless it is otherwise specifically excepted in and by such agreement. 
(b)  Between October 1 and May 1 of the following year, the minimum temperature which shall be maintained in any building, apartment or room shall be 68 degrees Fahrenheit, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to maintain any such premises or part thereof at a lesser temperature than specified in this section. All complaints shall be delivered to the economic development department, unless outside of normal business hours, and then to the police department. In the event of an emergency, residents should immediately contact the police department to complain about a violation of this section so that appropriate health and safety measures can be taken. 
(c)  Failure to furnish the heat required shall not constitute an offense where it is due to a breakdown of the heating plant, if diligence is used to have such a plant repaired, or where it is due to strikes, to a general shortage of fuel, to any act of the tenant who makes the complaint, or to any cause beyond the owner's control. For the purpose of determining whether or not the temperature is in accordance with the provisions in this section, the health officer shall cause temperature readings to be made by means of a standard Fahrenheit thermometer in two opposite parts of the room or apartment as near the extremes as practicable. Such thermometer is to be placed at a point not less than four feet and not more than six feet away from any door or window. Such temperature reading shall not be taken until either the code enforcement officer or a representative of the police department has taken a written complaint under oath from the complaining resident. 
(Code 1972, § 17-50; Ord. No. 99-08, § 1, 1-18-1999; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 08-116, § 1, 8-4-2008)  
Secs. 58-5258-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - GRAFFITI 
 
Sec. 58-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Graffiti means the inscription, drawing or otherwise placing upon any sidewalk, street or the surface of any structure or wall, whether publicly or privately owned, any word, phrase, diagram, symbol, sketch or letters wherein the content thereof is visible to any member of the general public, and contains, without limitation but merely as illustration, references to sexual activity or sexual organs, references to criminal activities or groups involved in criminal activity, swearing or fighting words, defamatory materials or words about any person, or references to relationships. 
(Code 1972, § 17-65(a)) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-132. - Prohibitions. 
Graffiti is declared a public nuisance and is prohibited in the Village of Westmont. 
(1)  Possession, sale and use regulations and prohibitions. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to inscribe, draw or otherwise place upon any sidewalk, street or the surface of any structure or wall, whether publicly or privately owned, any graffiti. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for the owner and/or occupant of fixed real or personal property which is in the public view to place or give permission to place any graffiti, as described in section 58-131, on such real or personal property, if such graffiti incites violence by reference to gang or criminal activity, depicts or expresses obscenity by referring to sexual activity or contains defamatory materials about a public or private person. 
c.  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess while in any public building or public facility, or on any public street or sidewalk, or while on private property, spray paint containers, paint, ink, marking pens which contain a nonwater-soluble fluid, brushes, applicator or other materials for marking, scratching or etching with the intent to use such materials to violate subsections a. or b. of this subsection. 
d.  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess within the village while upon or immediately adjacent to any public property or while in or upon private property without the consent of the owner, any paint in an aerosol spray paint container or any marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble and has a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface of 3/8 of an inch or greater. This prohibition shall not apply to: 
1.  A child using paint or a marker while under the immediate supervision of his or her legal guardian; 
2.  A student using paint or a marker while under the immediate supervision of his or her teacher or who is actively enrolled and attending a class which requires use of such implements, for which written permission from the school is in his or her possession; 
3.  An employee using paint or a marker at the direction and under the supervision of his or her employer. 
(2)  Exception. The provisions of this section shall not apply to federal, state or local government officials and employees, or to authorized public or private utility officials and employees, with respect to the posting or labeling of tags, notices, or other markings on buildings or other property while in the course of their employment or in the performance of their official duties. 
(3)  Sale to minors. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any retail business owner, employee or agent to sell, give or otherwise deliver any paint in an aerosol spray paint can or any marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble and has a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface of 3/8 of an inch or greater to any person under the age of 18 years. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any retail business owner, employee, or agent of a hardware store, as defined in chapter 22, to fail to display signage as required in section 22-202. Each day signage is not visible shall constitute a separate violation. 
c.  It shall be unlawful for any retail business owner, employee, or agent of a hardware store, as defined in chapter 22, to fail to require a photographic form of identification to be produced by each person purchasing paint in an aerosol spray paint can or any marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble and has a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface of 3/8 of an inch or greater establishing that such person is 18 years or older. 
(Code 1972, § 17-65(b); Ord. No. 11-159, § 1, 10-3-2011)  
Sec. 58-133. - Responsibility for removal. 
(a)  Owner. It shall be the duty of the owner of the sidewalk, street, structure or wall upon which any inscription or representation prohibited in section 58-132 to remove, eradicate or eliminate such inscription or representation within 14 days from the occurrence of the offense. If the owner has failed to eliminate such graffiti, the village shall notify the owner via certified mail or personal notice that he has an additional seven days to remove such graffiti. It is unlawful and constitutes a violation for any real property owner to permit property that is defaced with graffiti to remain defaced after 14 days from the date of the occurrence. Each day may constitute a new violation. 
(b)  Right of village to remove, invoice and lien owner. 
(1)  The village may remove graffiti from the exterior surfaces of private property if: 
a.  An owner informs the village of the presence of graffiti on the owner's property and the owner's inability to remove the graffiti; 
b.  Prepays the village for the cost of the removal; and 
c.  Signs a statement authorizing removal by the village and releasing and holding the village harmless from any claims or suits brought for damages resulting from any chemicals or from any actions taken by the village or its employees to remove the graffiti. 
(2)  The village may enter and remove graffiti from exterior surfaces of private property viewable from a public or quasi-public place if the owner of the real property permits, allows to remain or otherwise fails to remove such graffiti provided: 
a.  The village has given notice to the owner as described in subsection 58-133(a); and 
b.  The village requests in writing that the owner consent to the removal by the village and sign a release of the village from liability for damage; and 
c.  Either the owner has provided such consent or ten days have elapsed since the date of the written request for owner consent and the owner has failed to consent and/or remove the graffiti. 
(3)  If the village removes the graffiti as provided in subsection (2) above, the village shall invoice the owner of the property for all costs associated with the removal of the graffiti. It shall be unlawful for any owner of such property to fail to pay the village invoice when due. 
(4)  In addition, the costs of removal shall constitute a lien on the property. Upon the failure of the real property owner to pay graffiti removal costs, the village may file a lien with the DuPage County Recorder. Such lien may include costs of removal plus an additional administrative fee of not less than $50.00 nor more than $250.00 to cover general overhead, inspection expenses, location of and notice to owner, and incidental and related actions. Nine percent interest shall accrue per year on the unpaid amount, which interest shall begin to accrue 60 days after the cost is incurred. Such lien shall be in addition to and shall not constitute a waiver of any additional penalties, including but not limited to fines or restitution as may be available by law. 
(Code 1972, § 17-65(c); Ord. No. 11-159, § 1, 10-3-2011)  
Sec. 58-134. - Compensation, restitution and parental responsibility. 
(a)  Compensation and restitution. The owner of the property shall be entitled to restitution and compensation for the direct costs incurred in the repair and restoration of his property to its previous condition from any person convicted of the offense listed in section 58-132, provided that the property owner submits receipts or other evidence of the costs for the removal or repair of the graffiti and provided further that the court enters an order of restitution. 
(b)  Parental responsibility. 
(1)  The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have failed to exercise proper parental responsibility and such minor shall be deemed to have committed the acts described below with the knowledge and permission of the parent or guardian upon the occurrence of the following three events: 
a.  An unemancipated minor is adjudicated to be in violation of article III entitled graffiti or has incurred non-judicial sanctions from this or another official agency resulting from an admission of guilt in violation of graffiti laws or ordinances; and 
b.  The parent or legal guardian has received a written notice, either by certified mail or by personal service following said adjudication or nonjudicial sanction; and 
c.  If, at any time, within one year following receipt of the notice described above, the minor is adjudicated to be in violation of this article III entitled graffiti, or has incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another or this official agency resulting from an admission of guilt in violation of graffiti laws or ordinances. 
It shall be unlawful for a parent or legal guardian to allow an unemancipated minor to engage in acts in violation of article III entitled graffiti. Each parent and legal guardian shall be jointly and severally liable. 
(2)  If a minor fails to pay a fine, cost, compensation or restitution lawfully imposed upon him or her, the parents or legal guardians shall be jointly and severally liable for said fines, costs, compensation and restitution. 
(Code 1972, § 17-65(d); Ord. No. 11-159, § 1, 10-3-2011) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 11-159, § 1, adopted Oct. 3, 2011, amended § 58-134 title to read as herein set out. Former § 58-134 title pertained to compensation and restitution.  
Sec. 58-135. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Upon a finding of guilty for violation of section 58-132, there shall be imposed a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $750.00. Upon a finding of guilty of a violation of section 58-133, there shall be imposed a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $750.00. Additionally, the court may, as a condition of probation, supervision, or conditional discharge, require that the party guilty of violating the provisions of section 58-132 make full and complete restitution to the owner of the property for expenses incurred in the removal of the graffiti and/or restoration of the structure or wall to its previous condition. 
(Code 1972, § 17-65(e); Ord. No. 11-159, § 1, 10-3-2011)  
Secs. 58-13658-155. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CURFEW FOR MINORS 
 
Sec. 58-156. - Established; defenses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person 17 years of age and under to be or remain upon any street or alley or any public place in the village pursuant to the following restrictions: 
(1)  For persons 1317 years of age: 
a.  Between 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. SundayThursday; 
b.  Between 11:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. Friday, Saturday; 
(2)  For persons age 12 and under: 
a.  Between 8:30 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. SundayThursday; 
b.  Between 9:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. Friday, Saturday. 
(b)  The following are defenses to a charge under this chapter: 
(1)  The minor is accompanied by the child's parent, legal guardian, or responsible adult who is 21 years of age or older and who is authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of the minor (for purposes of this section, "responsible adult" means a person who does not meet the criteria to establish criminal street gang membership pursuant to the Law Enforcement Agency Data System and who has no criminal history of any kind for offense against a child or with a child victim); 
(2)  The minor is participating in, going directly to, or returning directly from any of the following: 
a.  Employment which the minor is authorized by federal or Illinois law to perform; 
b.  An activity sponsored by the minor's school; 
c.  A religious activity; 
d.  An emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage; 
e.  Any activity involving the exercise of the minor's rights protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution or Article 1, §§ 3, 4 and 5 of the constitution of the State of Illinois, or both; 
f.  Any activity conducted by a non-profit or governmental entity that provides recreation, education, training or other care under the supervision of one or more adults; 
g.  Married or has been married or is an emancipated minor under the Emancipation of Mature Minors Act, as amended; 
h.  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
i.  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop. 
(c)  Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public place. Based on any response and other circumstances, a citation for violation of subsection (a) may be issued or a juvenile may be detained by a police officer only if he reasonably believes that a violation has occurred and none of the defenses in subsection (b) are applicable. 
(Code 1972, § 17-37; Ord. No. 04-120, § 1, 6-8-2004; Ord. No. 11-160, § 1, 10-3-2011; Ord. No. 12-15, § 1, 2-6-2012)  
Sec. 58-157. - Permitting minors to violate curfew. 
It shall be unlawful for any person having the legal care and custody of children under 17 years of age, or any other person, to knowingly allow or permit such children to go or be upon any public street, alley or other place in the village in the nighttime, as restricted in section 58-156. 
(Code 1972, § 17-38; Ord. No. 04-120, § 2, 6-8-2004)  
Sec. 58-158. - Detention of minor for violation; notification of parent or guardian. 
Every member of the police force while on duty is hereby authorized to detain any minor wilfully violating the provisions of this article until the parent or guardian of the child shall take him into custody; but such officer shall immediately upon taking custody of the child communicate with the parent or guardian. 
(Code 1972, § 17-39)  
Sec. 58-159. - Proceedings to be instituted when minor is dependent or incorrigible. 
If it shall appear that any minor taken into custody for a violation of this article is incorrigible, or is wanting in proper parental care or has no home, proper proceedings shall be taken to have such child placed in the care of a state institution, as provided by state statute. 
(Code 1972, § 17-40)  
Sec. 58-160. - Parental responsibility. 
Any parent or legal guardian having custody or control of a minor person age 17 and under is subject to the provisions of this section. Any parent or legal guardian of such minor person who knowingly or willfully permits such child to violate the provisions of this section or any parent or legal guardian having custody or control of such minor person who fails to take reasonable steps to ensure compliance by such minor person with this section shall be fined in an amount not less than $25.00 nor more than $750.00. 
A rebuttable presumption shall exist that a parent or legal having custody or control of minor person has failed to take reasonable steps to ensure compliance with this section, upon such minor person committing a third or subsequent violation within the school year, following the parent or legal guardian having received two written notices of a violation of this section. The foregoing presumption may be overcome by clear and convincing evidence to the contrary. 
(Ord. No. 11-160, § 1, 10-3-2011)  
Secs. 58-16158-180. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 58-181. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the terms below have the following meanings: 
Legal guardian means a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the Juvenile Court Act or the Juvenile Court Act of 1987. [3] 
Minor means a person who is above the age of 11 years, but not yet 19 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 2(17-66), 9-18-1995)

Sec. 58-182. - Liability of parent or legal guardian for wilful or malicious acts of minor. 
The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian is liable for actual damages for the wilful or malicious acts of such minor which cause injury to a person or property, including damages caused by a minor who has been adjudicated a delinquent for violating section 21-1.3 of the Criminal Code of 1961. [4] 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 2(17-67), 9-18-1995)

Sec. 58-183. - Enforcement of liability. 
The village or any person, partnership, corporation, or association or any incorporated or unincorporated religious, educational or charitable organization is entitled to enforce the liability imposed by section 58-182. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 2(17-68), 9-18-1995)

Sec. 58-184. - Limitation on damages allowable; common law damages. 
(a)  No recovery under section 58-182 may exceed $1,000.00 actual damages for each person or legal entity as provided in section 58-183, for each occurrence of such wilful or malicious acts by the minor causing injury, in addition to taxable court costs. In determining the damages to be allowed in an action under sections 58-182 and 58-183 for personal injury, only medical, dental and hospital expenses and expenses for treatment by Christian Science practitioners, and nursing care appropriate thereto, may be considered. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not affect the recovery of damages in any other cause of action where the liability of the parent or legal guardian is predicated on a common law basis. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 2(17-69), 9-18-1995)

Section 12-107 of the Code of Civil Procedure, [5] as now or hereafter amended, is not applicable to judgments obtained under this article. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 2(17-70), 9-18-1995)
