ARTICLE VI. - PROHIBITION OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA AND RELATED TRANSACTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22; violation of drug paraphernalia laws by tobacco dealers, § 22-1268; health and sanitation, ch. 46. 
 
Sec. 58-210. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the following definitions shall apply: 
Cannabis has the meaning ascribed to it in section 3 of the Cannabis Control Act, 720 ILCS 550/3, as may be amended from time to time, as if that definition were incorporated in this article. 
Controlled substance has the meaning ascribed to it in section 102 of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, 720 ILCS 570/102, as may be amended from time to time, as if that definition were incorporated in this article. 
Deliver and delivery mean the actual, constructive or attempted transfer of possession, with or without consideration, whether or not there is an agency relationship. 
Drug paraphernalia means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are intended to be used unlawfully in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance in violation of the Cannabis Control Act, 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq., or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, 720 ILCS 570/100 et seq., as these statutes may be amended from time to time. It includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Kits intended to be used unlawfully in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing cannabis or a controlled substance; 
(2)  Isomerization devices intended to be used unlawfully in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis or a controlled substance; 
(3)  Testing equipment intended to be used unlawfully in a private home for identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of cannabis or controlled substances; 
(4)  Diluents and adulterants intended to be used unlawfully for cutting cannabis or a controlled substance by private persons; 
(5)  Objects intended to be used unlawfully in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body including, where applicable, the following items: 
a.  Water pipes; 
b.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
c.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
d.  Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; 
e.  Carburetor pipes; 
f.  Electric pipes; 
g.  Air-driven pipes; 
h.  Chillums; 
i.  Bongs; 
j.  Ice pipes or chillers; 
(6)  Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use in violation of this Act. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998; Ord. No. 04-01, § 1, 1-5-2004) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-211. - Sale or delivery prohibited. 
The following activities, generally referred to as the sale or delivery of drug paraphernalia, are illegal in the village: 
(1)  Keeping for sale, offering for sale, selling, or delivering for any commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia. 
(2)  Selling or delivering for any commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia to a person under 18 years of age. 
(3)  Selling or delivering for a commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia to a woman known by the seller or deliverer to be pregnant. 
(4)  Keeping for sale, offering for sale, selling, or delivering for any commercial consideration and [any] literature, photographs, drawings, designs, artwork, or other written or photographic material which instructs persons as to the use or manufacture of an item of drug paraphernalia. 
(5)  Knowingly possessing an item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis or a controlled substance into the human body, or in preparing cannabis or a controlled substance for that use. Factors to consider in determining a violation of this subsection (5) has occurred may be the proximity of the cannabis or controlled substances to drug paraphernalia, the presence of cannabis or a controlled substance on the drug paraphernalia, or the presence of cannabis, a controlled substance, or their derivatives in the person possessing the drug paraphernalia. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998)  
Sec. 58-212. - Exemptions. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Items marketed for use in the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other use of cannabis or a controlled substance as an incident to lawful research, teaching, or chemical analysis and not for sale; or 
(2)  Items marketed for or historically and customarily used in connection with the planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, or inhaling of tobacco or any other lawful substance. Items exempt under this subsection include, but are not limited to, garden hoes, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco pipes, and cigarette-rolling papers. 
(3)  Items listed in section 58-210 which are marketed for decorative purposes, when such items have been rendered completely inoperable or incapable of being used for any illicit purpose prohibited by this article. 
(b)  The following considerations, in addition to the marketing of an item and all other logically relevant factors, should be considered in determining whether or not a particular item is exempt under this section: 
(1)  The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved has been put; 
(2)  Expert evidence concerning the ordinary or customary use of the item and the effect of any peculiarity in the design or engineering of the device upon its functioning; 
(3)  Any written instructions accompanying the delivery of the item concerning the purposes or uses to which the item can or may be put; 
(4)  Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the time and place of sale or commercial delivery; 
(5)  Any national or local advertising concerning the design, purpose or use of the item involved, and the entire context in which such advertising occurs; 
(6)  The manner, place and circumstances in which the item was displayed for sale, as well as any items displayed for sale or otherwise exhibited upon the premises where the sale was made; 
(7)  Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products; and 
(8)  The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998)  
Sec. 58-213. - Penalties. 
Any person convicted of an offense noted in section 58-211 shall be guilty of a local offense for which the maximum fine permissible under state and local law for each such item shall be imposed. The attorney for the village is also authorized to seek mandatory imposition of hours of community service and other penalties as permitted by the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998)  
Sec. 58-214. - Declaration of nuisance; abatement. 
(a)  Generally. Any store, place, or premises from which or in which any item of drug paraphernalia is kept for sale, offered for sale, sold, or delivered for any commercial consideration is declared to be a public nuisance. The attorney for the village may commence an action in the circuit court, in the name of the village, to abate the public nuisance as described in this section. 
(b)  Temporary and preliminary relief. The attorney shall present affidavits or other sworn evidence that an alleged public nuisance exists and request that the court, without bond, enter a temporary restraining order to enjoin any defendant from maintaining the nuisance and that the court, without bond, enter a preliminary injunction restraining any defendant from removing or interfering with any property used in connection with the public nuisance. 
(c)  Permanent relief. If during the proceedings and hearings upon the merits the existence of the nuisance is established, and it is established that the nuisance was maintained with the intentional, knowing or reckless permission of the owner, or an agent of the owner managing the premises, the attorney shall ask the court to enter an order restraining all persons from maintaining or permitting the nuisance and from using the premises for a period of one year thereafter. 
(d)  Bond. If convicted of an offense under this article or ordered to abate a nuisance, an owner, lessee, or other occupant thereof may use the premises, notwithstanding subsection (c) of this section, if the owner gives bond with sufficient security or surety, in an amount between $5,000.00 and $10,000.00, approved by the court, payable to the village. The bond shall include a condition that no offense specified in this article shall be committed at, in, or upon the property described, and a condition that the principal obligor and surety assume responsibility for any fine, costs, or damages incurred by any person resulting from such an offense. 
(e)  Invalidity of leases. All leases or other arrangements providing a right of possession short of fee simple title to a person convicted of an offense under section 58-211 or ordered to abate the nuisance declared in section 58-214 are voidable by the owner of the premises due to the fact that the purpose of the lease was ostensibly to promote conduct which violates this article and the Criminal Code of the State of Illinois. 
(f)  Recovery of costs and expenses. The village may seek to recover all of its expenses, including but not limited to the costs of surveillance, court costs, and attorneys' fees, incurred in abating the nuisance declared in section 58-212 [58-214]. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998) 
Cross reference Nuisances, § 38-81 et seq.  
Sec. 58-215. - Forfeiture and seizure of property. 
(a)  All drug paraphernalia is subject to forfeiture. 
(b)  Property subject to forfeiture under this article may be seized by any peace officer upon process issued by any court having jurisdiction over the property. Judgments in favor of the village in a criminal or forfeiture proceeding based upon this article against a person's specific property shall serve as process authorizing a police officer to seize such property without further process. 
(c)  Seizure by a police officer may be made without process if: 
(1)  There is probable cause to believe that the property is directly dangerous to health or safety and existing circumstances do not allow reasonable time for the officer to obtain lawful process; or 
(2)  In accordance with the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure of 1963, 725 ILCS 5/101-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(d)  The presence of items which are deemed violative of this article or are otherwise subject to its forfeiture provisions in an inventory shall not subject the entire inventory to seizure or forfeiture. 
(e)  Property taken or detained under this section shall not be subject to replevin, but is deemed to be in the custody of the law enforcement department or agency employing the seizing officer, subject only to the order and judgments of the circuit court having jurisdiction over the forfeiture proceedings. When property is seized under this article, the chief of police may place the property under seal, or remove the property to a place designated by him. 
(f)  No disposition may be made of property under seal until the validity of the seizure has been determined in the circuit court, unless such court, upon application therefor, orders the sale of perishable substances and the deposit of the proceeds of the sale with the clerk of the court. The attorney for the village shall take the steps necessary to permit the circuit court to rule on the validity of the seizure within 30 days after the seizure, unless a continuance is obtained by a person from whom the items were seized or a person who otherwise has standing to complain, or by the village for good cause shown. The attorney for the village shall not request a continuance for the village pursuant to this subsection beyond 30 days. If judgment is entered in favor of the person from whom the property is seized, all seized property shall be returned immediately. Appeals from orders of the circuit court shall be heard in accordance with applicable state law and in the manner provided in the Drug Paraphernalia Control Act. Judgments in favor of the person entitled to possession of the subject property shall serve as a mandate to the agency holding the property to return the property forthwith. 
(g)  When property is forfeited, the chief of police may retain it for official use, or forward it to the another municipal law enforcement agency, the county, the state police, the bureau of narcotics and dangerous drugs, the United States Department of Justice, or their successor agencies, for use or disposition. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998)  
Sec. 58-216. - Recordkeeping. 
Every person who sells licensee [such items] must keep a record of every item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs which is sold, and this record shall be open to the inspection of any police officer at any time during the hours of business. Such record shall contain the name and address of the purchaser, the name and quantity of the product, the date and time of the sale, and the signature of the licensee or agent of the licensee. Such records shall be retained for not less than two years. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998)  
Sec. 58-217. - Inference of legitimacy. 
This article is intended to be used solely for the suppression of the commercial traffic in and possession of items that, within the context of the sale or offering for sale, or possession, are by a preponderance of the evidence marketed for the illegal and unlawful use of cannabis or controlled substances. To this end, all reasonable and common-sense inferences shall be drawn in favor of the legitimacy of any transaction or item. 
(Ord. No. 98-144, § 1, 12-7-1998)  
Secs. 58-21858-235. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - LASER POINTERS 
 
Sec. 58-236. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Laser pointer means any device that emits light amplified by the stimulated emission of radiation or other energy that is visible to the human eye. 
Public place means a place to which the public or a substantial group of persons has access, and includes but is not limited to any street, highway, sidewalk, right-of-way, parking lot, plaza, transportation facility, place of amusement, park, playground, assembly hall, hospital or clinic, restaurant and any hallway, lobby, and other portion of an apartment house or hotel not constituting a room or apartment designated for actual residence. 
School premises means the buildings, grounds, or facilities, or any portion thereof, owned, occupied by, or under the custody or control of public or private institutions for the primary purpose of providing educational or recreational instruction to students, and any vehicles owned, operated, or leased by or on behalf of such institutions that are used to transport such students or the personnel of such institutions. 
(Ord. No. 99-32, § 2(58-200), 4-5-1999) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-237. - Gift or sale to underage person. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to give, sell, or offer to sell or cause any person to give, sell, or offer to sell a laser pointer to any individual 18 years of age or younger. 
(Ord. No. 99-32, § 2(58-201), 4-5-1999)  
Sec. 58-238. - Proper display for sale. 
(a)  No person who sells or offers for sale laser pointers shall place such laser pointers on open display so that such laser pointers are accessible to the public without the assistance of such seller, or his employee or other agent, offering such laser pointers for sale, unless: 
(1)  Such laser pointers on open display are clearly and fully visible from a place of payment for goods or services or customer information at which such seller or an employee or other agent of such seller is usually present during hours when the public is invited; or 
(2)  Such laser pointers are in a package, box, or other container provided by the manufacturer, importer, or packager that is larger than 41 square inches. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to display laser pointers in any manner or to post a sign advertising the availability of laser pointers unless a notice has been posted, in a form and manner prescribed by the police department, indicating that the sale or giving of laser pointers to persons 18 years of age or younger is a municipal offense. 
(Ord. No. 99-32, § 2(58-202), 4-5-1999)  
Sec. 58-239. - Use and possession in public place and schools. 
It shall be unlawful for any person 18 years of age or younger to possess a laser pointer on school premises or while in a public place. It shall also be unlawful for any person to direct light emitted from a laser pointer into or through a public place or moving vehicle; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall preclude: 
(1)  The temporary transfer on school premises of a laser pointer to, or possession on school premises of a laser pointer by, a person 18 years of age or younger for a valid instructional, school-related, or employment purpose, where such laser pointer, is provided by the school and used under the supervision of a school staff person, other authorized instructor, employee, or employer's agent; 
(2)  The temporary transfer in a public place of a laser pointer from an employer to, or possession in a public place of an employer's laser pointer by, a person 18 years of age or younger, during such person's hours of employment, for a valid employment purpose, where such employer's laser pointer is used under the supervision of the employer or employer's agent; or 
(3)  The direction of light from a laser pointer into or through a public place by a person 19 years of age or older, during such person's hours of employment, for a valid employment purpose. 
(Ord. No. 99-32, § 2(58-203), 4-5-1999)  
Sec. 58-240. - Use against persons and uniformed officials. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to direct light from a laser pointer at any person in the village. Directing light from a laser pointer at a uniformed police officer, uniformed security guard, school crossing guard, agent, uniformed member of a paid or volunteer fire department, uniformed emergency medical service worker or uniformed ambulance worker, other uniformed village, state, or federal peace officer, investigator, or emergency service worker, the marked service vehicle of any such individual, or any such individual who is not in uniform but known by the person directing the light from the laser pointer to be such a person shall constitute an aggravated violation of this article justifying an increase in the fine from the applicable level to the next higher fine level. 
(Ord. No. 99-32, § 2(58-204), 4-5-1999)  
Sec. 58-241. - Defenses. 
It shall be a defense to a violation of section 58-239 if the person requires a laser pointer for a medical reason or for law enforcement or the purposes of performing the duties of a uniformed official noted in section 58-240. 
(Ord. No. 99-32, § 2(58-205), 4-5-1999)  
Sec. 58-242. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Authorized agents and employees of the police department shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this article. A person, whether in business or personally, who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to prosecution, suspension, or revocation of a business license, and fines as follows: 
(1)  Not more than $300.00 for the first violation; 
(2)  Not more than $500.00 for the second violation by the same person within a two-year period; and 
(3)  Not more than $750.00 for the third and all subsequent violations by the same person within a two-year period. 
(b)  For purposes of determining whether a violation of this article should be adjudicated as a second, third, or subsequent violation, violations of this article by the same person within a two-year period shall be aggregated. Each day of each violation shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. Fines under this section are subject to enhancement under section 58-240. 
(Ord. No. 99-32, § 2(58-206), 4-5-1999)  
ARTICLE VIII. - TRUANCY 
 
Sec. 58-243. - Truancy prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person 18 years of age or younger who is required by law to attend school and who is subject to the compulsory attendance requirements of the Illinois School Code and/or enrolled in a public, private (including a home school) or a parochial school residing within the Village of Westmont, DuPage County, to absent him or herself from attendance at school during the hours in which he or she is enrolled without prior parental or school permission, observance of a religious holiday and be present in any place other than school, during any time when school is in session during the regular school term. Any person who shall so absent him or herself shall be guilty of the offense of truancy and be subject to the penalties hereinafter set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-274, § 1, 11-21-2005); Ord. No. 14-51, § 1, 3-20-2014)  
Sec. 58-244. - Parental responsibilities. 
It shall be unlawful for a parent, legal guardian or other person to permit a person in his or her custody or control to commit the offense of truancy. 
(Ord. No. 05-274, § 1, 11-21-2005)  
Sec. 58-245. - Contributing to truancy. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any act of commission or omission which act or omission encourages or contributes to the truancy of any person. 
(Ord. No. 05-274, § 1, 11-21-2005)  
Sec. 58-246. - Defenses to truancy. 
Those defenses and/or exceptions as set forth in the Illinois School Code for compulsory attendance or enrollment in school shall apply as a defense to this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-274, § 1, 11-21-2005)  
Sec. 58-247. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person 13 years or older violating the truancy section of this article shall be sentenced to a fine not less than $75.00 and/or performing not less than ten hours community service hours for the first offense, not less than 20 hours community service hours for the second offense or more than 40 hours community service for each offense thereafter. 
(b)  Any person violating the parental responsibilities or the contributing to truancy sections of this article may be fined not less than $75.00 for a first offense, not less than $100.00 for a second offense or not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00 for each offense thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 05-274, § 1, 11-21-2005)  
Sec. 58-248. - Conflict. 
In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this article and the provisions of the Illinois School Code and/or the Juvenile Court Act of 1987, the provisions of the Illinois School Code and/or the Juvenile Court Act of 1987 shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 05-274, § 1, 11-21-2005)  
Secs. 58-24958-259. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, adopted Nov. 1, 2010, amended Art. IX in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. IX, §§ 58-26058-272, pertained to the same subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 08-128, § 1, 8-18-2008 and Ord. No. 09-14, § 1, 2-17-2009. 
 
Sec. 58-260. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Automated traffic law enforcement system means a device within the village with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a steady or flashing red signal indication in violation of section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code ("Code"), 625 ILCS 5/11-306, or similar violation of the Village Municipal Code. The interval for any light change shall conform with the Illinois Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices ("MUTCD") published by the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
Disregarding a traffic control signal means failure to stop and remain stopped before an intersection that is controlled by a red signal as provided for in section 11-306 of the Code. 
No turn on red means failure to stop and remain stopped, and not proceeding to turn right at, an intersection controlled by both a sign indicating "No turn on red," or other similar language, and a red signal as provided for in section 11-306 of the Code. 
Recorded images means images produced by the automated traffic law enforcement system, which consist of either two or more photographs; two or more microphotographs; two or more electronic images; or, a video recording showing the motor vehicle and, on at least one image or portion of the recording, clearly identifying the registration plate number of the motor vehicle. 
Traffic compliance administrator means the person appointed e by the chief of police and shall have the following additional powers: adopt, distribute and process automated traffic law violation notices and other notices required by this article, collect money paid as fines and penalties, operate the automated traffic law enforcement system, and make certified reports to the Secretary of State as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-260.1. - Applicable intersection(s). 
The following intersection(s) may be equipped with automated traffic law enforcement cameras: 
Cass Avenue and Naperville Road 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-261. - Violations. 
It shall be a violation of this article for a vehicle to disregard a traffic control signal or turn on red in violation of section 11-306 of the Code. All violations must be reviewed and approved by a law enforcement officer of the Village of Westmont. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-262. - Defenses. 
The following may be considered defenses by the hearing officer for a violation of section 58-261: 
(1)  That the motor vehicle or registration plates of the motor vehicle were stolen before the violation occurred, and not under the control of or in the possession of the owner at the time of the violation; 
(2)  That the driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the light was red either (i) in order to yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle or (ii) as part of a funeral procession. 
To demonstrate that the motor vehicle or the registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the control or possession of the owner at the time of the violation, the owner must submit proof that a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates was filed with a law enforcement agency in a timely manner. 
A violation notice shall not be issued in instances where the motor vehicle comes to a complete stop past a stop line or crosswalk so long as the motor vehicle does not enter the intersection during the cycle of red signal indication and so long as no pedestrians are present. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-263. - Notice of violation. 
When the automated traffic law enforcement system records a motor vehicle entering an intersection in violation of section 58-261, the village shall issue a written notice of violation to the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, which shall be delivered by U.S. mail within 30 days after the Illinois Secretary of State notifies the village of the identity of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, and in no event later than 90 days following the violation. The village shall only be required to notify a lessee if the leasing company/lessor provides the lessee's name by an affidavit and a copy of the lease within 60 days of the notice's issuance. If the driver information is not provided within 60 days, the leasing company/lessor may be found liable. If any notice to an address is returned as undeliverable, a second notice shall be sent to the last known address recorded in a United States Post Office approved database of the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle. The second notice shall be made by first class mail postage prepaid. 
A notice of violation associated with an automated traffic law violation shall require a review of the associated recorded image by the traffic compliance administrator, who shall inspect the image and determine whether the motor vehicle was being operated in violation of Section 14.261, or whether one of the defenses enumerated in section 58-262 is visibly applicable upon inspection. Upon determination that the recorded image captures a violation and that no defense applies, the notice of violation shall be served upon the registered vehicle owner in the manner provided for above. The traffic compliance administrator shall retain a copy of all violation notices, recorded images and other correspondence mailed to the owner of the vehicle. Each notice of violation shall constitute evidence of the facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation of the above-noted statutory and local provisions and shall be prima facie evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in this article. 
The notice of violation shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, as indicated by the records of the Secretary of State, or, if such information is outdated or unattainable, then the last known address recorded in a United States Post Office approved database; 
(2)  The make (only if discernable) and registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation; 
(3)  The violation charged; 
(4)  The location where the violation occurred; 
(5)  The date and time of the violation; 
(6)  A copy of the recorded images; 
(7)  The amount of the civil penalty and the date by which the penalty should be paid (14 days from the date of issuance), if a hearing is not requested, and a statement that the payment of the fine shall operate as a final disposition of the violation; 
(8)  A statement that a failure to pay the civil penalty by the date noted may result in an additional late fee being assessed against the owner or lessee; 
(9)  The amount of the late fee; 
(10)  A statement that the failure to pay by the date specified will result in a final determination of liability and may result in the suspension of driving privileges for the registered owner of the vehicle; 
(11)  A statement that the recorded images constitute prima facie evidence of a violation; 
(12)  A statement that the person may elect to proceed by paying the fine or challenging the charge in court, by mail or by administrative hearing; and 
(13)  A statement of how an administrative hearing may be requested. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-264. - Hearing. 
The owner of a vehicle being operated in violation of section 58-261 may request a hearing by the respond-by date on the notice of violation (14 days from the date of issuance), to challenge the evidence or set forth an applicable defense. The notice of violation shall constitute evidence of the facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation of section 58-261. The notice of violation shall be prima facie evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in section 58-262. 
The owner's failure to appear at the hearing will result in a finding of liability. In the event of a failure to appear, a "Findings, Decision and Order" letter will be sent to the owner. The owner's failure to pay the amount by the date specified in that letter will result in a final determination. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-265. - Nonresidents. 
Where the registered owner or lessee of the cited vehicle is not a resident of the village but seeks to contest the merits of the alleged violation, such person may contest the charges using the same available defenses as stated above, but rather than attend the administrative hearing, they may submit any and all documentary evidence to the traffic compliance administrator no later than the hearing date, together with a written statement reflecting that they are non-residents of the village. The traffic compliance administrator shall forward all timely-submitted materials to the hearing officer for review and determination. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-266. - Final determination. 
A final determination of an automated traffic law violation(s) liability shall occur: 
(1)  Following the failure to pay the total assessed fine or penalty after the hearing officer's determination of vehicular standing, parking, compliance regulation or automated traffic law violation(s) liability within the required 25 days and the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust any administrative review procedures hereinafter set forth, or 
(2)  Where a person fails to appear at a prior requested administrative hearing provided to contest the alleged standing, parking or compliance regulation violation(s) on the date and at the time and place specified in a prior served or mailed notice, or fails to appear at the hearing for an automated traffic law violation on the date and at the time and place specified in a prior mailed notice. The hearing officer's determination of vehicular standing, parking, compliance regulation or automated traffic law violation(s) liability shall become final upon the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust any administrative or judicial review procedures hereinafter set forth: 
a.  Upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or 
b.  Upon the expiration of the period for filing a petition without a filing having been made. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-267. - Notice of determination of liability. 
A determination of automated traffic law violation liability shall occur following failure to pay the fine or penalty, or to contest the alleged violation within 14 days of the notice of violation. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing to contest the alleged violation in the time and manner specified in a prior mailed notice, the hearing officer will enter findings, decision and order's determination of automated traffic law violation liability which shall become final: (a) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or (b) upon expiration of the period for filing such a petition without a filing having been made. If a person appears at a hearing and is found liable or contests the violation by mail and is found liable, the hearing officer will enter findings, decision and order, which is a final determination of automated traffic law violation liability that is a final, appealable order. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-268. - Notice of final determination. 
A notice of final determination shall be sent following the final determination of automated traffic law violation liability and the conclusion of judicial review. The notice of final determination shall include the following information: 
(1)  A statement that the unpaid fine is a debt due and owing to the village; 
(2)  A warning that a failure to pay any fine due and owing to the village within 14 days may result in a petition to the Circuit Court of DuPage County to have the unpaid fine rendered as a judgment or may result in the suspension of the person's driver's license for failure to pay fines or penalties for five or more violation under this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-269. - Petitions to set aside determination. 
A petition to set aside determination of an automated traffic law violation must be filed with or mailed to the traffic control administrator within 14 days of the date of mailing of the notice of determination of liability. The grounds for the petition are limited to: 
(1)  The person was not the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle on the date of the violation notice was issued; 
(2)  The person having already paid the fine for the violation in question; and 
(3)  Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing. 
Upon receipt of a timely petition to set aside the determination of liability, the hearing officer shall review the petition to determine if cause has been shown to set aside the determination. If cause has been shown, the village shall forward the petitioner a new hearing date on which the petitioner must appear to present his case. The village shall notify the petitioner of the hearing officer's decision to grant a hearing or deny the petition within 14 days of the village's receipt. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-270. - Notice of impending driver's license suspension. 
A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to the person liable for any fine or penalty that remains due and owing on five or more violations of this article. The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall state the following information: 
(1)  The failure to pay the fine owing within 45 days of the notice's date will result in the village notifying the Secretary of State that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under section 6-306.5 of the Code; 
(2)  A statement that the person may obtain a copy of the original ticket imposing a fine by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the village along with a request for the copy. 
The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the Secretary of State or, if any notice to that address is returned as undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States Post Office approved database. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-271. - Driver's license suspension. 
The traffic compliance administrator, by certified report, may request that the Secretary of State suspend the driving privileges of an owner of a registered vehicle who has failed to pay any fine or penalty due and owing as a result of five automated traffic violations. The report shall be certified and contain the following: 
(1)  The name, last known address as recorded with the Secretary of State, as provided by the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of lease, or as recorded in a United States Post Office approved database if any notice sent under this article is returned as undeliverable, and driver's license number of the person who failed to pay the fine or penalty and the registration number of any vehicle known to be registered to such person in a state; 
(2)  The name of the municipality making the report pursuant to this section; and 
(3)  A statement that a notice of impending driver's license suspension has been sent to the person named in the report at the address recorded with the Secretary of State or at the last address known to the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of the lease or, if any notice sent under this article is returned as undeliverable at the last known address recorded at a United States Post office approved database; the date on which such notice was sent; and address to which such notice was sent. 
The traffic compliance administrator shall notify the Secretary of State whenever a person named in the certified report has paid the previously recorded fine or penalty or whenever the municipality determines that the original report was in error. A certified copy of such notification shall also be given upon request and at no additional charge to the person named therein. 
Any person receiving notice from the Secretary of State that their driving privileges may be suspended at the end of a specified period may challenge the accuracy of the certified report prepared by the traffic compliance administrator. The person shall, within seven days after having received notice from the Secretary of State, request an opportunity to speak with the traffic compliance administrator to challenge the accuracy of the certified report. If the traffic compliance administrator determines that the original report was in error due to the fact that the person challenging the report was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle or that the person has already paid their fine for the five or more automated traffic violations, the traffic compliance administrator shall immediately notify the Secretary of State of such error in a subsequent certified report. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Sec. 58-272. - Penalty. 
Any person violating section 58-261 shall be fined $100.00 for each offense. Failure to pay the original fine within 14 days of the issuance of the notice of final determination shall result in an additional $100.00 late payment fine. 
(Ord. No. 10-183, § 1, 11-1-2010)  
Chapter 62 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 62-1. - Title. 
The comprehensive directives set out in this chapter shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the Personnel Policy Manual (the "policy manual") of the Village of Westmont (the "village"). 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
All words used in this chapter in the singular number shall extend to and include the plural. All words used in the plural shall extend to and include the singular. All words used in any gender shall extend to and include both genders. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board of fire and police commissioners rules. In the event of any conflict between the provisions of this manual and the provisions contained in the rules and regulations of the board of fire & police commissioners (BFPC), the BFPC rules and regulations shall control with respect to the employee in question. If an issue is not addressed in the rules and regulations, this manual shall control. 
Board or board of trustees means the governing and policymaking body of the village. 
Employee or at-will employee means a person who has been appointed to, and currently holds and performs the duties of, an employment position within the Village of Westmont. At-will employees are those employees who have been hired by the village, but are not subject to a contractual provision regarding their employment term or disciplinary process. At-will employees may be terminated at any time, with or without cause, by the Village of Westmont. 
(1)  Full-time employee means one whose regularly scheduled hours total 40 hours or more per week. In instances of furlough a full-time employee means one whose regularly scheduled hours total 39 hours or more per week. 
(2)  Part-time employee means one whose regularly scheduled hours total less than 40 hours per week. In instances of furlough a part-time employee means one whose regularly scheduled hours total less than 39 hours per week. 
(3)  Part-time fire department employee means one whose classification consists of part-time and/or paid-on-call fire department personnel (excluding fire inspectors, training officers, and administrative positions) whose regularly scheduled, required call back, and training hours do not exceed 106 hours per two week pay period or 2,756 hours annually. 
(4)  Temporary/seasonal employees hired for a specific period or project, not to exceed 1,000 hours per year. This category of employees is eligible only for legally mandated benefits and the Employee Assistance Program. 
Employee serving during a qualification period means a new, transferred or promoted employee who is serving an introductory period for a specific job, during which time such employee's performance is subject to close review by his/her supervisor. Qualification periods are further defined within this policy manual. 
Exempt status classification: An exempt employee means an employee who has been appointed to an executive, administrative, or professional employment position as from time to time designated by the village and as further defined by the Fair Labor Standards Act. A non-exempt employee means an employee who has been appointed to an employment position which is not an executive, administrative or professional employment position as from time to time designated by the village and as further defined by the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
Furlough hours means a 39 hour work week. Refer to section 62-104 for more information. 
Human resources director means the employee subordinate to and appointed by the village manager, whose responsibility it shall be to administer the personnel policy manual, subject to the administrative direction of the village manager. 
Immediate family. For the purposes the definition of "immediate family" as contained herein, no distinction shall be made between kindred of the whole and half-blood. Immediate family means a spouse, children and grandchildren and their spouses, parents and spouse's parents, stepparent, spouses' stepparent, persons in loco parentis and their spouses, brothers and sisters and their spouses, spouses' siblings and their spouses' grandparents and their spouses' grandparents. 
Union employee. In the event of any conflict between the provisions of this manual and the provisions contained in any collective bargaining agreement applicable to union employees, the collective bargaining agreement shall control with respect to the union employees in question. If an issue is not addressed in a collective bargaining agreement, this manual shall control. 
Village manager means the chief administrative officer of the village, appointed by the board of trustees. 
Village officer means those persons holding the following positions: Village clerk, village treasurer, village attorney, head of a village department or division, members of the planning and zoning commission, police pension board, board of fire and police commissioners (hereinafter, referred to as "fire and police commission"), library board and members of any permanent village commission as may be established. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 09-84, § 1, 6-1-2009; Ord. No. 10-98, § 1, 6-7-2010; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-21-2012; Ord. No. 14-163, § 1, 9-18-2014; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-3. - Basis of employment. 
Employment with the village shall be based on merit and fitness, free of personal and political considerations. Appointments, promotions and other actions requiring the application of the merit principle shall be based upon objective evaluation. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-4. - Tenure. 
Tenure of employees covered by this policy manual shall be subject to good behavior, the satisfactory performance of work, necessity for the performance of work and the availability of funds. Fair administration of the policy manual shall be the intent at all times; and every consideration of the rights and interests of employees, consistent with the best interests of the public and the village, shall be given. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-5. - Position classification plan. 
The village manager or designee shall prepare and maintain a complete and accurate inventory of all positions in the municipal service and accurate descriptions and specifications for each class of employment. Specifications are deemed to be illustrative and explanatory of the kind of work performed and not necessarily inclusive of all duties performed or required. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-6. - Compensation plan. 
The compensation plan shall be administered by the village manager and shall include the schedules of standard salary ranges consisting of minimum and maximum rates of pay and may include intermediate steps for all classes of positions included in the classification plan. The objectives of the compensation plan are to: 
(1)  Provide equal pay for positions of relatively equal complexity and responsibility. 
(2)  Provide pay ranges which are reasonably comparable to those paid by other governmental jurisdictions and private industries in the immediate area. 
(3)  Provide an orderly and consistent means of rewarding employees for good performance. 
(4)  Simplify and facilitate payroll administration, budgeting and other phases of fiscal and personnel administration. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Secs. 62-762-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE AND SCOPE 
 
Sec. 62-31. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this policy manual shall be to outline rules and regulations and to define the respective rights, duties and obligations concerning wages, hours, benefits, work rules and other conditions of employment for the village and its employees. In the formulation of this policy, the village board of trustees recognizes that the village is a creature of the State of Illinois (the "state") and that employee rules and regulations must conform to the statutes of the state and to the ordinances of the village. Within this framework, the village board of trustees must be in final control. Subject to these conditions, the board of trustees can establish governing principles upon which a progressive program of employee relationships may be based. To achieve these ends, this policy manual sets forth regulations and standards to: 
(1)  Establish a system of personnel administration based upon merit and equitable administration. 
(2)  Establish and maintain a uniform and equitable plan of position classification and compensation based on duties and responsibilities of positions in the village service. 
(3)  Develop a personnel program that will make a career in municipal government attractive to persons who possess the ability, integrity and dedication to public service. 
(4)  Provide a plan for continuing growth and education of the municipal employee that will provide the competence and initiative required for effective performance, equitable compensation and public respect. 
(5)  Outline rules of conduct and procedure to be followed by employees that will result in effective performance and morale. 
(6)  Authorize the village manager or designee to develop interpretative rules, regulations and manuals based upon the policy manual. Such rules, regulations and manuals shall be developed for the sole purpose of providing more detailed and clearer guidance and explanation of the policies set forth in this chapter. If the village manager shall determine that the interpretative rules, regulations and manuals cannot reasonably be developed to explain village policies, the village manager shall recommend to the village board an amendment to this chapter. All interpretative rules, regulations and manuals developed by the village manager or his designee shall be approved by the village board. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-32. - Scope. 
This policy manual shall apply to all officers and employees of the village, except the president, members of the board of trustees and members of boards and commissions appointed by the president and board of trustees, and the village clerk. In the event that any of the provisions of this policy manual conflict with the laws of the State of Illinois or the United States Government, the latter shall take precedence. In the event that this policy manual shall conflict with any contractual provision(s) contained within village collective bargaining agreements, any outside rules, regulations, policies and procedures pertaining to those employees subject to village collective bargaining agreements, fire department rules and regulations, general orders and special orders adopted by the village board, or any other contractual provisions with employees, the latter shall control unless otherwise specified herein. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Secs. 62-3362-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EMPLOYMENT 
 
Sec. 62-56. - Recruitment. 
Upon separation of an employee from the village, the appropriate department head shall notify the village manager that a vacancy exists. Upon determination by the village manager that the vacancy is to be filled, the human resource director, upon notification, shall commence recruitment, as outlined within this section except for police officers who are governed by the fire and police commission. 
Before externally advertising a vacancy, the human resources director and the village manager, in consultation with the appropriate department head and/or division head, shall determine whether or not potential qualified internal candidates for a vacancy exist. If there are qualified candidates, section 62-56 of this policy manual should be followed as best possible to fill the vacancy. In cases where the village manager and human resources director determine that it is in the best interest of the village to utilize a staffing agency, such an agency may be utilized. With the assistance of legal counsel, the village manager and human resources director are authorized to execute agreements and related documents with such staffing agencies to fill such vacancies with temporary contract personnel or temporary contract-to-hire personnel. 
(1)  Advertising. The human resources director may advertise for qualified applicants by posting notices in all village departments and by submitting advertisements to publications distributed in the appropriate labor market. The advertisements or notice may include: 
a.  Position title; 
b.  Position qualifications; 
c.  Position salary range; and 
d.  Last date on which applications will be accepted. 
(2)  Qualifications. Qualifications for positions shall be based on job descriptions prepared and maintained by the human resources director. If the position is a newly created one, the human resources director shall prepare a job description after consultation with the appropriate department head and the village manager. 
(3)  Interviews. The human resources director may conduct interviews using an appropriate interview team ("interview team"). The interview team may vary based upon the position at issue, and may be comprised of the human resources director, the appropriate department head, and any other person(s) from the department at issue as may be appropriate. The interview team shall conduct personal interviews with those applicants whose backgrounds best fit the position qualifications. The human resources director along with any other employees or outside services as determined necessary, shall verify applicant information in a manner in accordance with all applicable federal, state and municipal laws, administrative orders and progressive personnel practice. 
(4)  Selection. Selection of new employees shall be on the basis of competitive or competency examinations, where required by state statute, village ordinance or administrative order. In the absence of such a requirement, new employees shall be selected on the basis of pertinent experience, skill, training and education. The human resources director and the interview team shall select the applicant best suited to the position and most able to serve the needs of the village. The position shall be offered to the selected applicant after approval by the village manager. 
(5)  Orientation . A new employee shall receive an orientation by appropriate staff and their respective department at the time of hire or shortly thereafter. Orientations generally include an overview of village organization, rules and regulations, benefits and general procedures. Each department is responsible for orienting new employees to departmental guidelines and procedures specific or unique to their department. If any employee feels the need for additional information during the orientation process or thereafter, he/she is encouraged to seek such information from their department head. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 11-81, § 1, 5-16-2011; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-57. - Appointments. 
Appointments to all positions within the village service shall be made on the basis of merit, which shall be determined by evaluation of the applicant's: 
(1)  Skill, training, education, experience and physical fitness (where relevant); 
(2)  Oral interview; 
(3)  Whenever practical, an examination or demonstration test; and 
(4)  Any other reasonable standard not prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-58. - Age. 
The minimum age for employment as a village employee shall be 18 years of age. The minimum age for employment as a village temporary employee shall be 16 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-59. - Residency. 
Except as provided otherwise within this policy manual, applicants for positions within the village need not reside within DuPage County or in a county contiguous to DuPage County at the time of application. However, as a condition of employment with the village, all employees must reside in DuPage County or in a county contiguous to DuPage County as of satisfactory completion of the qualification period. If an employee violates the residency requirements as set forth in this section, this action will be considered an automatic resignation from village employment. 
The village manager may approve an extension of time to fulfill the residency requirement beyond the date of satisfactory completion of the qualification period. The village board may waive the residency requirement for any employee upon written request by such employee, the recommendation of the village manager, and a showing of good cause to waive the residency requirement. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-60. - Qualification period. 
All appointments to village service shall be subject to a qualification period, which shall be for a minimum of twelve months, unless a department head requests an extension of the qualification period. The period of extension, if any, is not to exceed two such extensions, and must be approved by the village manager after consultation with the human resources director. During the qualification period, an employee's performance may be subject to review every 30 days as to competency in executing and completing assignments, general work attitude, and any other reasonable factors which the village determines to be necessary; except for probationary police officers and telecommunicators whose performance will be subject to review daily. At the completion of the qualification period, the appropriate department head and village manager will make a determination regarding the acceptance of the employee for a position with the village. 
During an employee's qualification period, the employee may be dismissed, with or without cause, at the discretion of the appropriate department head, with the concurrence of the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-61. - Reserved.  
Sec. 62-62. - Qualification period for police officers. 
Notwithstanding any other provision in this policy manual, all police officers accepting original appointment and appointed to the village police department shall be serving a qualification period of 18 months duration. No officer serving a qualification period shall have his or her qualification period extended. During any officer's qualification period, the board may dismiss an officer with or without cause upon recommendation of the chief of police. At the satisfactory completion of an officer's qualification period, he or she shall be considered an at-will employed police officer of the village. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-63. - New employee registration and record maintenance. 
Information required for payroll, pension, insurance or other personnel purposes shall be supplied in a manner designated by the village manager or designee. 
Employees have the responsibility to notify the human resources director in writing of the following changes: Name, address, phone number, marital status, family status, beneficiaries, and emergency contact, and when applicable, may need to provide supporting documentation. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, adopted Jan. 4, 2018, amended § 62-63 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "New employee registration" to "New employee registration and record maintenance," as set out herein.  
Sec. 62-64. - Physical examination. 
New employees shall undergo a post-employment offer physical examination, at village expense, by a physician designated by the village. Employees may be required to submit evidence of a physical check-up, chest x-ray, tuberculin test or any other tests, as permitted by law and as determined reasonable by the village. The expense for these examinations, if required by the village or otherwise mandated, shall be paid for by the village. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-65. - Promotion policies. 
All vacancies occurring in the village service shall, whenever possible, be filled by promotion of a qualified employee within the village service. However, the village manager may authorize recruitment of applicants from outside the village service whenever he has reason to believe that better qualified applicants are available outside of the village. Promotion within the village shall be based on the qualifications of the person being appointed. Usually, the first consideration in the filling of vacancies will be given to the most qualified applicant in the department in which the vacancy exists. Next, consideration will be given to the most qualified applicant from outside the department. The criteria used in the selection of the most qualified applicant shall be based upon experience, performance, evaluation and, where feasible, examination. 
If no acceptable applicant is found among the village employees, the vacancy will be filled from outside the village service. Transfer between departments within the same position classification will be considered when a vacancy occurs, but first preference will be given to promotion within the department. 
Police department supervisory promotions are administered by the fire and police commission. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-66. - Outside employment. 
No employee shall accept outside employment, whether full-time, part-time, temporary or permanent, without prior written approval from the village manager. Each employee who wishes to engage in outside employment shall notify the village manager in writing through his or her department head. Such notification shall carry the following information: 
(1)  The name of the employee; 
(2)  The name of the prospective employer; 
(3)  The nature of the outside work; and 
(4)  The schedule of the outside work. 
Each and every change in outside employment shall require separate approval. Approval shall not be granted when such outside employment conflicts or interferes, or is likely to conflict or interfere, with the employee's position within the village. No employee shall engage in or accept private employment or render any service for private interest when such employment or service is incompatible or creates a conflict of interest with his or her official duties within the village. Employees of the village may not engage in outside business activities while on normal duty, nor on village property at any time whatsoever. 
In a situation where the village manager has approved outside employment, the village manager may thereafter prohibit the outside employment at any time if, in his judgment, such employment might or has become detrimental to the best interests of the village. In such cases, the employee will be given an appropriate notice and then must decide if he wants to continue his service with the village, or with the outside employer. 
Upon review and approval of the village manager individual departments may impose more restrictive guidelines for outside employment as deemed appropriate and necessary. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-67. - Employment of relatives. 
It shall be the policy of the village not to employ immediate family members of any person on the village board or any village board appointed boards and commissions, in any full-time position. With respect to other village employees, no such immediate family member shall be employed by the village in any capacity unless such person is otherwise qualified and meets all requirements for such employment. It shall also be the policy of the village to not allow two or more relatives to work in the same department/division in circumstances where one relative occupies a position that supervises the other relative or has influence involving the relative's employment, promotion, supervision, salary advancement, or other personnel decisions; the only exception being temporary seasonal employment. The same prohibitions apply to employees who marry, cohabitate, or become related by marriage. If immediate family members of such village employees are employed as permitted by this section, they shall, in all cases, be treated the same as any other employee in a comparable position for purposes of wages, benefits paid, and work evaluations. 
The provisions of this section shall not be retroactive, and no action is to be taken concerning those members of the same family employed at the time of adoption of this section. This section shall not be construed nor applied to discriminate on the basis of marital status. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-68. - Political activity. 
Employees shall not be appointed or retained within the village on the basis of their political activity. Employees shall not be coerced to take part in political campaigns, to solicit votes, to levy, contribute or solicit funds or support for the purpose of supporting or opposing the appointment or election of candidates for any municipal office. Employees are encouraged to exercise their individual right to vote. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-69. - Seeking public office. 
No village employee shall seek election to public office of the village without first having obtained an unpaid leave of absence from his position in the village service. Such leave of absence shall continue until after the election takes place. Upon taking the oath of village office, the leave shall automatically cease and the employee shall be deemed to have forfeited his or her position as a village employee. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-70. - Solicitation and distribution. 
To eliminate interference with the work and promote the productivity of village employees, it is necessary to maintain orderly conditions on village property and work areas. Rules regarding solicitation and/or distribution of materials by employees are as follows: 
(1)  Employees are prohibited from soliciting and/or distributing non-work related materials or literature during the working time of any employee involved in the solicitation, distribution and/or receipt of said materials. 
(2)  Employees are prohibited from distributing non-work related materials or literature at any time in the nonpublic work areas of the village. 
(3)  Non-employees are prohibited from soliciting and/or distributing materials or literature during the working time of any employee involved in the solicitation, distribution and/or receipt of such materials, at any time in the nonpublic work areas of the village. 
(4)  Employees and non-employees are prohibited from posting non-work related materials or literature on village property, including but not limited to bulletin boards. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-71. - Standards of dress-groom-personal hygiene. 
(a)  Introduction. Each employee's dress, grooming, and personal hygiene shall be appropriate to the work situation. Employees are expected at all times to present a professional, businesslike appearance to customers and the public. A professional image means wearing clothing that is clean, neat and with no holes or fraying. Without compromising the professional image the village seeks to portray, the village also wishes to allow employees to dress comfortably. Employees are expected to be well groomed and dressed as described below. Standards of dress may be adopted on a departmental basis. 
(b)  Appearance standards. 
(1)  Uniformed employees. Employees required to wear a standardized uniform shall follow the particular standards established in their respective departments related to acceptable and required uniform attire including any required safety related equipment and clothing. When permitted by department policy, if a typically uniformed employee is allowed to wear non-uniform attire when performing job tasks, the employee shall follow the standards established for non-uniformed employees. 
(2)  Non-uniformed employees. Employees not required to wear a uniform are required to follow a business or business casual standard (except on Casual Friday). The village defines business casual as the following: 
Slacks (dress, khakis, corduroy); skirts, dresses, skorts, shirts (collared, turtlenecks, polo), blouses, sweaters, blazers, sport coats; shoes (loafers, leather boat/deck shoes, dress shoes, dress boots, dress sandals, and open toed shoes). 
(3)  Unacceptable clothing/accessories. The following is a list of clothing/accessory items that are not allowed and shall not be worn. While this list provides a broad range, it is not all inclusive, and, at any time, a department head may deem attire unacceptable that is not listed below: 
a.  Sweat suits, sweat pants, sweat shirts, wind suits (except as provided by the village); 
b.  Leggings, jumpsuits or form-fitting stretch pants; 
c.  Shorts or short skirts (more than three inches above knees); 
d.  Tank tops, t-shirts, halter tops, spaghetti straps, low cut tops or tops with a low neckline; 
e.  Any type of shirt with an objectionable logo or slogan; 
f.  Beachwear or bib overalls; 
g.  Athletic shoes, flip flops, hiking sandals; 
h.  Torn or frayed clothing; 
i.  Visible undergarments; 
j.  Jeans of any color (except on designated casual days)**; 
k.  Men's work boots or shoes with lugged soles**; 
l.  Objectionable tattoos; 
m.  Body piercing (except limited ear piercing); 
n.  Hats (except as provided by the village or approved by department head). 
** Exceptions: It is understandable that employees doing field, maintenance, or custodial work may be wearing jeans/work pants and work boots through the week. 
The village permits employees to wear jewelry, display tattoos, or limited ear piercing at the workplace within the following guidelines. Factors that management will consider in determining whether jewelry, tattoos, or ear piercing may pose a conflict with the employee's job or work environment include: 
1.  Personal safety of self or others, or damage to village property. 
2.  Productivity or performance expectations. 
3.  Offensiveness to co-workers, customers, vendors, or others in the workplace based on racial, sexual, religious, ethnic, or other characteristics or attributes of a sensitive or legally protected nature. 
4.  Corporate or societal norms. 
5.  Customer complaints. 
If management determines an employee's jewelry, tattoos, or ear piercings may present such a conflict, the employee will be encouraged to identify appropriate options, such as removal of excess or offensive jewelry or piercings, covering of tattoos, or other reasonable means to resolve the conflict. 
(c)  Casual dress day. Casual dress day will be on Fridays. Although the dress code is relaxed, clothing will not detract from the professional image of the department. Jeans, if worn, will be clean and of good quality and repair (no holes or fraying). Apparel such as sweat/wind suits, t-shirts, shorts, exercise pants and jogging suits are not allowed for casual days. 
(d)  Enforcement. Department heads are responsible for monitoring the appearance of their respective employees. The determination as to what is acceptable appearance shall be made by the department head. If a department head determines that an employee is not in compliance with the village's standards for appropriate workplace appearance, the employee may be sent home (without pay unless an employee is permitted to use accrued benefit time) to charge. Progressive disciplinary action may be taken for repeated violations of this policy. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 10-86, § 1, 5-17-2010; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 10-86, § 1, adopted May 17, 2010, amended § 62-71 title to read as herein set out. Former § 62-71 title pertained to standards of dress.  
Sec. 62-72. - Equal opportunity in employment. 
The village is firmly committed to equality of opportunity in employment. It is the responsibility of the village to ensure that employment, training, compensation, promotion and other conditions of employment are provided without regard to race, color, religion, sex (including pregnancy and related medical conditions), sexual orientation, national origin, ancestry, age, genetic information, marital or parental status, military status, unfavorable discharge from military service, (except dishonorable discharge), and mental or physical disability unrelated to the employee's ability to perform the job, except where it is determined to be a bona fide occupational qualification in accordance with federal, state, and local laws. It is also the responsibility of the village to ensure that it does not deny equality of opportunity to any qualified individual who is able, with or without reasonable accommodation, to perform the essential functions of the employment position which he or she holds or for which he or she applies. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-73. - Sexual harassment. 
The village shall provide employees an employment environment free of unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct or communications constituting sexual harassment, as defined and otherwise prohibited by state and federal law. The village will not tolerate sexual harassment of any of its employees and will take immediate steps to investigate and stop it when it occurs. The village has created a policy entitled "sexual harassment" ("sexual harassment policy") which explains the rules and procedures pertaining to sexual harassment in the workplace. All village employees and elected officials are required to read, abide by, and acknowledge receipt of the sexual harassment policy upon employment and as may be required thereafter. 
Additionally, all village employees must attend an annual training session on this sexual harassment policy, as provided or approved by the village. 
(1)  Definition of sexual harassment. Village employees shall not make sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal, written, or physical conduct of a sexual nature when: 
a.  Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of the individual's employment; 
b.  Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for an employment decision affecting that individual (tangible employment action); or 
c.  Such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment. 
d.  For purposes of this definition, the phrase "working environment" is not limited to a physical location an employee is assigned to perform his or her duties and does not require an employment relationship. 
The terms intimidating, hostile or offensive include, but are not limited to, conduct which has the effect of humiliation, embarrassment or discomfort. Sexual harassment may include, but is not limited to: 
a.  Physical assaults of a sexual nature, including but not limited to rape, sexual battery, molestation, intentional physical conduct which is sexual in nature, such as touching, pinching, patting, grabbing, etc.; 
b.  Unwanted sexual advances, propositions, or other sexual comments including, but not limited to sexually oriented gestures, noises, remarks, jokes or comments or verbal abuse of a sexual nature. Also included are preferential treatment and promises of a preferential treatment to an employee for submitting to sexual conduct; 
c.  Sexual or discriminatory displays or publications anywhere in village workplace by village employees including, but not limited to, pictures, posters, calendars, graffiti, objects, reading materials, or other materials that are sexually suggestive, demeaning or pornographic. 
Sexual harassment may involve individuals of the same or different gender. Sexual harassment often is associated with those situations in which a power differential exists between the persons involved, but it also can occur between individuals of the same employment status. Sexual harassment includes conduct based on gender regardless of whether the offensive conduct is sexual in nature. 
d.  Electronic harassment such as sexting, the use of sexually explicit language, cyber stalking and threats via all forms of electronic communication, i.e. e-mail, text, picture, video messages, intranet, online postings, blogs, instant messages, and social network websites like Facebook and Twitter. 
(2)  Reporting of sexual harassment. Employees are encouraged to report any incidents of sexual harassment to their immediate supervisor and to the human resources director. Employees may also choose to report incidents of sexual harassment to any number of persons who will be designated annually on a list distributed annually and posted by the village manager's office. 
In addition, employees may file a report of harassment in accordance with the standard grievance procedure as specified in this policy manual. Personnel subject to the jurisdiction of the fire and police commission may file complaints of harassment in accordance with the board's established rules and regulations. 
Anyone receiving a report of harassment must promptly notify the human resources director, unless it would be inappropriate to do so, given the fact that the human resources director or someone closely connected to the human resources director is involved in the alleged harassment. 
(3)  Employee responsibility. All persons at the village can help assure that our workplace is free from prohibited sexual harassment. Every employee is expected to avoid any behavior or conduct that could reasonably be interpreted as sexual harassment. No employees, not even the highest-ranking village employees, are exempt from the requirements of the sexual harassment policy.
