(4)  Investigation and corrective action. If you believe you have been subjected to sexual harassment, you have the right to file a complaint. Once notified of a complaint, the human resources director (or someone else, where appropriate) will investigate the report promptly, thoroughly, and, to the extent possible, confidentially. The fact that the complainant may not wish to cooperate does not relieve the village of the responsibility to investigate harassment reports. If investigation confirms that a violation of the sexual harassment policy has occurred, the village will take corrective action, including discipline, up to and including termination of employment, as is appropriate. procedures and rights under the established rules and regulations of the board of police and fire commissioners will be followed during any investigation or disciplinary action where applicable. All other applicable rights guaranteed by law will be followed during any investigation or disciplinary action. The village may discipline an employee for any inappropriate conduct discovered in investigating reports made under the sexual harassment policy, regardless of whether the conduct amounts to a violation of law or even a violation of policy. 
a.  Any person who violates section 5-65 of Public Act 100-0554 is subject to a fine of up to $5,000.00 per offense, and is subject of discipline or discharge by the appropriate ultimate jurisdictional authority (as described above). Each violation of section 5-65 is a separate offense. Any penalty imposed by an ethics commission of the state shall be separate and distinct from any fines or penalties imposed by a court of law or state or federal agency. 
(5)  False complaints. Employees who in bad-faith make a false complaint of harassment will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. 
Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of Public Act 100-0554 to an ethics commission, an inspector general, the state police, a state's attorney, the attorney general, or any other law enforcement official is guilty of a class A misdemeanor. 
An ethics commission may levy an administrative fine of up to $5,000.00 against any person who intentionally makes a false, frivolous or bad faith allegation. 
(6)  Confidentiality. Complaints of harassment, investigation of complaints of harassment, and any corrective actions taken in response to harassment will be kept confidential to the extent possible. 
(7)  No retaliation. The village prohibits reprisal or retaliation against an employee for filing a good-faith complaint of harassment or for supporting or assisting in good-faith another employee in pursuing a complaint. For the purposes of this policy, retaliatory action means a reprimand, discharge, suspension, demotion denial of promotion or transfer, or change in the terms or conditions of employment taken in retaliation for an employee's involvement in protected activity pursuant to this policy. Employees are afforded protections pursuant to the Whistleblower Act (740 ILCS 174/15(a)-(b)) and the Illinois Human Rights Act (775 ILCS 5/6-101). Employees must report incidents of retaliation on the same basis as they are to report incidents of harassment. 
(8)  State and federal remedies. The purpose of this policy is to establish prompt, thorough, and effective procedures for responding to every report and incident so that problems can be identified and remedied by the village. Consistent with the sexual harassment policy, the village maintains posters on bulletin boards that refer to legal definitions of harassment. These posters identify governmental agencies to contact on how and when to file administrative claims. In addition to using the village complaint process an employee has the right to contact the Illinois Department of Human Rights (IDHR) or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) for information regarding filing a formal complaint with those entities. An IDHR complaint must be filed within 180 days of the alleged incident(s) unless it is a continuing offense. The time period for an EEOC filing is 300 days from the harassment. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006, § 2, 1-4-2018; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-74. - Discrimination and harassment. 
(a)  Definition. The village shall provide employees an employment environment free from unlawful discrimination and/or harassment based on race, color, religion, national origin, age, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, or physical or mental disability. The village will not tolerate discrimination and/or harassment of any kind by any of its employees. The village will implement steps to stop the discrimination when it occurs. 
Village employees shall not engage in any conduct constituting discrimination and/or harassment of any kind on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, age, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, or physical or mental disability. Discrimination is any hostile or offensive act or expression against a person on the grounds of his or her race, color, religion, national origin, age, gender, sexual orientation, marital status or disability. Harassment is conduct, verbal or physical, towards another person or identifiable groups of persons that has the purpose or effect of: 
(1)  Creating an intimidating or hostile work environment; 
(2)  Unreasonably interfering with a person's work environment; 
(3)  Unreasonably affecting a person's work opportunities; or 
(4)  Causing an individual to feel intimidated, demeaned or abused. 
Harassment can take many forms. It may include display or circulation of written materials degrading to a person's gender, race, ethnicity or religion. It may include verbal abuse or insults directed at or made in the presence of members of a racial, ethnic, religious or minority group. 
(b)  Violation of policy. A violation of this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment with the village. 
(c)  False complaints. Any person making a knowingly false accusation regarding discrimination and/or harassment pursuant to this section will likewise be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment with the village. 
(d)  Reporting of discrimination/harassment. Employees are encouraged to report any incidents of discrimination and/or harassment to their immediate supervisor and to the human resources director. Employees may also choose to report incidents of discrimination and/or harassment to any number of persons who will be designated annually on a list distributed annually and posted by the village manager's office. 
In addition, employees may file a report of discrimination and/or harassment in accordance with the standard grievance procedure as specified in this policy manual. Personnel subject to the jurisdiction of the fire and police commission may file complaints of discrimination and/or harassment in accordance with the board's established rules and regulations. 
Anyone receiving a report of discrimination and/or harassment must promptly notify the human resources director, unless it would be inappropriate to do so, given the fact that the human resources director or someone closely connected to the human resources director is involved in the alleged discrimination and/or harassment. 
(e)  Investigation and corrective action. Once notified of a report of harassment, the human resources director (or someone else, where appropriate) will investigate the report promptly, thoroughly, and, to the extent possible, confidentially. The fact that the complainant may not wish to cooperate does not relieve the village of the responsibility to investigate the reports. If investigation confirms that a violation of this policy has occurred, the village will take corrective action, including discipline, up to and including termination of employment, as is appropriate. Procedures and rights under the established rules and regulations of the board of police and fire commissioners will be followed during any investigation or disciplinary action where applicable. All other applicable rights guaranteed by law will be followed during any investigation or disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-75. - Drug-free workplace. 
The Village of Westmont is committed to maintaining a drug-free workplace in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. In order to protect the public, ensure a safe work environment and provide a healthy, productive workforce, the village requires compliance with the following procedures and guidelines: 
(1)  The village prohibits the unlawful use, consumption, manufacturing, dispensing, distribution, or possession of a controlled substance or alcohol while on village premises, in village vehicles, or while performing work for the village. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, a controlled substance includes: 
Cannabis; 
a.  Any substance that is not legally obtainable; 
b.  Any substance that is being used in a manner different than prescribed; 
c.  Any substance that is legally obtainable, but has not been legally obtained; 
d.  Any substance that is defined as such by any state or federal law, rule or regulation. 
(3)  Any employee found using, possessing, manufacturing, distributing or dispensing a controlled substance or alcoholic beverage on village premises or in village vehicles, while performing work for the village, or being under the influence of a controlled substance or alcoholic beverage while performing work for the village, shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination from employment. Such disciplinary action may include the completion of an appropriate rehabilitation program as a condition of reinstatement or continued employment with the village. 
(4)  The village may require employees to submit to appropriate alcohol and/or drug testing, including but not limited to urinalysis and/or blood testing, prior to hiring, promotion, or subsequent to any on-the-job injury or accident. The village may also require testing whenever there is reasonable suspicion of controlled substance or alcohol abuse by an employee. The results of any drug and/or alcohol testing shall be sent to the human resources director, but shall remain confidential to the extent required by law. Refusal to submit to such testing or failure to pass such testing shall be cause for disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. 
(5)  Any employee who is involved in an accident while operating a village owned or leased vehicle, will be subject to post-accident testing. Testing will take place immediately following the incident, when practical. If not completed immediately, the test must be taken within 24 hours following such incident. The employee shall consume no alcohol or controlled substances subsequent to the accident and prior to the post-accident test. Failure to complete a test within the allotted times will be considered by the village as the employee having refused to submit to testing. 
Post-accident testing will take place when one or more of the following conditions exist: 
a.  The employee has been issued a citation. 
b.  The accident results in a fatality, or the transport of one or more patients to a medical facility or if a person is injured, is treated but signs a refusal. 
c.  The accident results in one or more motor vehicles incurring disabling damage, requiring the vehicle(s) to be transported away from the scene by a tow truck or other vehicle. 
d.  Immediately following an accident, the police officer, or a department supervisor notices that the employee involved in the accident demonstrates impaired movements or speech, or they have any reasonable suspicion of improper controlled substance or alcohol use. When an employee is requested to immediately go for an alcohol and/or drug test following an incident, he or she shall be accompanied by a supervisor. 
(6)  When the lab finds an employee's results to be negative, no other action is taken and the results are recorded as negative. All negative results will be reported back to the human resource director within three calendar days of such test. 
(7)  If the results of an employee's alcohol and/or drug test are positive, no immediate results or notifications are made until the medical review physician from Midwest Orthopaedics reviews those results. Contact will be made with the employee in order to make a judgment of why these results were positive. If they are prescribed drugs, contact will be made with the employee's physician to insure that these were prescribed drugs. In some cases retesting may be necessary but only with direction from the medical review physician. This person will determine the time frame when another test is appropriate. 
a.  Results shall be transmitted to the human resource director for the village, or designee, in a confidential manner, and in writing. 
b.  When results are forwarded to the village, only a report of a positive or negative result will be sent. No reports with actual readings will be sent. This clearance will become part of the employee's medical record. In the case of a positive alcohol result, the result may be revealed. No employee will be allowed to report for duty with a positive alcohol reading. A violation of this policy will be considered to have occurred if the alcohol level is greater than .04 as determined by whichever testing method was used. Please note: An individual department's lower alcohol level supersedes the level in this policy. 
c.  Any employee found to test positive with an alcohol concentration of .02 or greater, but less than .04, will be sent home without pay, until the start of the employee's next regularly scheduled duty period, but not less than twenty-four hours following administration of the test. 
(8)  Any employee convicted of a criminal controlled substance or alcohol- related offense involving the workplace shall notify his or her supervisor in the village within five calendar days of the conviction. The village will notify any applicable contracting agency within ten calendar days of receiving such notice from the employee or other actual notice of the conviction. 
(9)  The village utilizes an ongoing drug education program which cautions employees about the dangers of controlled substance and alcohol abuse generally and in the workplace. The village will assist an employee in utilizing the Employee Assistance Program (EAP). The EAP personnel are qualified professionals who will make confidential assessment and referral for services and treatment for controlled substance and alcohol abuse, as well as other personal problems. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 16-031, § 2, 2-18-2016)  
Sec. 62-76. - Workplace violence. 
The village is committed to providing, as much as reasonably possible, a safe environment for working and conducting business. The village will not tolerate acts of violence committed by or against village employees, or members of the public, while on village property or while performing village business at other locations. 
Acts of violence include, but are not limited to, acts or behaviors that: 
 Are physically assaultive; 
 A reasonable person would perceive as obsessively directed, e.g. intensely focused on a grudge, grievance, or romantic interest in another person, and reasonably likely to result in harm or threats of harm to persons or property; 
 Consists of a communicated or reasonably perceived threat to harm another individual or in any way endanger the safety of an individual; 
 Would be interpreted by a reasonable person as carrying potential for physical harm to the individual; 
 Is a behavior, or action, that a reasonable person would perceive as menacing; 
 Involves carrying or displaying weapons, destroying property, or throwing objects in a manner reasonably perceived to be threatening; or 
 Consists of a communicated or reasonably perceived threat to destroy property. 
The village has created a workplace violence policy which describes in detail the policy's goals and objectives, the prohibitions on dangerous weapons by employees, employee responsibilities, procedures for dealing with acts of violence in the workplace, and procedures for investigations and reporting of incidents. Village employees are required to read, comply with, and acknowledge receipt of the workplace violence policy, which is provided at the commencement of employment and also available through human resources. Discipline for violation of the workplace violence policy may include disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. 
In order to prevent workplace violence, the village adopted a "no weapons policy" which specifically prohibits the possession of firearms by any employee while upon or inside [any] village building or vehicle. This ban specifically excludes sworn village police officers and arson investigators. No village employee shall carry, store, possess or bring any concealed weapon into any village building or vehicle. Any village employee who violates this prohibition is subject to discipline, up to and including termination. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 14-44, § 1, 3-6-2014)  
Sec. 62-77. - Information technology. 
Recent advances in electronic communications and information technologies present valuable opportunities for the village. These technologies, when properly used, support our business activities and enable us to better serve our customers and residents through closer and timelier communications and nearly instantaneous access to vast stores of information. In recognition of these benefits, the village has made a substantial investment in upgrading and maintaining its electronic communications and information systems. While the village encourages the use of its systems, such use carries with it important responsibilities. The careless or inappropriate use of these systems can have dramatic consequences, including harm to the village, our customers, our residents and the individual users of village systems. 
The village has created a computer use policy and an e-mail and electronic communication policy which govern the use of technology by village employees. Employees are required to read, comply with, and acknowledge receipt of these policies, which are available at the commencement of employment and at any time thereafter through human resources. 
The computer use policy and the e-mail and electronic communication policy are intended to minimize the likelihood of harm caused by electronic communications by educating users as to proper and improper usage of information technology, and by setting forth the conditions that apply whenever the village's electronic communications tools are being used. Usage guidelines for communications tools include those pertaining to conditions of access, acceptable use, unacceptable content, transmitting confidential information, etiquette and employer representation, limits of privacy and viruses. Discipline for misuse of any village communications tools or other violations of village policies may include disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. 
Many employees work in positions where innovations, improvements, inventions, discoveries, copyrightable work, or new ideas may be developed or conceived in the course of their employment. If these creative works are developed on village time or created through the use of village equipment and facilities, the employee is obligated to disclose these works and agree to assign all rights, title, and interest to the village, provided that they: 
 Relate directly to the business of the village. 
 Result from the employee's work with the village; or 
 Involve the use of village equipment, supplies, facilities, confidential information or time. 
The employee has no obligation to assign rights to creative works developed on their own time, without the use of village equipment, supplies, facilities, confidential information, or time. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-78. - No weapons policy. 
(a)  Purpose. The village strives to maintain a safe workplace environment for its employees and visitors. Workplace safety is enhanced by adopting this "no weapons" policy. 
(b)  Applicability. This policy applies to (a) all officials, employees, consultants, agents, and others who work for or with the village at all times while on or in village property, whether on duty or off duty, except as provided for in subsection (e), Exceptions, below, (b) contractors and vendors, and their personnel, when engaged in work for or business with the village, and (c) all clients, guests, and other persons who are not workplace staff. See the definitions of "village property," "visitor," and "workplace staff" under subsection (c), Definitions, below. 
(c)  Definitions. 
Tools means hammers, saws, loppers, axes, hatchets, staple suns, chains, rakes, and other devices commonly recognized as tools useful for village purposes, when being used for village purposes or kept in their usual storage location. 
Village property means every building and property, or portion of a building or property, owned or leased by or otherwise under the control of, the village. "Village property" also means, every village owned or leased vehicle. Further, "village property" also includes any location, building or property where a village-permitted special event is located. This includes, but is not limited to, permitted special events such as fairs, parades, open-air markets, car shows and public gatherings. 
Visitor means every person other than a workplace staff member, as described in phrase (c) under subsection (b), Applicability, above. 
Weapon means: 
  Knives, except that the following knives are not prohibited: common kitchen knives such as dinner knives, steak knives, and carving knives, but only in kitchen and break room areas. 
  Devices from which a projectile can be fired, but not including tools as defined in this policy. 
  Electronic devices such as conducted electrical weapons, stun guns, and tasers. 
  Firearms of all types and sizes, whether loaded or unloaded. 
  Machine guns, rifles, shotguns and paintball guns, of all types and sizes, whether loaded or unloaded. 
  Clubs and any other instrument or object that can be used in a club-like manner and the presence of which poses a reasonable risk to others, but not including tools as defined in this policy. 
  Any device designed primarily for a destructive purpose, but not including tools as defined in this policy. 
Workplace staff means everyone described in phrases (a) and (b) of subsection (b), Applicability, above. 
(d)  Weapons prohibited. 
(1)  Workplace staff. Except as provided under subsection (e), Exceptions, below, no workplace staff may wear, carry, store, transport, or otherwise possess a weapon at any time in or on village property or while performing any duties for or on behalf of the village. 
Examples of prohibited times and places include, but are not limited to, the following: 
  Performing work for the village at any location including private residences and commercial establishments and other customer or client locations; 
  Driving or riding as a passenger in a village vehicle; 
  Attending conferences or training on behalf of the village; 
  Attending village directed, permitted or sponsored activities or events (intended for village employees only and not the general public) independent of venue; 
  Riding any type of mass transit while on village business; 
  Working off-site on behalf of the village (excluding the employee's residence); and 
  Performing emergency or on-call work for the village after normal business hours and on weekends. 
(2)  Visitors. Except as provided; under subsection (e), Exceptions, below, no visitor may wear, carry, store, transport, or otherwise possess a weapon in or on village property at any time (see subsection (e)(3), Parking lots, below for further information). 
(3)  Use of private vehicle. No village employee, may use a privately-owned vehicle for village business if that vehicle contains a firearm of any type or size, whether loaded or unloaded. 
(e)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Police officers and other designated personnel. Village police officers and other village employees who have been specifically designated by the chief of police or his designee may possess their work-authorized weapons. Police officers or similar law enforcement officers from other departments or agencies may possess their work-authorized weapons while engaged in official duties. Arson investigators may possess their work-authorized weapons while engaged conducting an arson investigation. 
(2)  Governmental. A state or federal government employee may possess his or her work-authorized weapons if engaged in official duties and required by law or regulation to possess a weapon. 
(3)  Parking lots. A workplace staff member or visitor may keep a weapon in his or her personal vehicle properly parked and locked in a village parking lot or parking area, so long as the weapon is kept (1) in compliance with all applicable federal and state laws and regulations; (2) entirely out of sight; and (3) if a firearm, so long as the workplace staff member or visitor is properly licensed and the firearm is unloaded before exiting the vehicle and locked in a glove box, trunk, or other secured container. 
(f)  Inspections. Village representatives may inspect or search any workplace area and any village property, at any time, for the presence of a weapon. 
(g)  Violations. Any violation of this policy by a workplace staff member will subject the workplace staff member to discipline, up to and including termination. 
Any violation of this policy by a visitor will subject the visitor to removal from village property, prohibition from returning to any village property, and arrest. 
(h)  Concealed carrying prohibited. Any property or building that is controlled by the village is a "prohibited area" under Section 65 of the Illinois Firearms Concealed Carry Act and thus, concealed carrying in or on any village property or building under the control of the village is not authorized by state law. Accordingly, and in all events, concealed carrying is not an exception to this policy. 
(i)  Responsibility. All village employees shall have the responsibility of familiarizing themselves with this policy and adhering to it. 
Any workplace staff member who sees or perceives a violation of this policy must report that violation to his or her department head or, in the department head's absence, to the village manager or, in an emergency, to the police department. 
No person should take any action that will risk his or her safety or the safety of others. No person should attempt to restrain or forcibly evict an individual with a weapon from village premises. Instead, a person may inform that individual of this policy and ask for compliance. 
If that individual does not comply, then the person should contact the police department immediately. 
(Ord. No. 14-44, § 2, 3-6-2014)  
Sec. 62-79. - Social media use policy. 
(a)  Policy introduction and purpose. This policy is meant to address the evolving Internet medium as an integral form of both business and social communications, by creating awareness among village employees of the related opportunities and risks associated with its use. The village recognizes that employees have the right to express themselves online, and this policy is not meant to create arbitrary rules for social media usage, or curtail constitutionally protected free speech. 
As an employer, however, it is appropriate to establish codes of conduct and reasonable expectations that should be applied to such communication activities when those expressions may have consequences to the Village of Westmont, its employees and/or the community that Village of Westmont employees represent. Positions funded by taxpayer dollars are subject to greater scrutiny, and therefore must be held to higher standards of behavior, than those in private sector organizations. The global accessibility of Internet communication makes representations related to the Village of Westmont even more important to monitor and protect. 
"Social media" (a/k/a social networking) is defined as: any website or medium (including video) that allows for interactive communication in the open with Internet users. Social media includes all types of postings on the internet, including but not limited to, social networking sites (i.e. Facebook, LinkedIn, Google+, etc.), blogs and other online journals or diaries, bulletin boards and chat rooms, microblogging (i.e. Twitter, etc.,), posting on video sharing sites (i.e. YouTube, etc.,) or photo management and sharing sites (i.e. Flickr, etc.) and posting on a personal profile or website. 
(b)  Rules and guidelines . 
(1)  General rules and guidelines . The following rules and guidelines apply to the use of social media, whether such use is for the Village of Westmont on Village time, for personal use during non-work time, outside the workplace or during working time while using village-owned equipment. (Using the Village of Westmont's equipment to access social media sites for personal use is also governed by the Electronic Communications and Record Retention Policy. Employees should also refer to this policy before accessing such sites via the village's equipment.) These rules and guidelines apply to all employees. 
a.  Employees must obtain advance permission and approval of content from the village before using social media for Village of Westmont business purposes. Employees granted permission to use social media outlets for village business purposes are responsible for complying with this policy and applicable federal, state, and county laws, regulations, and policies. This includes adherence to established laws and policies regarding copyright or plagiarism, records retention, Freedom of Information Act/FOIA, First Amendment, privacy, information security policies, and protocols established by the village. 
b.  Wherever appropriate, links to more information should direct users back to the village's official website for more information, forms, documents, or online services necessary to conduct business with the village. 
c.  Employees representing the village via social media outlets must identify themselves as village employees and conduct themselves at all times as representatives of the Village of Westmont. 
d.  Employees who fail to conduct themselves in a professional manner, and/or who are found in noncompliance with any personnel manual policies, administrative protocols, and department rules and regulations, will be subject to the corrective action procedures found in the personnel manual. 
e.  Employees are prohibited from discussing confidential, work-related matters are not limited to, security procedures, information technology systems and passwords, strategic plans, unapproved draft documents, documents and communications protected by attorney-client privilege, sensitive financial information, customer lists, and other proprietary, non-public information. Employees also have a duty to protect employees', vendors', and the public's home addresses and other personal information. 
f.  Employees cannot use social media to harass, threaten, libel or slander, malign, defame or disparage, or discriminate against co-workers, managers, customers, clients, vendors, elected officials, village administration, suppliers, any organizations associated or doing business with the Village of Westmont, or any members of the public, including web site visitors who post comments. The village's anti-harassment and EEO policies apply to use of social media in the workplace. 
g.  Employees with permission to use social media for village business purposes shall do so during their normal scheduled work week. Employees shall not use social media for village business purposes during off-duty hours without advance permission from their department supervisor. 
This protocol is not intended, nor shall it be applied, to restrict employees from discussing their wages, hours and working conditions with co-workers. 
(2)  Personal use of social media . The following rules and guidelines, in addition to the rules and guidelines set forth in section (1) above, apply to employee use of social media on the employee's personal time. 
a.  Employees should abide by the Village of Westmont's Electronic Communications and Record Retention Policy concerning personal use of the Village's computer and related equipment. 
b.  Employees who utilize social media and choose to identify themselves as employees of the Village of Westmont must make it clear that they are not speaking on behalf of the village. Employees are strongly encouraged to state explicitly, clearly, and in a prominent place on the site that their views are their own and not those of the Village of Westmont or of any person or organization affiliated or doing business with the Village of Westmont. 
c.  Employees may not use the Village of Westmont's logo, equipment or the name, or trademarks of any business partner, supplier, vendor, affiliate, or subsidiary on any personal blogs or other online sites unless their use is sponsored or otherwise sanctioned, approved, or maintained by the Village of Westmont. 
d.  Employees may not post the Village of Westmont's logo, image or confidential information or village-issued documents or equipment bearing the Village of Westmont's name or logo. 
e.  Employees may not post photographs of work-related events, accident scenes, crime scenes, other employees or village employees engaged in the Village of Westmont's business, events, or village products [e.g. clothing, hats] unless employees have received the Village of Westmont's explicit permission. Any photographs that appear on the Village of Westmont's official website, social media sites, or other official releases, may be reposted by employees without requiring advance permission. 
f.  Employees cannot advertise or sell village-owned products or services through social media unless employees have received the Village of Westmont's explicit permission. 
(3)  Employee conduct. Employees are reminded that if it comes to the village's attention that an employee's private communications on any social media site are inconsistent with this policy, other policies, rules and protocol of the village, and their employment obligations with the village, their conduct may be considered by the village in any evaluation or other employment action. Employees should have no expectation of privacy while using village equipment and facilities for any purpose, including the use of social media. The Village of Westmont reserves the right to monitor and review the use of the village's IT systems and to block content that violates this policy, and any Village of Westmont's rules and guidelines. 
All Village social media sites are subject to the Illinois Local Records Act, the Freedom of Information Act, and e-discovery laws and therefore, content must be able to be managed, stored and retrieved to comply with these laws. 
(4)  Protocols and procedures regarding official village use of social media . The village manager and the Westmont Public Information Officer are authorized to create a document of protocols and procedures regarding official use of social media which will supplement this policy. This policy is subject to such protocols and procedures. The protocols and procedures, which will relate to content and style of village-approved messages, must be followed by any employee authorized to post on social media as an official representative of the village. 
(5)  Violations . The village will investigate and respond to all reports of violations of this policy and other village rules and guidelines. Employees are urged to report any violations of this policy to human resources. A violation of this policy may result in discipline up to and including termination of employment. 
(Ord. No. 16-032, § 2, 2-18-2016)  
Sec. 62-80. - Dual village employment policy. 
No full-time employee is eligible for hire in another full-time or part-time employment position with the village. A part-time employee is eligible for hire in another part-time employment position within the village. 
(Ord. No. 16-030, § 2, 2-18-2016)  
Sec. 62-81. - Workplace search policy. 
All offices, desks, computers, telephones, files, lockers, equipment, vehicles, etc. are the property of the village and are issued for the use of employees for business purposes only during their employment with the village. An employee has no reasonable expectation of privacy when using village-owned vehicles, property or equipment. In this connection, the Village of Westmont reserves the right to inspect or search an employee's office, desk, computer(s), emails, voicemail, files, locker, vehicle. etc. or any other area on the village premises, or property brought onto village premises by an employee and used for business purposes, to the extent permitted by law. Personal property which is not a fixture of the worksite (such as a purse, briefcase, or lunch box) may be searched upon permission of the employee or for cause as part of an investigation, generally with the cooperation of law enforcement personnel. An inspection or search will typically be conducted based upon a reasonable suspicion of employee misconduct or criminal activity or for work-related purposes. The village may conduct an inspection or search at any time, with or without notice, at the discretion of the village. Inspectors or searches shall be conducted by village supervisors and/or their designees. The village reserves the right to seize all drugs, paraphernalia, weapons, or other contraband found on the village's premises and may turn over such evidence to the appropriate authorities. An employee who fails or refuses to comply with this policy may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including discharge. The acceptance of, or continued employment with this policy, constitutes consent to all of the provisions of this search policy. 
(Ord. No. 16-169, § 1, 10-13-2016)  
Sec. 62-82. - Workplace bullying. 
The village defines workplace bullying as repeated inappropriate behavior, either direct or indirect, whether verbal, physical or otherwise, conducted by one or more persons against another or others, at the place of work and/or in the course of employment. Such behavior violates the village's conduct policy, which clearly states that all employees will be treated with courtesy and respect. 
The purpose of this policy is to communicate to all employees that the village will not tolerate bullying behavior. Employees found in violation of this policy will be disciplined up to and including termination. 
Bullying may be intentional or unintentional. However, it must be noted that where an allegation of bullying is made, the intention of the alleged bully is irrelevant and will not be given consideration when meting out discipline. As with sexual harassment, it is the effect of the behavior upon the individual that is important. 
The village considers the following types of behavior examples of bullying: 
(1)  Verbal bullying : Slandering, ridiculing or maligning a person or his/her family; persistent name calling that is hurtful, insulting or humiliating; using a person as the butt of jokes; abusive and offensive remarks. 
(2)  Physical bullying : Pushing, shoving, kicking, poking, tripping, assault or threat of physical assault; damage to a person's work area or property. 
(3)  Gesture bullying : Nonverbal threatening gestures or glances that convey threatening messages. 
(4)  Exclusion : Socially or physically excluding or disregarding a person in work-related activities. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-83. - Americans with Disability Act policy. 
The village maintains an equal opportunity policy ("EEO Policy") for all applicants and employees. To supplement the village's EEO Policy and in response to the Americans With Disabilities Act, the village has adopted this additional policy statement regarding discrimination against the disabled. Equal employment opportunity for the disabled (and all other protected classes) is one of the village's goals and it is expected that all employees shall assist in furthering this goal. 
The village gives fair consideration to all qualified individuals with disabilities and affords all employees and applicants opportunities for advancement according to their individual abilities without regard to disability. No opportunity for hire, advancement, or any other condition of employment will be diminished through discriminatory practices. In accordance with the law, the village will also reasonably accommodate qualified individuals with disabilities. 
If an employee believes that he/she has been discriminated against or harassed in violation of this policy, or if he/she is a qualified individual with a disability who would like to request a reasonable accommodation, please contact the human resources director immediately. Because each individual is different, the village will discuss the particular situation the employee and undertake an investigation of the specific circumstances involved. The village's goal will be to take action which will provide equal employment opportunity for individuals with disabilities so long as they can perform the essential functions of their respective position. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Secs. 62-8462-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS 
 
Sec. 62-91. - Pay policy. 
Compensation shall be governed by the salary ranges established for the particular position assigned. The village shall endeavor to make such compensation equitable and competitive with similar jurisdictions and positions. 
(1)  All full-time employees shall be paid at an annual rate computed to hours on the basis of 2,080 hours per year. During the 2012-2013 fiscal year, however, from May 1, 2012 through April 30, 2013, full-time employees shall be paid at an annual rate computed to hours on the basis of 2,028 hours per year. 
(2)  Employees shall be paid biweekly on every other Friday. The two-week work period shall be considered to begin on the Monday prior to payday. 
(3)  Salary increases shall be as budgeted, warranted and recommended by the applicable department head. 
(4)  At the discretion of the village, employees appointed to full-time employment after satisfactory completion of the qualification period may receive a salary increase from their salary during the qualification period. 
(5)  Longevity increase. A one percent (1%) longevity raise will be given to all full-time village employees after each five (5) consecutive years of service. Longevity ceases to accrue when an employee's status shifts to part-time status; however, in the event a part-time employee subsequently returns to full-time status, longevity will resume from the date the employee left full-time status and went to part-time status. Similarly, if an employee leaves village employment in a full-time position due to a lay-off, and subsequently returns to full-time status, the employee's longevity will resume from the date the employee was separated due to lay-off. Longevity will not resume in situations where an employee voluntarily resigns or retires from employment with the village or is terminated for any other reason than lay-off should the employee return to the village in a full-time capacity. 
(6)  The village shall pay all employee compensation (excluding expense reimbursement) via electronic fund transfer (a/k/a direct deposit) to each employee's personal bank account at a banking institution of the employee's choice. Each employee shall timely provide the village with required information necessary for the village to effectuate said electronic fund transfer of compensation. 
(7)  Automatic payroll deductions are made for federal and state income tax purposes and for employee's pension contributions and social security, where applicable. Other authorized deductions, as approved by the village manager, may also be arranged for at the employee's request in accordance with the Illinois Wage Payment and Collection Act, 820 ILCS 115/9. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 09-84, § 1, 6-1-2009; Ord. No. 10-35, § 1, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 10-98, § 1, 6-7-2010; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-21-2012; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-92. - Hours of work. 
The standard workweek for all full-time non-exempt employees shall be five days and 40 hours, except from May 1, 2012 through April 30, 2013, when the number of hours shall be reduced to 39. Exempt employees are required to work those hours necessary to assure the satisfactory performance of their duties within their departments, but not less than 40 hours per week, except from May 1, 2012 through April 30, 2013, when the number of hours shall be reduced to 39. Supervisory exempt employees shall assign to each supervised employee regular work duties and responsibilities which can normally be accomplished within the established workday and workweek. However, occasionally some overtime work may be necessary for proper performance of work duties and responsibilities. For exempt employees, such overtime is considered part of their job responsibility and does not justify overtime pay. 
Regular hours of work shall be as follows: 
(1)  Fire department. Hours of work for employees of the fire department, excluding the fire chief, shall be established at the discretion of the fire chief. 
(2)  Police department. Hours of work for employees of the police department, excluding the chief of police, shall be established at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(3)  Public works department. Hours of work for employees of the public works department, excluding the public works director, shall be established at the discretion of the public works director. 
(4)  Additional furlough time. Any department or division may implement additional voluntary furlough time for full-time employees with approval of the department head and village manager, without loss of eligibility for full-time benefits. 
(5)  Meeting attendance. Meeting attendance outside regularly scheduled hours of work may be required at the discretion of the village manager. 
(6)  Hours of duty. A minimum of eight hours of duty on five consecutive days in a calendar week to be interrupted each day by an unpaid meal period of not less than one-half hour beginning no later than five hours after the start of the duty period. The scheduling of the hours of duty shall be as determined by the department head. During the 2012-2013 fiscal year, however, from May 1, 2012 through April 30, 2013, the hours of duty shall comprise a minimum of eight hours of duty on four days and a minimum of seven hours of duty one day in a calendar week. 
(7)  Rest breaks. Employees shall be permitted two 15 minute rest breaks during the normal workday, the time of which shall be scheduled and designated by the heads of the various departments. Alternatively, at the discretion of the applicable department head, the two 15 minute rest breaks may be combined with the half hour unpaid meal period to provide the employee a one hour meal period (half hour unpaid). 
(8)  Habitual tardiness. Employees who are late more than twice in any four week period, measured backwards from the last incident of tardiness, or employees who are habitually late on a continuous basis, shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination. Each department may implement a more restrictive policy with respect to tardiness issues. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 08-186, §§ 1, 2, 12-1-2008; Ord. No. 09-84, § 1, 6-1-2009; Ord. No. 10-98, § 1, 6-7-2010; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-21-2012; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-93. - Overtime. 
Except as provided in section 62-92 and in any applicable collective bargaining agreements, the following will apply to overtime. 
(1)  Scheduled overtime. All scheduled overtime for non-exempt employees must be approved by the respective department head and authorized by the village manager. 
(2)  Emergency overtime. If a non-exempt employee receives notice of the need to work emergency overtime less than 12 hours before the time the duty is to commence, the employee shall be paid at the rate of time and one-half for hours so worked outside his or her scheduled workday (a minimum of two hours), plus one additional hour ("bonus pay") at the rate of time and one-half. Bonus pay will be paid only once in each 24-hour period. Bonus pay will not be paid for a continuation of less than two hours past the employee's scheduled work dismissal hour. 
(3)  Forty-hour rule. All non-exempt employees whose scheduled workweek is of at least 40 hours per week (except from May 1, 2012 through April 30, 2013, the scheduled workweek is of at least 39 hours per week), excluding sick time and compensatory time, will be compensated at time and one-half for of all hours worked over 40 hours per week. 
(4)  Saturday, Sunday and holiday overtime for non-public safety personnel. With respect to Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, non-exempt employees shall be paid at the rate of time and one-half, provided the employees have worked a scheduled workweek of at least five days at eight hours per day (except during the 2012-2013 fiscal year, from May 1, 2012 through April 30, 2013, the scheduled workweek shall comprise a minimum of eight hours of duty on four days and a minimum of seven hours of duty on one day in a calendar week), including village holidays, personal time, or vacation days' pay. However, unpaid time or sick time taken shall constitute forfeiture of the time and one-half rate and straight time shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 09-55, § 1, 3-20-2009; Ord. No. 09-84, § 1, 6-1-2009; Ord. No. 10-98, § 1, 6-7-2010; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-21-2012; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-94. - Public works standby. 
(1)  A non-exempt employee who has been designated as "standby" will receive two hours of pay per day as overtime pay for each day they are so classified, regardless of whether or not they are called out to work for an emergency. In the event of a call out to work, the time and one-half rate will be applicable for all hours worked after an employee's punch-in until the employee's scheduled work hour, at which time the employee's rate of pay will revert to straight time until his regular shift time expires. A two hour minimum call out period will be applicable per occurrence unless the call out period overlaps with the employee's scheduled work hours or overlaps with another previous call out period for that employee. 
For example, if an employee is called out to work during an evening, weekend or holiday and only works 30 minutes, the employee still receives two hours minimum pay at time and one-half plus one hour of bonus pay as defined above. If work continues beyond the two hour period, the employee receives such at time and one-half. However, when on scheduled standby, the employee does not get the bonus pay as defined above. 
(2)  It is mandatory that an employee designated as a "standby" be available on 30 minutes' notice. Failure to respond to the notice in the allotted time shall constitute forfeiture of the standby pay due for that period and may be the basis for further disciplinary action. Employees who cannot consistently demonstrate that they can respond (punch in) within the required time frame will no longer be eligible for scheduled standby. Consistent response time will be considered a minimum of four on-time responses for any five consecutive call out notifications. 
(3)  Winter standby. During the winter season for a 16 week period starting the Monday following Thanksgiving Day and through approximately the end of March, up to six additional employees may be scheduled for winter standby. In all cases, the regularly scheduled standby employee will be contacted first. In the event that the meteorological emergency requires more than one employee to address, the balance of the scheduled winter standby employees will be notified to respond. Meteorological emergencies include storms (snow, rain, wind, or otherwise) and unanticipated water main breaks/repairs. 
(4)  A nonexempt employee who has been designated as "winter standby" will receive one hour of pay per day as overtime pay for each day they are so classified, regardless of whether or not they are called out for an emergency. In the event of a call out, the time and one-half rate will be applicable for all hours worked after punch-in until the employee's scheduled work hour, at which time the employee's rate of pay will revert to straight time until his regular shift time expires. A two hour minimum call out period will be applicable per occurrence unless call-out period overlaps with the employee's scheduled work hours or overlaps with another previous call-out period. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-95. - Holidays. 
All full-time employees, except police department personnel shall receive time off and be paid for the following holidays: 
(1)  New Year's Day. 
(2)  Martin Luther King, Jr. Day. 
(3)  Presidents' Day. 
(4)  Memorial Day. 
(5)  Independence Day. 
(6)  Labor Day. 
(7)  Thanksgiving Day. 
(8)  The day after Thanksgiving Day. 
(9)  Christmas Eve. 
(10)  Christmas Day. 
(11)  Four floating holidays as further described in section 62-96, below. 
When any holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be considered a holiday. When a holiday falls on a Saturday, then the preceding Friday shall be considered a holiday. When a holiday falls within an employee's vacation period, the employee's vacation will be extended one day at the end of the vacation period. 
Holidays shall not be paid unless the employee shall have worked the scheduled workday immediately before and the scheduled workday immediately after the authorized holiday. An exception may be made for scheduled personal compensatory, and vacation days, verifiable illness, a death in the immediate family or unforeseen personal misfortune which can be confirmed. 
In place of time off for holidays, civilian police employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement and all sworn police employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement will receive additional pay per year as outlined in the applicable collective bargaining agreements. In lieu of time off for holidays, police sergeants, whose schedule is not affected due to holidays, will receive an extra eight hours regular time pay for each holiday that falls within the pay period, regardless of whether they are on duty or not for that holiday. This holiday leave exception for police employees will not affect their receipt of personal days. 
Part-time employees, who work 16 or more hours per week, except part-time sworn police officers and paid-on-call firefighters, shall receive paid time off (four hours per holiday) for the holidays listed above excluding (11). 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 16-120, § 1, 7-7-2016; Ord. No. 16-196, § 1, 12-8-2016; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018; Ord. No. 19-041, § 2, 4-11-2019)  
Sec. 62-96. - Floating holidays. 
All full-time, regular employees will receive four floating holidays (32 hours) per year in addition to vacation time, sick leave and the village's regular holidays. These four floating holidays allow employees to have additional paid leave to cover absences for personal reasons, such as religious observances or parent-teacher conferences, or to supplement vacation, sick and holiday leave. 
Floating holidays are available at the beginning of each calendar year. Any employee hired in the first quarter of the calendar year will receive the full allotment of floating holidays for the year. Any employee hired in the second quarter of the calendar year will receive three floating holidays. Any employee hired in the third quarter of the calendar year will receive two floating holidays. Any employee hired in the fourth quarter of the calendar year will receive one floating holiday. 
Floating holidays may be used to cover a full or partial day (to be used in minimum of four-hour block) absence. They must be taken in the calendar year in which received. Under no circumstances will these days be carried over to the next calendar year, nor may they be cashed out if not taken or paid upon termination of employment. 
A floating holiday must be scheduled and approved in advance by the employee's immediate supervisor. As much notice should be provided as practical, however, a minimum seven calendar days' notice is expected. Supervisors may make exception in agreed cases of emergency which may be documented after the fact. All floating holidays are subject to approval by an employee's supervisor and such approval will depend on the maintenance of adequate staffing levels within the village. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, adopted Jan. 4, 2018, amended § 62-96 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Personal days" to "Floating days," as set out herein.  
Sec. 62-97. - Vacation policy. 
Vacations are provided for the recreation and relaxation of full-time employees. Vacation credit is earned by full-time employees on a regular basis with the schedule of vacation determined at the discretion of the respective department head. In determining the vacation schedule, the department head shall consider as factors the desires of the individual full-time employee in relation to all other requests for vacation or other leave of department employees, the needs and demands of village operations and the workload of the department. The following rules must be followed by all employees with respect to vacation time: 
(1)  Full-time employees shall request approval of vacation as far in advance of the dates requested as practicable. All requests for vacation shall be tentatively approved by the department head, subject to final approval of the village manager. 
(2)  Unused vacation time from the current year shall be paid to the employee at the time of separation from village service, whether such separation is voluntary or involuntary. In the event of a change in employment status from full-time to part-time, the village will pay unused vacation from the current year within 14 days of the change in status. If the employee subsequently returns to full-time status, vacation credit resumes from the date the employee left full-time status and went to part-time status. Similarly, if an employee leaves village employment due to a lay-off, and returns to village employment in a full-time position, the employee's vacation credit will resume from the date the employee was separated due to lay-off. Vacation credit will not resume in situations where an employee voluntarily resigns or retires from employment with the village or is terminated for any other reason than lay-off should the employee return to the village in a full-time capacity. 
(3)  Vacation shall not be advanced. Vacation time earned in one year shall not carry over to the next calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 10-35, § 1, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-98. - Vacation award schedule. 
Except as in circumstances set forth in section 62-97(3), vacation time for village employees shall be awarded as follows: 
Forty hours upon hire. 
Eighty hours per year after one year of consecutive full-time employment; 
One hundred twenty hours per year after five years of consecutive full-time employment; 
One hundred sixty hours per year after ten years of consecutive full-time employment; and 
Two hundred hours per year after 20 years of consecutive full-time employment. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 10-35, § 1, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-99. - Educational reimbursement. 
(a)  In addition to training provided by the village, each employee shall be eligible for reimbursement for professional level educational courses, workshops, seminars, and courses that lead to certification directly related to their current village position and college-level educational courses, workshops, or seminars at an accredited college or university. Education reimbursement monies shall only be applied to the verified cost of tuition and registration, which have been approved by the department head and village manager subject to availability of budgeted funds. 
Proof of completion of the approved coursework shall consist of a transcript showing a letter grade of "B" or better, or in cases where no letter grade is given, a certificate of completion or written proof that the coursework was completed in a satisfactory manner. Requests for reimbursement may be submitted to the department head and must be accompanied by a receipt for all eligible expenses incurred. 
(b)  (1)  The village shall reimburse a maximum of $350.00 for education program expenses for the 12 month period from May 1April 30 each year except as provided below in section (b)(2). Requests for reimbursement for completed approved college or professional level educational course work will be paid for the 12 month period (May 1April 30) in which requests are received by the department head. 
(b)  (2)  If the entire $350.00 of education reimbursement referred to in section (b)(1) above is used solely for college-level course work and college related eligible expenses at an accredited college or university, then the employee shall be eligible to receive an additional $1,250.00 of educational reimbursement for additional college course work and college related eligible expenses. 
(c)  If an employee receives tuition payments or refunds from other sources for college-level course work at an accredited college or university, the village will contribute the difference between the amount the employee receives from the other source and the authorized costs incurred by the employee to the maximum cited in section (b) above. 
Stipulations: 
(1)  All courses should attempt to be taken other than during employee's regular work hours unless vacation time is used and department head approval has been given. As a general condition approval of course work during regular work hours will not occur except in very unique circumstances. 
(2)  There should be a reasonable assurance that the employee intends to remain an active village employee for at least one year after completion of course work in order to qualify for tuition assistance at public expense. If an employee seeks and receives approval to receive tuition reimbursement he or she must be willing to sign an "Educational Reimbursement Payback Agreement" and abide by the conditions of that agreement. 
(3)  Employees on worker's compensation shall remain eligible for the tuition reimbursement program. 
(4)  Reimbursement will not be made to an employee who was discharged or voluntarily terminates employment with the village before completion of a course(s) enrolled in. 
(5)  Reimbursement will not be made to an employee who withdraws from a course(s) due to personal reasons. 
If an employee is laid off for reasons beyond their control, subsequent to the approval enrollment, eligibility for reimbursement will continue through satisfactory completion of the course(s) currently enrolled in. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-100. - Professional society membership. 
Village employees are encouraged to affiliate with professional organizations or societies applicable to their position for which they qualify by education or training; provided, that such affiliation produces observable benefits for the village. Approval for village paid memberships must be obtained in advance by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-101. - Employee bonus incentive program. 
The village utilizes an employee bonus incentive program ("incentive program") available to all full-time employees. The incentive program was established in order to reward those employees who generate cost saving ideas for the village. The incentive program is further described in the village policy, "suggestion recognition and incentive program." The incentive program shall be administered by the village manager pursuant to the above policy. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-102. - Conference and travel policy. 
The village utilizes a conference and travel policy ("conference and travel policy") which sets criteria for payment and reimbursement of travel expenses incurred by the village president, village board of trustees, village employees and members of all village boards and commissions in the performance of their official functions. The conference and travel policy, which may be amended from time to time, sets forth the rules governing conferences and travel for official village functions. The conference and travel policy shall be distributed to all elected officials, employees and board and commission members, and kept on file with the village manager and village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-103. - Other benefits. 
The village offers a number of additional benefits to full-time time and part-time employees. Currently, these additional benefits include but are not limited to options for life insurance, disability insurance, health insurance, dental insurance, Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund ("IMRF"), Police pension plan, credit union membership, employee assistance program, deferred compensation plan, flexible spending/savings accounts and health club membership discounts. Such benefits will be further described upon employment with the village, and may be changed at anytime at the discretion of the village. 
COBRA: Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act is the Federal continuation of coverage rules for group health plans. In order for the plan sponsor to offer continuation coverage under COBRA, the employee must notify the human resources director of the applicable change in status that may qualify for extension of coverage under COBRA within 60 days of the qualifying event. Failure to properly notify the human resource director may result in extension of coverage being denied to the participant. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-104. - Furlough hoursThirty-nine hour work week. 
For the fiscal year 2012-2013, effective May 1, 2012 until April 30, 2013 unless extended by ordinance, for all full-time non-union employees, excluding police sergeants, the standard workweek shall be five days and 39 hours. Exempt employees are required to work those hours necessary to assure the satisfactory performance of their duties within their departments, but not less than 39 hours per week. Supervisory exempt employees shall assign to each supervised employee regular work duties and responsibilities which can normally be accomplished within the established workday and workweek. However, occasionally some overtime work may be necessary for proper performance of work duties and responsibilities. For exempt employees, such overtime is considered part of their job responsibility and does not justify overtime pay. 
Hours of work for employees shall be determined by department heads. 
(1)  Overtime. All scheduled overtime for non-exempt employees, including the 40 th hour which will be paid at the regular rate of pay, must be approved by the respective department heads and authorized by the village manager. 
All emergency overtime policies remain in effect and all emergency overtime worked outside of the employee(s scheduled workday will be paid at the rate of time and one-half, as described in the village employee handbook. 
All non-exempt employees whose scheduled workweek is of at least 39 hours per week, excluding sick time, will be compensated at time and one-half for all hours worked over 40 hours per week. Time worked between 39 and 40 hours will be compensated at the regular rate of pay. 
With respect to Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, non-exempt employees shall be paid at the rate of time and one-half, provided the employees have worked a scheduled workweek of at least four days at eight hours per day and one day at seven hours, including village holidays, personal time, or vacation days' pay. However, unpaid time or sick time taken shall constitute forfeiture of the time and one-half rate and straight time shall be paid. If employees have worked the scheduled workweek of 39 hours, if the 40 th hour is on a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday, the 40 th hour will be paid at the overtime rate. 
(2)  Vacation. Vacation time will continue to be awarded as follows: Eighty hours per year after one year of consecutive full-time employment; 120 hours per year after five years of consecutive full-time employment; 160 hours per year after ten years of consecutive full-time employment; and 200 hours per year after 20 years of consecutive full-time employment. 
(3)  Paid time off. All paid time off (PTO) will be taken based on how many hours the employee was scheduled to work. For an entire week of PTO, an employee would use 39 hours. An employee would use eight hours of PTO to be paid for a day in which he or she was scheduled to work eight hours. The employee would use seven hours of PTO to be paid for a day in which he or she was scheduled to work seven hours. 
Employees may not use PTO for time during which they were not scheduled to increase their weekly hours. 
(4)  Holidays. All village approved holidays will be paid at eight hours. If a holiday falls on a day in workday, the shortened day will need to be rescheduled for that week so that the total workweek hours, including the eight hours of holiday pay do not exceed the 39 hour work week. 
(5)  Insurance. Employees who work 39 hours will continue to maintain full time employee status and as such are eligible for the same insurance coverage which any employee who previously worked a 40 hour workweek was eligible. 
(Ord. No. 09-84, § 1, 6-1-2009; Ord. No. 10-98, § 1, 6-7-2010; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-21-2012; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-105. - Paid time off (PTO) bankPart-time employees. 
Part-time employees, who work 16 or more hours a week, except part-time sworn police officers and paid-on-call firefighters, shall be eligible for paid time off (PTO) as described in this section. 
(1)  This policy is in effect for all part-time employees as described above. 
(2)  No PTO shall be available until the completion of the first anniversary of consecutive regular part-time employment. 
(3)  Employees requesting to use PTO for a planned absence are required to request PTO from their supervisor as far in advance of the dates requested as practicable, in accordance with vacation policy section of the personnel policy as applies to full-time employees. All requests shall be tentatively approved by the department head, subject to final approval of the village manager. 
(4)  Employees who need to use PTO for an unplanned absence, need to give notification to the supervisor at least 30 minutes before the start of their shift. Employees are required to give their supervisor the reason for the unplanned absence, such as illness of themselves, their spouse, or any member of their immediate household. Use of PTO for illness is not to be abused by the employee and excessive absenteeism will not be tolerated. The village reserves the right to require the employee to verify illness of themselves, their spouse, or any member of their immediate household via a healthcare provider's note or any other communication deemed appropriate by the village. 
(5)  Unused PTO from the current year shall be paid to the employee at the time of separation from village service, whether such separation is voluntary or involuntary. 
(6)  PTO shall not be advanced. PTO awarded in one year shall not carry over to the next anniversary year. 
(7)  Part-time regular employees will be awarded PTO according to the following schedule: 
a.  Two weeks (proportionate to hours worked the previous year) after one year consecutive service. 
b.  Three weeks (proportionate to hours worked the previous year) after five years consecutive service. 
(8)  Full-time regular employees with less than one year of full-time service and who were part-time employees immediately preceding becoming full-time employees, will be awarded PTO on their regular part-time anniversary according to the following schedule: 
a.  Two weeks (proportionate to hours worked as a part-time employee the previous year) after one year consecutive service. 
b  Three weeks (proportionate to hours worked as a part-time employee the previous year) after five years consecutive service. 
(Ord. No. 16-195, § 1, 12-8-2016; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-106. - Compensatory time policy. 
Non-exempt (hourly) employees who are eligible to be compensated for overtime as identified in section 62-93 or 62-94 will have the option of receiving cash overtime pay (same pay period) or compensatory time (accumulated at the same rate) up to a cap of 48 replenishable hours to be used as paid time off. If a non-exempt employee fails to specify how the individual over-time segments should be received, it will default to the method established by the department head for that position which will be communicated in writing to department staff, department administrative assistants, finance department, and human resources. 
On the first pay period in December and the last pay period in April, a non-exempt employee may elect to be paid out for any amount of unused compensatory time. On the last pay period in April, a non-exempt employee will be paid out for any amount of unused compensatory time over 24 hours in their comp time bank at the employee's then current rate of pay. In the event that a non-exempt employee is promoted to an exempt position, before the effective date of the promotion, the employee will be paid out for any unused compensatory time, accumulated as a non-exempt employee. Unused compensatory time will be paid out to a non-exempt employee at the time of separation from village service, whether that separation is voluntary or involuntary. 
Exempt employees accumulate compensatory time at the rate of one hour for each regular hour of actual work in excess of 40 hours per week. In terms of exempt employees accumulating compensatory time, paid time off including holiday, vacation, personal, or other compensatory time, are not included as regular hours of actual work. Exempt employees can use no more than eight hours of compensatory time in any given pay period, unless otherwise directed by the village manager. Exempt employees may only use compensatory time accrued in the previous two pay periods in addition to time within same pay period. Exempt employees will not be paid out for any unused compensatory time. 
For both non-exempt and exempt employees, the use of compensatory time shall be by mutual agreement between the employee and their supervisor, as scheduling permits. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-107. - Insurance benefits policy and procedure. 
(a)  Purpose. To document policy and procedure regarding eligibility of insurance benefits for full and part time employees of the village (also known as Policy PP-26, effective 12/01/2012). 
The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (PPACA) establishes certain regulations for individuals and employers and requires compliance over a specific time frame some of which will be addressed in this policy. 
(b)  Eligibility . 
(1)  Full-time employees. All full-time employees, as defined in section 62-2(1), except for specific job classifications as described below, are eligible to participate in the village's group major medical, dental, and life insurance programs. Insurance coverages shall commence after 30 days of full-time continuous employment with the village. 
(2)  Part-time employees. All part-time employees, as defined in section 62-2 (2), except for specific job classifications as described below, are eligible to participate in the village's group major medical and dental insurance programs. Insurance coverages shall commence after thirty (30) days of part-time continuous employment with the village. 
(3)  Part-time fire department employees. This classification consists of paid-on-call and part-time fire department personnel that receive an hourly wage for hours worked. They are not salaried. Overtime is calculated based on 106 hours per two-week pay period for operations personnel and 40 hours per week for administrative personnel (EMA, administrative assistants, fire inspectors). 
Titles in this classification include, but are not limited to: 
 Paid-on-call personnel 
 Part-time firefighter, paramedic, lieutenant, captain, duty chief, deputy chief 
 Part-time training safety officer 
 Part-time administrative assistant 
 Part-time fire inspector, public education officers 
 Such other part-time positions as the village may designate from time to time 
All paid-on-call and part-time fire department personnel as defined above are eligible to participate in the village's group major medical insurance program (dental is not included). Only certain paid-on-call and part-time fire department personnel are eligible to participate in the village's life insurance program as described in the life insurance section of this policy. 
Full-time village employees that are also paid-on-call or part-time fire department personnel working under a 7G agreement are paid according to those agreements. By virtue of their full-time positions, these personnel are treated the same as all other full- time village employees for benefit purposes. 
(c)  Group major medical insurance. 
(1)  Full-time employees. The village will pay for a portion of the cost of the coverage in accordance with village policies as established by the village board prior to the beginning of each fiscal year. Each employee electing such coverage shall be obligated to pay the remaining portion of the cost for his/her own coverage as well as the portion of the cost of family coverage if elected as determined by the village board prior to the beginning of each fiscal year. Employees who opt to not be covered by the village's group major medical insurance will be paid an annual stipend of $2,000.00 (paid out in 26 checks), or such other amount as may be determined by the village board from time to time. 
(2)  Part-time employees. The village will pay for a small portion of the cost (11.5 percent) of the coverage in accordance with village policies. Each employee electing such coverage shall be obligated to pay the remaining portion of the cost for his/her own coverage as well as the portion of the cost of family coverage (88.5 percent). 
(3)  Part-time fire department employees. The village will pay for a small portion of the cost (11.5 percent) of the coverage in accordance with village policies.
