Each employee electing such coverage shall be obligated to pay the remaining portion of the cost for his/her own coverage as well as the portion of the cost of family coverage (88.5 percent). 
The Village may also provide a low benefit, low cost option designed to cover 60 percent of the cost of care. 
(d)  Group dental insurance. 
(1)  Full-time employees. Group dental insurance shall be made available to all full-time employees and their families. If elected, insurance coverage shall commence after 30 days of full-time continuous employment with the village. The village will pay for a portion of the cost of the coverage in accordance with village policies as established by the village board prior to the beginning of each fiscal year. Each employee electing such coverage shall be obligated to pay the portion for family coverage if elected as determined by the village board prior to the beginning of each fiscal year. 
(2)  Part-time employees. The village will pay for a small portion of the cost (11.5 percent) of the coverage in accordance with village policies. Each employee electing such coverage shall be obligated to pay the remaining portion of the cost for his/her own coverage as well as the portion of the cost of family coverage (88.5 percent). 
(e)  Life insurance. A term life insurance policy with a minimum of $50,000.00 coverage shall be provided at the village's cost for any full-time employee while he/she is employed by the village. This life insurance policy terminates upon termination of employment except upon retirement when a retiree may opt to retain the life insurance policy at their cost. 
Any paid-on-call member or part-time firefighter who works a minimum of 780 hours or more in a calendar year will be eligible for this life insurance, effective for the calendar immediately following a 780 hour year. Example: Firefighter works 780 hours from January 1, 2011 to December 31, 2011. The firefighter is eligible for life insurance for January 1, 2012 to December 31, 2012. This life insurance policy terminates upon termination of employment. 
(f)  Health care reform. According to the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, the only insurance benefit an employer must offer to an employee designated to be full-time according to this Act, is health insurance. Health insurance includes major medical, prescription, and may include vision. 
(1)  Designation of full-time and part-time . The designation of an employee as full-time or part-time in this section simply identifies if they are considered a full-time employee in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The classifications in this health care reform section should not be confused with the classifications in the above eligibility section. 
Employees that are designated as full-time for the purposes of this section, will be able to receive insurance. However, the contributions required for that insurance will be based on the employee's classification in the eligibility section, as applied to the various insurance benefits as described in their specific sections. Employees that are designated as part-time for the purposes of this section, may also be able to receive insurance as described above. 
(2)  Standard measurement period (SMP). The SMP is the look back period to determine if the employee has worked an average of 30 hours per week. The village's SMP is November 1 through October 31 of each year. 
(3)  Stability period. If an employee averages 30 hours per week, the employee is considered full-time for the stability period. If the employee averages less than 30 hours per week, the employee is considered part-time for the stability period. The village's stability period is from January 1 through December 31 of each year. 
If an employee's hours change such that their status changes from FT to PT or PT to FT during the stability period, no changes will occur in insurance designation either way. Example: An employee is determined to be full-time during the SMP and elects to enroll in the village's insurance. If the employee's hours drop substantially and the employee essentially becomes part-time again, the employee will remain classified as a full-time employee for the purpose of Health Care Reform and may remain enrolled in insurance until the stability period has ended; after such time the employee may be eligible for COBRA. 
(4)  Administrative period The administrative period is the time allowed for eligible employee to decide whether or not to enroll in the village's insurance and time for village staff to administer the enrollment. The village's administrative period is November 1 through December 31 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Secs. 62-10862-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - LEAVES OF ABSENCE 
 
Sec. 62-131. - Sick leave. 
Sick leave is a privilege, not a right, extended to all full-time employees. Sick leave is accrued on the basis of eight hours for each full month of service. Sick leave may not be used as additional vacation time. Abuse of sick leave privileges is sufficient cause for discipline, up to and including termination of employment with the village. Further, employees may not convert pre-established paid leave (vacation, compensatory time, or personal time) to sick leave. 
(1)  Reporting. In cases where an employee cannot report for duty due to illness, the employee must advise his or her supervisor or department no later than 30 minutes before the employee's scheduled starting time on the day of the absence. 
(2)  Doctor's certificate required. Supervisors may require a doctor's certificate from employees who are absent due to illness. A doctor's certificate will be required in all cases where absences are three or more consecutive work days or any absence adjacent to other paid time off. At the village's discretion, employees may also be required to submit to a medical examination by a physician designated by the village. Sick leave shall not be payable if, in the opinion of the village physician, the absence was not necessary. 
(3)  Change in employment status. In the event of a change in employment status from full-time to part-time, any unused sick time will remain on the books and can be used during the part-time status. 
(4)  Longevity/retirement sick leave payout. Provided that an employee has given proper notice of separation, an employee shall be paid for unused and accrued sick leave up to a maximum of 120 working days upon such employee's separation from village service, only where that employee has served 20 or more consecutive years of full-time employment with the village, or if such employee has reached the minimum retirement age and has become vested in the applicable pension fund to be paid out at the following payout schedule: 
a.  For employees hired prior to January 1, 2018, they will be paid 100 percent for unused and accrued sick leave up to a maximum of 120 working days. 
b.  For employees hired on or after January 1, 2018, they will be paid 50 percent for unused and accrued sick leave up to a maximum of 120 working days. 
An employee who is terminated, laid off, or otherwise dismissed by the village is not eligible for sick leave payout. An employee who receives notice of layoff who subsequently gives notice to retire or resign prior to the effective date of the layoff may still be eligible for sick leave payout if he/she meets the requirements of this subsection (4). 
(5)  An employee also may use sick leave benefits accrued pursuant to this section 62-131 for absences due to an illness, injury, or medical appointments of the employee's "covered family member", for reasonable periods of time as the employee's attendance may be necessary, on the same terms upon which an employee is able to use sick leave benefits for the employee's own illness or injury. Provided, however, sick leave benefits taken by any employee for a "covered family member" is limited to the amount that the employee would accrue during six months of employment (i.e., up to 48 hours which is half of 96 hours accrued/year maximum). This limitation applies to non-FMLA absences. For purposes of this section 62-131 only, the phrase "covered family member" means the employee's child, spouse, civil union or domestic partner, sibling, parent, mother-in-law, father-in-law, grandchild, grandparent or stepparent. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 09-54, § 1, 4-20-2009; Ord. No. 10-35, § 1, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-132. - Bereavement leave. 
Full-time village employees may be granted emergency leave of absence with pay in cases of death of an immediate family member. Such leave shall be granted only upon the recommendation of an employee's department head, and is subject to approval by the village manager. Upon approval, such employees may be granted and compensated for up to a maximum of three consecutive working days for bereavement leave. Paid leave for this purpose will not be granted in instances where the bereavement leave occurs on a paid holiday, previously scheduled days off, weekends, or in any case where payment under this section would result in paying twice for the same time off. Further, employees may not convert pre-established paid leave (vacation, compensatory time, or personal time) to bereavement leave. However, if circumstances require more than the maximum three days paid bereavement leave, department heads shall consider the short-notice approval of other available vacation or personal time off. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-133. - Jury duty. 
Full-time village employees shall receive full pay for time not worked while serving on jury duty or testifying as a witness at the request of the village, or testifying under subpoena to matters related to their employment with the village. Such employees are required to endorse to the village any payment received for such jury or witness duty. No employee shall receive pay for time not worked while testifying as a witness in a case filed by the employee against the village, its officers or employees. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-134. - Military service. 
Employees inducted into active military service will, upon application, be granted a leave of absence for the period of military service, and shall be reinstated without loss of seniority or other benefits, provided they return to village service within 90 days after release from military service. Employees who are members of a reserve or national guard unit will be granted a leave of absence for periods of active military service and shall be reinstated without loss of seniority or other benefits, provided they return to village service immediately after release from active duty. If a member of a reserve or national guard unit is mobilized by presidential order, a leave of absence and reinstatement shall be granted in the same manner as if the employee was inducted into active military service. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-135. - Absences due to job related injuries. 
Village employees may be eligible to benefits under the Illinois Workers' Compensation Act for injuries sustained in the course of employment. Such eligibility and benefits are set forth in the Illinois Workers' Compensation laws. A copy of the "Handbook on Workers' Compensation and Occupational Diseases" is available from human resources or at www.iwcc.il.gov. 
(a)  Reporting an on-the-job injury : If an employee believes he/she has suffered an injury or illness related to employment with the village, the employee must immediately report the injury or illness to a supervisor, or no later than the end of the business day on which the injury occurred. All injuries, including those that do not require emergency medical care must be reported. Injuries that do not require medical care are reported on an employee first aid/incident report. Upon being advised of an injury or illness, the employee's supervisor will complete an Illinois Industrial Commission Form 45 (also known as the Employer's First Report of Injury or Illness), and a supervisor's accident investigation report (see human resources or the employee intranet for copies of these forms). The employee will complete the employee statement form, and any witnesses will complete the witness statement form. The originals of all reports along with any other related data and pictures shall be completed and emailed to our third party claims administrator (IRMA) as well as to human resources within 48 hours of receiving notice of the incident. The departmental safety committees shall review copies of the reports as well as the executive safety committee. 
(1)  The director or supervisor of a department shall contact the risk manager (human resources director) immediately, at any time, 24 hours a day, in the event of an injury or illness, or of a death. 
(2)  Upon receiving verbal notice of an injury or illness requiring emergency medical care, or death; or after receiving the completed reports of a less serious injury or illness, the risk manager (human resources director) will follow up on the claim with the village's third party claims administrator. 
(b)  Adjudication of a workers' compensation claim . The village's third party claims administrator will, in conjunction with the risk manager (human resources director), investigate the circumstances surrounding the injury, illness, or death of an employee. In accordance with applicable law, the third party claims administrator will determine if the employee's injury, illness, or death is compensable. If the claim for benefits is determined to be compensable, the third party claims administrator shall distribute all appropriate benefits. If the claim is determined not to be compensable, the third party administrator will notify the employee, or beneficiary if a death, in writing of the denial. If an employee disagrees with the determination made by the third party claims administrator, or for any other reason, the employee is entitled to file a claim for adjustment with the Illinois Industrial Commission. 
(c)  Benefits while on a workers' compensation absence . In the event the third party claims administrator determines that the injury, illness, or death is compensable, employees are entitled to, but not limited to, the following benefits: 
(1)  Medical benefits. The village will pay all medical bills related to an employee's injury or illness that are determined to be reasonable and customary by the third party claims administrator. Employees requiring medical treatment while on duty will be directed to the village's occupational health provider. The name and location of the occupational health provider is posted in all village facilities. Employees needing care will be treated and if necessary transported to an emergency care facility. Employees receiving medical treatment must forward all medical bills to the risk manager (human resources director). 
(2)  Light duty. The village makes every effort to return employees to work in a light duty capacity during recovery within the scope of specific work restrictions as determined by a health care provider. 
It is the responsibility of all employees to notify the treating health care providers of the village's availability of light duty, as well as notifying the department when released for light duty work. 
(3)  Injured on duty. For the first three days an employee is authorized off work by the treating health care provider due to an injury or illness, the employee must use time from accrued sick leave, or any other category of paid time off leave if the employee does not have sick leave remaining; unless PEDA applies (see below). 
(4)  Temporary total disability (TTD). Employees authorized off work for more than three days are entitled to temporary total disability (TTD) benefits. TTD benefits are paid at 66-2/3 percent of employee's average weekly wage. Average weekly wages are calculated on injured employee's regular wages for the 52 weeks prior to the date of injury. Employees are entitled to TTD benefits for as long as the employee is authorized off work due to the injury or illness, or until the employee has reached maximum medical improvement as determined by a health care provider. However, these TTD benefits are released to the village, as the employee receives their full rate of pay during the time of authorized injury or illness. 
(5)  Permanent partial disability (PPD). An employee may suffer a permanent partial disability (PPD) as a result of an injury or illness. An employee may be entitled to compensation for this disability. The Workers' Compensation Act determines the amount of PPD compensation. 
(6)  Permanent total disability (PTD). If an employee reaches the maximum medical improvement and is still medically unable to return to work, the employee may be entitled to permanent total disability benefits (PTD). These benefits are paid at a rate determined under the Workers' Compensation Act. 
(7)  Survivors benefits. In the event of an employee's death, spouses and dependents are eligible for survivor's benefits as determined under the Workers' Compensation Act. 
(8)  Public Employees Disability Act (PEDA). For the duration of up to one year, under the Public Employees Disability Act (PEDA), a sworn police or fire employee is eligible for compensation equal to 100 percent of their salary if the employee is off work due to a compensable injury or illness that occurred on duty. 
(9)  Illinois municipal retirement fund (IMRF) employees. TTD payments received by an employee due an on-the-job injury or illness are not considered 'earnings' by IMRF. Such time off of work, although authorized and receiving TTD payments, does not count as service time for the purpose of calculating future pension benefits. IMRF service time may be received during such periods by applying for an IMRF disability on forms available through IMRF or human resources. 
An employee is only entitled to lost time benefits if a health care provider authorizes time off work due to a compensable injury or illness. Upon returning to work after an injury or illness, the employee will be required to use benefit time, other than workers' compensation benefits, to attend any medical appointment during scheduled hours of work. IRMA does not pay TTD payments for work time missed to attend medical appointments during scheduled work hours unless attending a medical appointment requested by the village. 
(d)  Release to return to work . An employee authorized off work or released to a light duty assignment must have a duty status report completed by the treating health care provider. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-136. - Family Medical Leave Act. 
Employees who have worked for the village for the past 12 months, and for at least 1,250 hours, may request up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave in accordance with the provisions of the Family Medical Leave Act of 1993 ("FMLA"). Such leave may be requested for the following reasons: 
 The birth and care of the newborn child of an employee; 
 The placement with the employee of a son or daughter for adoption or foster care; 
 To care for an immediate family member (defined by FMLA as a spouse, child or parent) with a serious health condition; 
 To take medical leave when the employee is unable to work because of serious health condition; or 
 Because of any "qualifying exigency" (as defined by the Secretary of Labor) arising out of the fact that your spouse, child, or parent is deployed on active duty in a foreign country (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces. 
The employee requesting FMLA leave shall make a written request, stating the reasons for such request, and the date desired for the start of the leave and probable date of return to work. FMLA leave shall not exceed a maximum combined total of 12 weeks in any 12 month period. 
FMLA leave is further explained within the Family Medical Leave Act of 1993 and within the village's policy entitled "Family Medical Leave Act Policy and Procedure." 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 12-128, § 1, 8-6-2012)  
Sec. 62-137. - General leaves of absence. 
(a)  [General leave.] Village full-time employees may request a general unpaid leave of absence for personal matters. The decision to grant such leave shall be at the sole discretion of the village manager. Such leave may be requested for: 
(1)  The continuation or completion of a certificate, or pursuit of an accredited degree related to employment; 
(2)  To recover from a physical illness or to attend to a family illness not covered by FMLA; 
(3)  To take care of other personal matters not covered by FMLA. 
(b)  Procedure. Employees may submit a written request to their department head asking for a leave of absence without pay pursuant to this section. The request must state forth the reasons for the request, the date desired for the start of the leave and the probable date of return. The request will be reviewed by the department head and village manager. An employee is required to exhaust any available paid vacation, personal, and compensatory time before unpaid general leave of absence is commenced. 
(c)  Benefits. If a leave of absence pursuant to this section exceeds 30 consecutive calendar days, the employee may, at the employee's option, remain a member of any group hospital or medical plan provided by the village to its employees, provided the employee pays the full monthly premium for such coverage to the village. The employee is required to begin paying this premium beginning on the 31st consecutive day of leave. The premium shall include or exclude coverage for dependents at the option of the employee. 
(d)  Extension of other benefits. The village manager may extend health/life insurance coverage for up to 24 months to long tenure full-time employees when an employee can show good cause for such an extension. "Long tenure" is defined as employment with the village for at least five years. An employee taking a leave of absence pursuant to this section is not entitled to accrue any other employment benefit during the leave, including, but not limited to, vacation, sick and holiday leave. 
(e)  Resignation. A village employee who fails to return from a general leave of absence pursuant to this section on the designated return date, either as originally agreed or as extended by agreement, shall be considered as having resigned his or her employment position with the village. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 13-168, § 1, 8-8-2013)  
Sec. 62-138. - Illinois Pregnancy Accommodation Act. 
The village complies with the Illinois Pregnancy Accommodation Act (the "Act"), 775 ILCS 5/1, et seq. Generally, the Act prohibits discrimination against females based on pregnancy and childbirth and covers job applicants as well as part-time, full-time and probationary employees. It further gives protected individuals opportunities to request reasonable accommodations for medical or common conditions related to pregnancy or childbirth. 
Employees should not rely on the first paragraph of this subsection to become fully informed about the Act or its implications. Understanding the protections, obligations and remedies provided by the Act requires review of the entire Act. A copy of the Act may be reviewed and/or obtained at the website of the Illinois Department of Human Rights (www.illinois.gov/dhr) or from the village's human resources department. The village has displayed posters required by the Act at various prominent locations in village buildings. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-139. - Victim's Economic Security and Safety Act (VESSA). 
(a)  Policy and requirements. In accordance with the Illinois Victims' Economic Security and Safety Act, 820 ILCS 180/1, et seq., (VESSA), an employee is entitled to up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave per year, and/or reasonable accommodations for one of the following reasons: 
 To seek medical attention for, or recovering from, physical or psychological injuries caused by domestic or sexual violence to the employee or an employee's family or household member; or 
 To obtain services from a victim services organization for the employee or an employee's family or household member; or 
 To obtain psychological or other counseling for the employee or an employee's family or household member; or 
 To participate in safety planning, temporarily or permanently relocating or taking other actions to increase the safety of the employee or an employee's family or household member from future domestic or sexual violence or to ensure economic security; or 
 To seek legal assistance or remedies to ensure the health and safety of the employee or an employee's family or household member, including preparing for or participating in any civil or criminal legal proceeding related to or derived from domestic or sexual violence. 
An eligible employee is entitled to up to 12 workweeks of unpaid leave during a rolling 12 month period from the date of occurrence. Said leave may be taken on an intermittent or reduced work schedule basis. VESSA leave will run concurrently with any other applicable leave. For instance, leave taken under VESSA which also qualifies under FMLA, will be simultaneously designated as both VESSA and FMLA leave. Likewise, absences for which an employee receives short term disability benefits for a purpose covered under VESSA will be designated as VESSA leave. 
An employee can substitute, or the village may require substitution of, available paid vacation, sick, personal or similar leave for unpaid VESSA leave as is appropriate for the employee's situation. Such paid leave must be taken in accordance with the terms of this policy. The substitution of paid leave for unpaid leave under VESSA does not extend the 12 week leave period. In the event there is no deduction made for health insurance premiums, the employee is responsible for remitting payment to the village for monthly premiums. 
The employee is required to provide the village with at least 48 hours advance notice, if possible, of the employee's intention to take a VESSA leave. If the employee is unable to provide advance notice, the employee must provide notice when the employee is able to do so within a reasonable period of time. Failure to provide the required notice may result in treatment of the absences as unexcused. 
The employee is required to submit a certification that the employee or the employee's family or household member is a victim of domestic or sexual violence and that a leave is needed for one of the listed VESSA purposes. This VESSA certification may be satisfied by a sworn statement from the employee and other corroborating evidence (police or court record, documentation from a victim service organization, attorney, clergy or medical professional), once received by the employee. 
(b)  Definitions . 
Domestic violence means domestic abuse, sexual assault or stalking. 
Family or household member , means a spouse, parent, son, daughter, other person related by blood or by present or prior marriage, other person who shares a relationship through a son or daughter, and persons jointly residing in the same household. 
Parent means the biological parent of an employee or an individual who stood in loco parentis to an employee when the employee was a child. 
Son or daughter means a biological, adopted, or foster child, a stepchild, a legal ward, or a child of a person standing in loco parentis, who is under 18 years of age, or is 18 years of age or older and incapable of self-care because of a mental or physical disability. 
(c)  Insurance payments . While on VESSA leave, the employee and the village shall continue to pay for their proportionate share of the village's group health, dental and vision coverage, if the employee is enrolled in said plans at the time VESSA leave starts. Failure of the employee to make the employee's proportionate health, dental and vision insurance payments may result in cessation of coverage for the employee. The village can recover the cost of any premiums paid on behalf of an employee on VESSA leave who fails to return to work after exhausting their leave, unless the continuation, recurrence or onset of domestic or sexual violence or an event beyond the employee's control prevents their return. 
(d)  Confidentiality . All information provided to the village shall be retained in the strictest confidence, except to the extent that disclosure is requested or consented to in writing by the employee or otherwise required by applicable federal or state law. 
(e)  Accruals . During a VESSA leave, pension service will continue to accrue in certain circumstances; however, no sick, vacation, personal or holiday leave benefits, or seniority benefits will accrue to the employee during an unpaid leave. An employee remains entitled to their benefit time that accrued prior to the leave. An employee on VESSA leave is encouraged to discuss these potential accruals with the human resources department. 
(f)  Employee status after VESSA leave . If an employee wishes to return to work at the expiration of the employee's leave, the employee is entitled to return to the same position or to an equivalent position with equal pay, benefits and other terms and conditions of employment. If an employee takes leave because of the employee's own medical condition, the employee is required to provide medical certification that the employee is fit to resume work. 
(g)  Reasonable accommodations . The village supports VESSA and will attempt to provide reasonable accommodations in a timely fashion for employees who are entitled to reasonable accommodations under VESSA, unless such accommodations would present an undue hardship for the Village or unless the employee cannot perform the essential functions of the job even with the reasonable accommodation or unless reasonable accommodations are not required by law. 
Reasonable accommodation applies to employees who are otherwise qualified individuals and may include adjustment to a job structure, workplace facility, or work requirement, transfer, reassignment, or modified schedule, leave, a changed telephone number or seating assignment, installation of a lock, implementation of a safety procedure or assistance in documenting domestic or sexual violence that occurs at the workplace or in work-related settings, in response to actual or threatened domestic or sexual violence. 
A qualified individual is an individual who, but for being a victim of domestic or sexual violence or with a family or household member who is a victim of domestic or sexual violence, can perform the essential functions of the employment position that such individual holds or desires. 
Should an employee wish to request a reasonable accommodation pursuant to this policy, the employee should contact the human resources director in writing. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-140. - Voting leave. 
The village encourages its employees to exercise their right to vote. In accordance with the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS 5/17-15, an employee will be permitted up to two hours of paid leave for voting purposes during a general or special election, unless the employee has time to vote before or after work while the polls are open. Such leave will be granted only if the employee's normal work schedule begins less than two hours after the opening of polls and ends less than two hours before the closing of polls. Employees should notify their supervisors at least one day in advance of the absence. The supervisor may specify the hours during which the employee may be excused with pay to vote. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-141. - School visitation leave. 
If an employee finds it necessary to attend school conferences or classroom activities for their dependent children, the employee may be granted up to a total of eight hours each school year, with a maximum of four hours per occurrence. An employee must use all vacation leave, personal leave, compensatory leave, and any other leave except sick leave and disability leave, prior to non-paid time off approval in accordance with the School Visitation Rights Act, 820 ILCS 147/1. An employee must also provide the village with a written request for leave at least seven days in advance unless it is an emergency situation, in which case 24 hours' notice is required. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-142. - Local Government Disaster Service Volunteer Act. 
In accordance with the Disaster Service Volunteer Leave Act, 50 ILCS 122/1, an employee who is a certified disaster service volunteer of the American Red Cross or assigned to the Illinois Emergency Management Agency, may be granted leave from work with pay for no more than 20 working days in a 12-month period due to participation in specialized disaster relief services. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-143. - Blood donation leave. 
In accordance with the Employee Blood Donation Leave Act, 820 ILCS 149, a full-time employee who has been employed at least six months, is eligible to receive paid leave for blood donation; up to one hour every 56 days. This time off must be approved by the employee's department head and medical verification of the blood donation is required. This time off should be scheduled during non-work hours, when possible. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Secs. 62-14462-155. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - DISCIPLINE 
 
Sec. 62-156. - General/at-will employment. 
(a)  Except for employees who may be subject to a separate contract or agreement, or the rules and regulations of the fire and police commission, village employees are "at will" employees and may be dismissed from employment at any time, with or without cause. Adverse actions taken regarding an employee shall be classified as disciplinary or non-disciplinary in nature. 
(b)  Village employees are expected to maintain reasonable standards of performance and conduct. Employees are to use good judgment in their positions and treat other employees and citizens of the village properly. The village has established certain guidelines, rules and procedures regarding disciplinary actions which must be followed by employees. However, none of these guidelines, rules and procedures are intended to create a requirement of cause for termination of an employee. 
(c)  Although village employees may be discharged from employment with or without cause, when a disciplinary action is involved, the village supervisor shall take into account the seriousness of an offense, the employee's previous work record, and any other relevant information, when determining the type of discipline appropriate for an offense. It is the general policy of the village to apply progressive discipline where possible and practical. However, progressive discipline is not mandatory, and employees who commit serious first offenses will receive appropriate discipline, up to and including termination of employment. 
(d)  Nothing described in this section shall apply to reductions in force or reassignments due to reorganization or economic decisions of the village as further described in section 62-237 herein. The village retains the sole right to determine staffing level needs and organizational structure. Employee demotions, transfers, reassignments or discharges arising out of such reorganizations or reductions in force shall not be considered disciplinary action pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-157. - Cause for disciplinary action. 
Just cause for disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment, shall include, but is not limited to, the following actions: 
(1)  The employee has violated any provisions of this section or department policies, rules or regulations. 
(2)  The employee has been under the influence of i) a prescription medication taken in a manner other than that prescribed by the employee's doctor; ii) intoxicating liquor; iii) cannabis, or iv) a controlled substance while on duty, operating village property or equipment, or performing duties associated with the employee's position with the village. 
(3)  The employee has been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or moral depravity as specified in state statutes or village ordinance. 
(4)  The employee has violated any lawful official regulation or order, or has failed to obey any proper direction made and given by a supervisor or another party acting at the direction of a supervisor. 
(5)  The employee has been guilty of insubordination or conduct tending to bring the village or its employees into disgrace or discredit. 
(6)  The employee is offensive in his conduct or language in public or towards the public, village officials or fellow employees while on duty. 
(7)  The employee is incompetent, inefficient, or negligent in the performance of the duties of his position. 
(8)  The employee is careless or negligent with the monies of the village. 
(9)  The employee has failed to pay or make reasonable provisions for future payment of his debts to such an extent that such failure is detrimental to the reputation of the village. 
(10)  The employee has used, threatened to use, or attempted to use, personal or political influence in securing promotion, leave of absence, transfer, change of pay rate or character of work. 
(11)  The employee has induced, or has attempted to induce, an employee of the village to commit an unlawful act or to act in violation of any lawful department or official regulation or order. 
(12)  The employee has taken for his personal use from any person any fee, gift or other valuable thing in the course of his work, or in connection with it, when such gift or other valuable thing may create a reasonable perception that the action will result in better treatment than that accorded to any other person. 
(13)  The employee has engaged in outside business activities on village time, or has used village property for such activity. 
(14)  The employee has failed to maintain a satisfactory attendance record, which may include habitual tardiness. 
(15)  The employee has abused the sick leave privilege. 
(16)  The employee has been negligent or careless in the operation of village property. 
(17)  The employee has violated the village's policy regarding harassment or sexual harassment. 
(18)  The employee commits any act which endangers the safety, health, or well-being of another person, which is of such magnitude that the consequences act to cause a work disruption or unfavorable view of the village generally. 
(19)  The employee has committed theft or willful destruction of village property or the property of any other village employee. 
(20)  The employee has falsified or improperly amended time sheets, personnel records, employment applications or any other village records. 
(21)  The employee knowingly and intentionally made a false written or oral report or statement including, but not limited to, records pertaining to the employee's time and attendance, performance of duties, internal inquiry, personnel records, employment applications, and request for sick or bereavement leave. 
(22)  The employee has his/her driving privileges suspended or revoked or is prohibited from possessing or carrying a firearm when such activities are a necessary part of the employee's duties. 
(23)  Refusal to comply with a request for drug screening or alcohol testing where reasonable suspicion exists or where required by collective bargaining agreement, or state or federal laws, or the failure of the employee to submit to treatment or follow up testing for alcohol or drug abuse after testing positively in random, post-accident, or reasonable suspicion testing. 
(24)  Refusal to contact EAP in a timely manner following a mandatory referral, or failure to remain in compliance with the treatment as directed. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-158. - General procedure for disciplinary action. 
Disciplinary action may range from oral notification of an employee's unsatisfactory performance, written reprimand, suspension and/or termination of employment. 
(1)  Oral notification to employee of unacceptable performance. Should an employee's performance, attitude, work habits or personal conduct fall below an acceptable level, but not rise to the level of immediate termination, the employee's supervisor shall promptly notify the employee of such problem, and if practicable, assist the employee to improve himself. The supervisor may allow a reasonable period of time for such improvement, if practicable. The supervisor will also document the notification of unacceptable performance in writing. A copy of such writing shall be filed in the employee's personnel file. 
(2)  Written reprimand. Written warnings and reprimands will be used for repeated misconduct of a minor nature or for more serious misconduct which does not warrant suspension, demotion or termination. A written reprimand is considered more serious than an oral reprimand, but less serious than suspension, demotion or termination. A copy of an employee's written reprimand shall be filed in the employee's personnel file. 
(3)  Suspension. An employee may be suspended without pay by a department head for reasons of misconduct, negligence, inefficiency, insubordination, unauthorized absence or any other justifiable reason not prohibited by the Fair Labor Standards Act, where lesser action would be inappropriate, or after previous oral or written reprimands. The department head shall notify the human resources director in writing no later than 24 hours after the commencement of the suspension. Department heads may suspend an employee for a maximum of five days without prior approval of the village manager. For suspension periods longer than five days, approval of the village manager shall be obtained prior to notification of an employee. 
(4)  Termination. An employee may be terminated by his department head upon approval for such action by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-159. - Criminal charges arising out of employment with the village. 
(a)  Suspension. Subject to Fair Labor Standards Act provisions regarding suspensions, any employee charged with a criminal offense, occurring in the course of employment with the village or arising out of such employment, may be suspended with the approval of the village manager from all rights, assignments, duties and employment with the village. 
(b)  Partial payment of salary. The village manager may authorize continued payment of 50 percent of regular salary to the employees suspended under this section, unless the village manager shall find that the public safety, the ability of the village to render public service, or the public confidence in the village government would be impaired. 
(c)  Termination of suspension. The suspension from village employment pursuant to this section may be terminated by the village manager and back pay awarded to the employee if he is found not guilty, or if the criminal charge as indicated herein is dropped. 
(d)  Exception to provisions. Except with the express approval of the village board of trustees, the provisions of this section shall not apply if the employee accepts other employment during the period of time that the criminal charges are pending. Additionally, nothing herein shall bar disciplinary action against such employees, up to and including termination, based upon the acts or omissions of the employee which are related to the pending criminal charge. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Secs. 62-16062-180. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - GRIEVANCES AND APPEALS 
 
Sec. 62-181. - In general. 
Village employees are encouraged to promptly bring to the attention of their immediate supervisor any concern, complaint, question, or grievance which relates to their work situation. If for some reason an immediate supervisor is not an appropriate person to whom a particular concern can be brought, employees should either contact their department head or the human resources director. If either their department head or human resources director is not an appropriate person to whom a particular concern can be brought because of the nature of the issue, employees should contact the village manager. The village manager shall report to the village board any serious work-related concern which has been presented to him by village employees. 
It is the policy of the village to attempt to conduct personnel actions that are fair, and that provide an open line of communication with village employees. It is the desire of the village to adjust the causes of grievances informally, and both supervisors and employees are expected to make every effort to resolve problems in an open, direct and efficient manner. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-182. - Procedure for grievances. 
The following procedures shall govern the consideration of employee grievances except those covered by contract: 
(1)  An employee may present a grievance, or have an employee committee, selected by the employee, present the grievance on behalf of the employee. The following is the order for submission of a grievance. 
a.  Immediate supervisor. 
b.  Department head. 
c.  Human resources director. 
d.  Village manager. 
(2)  Each level in the above-listed order will have ten working days from receipt of the grievance to provide the employee a written response. If the employee disagrees with the decision, the employee will have ten working days from receipt of the decision to submit the grievance to next higher level of supervision. If the grievance involves one of the listed supervisory employees, the employee may submit the grievance directly to the next higher level. 
(3)  The village manager's decision in the matter is final and the employee will be notified of this final decision. 
(4)  No employee shall be disciplined or discriminated against in any way because of any proper use of this grievance procedure. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 08-82, § 1, 5-19-2008; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-183. - Appeals of disciplinary actions. 
All employees are granted the right to appeal any action taken against them in connection with a disciplinary matter. In such cases for personnel not covered by the rules and regulations of the fire and police commission, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Filing. The employee may file a written appeal to the human resources director not later than ten calendar days after the effective date of the disciplinary action. Such written appeal shall state the action which is being appealed and the reason(s) the action is being appealed. 
(2)  Investigation and level I appeal. The human resources director shall hear appeals submitted by an employee relative to any disciplinary action taken against the employee. Not later than ten calendar days after receipt of such an appeal, the human resources director shall investigate the matter and provide the employee with a written decision and determination of facts and findings on which the decision on the appeal was based. Documents pertaining to the level I appeal shall be filed in the employee's personnel file. 
(3)  Level II appeal. Not later than ten calendar days after receipt of the decision of the human resources director, the employee may file a written appeal of the decision of the human resources director to the village manager. The village manager shall review the determination and decision of the human resources director and render a written decision not later than five calendar days after receipt of the appeal from the employee. Copies of the decision shall be provided to the employee and placed in the employee's personnel file. The village manager shall report the appeal decision to the mayor and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 08-82, § 2, 5-19-2008; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-184. - Review of employee personnel file. 
In accordance to the Personnel Record Review Act (820 ILCS 40), employees may request an appointment with human resources to review their personnel file at a mutually agreed to place and time. In the event an employee does not agree with the contents of a document in their personnel file, the employee may attach a letter to the document which will be added to the personnel file. 
(Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018) 
Editor's note This section does not pertain to personnel files controlled by the board for police and fire commissioners (BFPC) for sworn fire and police personnel, which are governed by Illinois State Law.  
Secs. 62-18562-210. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - MISCELLANEOUS EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 62-211. - State Officials and Employees Ethics Act. 
As indicated further in Chapter 2, Article VIII of the Village's Municipal Code, all officers and employees are strictly prohibited from soliciting or accepting gifts and items of value prohibited by the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act (referred to as "the Act" in this section). Village employees are expected to be familiar with and comply with the provisions of the Act at all times. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-212. - Safety. 
All employees of the Village of Westmont are expected to provide a safe work environment. Employees are expected to practice and promote safety awareness and safe work procedures. The safety of village employees, village contractors and their employees, the public, and of all municipal operations is paramount. Safety will take precedence over expedience or shortcuts. 
(1)  General employee responsibilities. Employees are expected to perform their jobs in a safe manner and attempt to reduce the possibility of accident occurrence. The safety of fellow employees must be an equal concern. Any unsafe condition observed by employees shall be reported to supervisors as soon as practicable. All employees have the responsibility to familiarize themselves with and follow the rules set forth in village safety policies and procedures, as amended from time to time by the village. 
(2)  Operation of village vehicles. Employees operating village vehicles have a special duty to always drive defensively and courteously. Employees must follow the standard operating procedures for motor vehicles at all times ("The Rules of the Road"). Employees involved in traffic accidents should follow procedures set forth in "The Rules of the Road" as well as any and all procedures promulgated by their department head. 
(3)  Supervisor responsibilities. It is the responsibility of all department heads, supervisors and managers to make the safety of human beings in the workplace a part of their daily and hourly concern. This responsibility must be accepted by all who conduct the affairs of the village, no matter in what capacity they may function. Supervisors at all levels are charged with advancing the safety and loss prevention programs outlined in village policies and procedures. It shall be the responsibility of the village manager, in unison with the department heads, to develop and implement a proactive safety and loss control program, to provide and maintain safe and healthy working conditions, and to develop operating practices that will provide all employees and contractors with safe working conditions. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Secs. 62-21362-235. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - SEPARATION FROM EMPLOYMENT 
 
Sec. 62-236. - Termination. 
Termination from employment with the village shall cause an employee to be separated from pay status. A department head, with approval of the village manager, may terminate an employee with or without cause during employment, or at any time during an employee's qualification period. Upon termination, all village property must be returned. An employee may be subject to criminal prosecution in the event village property is not returned. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-237. - Reduction in force. 
(a)  Village employees may be terminated when the village manager deems it necessary by reason of: 
(1)  Shortage of funds or work; 
(2)  Abolishment of a position; 
(3)  Other material changes in employment duties or organization of the village. 
Termination for the above reasons is non-disciplinary in nature and is termed "reduction in force." 
(b)  The village shall use its best efforts to provide employees subject to a reduction of force notification of the reason and effective date of separation at least two weeks prior to the separation date. 
(c)  Job position, seniority, performance appraisal, conduct and qualifications shall be considered in determining the order of reduction of force. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 09-53, § 1, 4-20-2009)  
Sec. 62-238. - Resignation. 
In the event that an employee desires to resign from village employment, the village would request that the employee submit a written resignation to the human resources director. It is the village's preference that the resignation be submitted at least 14 days prior to the employee's last work day. 
The letter of resignation will become part of an employee's permanent file, and leaving the village's service without proper notice may result in ineligibility for re-employment. 
However, the period of notice may be reduced or waived upon recommendation of the department head with concurrence of the village manager. Once a resignation is accepted by the village manager, it may not be rescinded. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-239. - Retirement pension 
All full-time employees and eligible part-time employees shall be included in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF) and are governed by the provisions therein. Full-time sworn police department personnel shall be members of the police pension fund. Full-time firefighter personnel shall be members of the fire pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Sec. 62-240. - Payout at separation. 
Upon separation from the village, either voluntarily or involuntarily, employees shall be compensated for unused vacation time from the current year as described further in section 62-97 herein. Additionally, employees may be compensated for unused and accrued sick leave as described further in section 62-131 herein. 
All village owned property must be returned by an employee before separation benefits as described herein are distributed. The replacement cost of any missing items will be deducted from an employee's final paycheck. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 62-241. - Exit interview. 
All employees leaving village service by reason of retirement, voluntary resignation or termination shall be afforded the opportunity of an in-person exit interview with the human resources director. 
(Ord. No. 07-156, 10-15-2007; Ord. No. 18-006a, § 2, 1-4-2018)  
Chapter 63 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]

(Ord. No. 98-148, 12-21-1998)
