Chapter 66 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note Section 1 of Ord. No. 97-17, adopted March 3, 1997, amended ch. 66, art. I, in its entirety to read as herein set forth. Prior to such amendment, ch. 66, art. I, pertained to solid waste, generally, and derived from §§ 13-113-23 of the 1972 Code. 
Cross reference Administration, ch. 2; environmental improvement commission, § 2-421 et seq.; scavengers, § 22-556 et seq.; environment, ch. 38; fire prevention, fire protection and emergency services, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 46; disposal of restaurant wastes, § 46-75; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Law reference Disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes in municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; removal of garbage and debris, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13; land pollution and refuse disposal, 415 ILCS 5/20 et seq.; Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; spilling loads on highways, 625 ILCS 5/15-109. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 66-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial service means solid waste collection service provided to commercial and industrial businesses, for which such service is provided from standard commercial containers, commonly known as dumpsters, and for which billing is made directly by the village's exclusive provider, or, in the case of recyclable materials, by the village's exclusive provider or other licensed provider. 
Recyclable materials and recyclables mean materials which have a useful second life in the economic cycle if they are successfully collected, separated and marketed for return to the economic mainstream. Recyclable materials shall include any and all materials which are to be recycled pursuant to the village's exclusive contract for residential recycling, a list of which may be obtained from the office of the village clerk. 
Refuse means such terms as "garbage," "debris" and "solid waste," and shall include discarded items other than recyclables and yard waste. 
Residential service means solid waste collection service provided to detached or attached single-family dwellings, and to certain townhome or condominium units, for which such service is provided by standard residential containers from each dwelling unit, and for which billing is not made directly to the resident by the village's exclusive provider, unless otherwise provided in the village's exclusive contract for yard waste or other special collections. 
Residential/commercial service means solid waste collection service provided to multiple-family dwellings, including rental units and owner-occupied units, for which such service is provided from standard commercial containers, commonly known as dumpsters, and for which billing is made directly by the village's exclusive provider. 
Village's exclusive provider means the contractor with whom the village has entered into an exclusive contract for solid waste collection services, other than collection of recyclables under the commercial service. 
Yard waste means grass and garden clippings, leaves, weeds, plant materials, brown-stemmed branches and shrub prunings. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 66-2. - Enforcement. 
The code enforcement officer shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997)  
Sec. 66-3. - Exclusive contract for collection service. 
(a)  The village has entered into an exclusive written contract with the village's exclusive provider, for all solid waste collection services, other than the collection of recyclables under the commercial service. 
(b)  Except for the village's exclusive provider, no other person may engage in the business of collecting solid waste in the village, other than collection of recyclables under the commercial service. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997)  
Sec. 66-4. - Containers. 
(a)  Residential specifications . The approved refuse container for the residential service shall be provided to residents by the village's exclusive contractor at no charge to the residents. The approved containers for recyclable materials shall be provided to residents by the village's exclusive contractor at no charge to the residents. The use by residents of non-approved refuse containers or recycling containers is prohibited. 
(b)  Provision of refuse containers . 
(1)  The owners or occupants of any properties which receive the residential/commercial service shall be responsible to arrange with the village's exclusive provider for commercial containers for refuse and recyclables. 
(2)  The owners or occupants of any properties which receive the commercial service shall be responsible to arrange with the village's exclusive provider for commercial containers for refuse collection of an appropriate size, and for pickup of such containers as needed. 
(c)  Placement and removal . 
(1)  Residential service, alley collections . For alley collections, containers shall be placed at the alley line on the premises served, in a suitable space provided for such container by the owner or occupant, so as to be immediately accessible to refuse and recyclable materials collection vehicles. 
(2)  Residential service, curb collections . For curb collections, containers shall be placed at the curbline, not earlier than the evening preceding the designated day of collection, and shall be removed from the curbline not later than the evening of the day of collection. 
(3)  Other collections . No container used for the storage, collection or removal of garbage or other refuse shall be placed so as to constitute a nuisance to adjacent property owners or occupants. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997; Ord. No. 17-087, § 2, 5-25-2017)  
Sec. 66-4.5. - Collection from hotels and food establishments. 
Every person owning or controlling any hotel, restaurant, cafe or retail food establishment where more than 32 gallons of refuse is normally produced weekly shall arrange with the village's exclusive provider for the daily removal of all garbage and refuse from the premises. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997) 
Editor's note Ordinance No. 97-17, codified in this article, contained two sections numbered "66-4." Section 66-4.5 was originally numbered as § 66-4. The section number has been changed at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference Food and food handlers, § 46-31 et seq.  
Sec. 66-5. - Collection schedule. 
Except for food establishments, as provided in section 66-4.5, collection of refuse shall be in accordance with the village's contract with its exclusive provider, but not less than once each week. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997)  
Sec. 66-6. - Rates and billing. 
(a)  Rates. The rates for collection of refuse, recyclable materials, and yard waste shall be as set forth in the village's contract with its exclusive provider, except that the rates for collection of recyclables under the commercial service shall be negotiated between each property owner or occupant and a licensed recycling scavenger. 
(b)  Duty to pay. 
(1)  Residential service. The fee for residential service shall be paid to the village by the owner or occupant of every property entitled to such service, whether or not such service is accepted or utilized, except to the extent the fee is subsidized by the village in accordance with subsection (d) of this section. 
(2)  Residential/commercial and commercial service. For every property which is required to receive residential/commercial service or commercial service, the owner or occupant of such property shall be responsible to pay the required fee for such service directly to the village's exclusive provider, or, for collection of recyclables under the commercial service, to the village's exclusive provider or another licensed recycling scavenger. 
(c)  Application and deposit for residential service. Application for residential service shall be made in writing to the village manager and shall contain an agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept all the provisions of this chapter as conditions governing such service. At the time of application, a deposit shall be made which is equal to the current quarterly fee for such service, which shall be refundable, without interest, at such time as the applicant terminates service at the property. 
(d)  Subsidy for residential service. The village board may from time to time determine to fully or partially subsidize residential and residential/commercial service under such terms and conditions as it may deem to be appropriate. 
(e)  Billing and payment for residential service. Unless the village determines to fully subsidize residential service, billing for such service shall be made quarterly and shall be included on the quarterly water bill for the property. Payment for such service shall be due and payable at the same time that payment for the water bill is due. If any charge for residential service is not paid within 15 days after the date of billing, a penalty of ten percent of the amount of the bill shall be imposed in addition to the original charge. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997)  
Sec. 66-7. - Miscellaneous regulations. 
(a)  Unlawful deposits in refuse containers. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, in any approved refuse container, any article or thing other than refuse. 
(b)  Removal of refuse upon vacating premises. Before vacating any lot, building or structure, or any portion thereof, it shall be the duty of every person occupying or controlling such lot, building or structure, or any portion thereof, to remove or cause to be removed therefrom all refuse, recyclable materials, yard waste or other garbage. 
(c)  Unlawful uncovered deposits. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, anywhere in the village, any uncovered piles of garbage, rubbish, junk, manure, compostable materials, combustible materials or other refuse, except for such materials as may be placed in a compost pile in accordance with subsection (e) of this section. 
(d)  Depositing refuse, recyclables or yard waste on property of another. No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited any refuse, recyclables or yard waste on public property or on the property of another, including deposits into containers, dumpsters, trash cans or barrels which are intended for the deposit of such items by the owners or occupants of such property. The violation of this provision shall be punished by a fine of not less than $75.00 and not more than $750.00, and each day a violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(e)  Composting and compost piles. Yard waste may be placed in a compost pile, provided that such yard waste is placed in such a way as to prevent it from being windblown. The depositing of garbage, pet waste, meat scraps or other materials which may attract animals or vermin to the compost pile, or which may cause an obnoxious odor, shall be prohibited. No compost pile shall be placed in any required front yard or side yard fronting a street, as defined in the village zoning ordinance. Any compost pile shall be set back from any side yard lot line a minimum of three feet, and from the rear lot line a minimum of five feet, and shall not be located less than 30 feet from any neighboring residential dwelling structure. In no event shall a compost pile be located in any side or rear drainage or utility easement. A compost pile shall not exceed five feet in height or 100 square feet in ground or base area. 
(f)  Scavenging for recyclable materials prohibited. it shall be unlawful for any person, other than the village's exclusive provider and any person licensed as a recycling scavenger, to engage in the business of collecting recyclable materials in the village. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 1, 3-3-1997)  
Secs. 66-866-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LITTER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 66-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Litter means and includes, but is not limited to, putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; other putrescible waste, including dead animals, yard clippings and leaves; nonputrescible solid waste, except body waste, including rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, abandoned automobiles, solid market and industrial wastes, paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar materials; and all other waste materials which, if thrown or deposited as prohibited in this article, tend to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1972, § 13-30) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 66-62. - Depositing on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place within the village, except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles or in the village dumps. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street, alley or other public place in the village, the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk and driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk and parkway in front of their premises free from litter. 
(Code 1972, § 13-31)  
Sec. 66-63. - Depositing on private property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter on any private property within the village, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter may be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1972, § 13-32)  
Sec. 66-64. - Throwing from vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, to throw or deposit litter upon any street, alley or other public place within the village or upon private property. 
(Code 1972, § 13-33)  
Sec. 66-65. - Vehicles depositing mud and other substances. 
No person shall drive or move any vehicle or truck within the village, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley, or other public place, mud, debris, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Code 1972, § 13-34) 
State Law reference Spilling loads on highways, 625 ILCS 5/15-109.  
Sec. 66-66. - Duty of property owners to keep property free of litter. 
The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter; however, this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in private receptacles for collection, which receptacles shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be so constructed as to prevent the litter deposited therein from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1972, § 13-35)  
ARTICLE III. - MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURE RECYCLING 
 
Sec. 66-67. - Definitions. 
Multi-family structure is defined for the purposes of this article as a building with more than one residential living unit which is not included in a curbside refuse, recyclables, and landscape waste collection service. 
Multi-family property is defined for purposes of this article as a property consisting of one or more multi-family structures. 
Owner shall mean any persons, corporation, partnership, or entity such as a condominium or homeowners association, jointly or severally having an ownership interest in a multi-family property or otherwise being responsible for solid waste collection for said multi-family property. 
Private scavenger shall mean any person, firm or corporation engaged in the removal of solid waste, compostable materials and/or recyclable material from any location within village not covered by either an exclusive collection contract between the village and a contracted hauler, or a franchise agreement between the village and a franchised hauler. 
Recyclable material is a material which would otherwise be abandoned or discarded but which can be utilized in the secondary material market. 
Recycling shall mean the process by which materials that would otherwise be disposed of or discarded are collected, separated or processed and returned to the economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products. 
Source separation shall mean a process that separates recyclable material from other refuse prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-68. - Multi-family recycling program requirements. 
All multi-family properties, as defined above, shall be required to institute an on-site recycling program, with collection of recyclable materials to be no less than one pickup per week. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-69. - Commencement date. 
Said program shall be instituted by all multi-family properties as defined above on or before January 1, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-70. - Private scavenger services. 
Multi-family property owners may contract for recycling and refuse services with a private scavenger, duly licensed by the village. Multi-family property owners shall be billed for recycling and refuse services directly by the private scavenger. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-71. - Acceptable recycling program. 
An acceptable recycling program shall include, but is not limited to, the following components: 
(1)  Siting and design of common area collection locations for recyclable materials; 
(2)  Recyclable materials collection; 
(3)  Provision of common area recycling containers; 
(4)  Data collection and reporting; 
(5)  Educational campaign and materials; and 
(6)  Recycling program administration and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-72. - Recycling collection areas. 
(a)  Recycling collection areas for residents shall be conveniently located and maintained within common areas in or near the buildings, and consist of separate containers for the purposes of temporary storage of recyclables. Whenever possible, recycling containers should be placed adjacent to common area solid waste collection containers. 
(b)  Indoor common area collection/storage areas shall be established in accordance with village fire or safety codes. 
(c)  Exterior recyclables storage areas shall be established in accordance with village requirements for solid waste enclosures. 
(d)  The multi-family property owner shall maintain all recycling areas, including the containers, in a clean, sanitary, and litter-free manner. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-73. - Types of recyclable materials collected. 
On-site multi-family structure recycling programs are required to offer collection of the same recyclable materials collected through the village residential recycling program as contained in the exclusive contract or franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-74. - Recycling containers. 
(a)  Recyclable materials must be source separated from other solid waste prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. Separate collection containers and collection vehicles shall be employed. 
(b)  The minimum gallon amount of recycling container capacity (base capacity) an owner shall provide weekly for each structure shall be based on the following formula: 
7 gallons × number of 1 bedroom units + 
8 gallons × number of 2- bedroom units + 
9 gallons × number 3 bedroom units + 
= total base weekly recycling container capacity (base capacity) 
(c)  The weekly base recycling container capacity may be met by any combination of container sizes and number of pick-ups, such as containers totaling half the base capacity picked up twice a week. Capacity per structure may be shifted within the multi-family property if necessary so long as the total required capacity is met. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-75. - Hauler responsibilities. 
The licensed private scavenger providing the on-site recycling collection service shall be responsible for furnishing, maintaining, and replacing all common area recycling containers and collection vehicles which are deemed necessary in the recycling program. The private scavenger shall be responsible for the collection, intermediate storage, or transfer, transportation, and sale of recyclable materials to a processor, broker, or market desired for reuse of materials. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-76. - Multi-family owners responsibilities. 
Multi-family property owners shall notify residents of the availability of recycling services through a formal and ongoing educational campaign, and shall use their best efforts to gain and maintain participation in the program. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-77. - Ownership of recyclable materials. 
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized persons to remove or damage any recyclable materials placed in designated containers, or the containers themselves. Title to recyclable material shall pass to the private scavenger when the materials are placed into the collection vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-78. - License requirements. 
(a)  All private scavengers desiring to receive a scavenger license to collect recyclable material from multi-family properties in the village, must comply with all applicable federal, state, county and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. As a condition of receiving, renewing and maintaining a scavenger license to collect recyclable material from multi-family properties within the village, each licensee or applicant for such license shall: 
(1)  Obtain all permits and licenses required by federal, state and county laws, ordinances, rules and regulations and maintain the same in full force and effect. 
(2)  Submit to the village a list of the multi-family properties it serves within the village's jurisdiction. 
(3)  Provide collection and recycling services for any multi-family property owner that requests such services in accordance with the on-site multi-family structure recycling program requirements set forth herein. 
(b)  Failure to comply with the above provisions shall result in a denial of receiving, renewing or maintaining a scavenger license until such time as the applicant complies with all provisions set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-79. - Reporting requirements. 
(a)  Each licensed private scavenger shall submit quarterly reports to both the multi-family property owners or their designee and the village and/or its designee that contains the following information: 
(1)  Total weight or volume of refuse collected from multi-family properties it serves within the village; 
(2)  Total weight or volume of yard waste collection from multi-family properties it serves within the village; 
(3)  Total weight or volume of recyclable materials collected from multi-family properties it serves within the village; 
(4)  A summary of recycling services provided to each multi-family property (to be submitted only on an annual basis with the last quarter report). 
(b)  Quarterly reports submitted to the multi-family property by the licensed private scavenger shall only pertain to that property's activity. 
(c)  Quarterly reports submitted to the village shall contain aggregate totals concerning the information listed above for all multi-family properties the licensed private scavenger serves within the village's jurisdiction. 
(d)  Reports shall be due no later than 15 calendar days after the close of each quarter. Quarters are defined as follows: 
First quarter: January 1 through March 31; 
Second quarter: April 1 through June 30; 
Third quarter: July 1 through September 30; and 
Fourth quarter: October 1 through December 31. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-80. - Implementation of program. 
Implementation of on-site multi-family structure recycling programs shall be required as stated in section 66-68 of this article. Such recycling programs shall be maintained in effect regardless of any change of building ownership or private scavenger service. Multi-family property owners shall be required to notify the village in writing within 30 days after a change in their choice of private scavenger. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Sec. 66-81. - Violation of article. 
Any person, firm or corporation guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 00-121, § 1, 9-18-2000)  
Chapter 70 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Administration, ch. 2; advertising, ch. 6; certain animals prohibited from running at large, § 14-2; solicitation for charitable purposes, § 22-301 et seq.; engineering and flood control, ch. 34; environment, ch. 38; street food vendors, § 46-146 et seq.; planning and development, ch. 63; street and bridge tax, § 74-221 et seq.; telecommunications systems, ch. 76; telecommunications infrastructure maintenance fee, ch. 77; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 82; vegetation, ch. 86; vehicles for hire, ch. 90; land development, app. B; schedule of fees, taxes and charges, app. C. 
State Law reference Local improvements, 65 ILCS 5/9-1-1 et seq.; municipal streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq.; Illinois Highway Code, 605 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.; municipal administration of streets, 605 ILCS 5/7-101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Supervision generally; enforcement. 
All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways shall be under the direction of the public works director and the supervision of the street superintendent. They shall have supervision over all work thereon, and the cleaning thereof, and shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinances relating to such public places, except traffic ordinances, and are hereby authorized to enforce such ordinances. 
(Code 1972, § 23-1; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-2. - Injury to pavement. 
It shall be unlawful to walk upon, drive any vehicle or animal upon or injure any newly laid street or alley pavement while such pavement is guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure or deface any street, sidewalk or alley pavement. 
(Code 1972, § 23-2)  
Sec. 70-3. - Pavement to be kept in good repair; supervision of work. 
All public streets, alleys and sidewalks shall be kept in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the village or the abutting owner, shall be under the supervision of the public works director. 
(Code 1972, § 23-3; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-4. - Duty of village employees to report defects. 
It shall be the duty of every village officer or employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk or any obstruction thereof to report such defect to the public works director as soon as possible. 
(Code 1972, § 23-4; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-5. - Obstructions generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way except as may be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the village manager or public works director. 
(Code 1972, § 23-5; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-6. - Obstructing drains. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any drain in any public street or alley. 
(Code 1972, § 23-6)  
Sec. 70-7. - Obstructing vision at corner lots. 
It shall be unlawful to maintain any hedge or bush or any other object which would obstruct the view on any corner lot at a height greater than 24 inches above the street grade, closer to the street than a distance equal to the setback from the front lot line. A lot located at an intersection between a street and an alley shall be considered a corner lot for purposes of this section only. 
(Code 1972, § 23-7; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1(23-7), 7-17-1995)  
Sec. 70-8. - Duty to keep driveways free from obstructions and in good repair. 
It shall be the duty of any person maintaining any driveway within the village to keep such driveway free from snow and ice or any obstructions and to keep such driveway in good repair where such driveway crosses a public sidewalk. 
(Code 1972, § 23-8)  
Sec. 70-9. - Use of streets for storage of construction materials; bond required. 
The use of streets for the storage of materials in the process of construction or alteration of a building may be granted when such use will not unduly interfere with traffic and will not reduce the usable width of the street to less than 18 feet. No portion of a street other than that directly abutting on the premises on which work is being done shall be used except with the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises abutting on such portion. Any person seeking to make such use of the street shall file an application with the village manager, together with a bond with sureties to be approved by the village attorney, to indemnify the village for any loss or damage which may be incurred by reason of such use and occupation. 
(Code 1972, § 23-9)  
Sec. 70-10. - Bond required for excavations, hauling of heavy equipment over public ways; deposit in lieu of bond; repairs. 
It shall be unlawful to commence work on any excavation, or on any construction work in the village involving driving or hauling machinery, trucks or equipment over any parkway or sidewalk area or involving excavating or leveling of any parkway or sidewalk area, unless the person doing such work shall first have filed with the village a bond, with a corporate surety, conditioned to indemnify the village for any damage done to any village property, including any curb, pavement, cable, pipe, shutoff box or other equipment in the course of such work. 
(1)  Where the work contemplated by this section includes the making of any excavation for any structure or foundation, the bond shall also be conditioned that the building or structure contemplated shall be completed within one year from the date of commencement of the work and the excavation refilled and the surface restored to its original condition. 
(2)  Such bond shall be in the principal amount of $5,000.00, payable to the village in the event of any breach of the conditions of such bond. In lieu of such bond, a deposit of $50.00 may be made by the contractor. 
(3)  Any repairs or replacements of parkways or sidewalks shall be completed within three months of the time such construction is finished. 
(Code 1972, § 23-10)  
Sec. 70-11. - Scaffolds and ladders over public ways. 
Any scaffolds or ladders placed in such a position that they overhang or can fall onto any public street, alley or other public place in the village shall be firmly and properly constructed and safeguarded. 
(Code 1972, § 23-11)  
Sec. 70-12. - Placing articles on window ledges, overhangs. 
It shall be unlawful to place any moveable article on any window ledge or other place abutting on a public street, alley or other public place at a height above four feet from the ground in such a manner that such article can be or is in danger of falling onto such street, alley, sidewalk or other public place. 
(Code 1972, § 23-12)  
Sec. 70-13. - Sidewalk sales. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk or other public place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale without first obtaining permission from the village president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 23-13)  
Sec. 70-14. - Deliveries to businesses on Cass Avenue to be to rear of building. 
All deliveries within the village to business establishments on Cass Avenue must be made at the rear of the establishment, where access to an alley is available. 
(Code 1972, § 23-14)  
Sec. 70-15. - EncroachmentsGenerally. 
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street or other public property. 
(Code 1972, § 23-15)  
Sec. 70-16. - SameWithin project or roadway right-of-way. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Encroachment means any building, fence, sign, or any other structure or object of any kind, with the exception of utilities and public road signs, which is placed, located or maintained in, on, under, or over any portion of the project right-of-way or the roadway right-of-way where no project right-of-way line has been established. 
Permissible encroachment means any existing awning, marquee, advertising sign or similar overhanging structure supported from a building immediately adjacent to the limits of the platted street where there is a sidewalk extending to the building line and which does not impair the free and safe flow of traffic on the highway; the permissive retention of overhanging signs is not to be construed as being applicable to those signs supported from poles constructed outside the project right-of-way line and not confined by adjacent buildings. 
Project right-of-way means those areas within the project right-of-way lines established jointly by the city and state, which will be free of encroachments except as otherwise defined in this section. 
Roadway right-of-way means those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by fee simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement during the time the easement is in effect. 
(b)  Encroachments declared unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or cause to be erected, to retain or cause to be retained, any encroachment within the limits of the project right-of-way or roadway right-of-way where no project right-of-way lines have been established. 
(c)  Intent of section. This section is intended to and shall be in addition to all other ordinances, rules and regulations concerning encroachments and shall not be construed as repealing or rescinding any other ordinance or part of any ordinance unless in direct conflict therewith. 
(Code 1972, § 23-15.1)  
Sec. 70-17. - Erection of poles and wires. 
It shall be unlawful to erect any poles or wires or maintain any poles or wires over any public place, street, alley or other public way without having first secured permission from the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 23-16)  
Sec. 70-18. - Erection of gas pumps. 
It shall be unlawful to maintain or erect any gasoline pump or tank in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1972, § 23-17)  
Sec. 70-19. - Stairways, other openings. 
It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street or alley or sidewalk or other public place without a permit from the public works director. All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitably strong cover or railing subject to the approval of the director of public works and services. 
(Code 1972, § 23-18; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-20. - Deposits on sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk or parkway any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, landscape waste, leaves, vegetation, snow, glass or any other articles which might cause injury to persons, animals or property, or to cross any sidewalk with a truck or other vehicle without protecting the public sidewalk with planking or other methods approved by the village. 
(b)  Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on public sidewalks or parkways preparatory to delivery, provided that the usable width of the public sidewalk is not thereby reduced to less than four feet, and provided that no such article shall remain on such walk for more than ½ hour. 
(c)  No owner or occupant of a residence or business shall cause or allow the shoveling, blowing, plowing, hauling or otherwise depositing snow and ice onto any public sidewalk. This prohibition shall not be construed to require residents to remove snow or ice from sidewalks which has fallen there naturally. 
(Code 1972, § 23-19; Ord. No. 11-197, § 1, 11-21-2011)  
Sec. 70-21. - Deposits on streets and alleys. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public street or alley any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, landscape waste, leaves, vegetation, snow and ice, glass or any other articles which may cause injury to any person, animal or property. 
(b)  Materials may be deposited on public streets and alleys preparatory to delivery for use, provided such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the street or roadway at that point to less than 18 feet and in public alleys not less than 10 feet, and provided that such material, other than material used in actual building construction, shall not be permitted to remain in such street or alley for more than three hours. Any such material shall be guarded by lights if it remains upon any street at nighttime. 
(c)  No owner or occupant of a residence or business shall cause or allow the shoveling, blowing, plowing, hauling or otherwise depositing snow and ice onto any public street or upon any private street, where members of the general public may be reasonably expected to travel. This prohibition shall not be construed to require residents to remove snow or ice from sidewalks which has fallen there naturally. 
(Code 1972, § 23-20; Ord. No. 11-197, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 11-197, § 1, adopted Nov. 21, 2011, amended § 70-21 title to read as herein set out. Former § 70-21 title pertained to deposits on streets.  
Sec. 70-22. - Sump pump discharge. 
(a)  The discharge flow from all sump pumps shall be controlled so as not to create a health or safety hazard or nuisance for the public. Sump pumps shall not be allowed to discharge onto the surface of any village street, alley or sidewalk. 
(b)  If a lot being developed is adjacent to an existing storm sewer, a storm pipe service line shall be provided from the discharge point of the sump drainage to the storm sewer system. If at some time in the future the storm sewer is modified, moved or eliminated, it shall be the sump pump owner's responsibility to modify the storm sewer service line as necessary to meet the requirements of this section. If a storm sewer is not available to connect to, the sump drainage shall be discharged to an adequate surface watercourse. Any point of discharge shall be located at least 25 feet from any village right-of-way and the flow caused to dissipate before reaching such right-of-way. 
(c)  Wherever a new building is contemplated having a basement or crawlspace, the point of discharge of sump pumps from the building shall be shown on the site plan submitted with the permit application. The design for handling the discharge shall adhere to the provisions of this section. 
(d)  For new subdivisions containing at least three lots, a storm sewer system shall be provided to handle the drainage of the subdivision as well as the sump flows of all the lots in the subdivision. Storm sewer services shall be provided between discharge points from each building and the storm sewer system. 
(e)  Piping intended to service the sump discharge from more than one building shall be adequately sized, but not less than six inches in diameter. Storm sewer piping serving sump pump discharges for individual buildings shall not be less than four inches in diameter. Storm sewer service pipe for sump pump discharges shall be polyvinylchloride pipe meeting ASTM D 3034 for SDR 35 pipe; ductile iron pipe meeting AWWA C-151; or concrete pipe conforming to ASTM C14. 
(f)  Sump pump discharge lines shall be installed sufficiently deep so as to prevent freezing. Except where elevations at the storm sewer connection point prevent this criteria being met, minimum cover shall be three feet. 
(g)  Whenever a direct connection to the storm sewer is made, a checkvalve bypass or other special design may be necessary to prevent backup flows from the storm drainage system. The village shall not be responsible for damages caused by backup flows due to poor service design or malfunctioning equipment on the service line. 
(h)  Whenever a connection is proposed to a storm sewer or drainage ditch, an engineering permit must be obtained before work commences. The cost of the permit shall be a minimum of $20.00. A cash bond of at least $300.00 shall also be posted to ensure that completion of the work follows village standard specifications. 
(i)  Sump pump systems existing on the date of adoption of this section shall be modified within 30 days of village notice of noncompliance with this section. 
(Code 1972, § 23-21)  
Sec. 70-23. - Construction and regulation of mailboxes. 
All residential mailboxes within the village shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Mailbox standards. The standards for the placement of freestanding mailboxes shall be as follows: The face of the mailbox shall not be less than eight inches nor more than 12 inches from the back edge of the curb, or where no curb exists, less than 16 inches nor more than 20 inches from the near edge of the public street pavement. 
(2)  Mailbox construction. Mailboxes shall be mounted on a support structure which is a minimum of four inches by four inches or a maximum of six inches by six inches treated wood post, or a minimum 1½ inches to a maximum of three inches diameter light gauge galvanized steel hollow pipe, or on such similar structure as is approved by the streets superintendent, and found by him to be of comparable quality and safety to the wooden post or light gauge steel pipe structures. 
(3)  Prohibited construction. Other support structures, including but not limited to, masonry columns, railroad rails and ties, tractor wheels, plow blades, milk cans, and barrels filled with concrete or sand, are expressly forbidden. 
(4)  Failure to comply. Failure to comply with these mailbox regulations may result in penalties pursuant to section 1-8 of this Code, and shall render the mailbox owner ineligible to receive any appropriate reparations under subsection (e) hereof. 
(5)  Reparations. In the event of municipal snow plowing along the streets of the village which results in direct contact damaging a mailbox which is in compliance with this section, the village shall make reparations to the mailbox owner in an amount of said damage, not to exceed $100.00 per mailbox per event causing such damage. Nonconforming mailboxes and/or nonconforming mailbox support structures previously in existence upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived which are damaged by direct contact by municipal snow plowing along the streets of the village, shall likewise be entitled to reparations not to exceed $100.00 per event causing such damage. 
(Ord. No. 00-113, § 1, 9-5-2000)  
Secs. 70-2470-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND EXCAVATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-51. - Barricades and lighting. 
(a)  Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place or making an excavation in such pavement shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury of any person or vehicle by reason of the work; such barricades shall be protected by suitable lights at nighttime. 
(b)  Any defect in any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place shall be barricaded to prevent injury, and any person properly maintaining any opening or excavation in any such place shall guard such opening or excavation while it remains open by proper barricades and lights. 
(Code 1972, § 23-31)  
Sec. 70-52. - Disturbing barricades, warning lights. 
It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or lights lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1972, § 23-32)  
Secs. 70-5370-70. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - EXCAVATIONS AND TUNNELING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference Excavations near trees and shrubs, § 86-39. 
 
Sec. 70-101. - Permit required; compliance; alternative methods. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tunnel under or to make any excavation in any street, alley or other public place in the village without having obtained a permit therefor and complying with the provisions of this division and the terms of the permit. 
(b)  No permit for any excavation in or open cutting of any street and alley shall issue unless and until the public works director determines that an alternative method of tunneling or augering under such street and alley cannot practicably be accomplished. 
(Code 1972, § 23-51; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-102. - Exemptions from permit. 
The provisions of this division relative to securing permits shall not apply to officers or employees of the village engaged in doing work for the village; nor to persons doing work for the village under contract; nor to persons operating under a franchise or grant from the village if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels without securing a permit therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 23-52)  
Sec. 70-103. - Application for permit; contents. 
Application for a permit required by this division shall be made to the public works director and shall describe the location of the intended excavation or tunnel, the size thereof, the purpose therefor, the person doing the actual excavating work, and the name of the person for whom the work is being done. The application shall also contain an agreement that the applicant will comply with all ordinances and laws relating to the work to be done. 
(Code 1972, § 23-53; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-104. - Permit fees. 
The fees to be paid for permits required by this division are as shown in section 34-111. 
(Code 1972, § 23-54; Ord. No. 93-28, § 23-54, 5-17-1993; Ord. No. 05-254, § 5, 11-7-2005)  
Sec. 70-105. - Deposit. 
In addition to a permit fee, any person desiring to do work requiring a permit under this division shall be required to deposit a cash bond as shown in section 34-112. 
(Code 1972, § 23-55; Ord. No. 93-28, § 23-55, 5-17-1993; Ord. No. 05-254, § 5, 11-7-2005)  
Sec. 70-106. - Bond required. 
Each applicant for a permit required by this division shall file a bond in the amount of $100,000.00 for each person, $300,000.00 for each accident, and $50,000.00 for property damages, with sureties to be approved by the village attorney, conditioned to indemnify the village from any loss or damage resulting from the work undertaken or the manner of doing such work. Such bond is to be filed with the public works director. 
(Code 1972, § 23-56; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-107. - Time limit on work permits; notice of completion. 
Openings or excavations authorized by a permit issued under this division shall be made within five days from the date of such permit, unless an extension is granted, and the work for which such opening or excavation was made shall be completed within three days thereafter. The village shall be immediately notified as to completion of such work. 
(Code 1972, § 23-57)  
Sec. 70-108. - Manner of excavating. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to make any excavation or tunnel without providing proper bracing to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground and no excavation shall have anywhere below the surface any portion which extends beyond the opening at the surface. 
(b)  No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables or conduits in the making of excavations or tunnels; and notice shall be given to the persons maintaining any such pipes, cables or conduits or to the village department or officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel before such pipes, cables or conduits shall be disturbed. 
(c)  No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree or shrub or the roots thereof during the course of the making of excavations or tunnels. 
(Code 1972, § 23-58)  
Sec. 70-109. - Temporary sidewalks required. 
If any sidewalk is blocked by any excavation work a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users. 
(Code 1972, § 23-59)  
Sec. 70-110. - Restoration of street, pavements. 
Any person obtaining a permit under this division shall restore all excavations in any pavement, street, alley or other public ground in accordance with specifications which are available in the public works department. 
(Code 1972, § 23-60; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-111. - Notice prior to backfilling. 
Notice shall be given to the public works director at least ten hours before the work of refilling any excavation or tunnel commences. 
(Code 1972, § 23-61; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-112. - Inspections. 
The public works director shall provide inspections of all excavations and tunnels being made in or under any public street, alley or other public place in the village to ensure the enforcement of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1972, § 23-62; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)

ARTICLE III. - REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE 
 
Sec. 70-136. - From dedicated, unaccepted streets. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to ensure the safety of the village streets not yet formally accepted by keeping them substantially clear of unreasonable accumulations of snow and ice. Until final acceptance of a planned unit development or subdivision's streets, this responsibility should properly rest on the developer thereof. 
(b)  Responsibility of developer. The subdivider or developer shall be responsible for keeping reasonably clear of ice and snow all dedicated, unaccepted streets within a subdivision. A snow of over two inches, locally measured, and/or a snow that drifts which may obstruct or impair normal traffic movement, shall be removed within six hours of the accumulation thereof. If such accumulation is not removed within the aforementioned period, the village will effect such removal at cost to the developer. In addition, the developer shall keep the streets substantially clear of ice and snow to the maximum degree possible, weather conditions permitting. Further, to ensure safety of drivers and reduce equipment damage, all developers shall bridge manholes on streets that have only a base course. The material used for bridging shall be comparable to that used for the base. 
(c)  Agreement with village. The developer may fulfill the obligations of this section by entering into an agreement with the village for the removal of snow and ice based upon the cost of such removal to the village. The developer shall hold the village harmless and indemnified for any and all damages to subdivision street improvements resulting from ice and snow removal, and shall repair any such damages prior to acceptance of such street improvements by the village. The developer shall also indemnify the village for any damage to village equipment caused by improper street construction. 
(d)  Bond requirement. All developers with dedicated, unaccepted streets shall post a cash bond in the following amount based upon lineal mileage of dedicated, unaccepted streets: 
Under two miles ..... $ 2,500.00 
Two miles to four miles ..... 5,000.00 
Four miles to seven miles ..... 7,500.00 
Over seven miles ..... 10,000.00 
Such bond must be posted by November 1 of each year and will be returned to the developer upon satisfactory compliance with this section on May 1 of the following year. Under such bond requirement, it is the responsibility of the developer to keep all dedicated, unaccepted streets clear of ice and snow or contract with the village for this service. Either improper maintenance of ice and snow removal or failure to promptly reimburse the village for such costs or pursuant to any such service agreement will result in forfeiture of part or all of the bond. 
(e)  Insurance requirement for contractors or subcontractors clearing streets. Any person performing ice or snow removal work shall maintain, for a period from November 1 through May 1 of any winter season, liability and property damage insurance in the amount of $1,000,000.00 each person, $1,000,000.00 aggregate, which shall cause such person, village and the village's representatives to be named insured against liability and property damages which may arise from ice and snow removal work. Such certificate shall be in form and substance satisfactory to and approved by the village. Workers' compensation and employer's liability insurance must also be provided by the contractor, with a minimum amount of $100,000.00 for employer's liability. 
(Code 1972, § 23-98(a)(e))  
Secs. 70-13770-155. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - LOT NUMBERING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 70-156. - Numbering plan. 
(a)  All lots, buildings and structures in the village shall be numbered in accordance with the following plan: 
(1)  On streets running north and south or northerly and southerly, even numbers shall be used on the west side of the street and odd numbers on the east side of the street. 
(2)  On streets running east and west, even numbers shall be used on the north side of the street and odd numbers on the south side of the street. 
(3)  Numbers of lots shall be apportioned on the basis of one for every 25 feet. 
(b)  The following baselines shall be used in implementing the provisions of this article: 
(1)  For all streets running north and south or northerly and southerly, the right-of-way of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad tracks shall be taken as a baseline and the lots north of such right-of-way shall start with the number 1 and increase northerly. Lots south of the baseline shall begin with the number 1 of such baseline and increase southerly. 
(2)  For all streets running east and west or easterly and westerly, Cass Avenue will be taken as the baseline and lots shall begin at number 1 at such baseline and increase both westerly and easterly. 
(Code 1972, § 23-73)  
Sec. 70-157. - Short streets to conform to plan. 
Short streets that do not extend to the baselines established by this article shall be as uniform as possible with the corresponding section of other parallel streets. 
(Code 1972, § 23-74)  
Sec. 70-158. - Street names to include location prefix. 
Streets which cross either of the baselines established by this article shall have prefixed to their names the word "North," "South," "West" or "East," as their location may require. 
(Code 1972, § 23-75)  
Sec. 70-159. - Chart to be kept; availability for inspection. 
The economic development director shall keep a chart showing the proper street number of every lot in the village, which shall be open to inspection by interested persons. 
(Code 1972, § 23-76; Ord. No. 07-102, § 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-160. - Placement of house numbers by owners and occupants; size of numbers; failure to comply. 
It shall be the duty of the owner and/or occupants to display the approved building identification number (address numbers) in a location and manner that is visible from the public right-of-way (i.e. alley, street or road fronting the property) as follows: 
(1)  Single-family residential premises identification: Single-family residences shall have approved address numbers that contrast with their background. Address numbers shall be in Arabic numerals or alphabet letters. Address numbers shall be a minimum of four inches (101.6 mm) high with a minimum stroke width of 0.5 inches (12.7 mm). Address numbers shall be placed on the front of the house facing the street. If a fence, garage or other structure is built adjacent to an alley or other vehicle access route, secondary address numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous location on the side of the fence, garage or other structure facing the alley or other vehicle access route. Such secondary address numbers shall conform to the size requirements stated above. Such secondary address numbers shall not be required where the rear of the property is not adjacent to an alley or other vehicle access route or where no fence, garage or other structure is located adjacent to an alley or other vehicle access route. New and existing single-family residences must comply with this code requirement. 
(2)  Multiple-family dwellings and commercial premises identification: Multiple-family dwelling buildings and commercial buildings (or structures) shall have approved address numbers that shall contrast with their background. Address numbers shall be in Arabic numerals or alphabet letters. Address numbers shall be a minimum of six inches (152.4 mm) high with a minimum stroke width of 0.5 inches (12.7 mm). Address numbers shall be located on the front of the building (or structure). If a building, fence, garage or other structure is located or built adjacent to an alley, access road, parking lot or other vehicle access route, secondary address numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous location on the side of the building, garage, fence, or structure or otherwise as directed by the village community development department. Where required by a building code, fire, or police official, additional address numbers shall be provided in additional approved locations to facilitate emergency response (i.e. on doors accessing a multi-tenant building). Such secondary or additional address numbers shall conform to the size requirements stated above. Secondary address numbers shall not be required where the property is not adjacent to an alley, access road, parking lot or other vehicle access route. New and existing multiple-family dwellings and commercial buildings or structures must comply with this code requirement. 
(3)  Any person failing to comply with the provisions of this section after receiving notice to do so from the village shall be subject to the penalty prescribed in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 23-77; Ord. No. 18-142, § 2, 9-13-2018)  
Secs. 70-16170-180. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PARADES AND OPEN AIR MEETINGS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference Parades in connection with circus, § 22-1102. 
State Law reference Illinois Public Demonstrations Law, 430 ILCS 70/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 70-181. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Open air meeting means any congregation of citizens held outdoors and upon any public property for the purpose of hearing speakers or discussing some matter of common interest where the number of participants expected may reasonably be assumed to exceed 50. 
Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the village. 
(Code 1972, § 23-88) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-182. - PermitRequired. 
No person shall participate in a parade or open air meeting on any public way or on any public property unless a written permit therefor shall first be obtained from the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 23-89)  
Sec. 70-183. - SameApplication; contents. 
Applications to conduct a parade or open air meeting shall be made in writing to the chief of police at least 72 hours prior to the event by a representative of the group seeking the permit, and shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the parade or open air meeting. 
(2)  If the parade or open air meeting is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the chairman of the parade or open air meeting. 
(4)  The date when the parade or open air meeting is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point, the termination point, and the location of the speakers' platforms. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade or open air meeting; the type of animals and the description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The hours when such parade or open air meeting will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade or open air meeting. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas. 
(Code 1972, § 23-90)  
Sec. 70-184. - Hours when permitted. 
All parades shall be held during daylight hours at times other than between 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and not before noon on Sundays. All open air meetings shall conclude by midnight and shall not be held before noon on Sunday. 
(Code 1972, § 23-91)  
Sec. 70-185. - Number of participants. 
Parades and open air meetings shall be limited to such numbers of persons as will not obstruct either vehicular or pedestrian traffic in an unreasonable manner, and in no event shall a parade or open air meeting consist of more than 500 persons. 
(Code 1972, § 23-92)  
Sec. 70-186. - Action on application for permit; reapplication. 
(a)  Following receipt of an application or reapplication for a permit required by this article, the chief of police shall, within 24 hours, either issue a permit for a parade or open air meeting or reject the application. 
(b)  Permits for parades and open air meetings may be rejected on the basis of improper or incomplete application or other valid reasons, and the reasons for such rejection shall be made known to the applicant, in writing, at the time of rejection. 
(c)  The applicant for a permit under this article shall be allowed to correct or complete an improper application and resubmit it to the chief of police, the original 72-hour required advance notification time being still valid if a corrected application is resubmitted within 24 hours prior to the time of the event. If a corrected application is not received by the chief of police within 24 hours prior to the time of the event, a new period of 48 hours will be imposed prior to which the event may not be held. Such 48-hour period shall commence upon receipt of the corrected application. 
(Code 1972, § 23-93)  
Sec. 70-187. - Conflicting applications; limitations on issuance of permits. 
(a)  If the chief of police shall receive more than one application for a parade or open air meeting at the same time and the same place, or on the same day, the applications filed first in time shall take precedence. 
(b)  An application shall be considered to be "at the same time" for the purpose of this section if the event is scheduled to commence within two hours before or after the holding of another event. 
(c)  An application shall be considered to be "at the same place" for the purpose of this section if the requested parade route comes at any point within six blocks or any equivalent distance from the route of another parade or if the open air meeting is conducted within one-half mile of another open air meeting. 
(d)  If the chief of police receives an application for more than one parade or open air meeting in a single day, he may set a time for the duration of each parade or open air meeting, which time shall not, without the consent of the group seeking the permit, be less than three hours. 
(e)  The chief of police shall issue permits for more than a single parade during one day in accordance with the requirements of this article; however, he may not issue multiple permits beyond the point at which the issuance of an additional permit would require the continuing diversion of so great a number of police officers or other village personnel so as to prevent normal police protection or other services to the village. 
(Code 1972, § 23-94)  
Sec. 70-188. - Chief of police may prescribe conditions, regulate parking. 
The chief of police may prescribe the conditions governing any parade or open air meeting held or proposed to be held on any public street in the village, should the public interest so require. He may, for limited periods of time, prohibit or restrict parking on any street where unrestricted or restricted parking is permitted if signs are placed, police officers stationed, or other steps are taken to inform the public of such special regulations. 
(Code 1972, § 23-95)  
Secs. 70-18970-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC SIDEWALK POLICY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 05-285, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Dec. 19, 2005, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions have been included herein as Article VI, §§ 70-20170-204. The users attention is also directed to § 70-73. 
 
Sec. 70-201. - Introduction. 
This article is intended to formalize a policy for the installation of public sidewalks in the Village of Westmont, Illinois. 
(1)  Reason for installation. Walking is a basic means of travel for citizens. It is the village's desire to install paved public sidewalks in order to provide a clean and safe path for use by pedestrians. 
(2)  Goal of the policy. It is the village's intention to provide public sidewalks initially on at least one side of all streets in the village and on both sides of all heavily-traveled streets in order to minimize the need for pedestrians to cross over said streets to access a public sidewalk. Ultimately, the village intends to provide public sidewalks on both sides of all streets within the village's boundaries. 
(3)  Sidewalk maintenance. Once installed, the village desires to keep its sidewalks in reasonably safe condition for use by the public. To this end, an Inspection and Repair Program has been established, and this is described in the attached Appendix A. 
(Ord. No. 05-285, § 1(Exh. A), 12-19-2005) 
Note Appendix A, referenced above, is not set out herein but is on file and available for inspection in the village offices.  
Sec. 70-202. - Location. 
(a)  General location. 
(1)  Within the village: Public sidewalks shall be located along both sides of all streets in the village. 
(2)  Within the right-of-way: Public sidewalks are generally installed one-foot from the edge of the right-of-way (ROW). This location may be adjusted with the public works director's approval where existing trees or obstructions interfere with the proposed location. However, in order to provide room for snow storage, whenever possible, no sidewalk should be located less than five feet from the edge of the street pavement or back edge of curb and gutter, where it exists. 
(b)  High-priority locations. Wherever there are no existing public sidewalks, priority shall be given to their installation in certain locations where high usage is expected, such as: 
(1)  Schools, parks, and churches: At least one side of the street, within a minimum of 1,200 feet from the property. 
(2)  Business districts: Both sides of streets, to reduce the need for pedestrians to cross. 
(3)  Arterial and collector roads: Both sides of streets, to reduce the need for pedestrians to cross. 
(c)  New development and redevelopment. Village Code requires that public sidewalks be installed along all street rights-of-way where none yet exists. Permits for construction of subdivisions, buildings on individual lots, and additions of 150 square feet or greater shall include the installation of the required sidewalks. In addition, any existing sidewalk that is in need of repair adjacent to said construction shall be required to be replaced as part of the permit. Village staff shall ensure that this requirement is being followed. 
(d)  Special requests. 
(1)  Recommended by staff. Village staff shall maintain a list of locations that have shown a special need for having a sidewalk. 
(2)  Requested by residents. From time to time, the village may receive sidewalk requests from residents. A separate list of these locations shall be maintained for consideration as funding becomes available. In addition to the high priority locations listed above, the village shall give preference to locations that would be an extension to existing sidewalks or complete an entire block. Also, a location will more likely be moved up in priority if the resident or residents offer to pay half or all of the installation costs. 
a.  When a request is received from an owner for a location that is in front of that owner's lot and is adjacent to an existing sidewalk or sidewalks, the village shall immediately add the location to the consideration list. 
b.  When a proposed location is in front of properties with one or more owners. Other than the person making the request, the request must include evidence that at least 51 percent of the owners desire to have the sidewalk installed. Otherwise, the proposed sidewalk shall not be added to the consideration list. 
(Ord. No. 05-285, § 1(Exh. A), 12-19-2005; Ord. No. 06-39, § 1(Exh. A), 3-6-2006; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 70-203. - Scheduling of installation. 
(a)  General. In order to meet the goals described above, the village shall schedule the installation of sidewalks as soon as practicable as needs are identified and as funding permits. 
(b)  Setting priorities. As lists of proposed sidewalk locations are developed, it may be necessary to prioritize the scheduling of the installations. A high priority shall be given to those locations listed above in section 70-202(b). Special request locations shall be considered based on amount of public benefit. 
(c)  Funding. The village shall strive to provide a reasonable amount of funding each year for sidewalk installation in its annual budget. In order to maximize the available funds, the village shall continue its current practice of applying for federal and state grants as they become available. 
(Ord. No. 05-285, § 1(Exh. A), 12-19-2005)  
Sec. 70-204. - ExceptionsAppeals. 
(a)  Requirements for a waiver. It is strongly recommended that village requirements for sidewalks be followed, but if a waiver is desired, only the village board can grant a waiver. 
(b)  Cash in-lieu-of payment. If a waiver is granted, the costs for construction of the sidewalk shall be paid to the village to defray the future costs of installation of that sidewalk. The village shall determine the costs using current prices. 
(Ord. No. 05-285, § 1(Exh. A), 12-19-2005)  
Chapter 74 - TAXATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 74-1. - Working cash fund established; tax. 
There is hereby created and established a working cash fund in the village, which fund shall be levied and collected in like manner as the general taxes of the village, and shall be in addition to the maximum of all other taxes which this municipality is authorized by law to levy upon the taxable property within the village. 
(Code 1972, § 25-1) 
State Law reference Working cash fund, 65 ILCS 5/8-7-1 et seq.  
Sec. 74-2. - Tax for public liability insurance authorized. 
The levy of a tax sufficient in amount to pay the cost of purchasing public liability insurance is hereby authorized, and shall be exclusive of and in addition to the amount of tax which the village may levy for general purposes. 
(Code 1972, § 25-2)  
Secs. 74-374-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX AND NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 15-081, § 2, adopted May 14, 2015, repealed Art. II, §§ 74-3174-38. Section 3 of said ordinance added a new Art. II, §§ 74-3174-33, as set out herein. Former Art. II pertained to the Municipal Retailer's Occupation Tax and derived from Code 1972, §§ 25-1825-21; Ord. No. 08-141, § 2, adopted Sept. 15, 2008; and Ord. No. 08-160, § 2, adopted Oct. 20, 2008. 
 
Sec. 74-31. - Tax imposed. 
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled and registered with an agency of this State's government, at retail in this municipality at the rate of one-half percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this article is in effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality in the business of making sales of service, at the rate of one-half percent of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. This "Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax" and this "Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax" shall not be applicable to the sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and non-prescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics. 
The imposition of these non-home rule taxes is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of sections 8-11-1.1, 8-11-1.2, 8-11-1.3 and 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.1, 8-11-1.2,8-11-1.3 and 8-11-1.4). 
(Ord. No. 15-081, § 3, 5-14-2015)  
Sec. 74-32. - Illinois Department of Revenue to Administer. 
The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois. The department of revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-081, § 3, 5-14-2015)  
Sec. 74-33. - Limitations on use of tax revenue. 
The tax revenue received by the village pursuant to section 74-31 shall be utilized exclusively by the village to address municipal stormwater and infrastructure improvements. 
(Ord. No. 15-081, § 3, 5-14-2015)

ARTICLE V. - AUTOMOBILE RENTAL USE AND OCCUPATIONAL TAXES 
 
Sec. 74-111. - Tax on use of rental vehicle from outside state. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in this village an automobile which is rented from a renter outside the state and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government in this village, at the rate of one percent of the rental price of such automobile, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code. [5] 
(b)  The tax provided for in this section shall be collected from the persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being in this village. 
(c)  The tax imposed by this section shall be paid to the state department of revenue. 
(Code 1972, § 25-101)

Sec. 74-112. - Tax on automobile rental business. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in this village at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such rentals made in the course of such business, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-7 of the Illinois Municipal Code. [6] 
(b)  Every person engaged in the business of renting automobiles in the village shall file, on or before the 20th day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by 35 ILCS 120/3. 
(c)  At the time the monthly report required by this section is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax imposed by this section on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Code 1972, § 25-102)
