ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 82-1. - Turning on water supply; prerequisites. 
The water supply line serving any property shall not be turned on by anyone other than water division employees or other agents duly authorized by the water superintendent. No water shall be turned on for service other than for construction purposes until the economic development department of the village has certified that the water supply lines in the building comply with chapter 18, article IV, of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 28-1; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-2. - Tampering with water system prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the superintendent of water, or his duly authorized representative, to connect to, tamper with, alter, operate or injure any part of the city waterworks or supply system, or any water meter. Tampering shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Defacing or breaking any seal affixed by the water division to any meter, valve, fitting or other water connection. 
(2)  Opening, operating or using water from any fire hydrant other than by fire department or other duly authorized personnel. 
(3)  Tampering with, or interfering with the proper registration of water meters. 
Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to penalty, and held liable to pay for any damages and/or water determined to have been used. 
(Code 1972, § 28-2; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-3. - Resale of water. 
No water shall be resold or furnished by the purchaser to any other premises or buildings except in case of emergency and on approval of the water superintendent. 
(Code 1972, § 28-3)  
Sec. 82-4. - Water supply for premises outside village limits. 
Water supply for any building or premises outside the corporate limits may be furnished only upon application to and authorization by the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, § 28-4) 
Cross reference Quarterly and monthly rates outside village limits, §§ 82-203, 82-204.  
Sec. 82-5. - Only properly trained persons to use fire hydrants. 
No person shall use a village fire hydrant unless he has been trained by a village employee trained in the use of the hydrant. The training shall include instruction in the proper method of opening, closing and draining the hydrant and proper use of caps to prevent foreign objects from entering the hydrant body and proper drainage to prevent freezing. 
(Code 1972, § 28-5)  
Sec. 82-6. - Right of entry by waterworks employees; appointments; refusal of entry prohibited. 
(a)  Employees of the waterworks system shall have the right of access to any premises served by the waterworks system for the purpose of reading or maintenance of water meters or for the purpose of making inspections in order to maintain the waterworks system in good condition and to provide for the protection of the system and efficient management thereof. 
(b)  Where inspections are not of an immediate or urgent nature, employees of the waterworks system shall arrange for appointments mutually convenient to the owners or occupants of the premises served and such employees. 
(c)  Any person refusing to permit any employee of the waterworks system lawful access to his premises for purpose of reading or maintenance of the water meter shall be in violation of this Code. In addition to other remedies available to the village, the village shall have the authority to terminate and discontinue the water service to such premises pursuant to the procedures set forth in subsection (d) of this section, and shall not be reinstated until lawful access to the water meter has been allowed. 
(d)  Notice shall be mailed to the water customer and occupant of the premises, if different than the water customer, stating that water service shall be terminated due to the failure to permit access to the property's water meter. The notice shall inform the customer and/or occupant that access to the water meter is required by the village to prevent termination of service, and the date by which such access must be granted to avoid termination of service (which shall not be less than ten days from the date such notice is mailed.) The notice shall provide contact information of the appropriate village personnel to arrange for this access. The notice shall provide the contact information for the village manager who shall have authority to resolve disputes and the procedure and timing requirements for making a written request for review of this dispute. If no request for review is received by the village prior to the date on which service is to be terminated and access to the water meter is not granted, water service may be discontinued without further notice. If a request for review is made, a hearing shall be conducted by the village manager or his designee within five days of such request, and water service shall not be discontinued until such hearing is held. 
Water service shall not be discontinued to any building in which there are three or more multiple residential units which are served through a common meter until the village has mailed, delivered or posted on the premises the notice required above to all tenants or occupants. 
(Code 1972, § 28-6; Ord. No. 04-119, § 2, 6-8-2004)  
Sec. 82-7. - Penalties; actions and proceedings. 
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise provided, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each and every offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day a violation occurs or continues. In addition to such monetary penalty, the village attorney, at the request of the village manager, may institute in the name of the village any proper action or proceeding to enjoin, restrain, correct or abate any violation of the foregoing. 
(Code 1972, § 28-131)  
Secs. 82-882-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONNECTIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 82-31. - Required when property abuts waterworks system. 
It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant or party in possession of any house, building, factory, industrial or commercial establishment or any other structure located on property abutting on the public waterworks system to cause such structure to be connected with the waterworks system within six months from the date that water facilities become available to such property. 
(Code 1972, § 28-11)  
Sec. 82-32. - PermitRequired. 
No person shall make any connection to the water mains of the village without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 28-12) 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 22; connection and extension permits required, § 82-84.  
Sec. 82-33. - SameApplication. 
An application for permit required by this article shall be made in writing on forms provided by the village. All information necessary for the proper guidance of the official issuing the permit shall be included. 
(Code 1972, § 28-13)  
Sec. 82-34. - Standards and specifications. 
The village president and board of trustees are hereby authorized to make such rules and regulations consistent with this article for connections to the waterworks system, specifying the types and sizes of pipes and all the other appurtenances and extensions thereto, and to amend such regulations from time to time as may be deemed necessary. All service pipes and connections to the waterworks system shall comply with such specifications and rules. 
(Code 1972, § 28-14)  
Secs. 82-3582-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FEES 
 
Sec. 82-51. - Water main extension charges. 
There shall be and there are hereby established certain charges for water main extension as follows: 
Extension recapture charges. To apportion the cost of the installation of the water main which serves any property, an extension fee shall be due and payable prior to connection to a water line. It is intended that each user shall pay that portion of the cost of installation applicable to that particular use. No extension fee shall be charged against any property for any water main for which any owner of that property has previously and directly borne the prorated share of such cost. 
(1)  Single-family dwelling. The charge shall be based on the lot width, as defined in the zoning ordinance, of the property served multiplied by a rate per foot. The rate per foot shall be 50 percent of the cost of a six-inch water main at the time of installation. If the improvement cost is not paid within 90 days of construction acceptance, then an interest rate of six percent per annum shall be charged to the date of payment. 
(2)  Multiple-family dwellings, commercial, church, school and industrial property. The charge shall be based on the lot width of the property served, multiplied by a rate per foot. The rate per foot shall be 50 percent of the cost of the water main at the time of its installation. If the improvement cost is not paid within 90 days of construction acceptance, then an interest rate of six percent per annum shall be charged to date of payment. In no case, however, shall the charge be based on the cost of a main greater than the main to which the service is connected. 
(Code 1972, § 28-21(a))  
Sec. 82-52. - Connection fees. 
To ensure that each user shall bear a share of the cost of the basic city water system, a connection privilege fee shall be charged each user at the time connection to an existing water service is made. 
(1)  The charges for making connection to the water mains of the village waterworks system with the village shall be as follows: 
Size of tap 	Connection charge 
One-inch 	$ 1,000.00 
1½-inch 	1,500.00 
Two-inch 	2,000.00 
Three-inch 	3,500.00 
Four-inch 	5,000.00 
Six-inch 	10,000.00 
 
(2)  Multiple-family units shall be charged a basic connection charge based on tap size which shall be considered the charge for the first unit. Every unit thereafter shall be charged on the basis of $450.00 per living unit and shall be due in addition to the charge for the first unit as set forth in this subsection. 
(3)  Industrial users and those users having sprinklers and/or standby fire protection shall be charged for connection as follows: 
Size of tap 	Connection charge 
Three-inch 	$ 3,000.00 
Four-inch 	5,000.00 
Six-inch 	10,000.00 
Eight-inch 	20,000.00 
Ten-inch 	30,000.00 
12-inch 	40,000.00 
 
(Code 1972, § 28-22; Ord. No. 07-133, § 1, 8-6-2007) 
Editor's note As provided for in Ord. No. 07-133, § 6, the provisions in this section shall be in full force and effect on September 1, 2007.  
Sec. 82-53. - Water main flushing required prior to connection. 
Contractors constructing water mains for connection to the village system shall be required to sterilize and flush those lines prior to acceptance by the village. 
(Code 1972, § 28-23)  
Sec. 82-54. - Tap fees. 
(a)  Water main taps. The village will provide one-inch and two-inch water taps for a charge to be determined by the water division from time to time on the basis of the costs of labor, equipment, and materials used in making such taps. 
(b)  Taps over two inches. Water taps over two inches may be made by a builder under permit and direction of the village. The permit fee for such tap shall be $35.00. 
(Code 1972, § 28-24; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-55. - Fire hydrant meter deposit and fee. 
The water division shall require a deposit in the sum of $300.00 for the use of a fire hydrant meter plus $5.00 for each day's use of the meter. The contractor, owner or builder shall pay the monthly rate for water established in this chapter, to be measured through a hydrant meter furnished by the village. If a fire hydrant is used as a source of building water, the hydrant used shall be assigned by the water superintendent or the superintendent's designee. 
(Code 1972, § 28-25; Ord. No. 07-133, § 2, 8-6-2007) 
Editor's note As provided for in Ord. No. 07-133, § 6, the provisions in this section shall be in full force and effect on September 1, 2007.  
Sec. 82-56. - Inspection fee. 
An inspection of water service from the curb stop to the house shall be required at the time of construction. The inspection fee shall be $50.00 for residential properties and $100.00 for commercial properties. 
(Code 1972, § 28-26; Ord. No. 07-133, § 3, 8-6-2007) 
Editor's note As provided for in Ord. No. 07-133, § 6, the provisions in this section shall be in full force and effect on September 1, 2007.  
Sec. 82-57. - Collection of additional costs incurred. 
Nothing contained in this division shall preclude or bar the village from recovering unforeseen or excessive and uncontemplated construction costs incurred by the village in performing any of the services set forth in this division; the village is obliged to give prompt notice to the user of such unforeseen or uncontemplated costs as soon as they become evident, and afford such user the opportunity to cancel any further work. 
(Code 1972, § 28-27)  
Sec. 82-58. - Main to curb stop installation fees. 
When main to curb stop installations are made for residential service by the village, the charge for this service shall include the reasonable costs to the village for labor, equipment and materials, as established by water division policy from time to time. 
(Code 1972, § 28-28; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Secs. 82-5982-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE PIPES 
 
Sec. 82-81. - Installation to be supervised. 
Installation of service connections shall be under the supervision of the water superintendent or the superintendent's designee. 
(Code 1972, § 28-31)  
Sec. 82-82. - Water service connection defined. 
A water service connection shall consist of a service pipe extending from the water main to and including a curb stop and a curb stop box (B-box). 
(Code 1972, § 28-32)  
Sec. 82-83. - Water service extension defined. 
A water service extension is the service line from the water service connection curb stop to the water meter location on the premises being served. 
(Code 1972, § 28-33)  
Sec. 82-84. - Connection and extension permits required. 
When installation of a water service connection or a water service extension is required, a permit for each shall be obtained from the village upon payment of the required fee as set forth in division 2 of this article and village policy. 
(Code 1972, § 28-34) 
Cross reference Connections, § 82-31 et seq.  
Sec. 82-85. - Location, installation of curb stop. 
The curb stop shall be located 7½ feet from the property line toward the street. When this is not feasible, the curb stop shall be located not less than six inches or more than one foot from the street side of the sidewalk toward the street. The curb stop and box shall be a design approved by the water division. 
(Code 1972, § 28-35)  
Sec. 82-86. - Material specifications. 
Service pipe material shall meet applicable American Water Works Association specifications and shall be either copper, cast iron or ductile iron pipe. Any new water service connection shall not be less than one-inch nominal diameter pipe to the curb stop. 
(Code 1972, § 28-36)  
Sec. 82-87. - Installation of water main prerequisite to connection. 
No water connection may be made unless an adequate water main has been installed in the street adjacent to the property to be served. However, if in the opinion of the water superintendent and the public works director the length of such extension would be detrimental to the operation of the water system, then the connection shall be made by the most direct route from the existing water main. 
(Code 1972, § 28-37; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-88. - Persons authorized to make connections. 
All water service connections, other than those in subdivisions of two or more lots, of the size of two inches or smaller shall be made by the water division or by contractors employed by the village and supervised by the village. 
(Code 1972, § 28-38; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-89. - Entrance of connections, extensions into buildings; number of connections. 
All service connections or extensions shall be laid in streets to the premises so as to enter the building to be served by the most direct route from the main. Only one water service shall be permitted per lot. 
(Code 1972, § 28-39)  
Sec. 82-90. - Reconstruction of existing connections. 
Where an existing property is served by a water service connection extending past adjacent property, such service connection shall be reconstructed at the expense of the owner of the property served by such service connection to conform to this Code within one year after the placing in service of a city water main adjacent to such property. 
(Code 1972, § 28-40)  
Sec. 82-91. - Installation of service connection. 
All service connections crossing under any roadway must be accomplished by augering or pushing. No open cutting of streets is permitted; except under unusual conditions, where permission must be obtained from the superintendent of water. It shall be the responsibility of the person making the open cut to make all necessary repairs at his expense. 
(Code 1972, § 28-41)  
Sec. 82-92. - Conduction of connections, extension to adjoining premises prohibited. 
No consumer will be permitted to conduct a water service connection or extension across a lot to adjoining premises. 
(Code 1972, § 28-42)  
Sec. 82-93. - Licensed plumber to install extensions at owner's expense. 
Water service extensions shall be installed by a licensed plumber at the sole expense of the owner of the premises being served. 
(Code 1972, § 28-43)  
Sec. 82-94. - Extensions to be tested. 
Each service extension shall be tested prior to backfilling in the presence of an inspector from the water or economic development department and satisfy the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 28-44; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-95. - Proximity of extension to sewer line. 
(a)  Horizontal separation. Wherever possible, a water service should be laid at least ten feet horizontally from any storm or sanitary sewer. Should conditions exist to prevent the ten-foot separation, the water service may be laid closer to the storm or sanitary sewer provided that the water service is at least 18 inches above the crown of the sewer, and is either in a separate trench or in the same trench on an undisturbed earth shelf. If it is impossible to obtain the ten-foot separation or the 18-inch vertical separation, the sewer must be constructed of water main grade pipe pressure tested to assure watertightness before backfilling. 
(b)  Vertical separation. Whenever water services must cross storm or sanitary sewers, the water services shall be laid so that the invert is 18 inches above the crown of the sewer. If it is impossible to maintain the proper vertical separation or if the water service has to pass under a sewer, the sewer shall be constructed of water main grade pipe pressure tested to assure watertightness before backfilling. 
(Code 1972, § 28-45)  
Sec. 82-96. - Specifications for service extension pipe. 
(a)  Water service extension pipe material shall be either type K copper, ductile iron, or water main class PVC for four-inch or larger pipes. Such service shall be a minimum of 60 inches in depth. 
(b)  Water service extensions crossing a driveway or sidewalk shall be backfilled with compacted crushed stone or bankrun gravel. 
(c)  When a water service passes through concrete walls and/or floors, clearance between the pipe and the wall and/or floor shall be not less than one-half inch. The space between the wall and/or floor and the pipe shall be packed or caulked with lead or some waterproof, rodent-resistant material. 
(d)  The water service shall not show signs of leakage under full city water pressure. 
(Code 1972, § 28-46)  
Sec. 82-97. - Maintenance of extensions responsibility of owner. 
(a)  Water service extensions are the property of and shall be maintained at the expense of the owner of the property served. 
(b)  Any leaks or defects in water service extensions shall be repaired within five working days by the owners, and if leaks develop in an existing service extension not meeting the requirements of this chapter, it shall be replaced with a line that does meet such requirements. 
(c)  In case any leak in a water service extension is not repaired within five working days, the water supply shall be shut off by the water division and not turned on again until such leak has been repaired and any expense incurred by the city in connection therewith has been paid. 
(Code 1972, § 28-47)  
Sec. 82-98. - Liability of village, property owner, repairman. 
(a)  The village shall not be liable for any damage caused by a leak or break in any service pipe. 
(b)  The village, while in the process of working on or replacing a water meter, shall not be held liable for damage to shutoff valves or interior plumbing. 
(c)  The property owner shall be responsible for any damage to all buildings, trees or other obstructions within village easements that may result from work being performed in such easements. 
(d)  If a leak should develop in the water service connection while a party is performing work on a water service extension, it shall be the responsibility of the person causing the leak to repair such item at their expense. 
(Code 1972, § 28-48)  
Sec. 82-99. - Physical connections. 
(a)  No physical connection shall be permitted between the curb stop and the water meter. 
(b)  No physical connection shall be permitted between the piping of the village water supply system and any water derived from any other source, except a state certified public water supply system. 
(Code 1972, § 28-49)  
Sec. 82-100. - Discontinuance of existing service. 
Should it become necessary to discontinue or remove the existing service, it shall be done at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1972, § 28-50)  
Secs. 82-10182-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CROSS CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 82-121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood-level rim of the receptacle. 
Approved means accepted by the village water division as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this division, or as suitable for the proposed use. 
Auxiliary supply means any water source or system other than the potable water supply that may be available in the building or premises. 
Backflow means the flow of any water, foreign liquids, gases or other substances back into the distribution pipes of the potable water system. 
Backflow preventer means a device or means to prevent backflow. 
Backsiphonage means the flowing back of used, contaminated or polluted water due to a negative gauge or subatmospheric pressure in that pipe. 
Contamination. See pollution. 
Cross connection means any actual or potential connection between the potable water supply and a course of contamination or pollution. 
Drain means any pipe that carries wastewater or waterborne wastes in a building drainage system. 
Fixture, plumbing means installed receptacles, devices or appliances supplied with water or that receive or discharge liquids for liquid-borne wastes. 
Flood-level rim means the edge of the receptacle from which water overflows. 
Hazard, health means any condition or device which, in the judgment of the superintendent of water, may create a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. An example of a health hazard is a structural defect in the water supply system, whether of location, design, or construction, that regularly or occasionally may prevent satisfactory treatment of the water supply or cause it to be polluted from extraneous sources. 
Hazard, plumbing means any arrangement of plumbing including piping and fixtures whereby a cross connection is created. 
Hydropneumatic tank means a pressure vessel in which air pressure acts upon the surface of the water contained within the vessel pressurizing the water distribution piping connecting to the vessel. 
Outlet means the open end of the water supply pipe through which the water is discharged into the plumbing fixture. 
Plumbing system includes the water supply and distribution pipes, plumbing fixtures and traps; soil, waste and vent pipes; building drains and building sewers, including their respective connections, devices and appurtenances within the property lines of the premises; and water treating or water using equipment. 
Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer means an assembly of differential valves and checkvalves including an automatically opened spillage port to the atmosphere designed to prevent backflow. 
Surge tank means the receiving, nonpressure vessel forming part of the air gap separation between a potable and an auxiliary supply. 
Vacuum means any pressure less than that exerted by the atmosphere. 
Vacuum breaker, nonpressure type means a vacuum breaker designed so as not to be subjected to static line pressure. 
Vacuum breaker, pressure type means a vacuum breaker designed to operate under conditions of static line pressure. 
Water, nonpotable means water that is not safe for human consumption or that is of questionable potability. 
Water, potable means water free from contaminants in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful physiological effects. Its bacteriological and chemical quality shall conform to the requirements of the federal and state drinking water regulations and to any regulations of the public health authority having local jurisdiction. 
(Code 1972, § 28-52; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 82-122. - Prohibited. 
(a)  Cross connections between potable water systems and other systems or equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable quality are prohibited except when and where, as approved by the water division, suitable protective devices such as the reduced pressure zone backflow preventer or equal are installed, tested and maintained to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis. 
(b)  To protect the public water system from contamination due to contaminants through the water service connection into the public water system, a program of inspection and regulation shall be provided. 
(c)  The superintendent of water, or his designated agent, shall inspect the plumbing in every building or premises served by the public water system as frequently as in his judgment may be necessary to ensure that such plumbing has been installed and maintained in such a manner as to prevent the possibility of pollution of the water supply of the village. The superintendent shall notify or cause to be notified in writing the owner, or authorized agent of the owner, of any such building or premises, to correct, within a reasonable time set by the superintendent, any plumbing installed or existing contrary to or in violation of this division, and which, in his judgment, may therefore permit the pollution of the village water supply, or otherwise adversely affect the public health. 
(d)  The superintendent of water, or his designated agent, shall have the right of entry into any building during reasonable hours for the purpose of making inspection of the plumbing systems installed in such building or premises; provided, that with respect to the inspection of any single-family dwelling, consent to such inspection shall first be obtained from a person of suitable age and discretion therein or in control thereof. Consistent refusal to allow inspection of a specific dwelling may be cause for requiring installation of suitable backflow protection or discontinuation of potable water service. 
(Code 1972, § 28-51; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-123. - Technical requirements. 
(a)  Design, installation and maintenance of potable water supply system; connections prohibited unless protected against backflow. A potable water supply system shall be designed, installed and maintained in such a manner as to prevent contamination from nonpotable liquids, solids or gases from being introduced into the potable water supply through cross connections or any other piping connections to the system. Connection to the potable water supply system is prohibited unless protected against backflow as set out in this division. Residential properties shall be protected with dual check and dual check assemblies. All other properties shall be protected with a reduced pressure zone backflow protector or RPZ. 
(b)  Certification of devices to prevent backflow or backsiphonage. Before any device for the prevention of backflow or backsiphonage is installed, it shall have first been certified by the Foundation For Cross-Connection Control Research of the University of Southern California and/or the National Sanitation Foundation. Devices installed on a building's main service line at the water meter, for the purpose of safeguarding the public water supply, shall be tested or maintained by the village water division or other state certified backflow preventer maintenance/tester as provided in section 82-124(3). Reduced pressure zone backflow preventers installed in a building's potable water supply distribution system shall be tested and/or maintained by the village water division or other state certified backflow preventer maintenance/tester as provided in section 82-124(3). The water division superintendent or his designee shall inspect routinely such devices and if they are found to be defective or inoperative shall require the replacement thereof. All devices shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations and the state plumbing code. 
(Code 1972, § 28-53(a), (e); Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-124. - Backflow prevention devices required. 
All construction requiring permits by the economic development department which involves construction revisions or additions to the potable water distribution system of the building or premises shall require the installation of a backflow prevention device immediately downstream of the water meter. The following provisions shall apply to such installation of backflow devices: 
(1)  Issuance. Backflow preventers will be issued by the water division upon receipt of payment therefor. 
(2)  Installation. Backflow preventers shall be installed by a licensed plumber at the sole expense of the owner of the premises being served. Backflow preventers shall be installed as follows: 
a.  Installation shall be in a location where the unit is readily accessible for maintenance and testing. Location should be immediately downstream of the water meter. 
b.  Minimum clearances recommended by the manufacturer shall be observed. 
c.  The unit shall be protected against flooding and freezing. 
d.  Free draining of the relief port must be maintained under all conditions and provisions such as floor drains should be provided. 
e.  If installed at ceiling level, a collection system shall be installed with proper air gap under the drain port to protect areas below the unit from drainage. 
f.  There shall be no reduction made in the size of the relief port drain. 
g.  Provision shall be made for easy and unrestricted removal of the unit. 
h.  Strainers shall be provided in accordance with the state plumbing code. 
(3)  Testing of backflow preventers. The following regulations shall govern the testing of backflow prevention devices: 
a.  Each year the village will cause the testing of each backflow preventer installed at the meter. 
b.  Testing of units shall be the responsibility of the water division superintendent, or his duly authorized representative. Minimal maintenance, such as internal cleaning, if needed, shall be provided. Costs for tests, parts and/or replacement of units will be the responsibility of the building owner. 
c.  Testing of initial installation before occupancy shall be required. Initial certification test will be done at no charge. 
d.  The water division shall perform inspection and testing each year based on the anniversary date of the installation. Such tests shall be conducted within 30 days of such anniversary date. 
e.  The water division shall perform all necessary tests and file all necessary reports with state and local authorities and will certify that the owner's backflow preventers are operating and being maintained in accordance with existing state code requirements and manufacturer's recommendations. 
f.  Cost of subsequent annual inspections and testing of units shall be the owner's responsibility. The charge for inspection and testing will be based on $125.00 per unit. 
g.  All parts necessary to rebuild a unit to meet factory and/or state standards shall be invoiced at current published prices after expiration of factory warranty. 
h.  Any maintenance and/or inspections and testing requested of the water division by the owner between annual inspections will be performed by the water division and invoiced at then current prices or rates. 
i.  Tampering prohibited. No persons other than the water superintendent or his designee or other state certified backflow preventer maintenance/tester shall remove, repair, test or perform any maintenance on any backflow preventer. 
j.  Owners of all backflow preventers in excess of two inches shall provide easy access to units and/or necessary tools and equipment and shall furnish the water division with necessary ladders and/or scaffolding, and shall assign an employee or employees to assist the water division in performing its service according to this Code, as may be necessary, all at the owner's expense. 
(4)  Units out of service or in need of repair. When a backflow prevention device is out of service or otherwise is in need of service, the water division shall be notified within 24 hours. 
(5)  Bypasses. If there is only one service line and the water service cannot be interrupted, a second backflow preventer may be installed parallel with the first. Under no circumstance will a backflow preventer be bypassed by unprotected piping. 
(Code 1972, § 28-54; Ord. No. 06-63, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-125. - Corrections and protective devices. 
Any user of water shall obtain written approval from the water division of any proposed corrective action or protective device before using or installing it. The total time allowed for completion of the necessary corrections shall be contingent upon the degree of hazard involved and include the time required to obtain and install equipment. If the cross connection has not been removed within the time as specified in this division, the village shall physically separate the village water supply from the on-site piping system in such manner that the two systems cannot be connected by any unauthorized person. 
(Code 1972, § 28-55; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-126. - Piping identification. 
When a secondary water source is used in addition to the village water supply, exposed village water and secondary water piping shall be identified by distinguishing colors or tags and so maintained that each pipe may be traced readily in its entirety; it will be necessary to protect the village water supply at the service connection in a manner acceptable to the water division. 
(Code 1972, § 28-56; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-127. - Private water storage tanks. 
A private water storage tank supplied from the village water supply system shall be deemed a secondary water supply unless it is designed and approved for potable water usage. 
(Code 1972, § 28-57)  
Sec. 82-128. - Elimination of existing cross connections. 
All existing cross connections to the village water supply systems shall be eliminated. The expenses of such elimination shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property on which such cross connection exists. 
(Code 1972, § 28-58)  
Sec. 82-129. - Notification of violation. 
The superintendent shall notify the owner, or authorized agent of the owner, of the building or premises in which there is found a violation of this division of such violation. The superintendent shall set a reasonable time, based on the level of hazard to health, for the owner to have the violation removed or corrected. Upon failure of the owner to have the defect corrected by the end of the specified time interval, the superintendent may, if in his judgment an imminent health hazard exists, cause the water service to the building or premises to be terminated, and/or recommend such additional fines or penalties to be invoked as may be provided in this division. 
(Code 1972, § 28-59)  
Sec. 82-130. - Penalty for violation. 
The owner, or authorized agent of the owner responsible for maintenance of the plumbing systems in the building, who knowingly permits a violation to remain uncorrected after the expiration of time set by the superintendent shall, upon conviction thereof by the court, be required to pay a fine in accordance with section 82-7. 
(Code 1972, § 28-60)  
Sec. 82-131. - Use of groundwater as a potable water supply in a limited and designated area within the village. 
(a)  The use or attempt to use as a potable water supply groundwater from within the corporate limits of the Village of Westmont in that area depicted on Exhibit A, by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited. This prohibition expressly includes the Village of Westmont. 
Note Exhibit A, as listed above, can be found on file with the village. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to $750.00 for each violation. Each day is a new violation. In addition to monetary penalties, the village declares any violation of the provisions of this section to constitute a nuisance, entitling the village to pursue injunctive and other equitable relief against any such person. 
(c)  Definitions. 
Person is any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
Potable water is any water used for human or domestic consumption, including but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, or preparing foods. 
(Ord. No. 11-195, §§ 13, 11-21-2011) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 11-195, §§ 13, adopted Nov. 21, 2011, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, theses provisions have been included as § 82-131, at the editor's discretion.  
Secs. 82-13282-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE APPLICATIONS AND DEPOSITS 
 
Sec. 82-151. - Application for water service; records. 
(a)  No person shall use water from the village water system until he has filed an application with the village finance department on forms provided for that purpose. The application shall contain the provision that it is being signed subject to all rules and regulations then in force or that may thereafter be adopted by the village board. 
(b)  The village economic development department shall receive all applications for water tap and meter permits and issue such permits upon approval of the water division and payment of appropriate fees. A record of all water applications shall be kept. 
(c)  The village treasurer shall maintain a record for each individual water tap or meter connection and an account with each water consumer for water used and other related charges provided in this chapter. This record shall provide for all information required for identification and billing purposes, and all collections shall be posted thereon. Each record shall bear the account number corresponding to that used on the meter record and shall be kept on file. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-61), 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-152. - Deposit. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, each applicant for water service shall pay to the village a cash deposit as security for payment of all charges incurred under any provision of this chapter in connection with water service to the premises covered by such application. The amount of such cash deposit shall be as follows: 
(1)  Single-family dwelling: 
Dwelling occupied or serviced by owner ..... none 
Dwelling occupied by nonowner ..... $ 40.00 
Attached single-family dwelling unit, serviced by management company, each ..... 40.00 
Maximum per building ..... 200.00 
(2)  Multifamily dwelling: 
Dwelling unit occupied by owner ..... none 
Dwelling unit occupied by nonowner ..... 20.00 
Maximum per building ..... 200.00 
Dwelling unit serviced by management company, each ..... 20.00 
Maximum per building ..... 200.00 
(3)  Commercial buildings ..... 60.00 
(b)  The cash deposit shall be paid to the village prior to connection or, in cases in which water service to the premises has not been interrupted, no later than 30 days from the date the application is received by the village. 
(c)  An applicant for water service to an owner-occupied single-family or multifamily dwelling unit may deposit with the village, in lieu of a cash deposit, an agreement to pay to the village, upon demand, the full amount of all charges incurred under any provision of this chapter, provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The applicant for such service is the owner of the premises to be served; 
(2)  The applicant has no unpaid bills for water service at the same or a different address; 
(3)  The applicant has not made two late payments of water bills during the preceding 12-month period; and 
(4)  The applicant has not previously received the benefit of any tampering with pipes, meters or other water supply equipment. 
(d)  If any water customer files for bankruptcy, such customer shall promptly notify the village thereof and the bankruptcy trustee shall, within 20 days of such filing, furnish to the village a deposit assuring payment for any water service provided after such filing. The amount of such deposit shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Generally, an amount sufficient to cover the average billing, plus an amount sufficient to cover services from the end of the billing period to the due date for payment for such period. 
(2)  For any bankrupt customer who has a poor payment history or poor ability to meet post-bankruptcy petition obligations, or who has committed acts of tampering with meters, shutoff valves or other service equipment, the deposit required in subsection (d)(1) of this section shall be multiplied by the number of such aggravating factors to determine the required deposit. Failure to provide the assurance of payment required by this subsection shall result in termination of water service as provided in section 82-180. 
(e)  Upon discontinuance of water service to the customer making the cash deposit, the excess, if any, of such deposit over the amount of all unpaid charges incurred under any provision of this chapter shall be refunded. 
(f)  In case of default in payment of any charge made by the village in connection with furnishing water, the village may, after 45 days from the date the bill is rendered, apply the deposit provided for in subsections (a) or (d) of this section, or so much thereof as may be necessary to pay the amount due the village. 
(g)  The amount of the cash deposit required of a water customer may be increased as a condition of continued water service at any time that the amount of the deposit is deemed by the village to be inadequate to secure payment of charges incurred under the provisions of this chapter. The cash deposit shall be deemed inadequate whenever: 
(1)  Three consecutive bills for water service exceed the amount of the deposit; 
(2)  The customer has made two late payments of bills during any 12-month period; 
(3)  The customer has filed for bankruptcy, in which case the deposit shall be determined as provided in subsection (d) of this section. 
The increased cash deposit shall be paid to the village no later than 30 days after the village's demand thereof. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-62), 1-3-1995)  
Sec. 82-153. - Discontinuance of water service at customer's request. 
Water service shall be discontinued within 48 hours after notice to the village finance department by the customer. Upon receipt of notice to discontinue water service, the village finance department shall notify the water division to take a final meter reading. The village shall not shall not discontinue water service to any property which is occupied by an owner, owner's family or owner's agent or tenant, except for non-payment of a water bill as set forth in article IV of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-63), 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 16-062, § 2, 4-14-2016)  
Secs. 82-15482-175. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - METERS AND WATER RATES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 82-176. - Joint and several liability for payment of water charges. 
The owner, occupant and user of water service on any single premises shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the water service on the premises. Water services are furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner, occupant and user of the service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-64), 1-3-1995)  
Sec. 82-177. - When water bills to be rendered; due date for payment. 
(a)  All bills for water service shall be rendered by the village as of the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the service is billed. 
(b)  Rates or charges for water service shall be payable bi-monthly for each residential single-family, owner occupied condominium, municipal, school or church user. Rates or charges for water service shall be payable monthly for each two or more multiple unit, commercial and industrial user. Payment on all accounts shall be made within 20 days after the bill therefore has been rendered by the village. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-65), 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 82-178. - Penalty for late payment. 
If payment of the full amount of any water bill is not made within 15 days from the time the bill is rendered, a penalty of ten percent of the bill shall be added thereto. Any payments made shall be applied to the customer's account in the following order: penalty, then garbage collection fees, then the water bill. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-66), 1-3-1995)  
Sec. 82-179. - Lien for nonpayment of charges. 
(a)  Whenever the charges for water service remain unpaid for 45 days after the date they become due and payable, the village treasurer shall cause to be filed with the county recorder a statement of lien claim covering the amount claimed by the village as delinquent for the water division services rendered to the premises. This statement shall contain a description of such real estate sufficient for identification thereof; the amount of money due for such water services; and the date when such amount became delinquent. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such real estate, after the notice of lien has been filed, the village shall issue a release of such lien, which may be filed of record by such person in the county recorder's office. 
(b)  If the village finance department has notice that the consumer to whom the water services were supplied is not the legal owner of the premises, notice shall be mailed to the legal owner of the premises at his last known address, whenever charges for water services remain unpaid for a period of 45 days after they become due and payable. Failure of the village finance department to mail such notice shall not affect the right of the village to foreclose the lien for unpaid water service charges as provided for in this section. 
(c)  The village treasurer is authorized to notify the village attorney to institute such proceedings as shall be necessary to enforce the liens of the village filed in accordance with this section. 
(d)  The remedy by enforcement of lien claims for unpaid water service charges shall not be exclusive of any legal remedy to collect the amounts delinquent. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-67), 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-180. - Authority to discontinue service; procedure. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, if charges for water services remain unpaid for 45 days after rendition of the bill for services, such services may be discontinued pursuant to the procedures set forth in subsection (b) of this section, and shall not be reinstated until all past due bills, including penalties thereon, are paid in full together with payment of $70.00 to cover the costs of dispatching the employee, for purposes of shutting off and/or reinstating said water service. (If the employee is sent to the property, the fee is due even if the service is not actually terminated at this particular time). 
(b)  Notice shall be mailed to the customer whose water service may be discontinued under authority of subsection (a) of this section. The notice shall inform the customer of the payment or other action required to prevent discontinuance of service, the date by which such payment or other action must be made to avoid discontinuation of service (which date shall not be less than ten days from the date such notice is mailed), the charges for disconnection and reconnection of service, the name of the person with authority to resolve disputes and the procedure for making a written request for review of disputed charges. If no request for review is made prior to the date on which service was to be discontinued and payment of unpaid charges is not made by such date, water service may be discontinued without further notice, except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section. If a request for review is made, a hearing shall be conducted before the village manager or his designee within five days of such request, and water service shall not be discontinued until such hearing is held. 
(c)  Water service shall not be discontinued to any building in which there are three or more multiple residential units which are served through a common meter until the village has mailed, delivered or posted on the premises a notice to all lessees or tenants, which notice shall state the specific date, which shall be no sooner than ten days after the notice is given, that water service will be discontinued; a statement of the tenant's right to either pay the village the amount owed by the landlord and deduct the amount from their rent, or to petition the court to appoint a receiver to collect rents due and pay the village for the unpaid water bills; the dollar amount owed on the date of the notice and the amount of the average monthly bill; and the name, address and telephone number of any legal service agency in the area where the tenants may obtain free legal assistance. Any such notice shall be on red paper, printed in at least 14-point boldface type, with "notice of possible termination of water service" printed in 36-point boldface type, and such notice shall state that it is a violation of state law for the landlord to remove or tamper with the notice. 
(d)  Water service shall not be terminated for failure of any customer who has filed for bankruptcy to pay any pre-filing charges. Any post-filing termination of water service shall be made pursuant to the requirements of section 82-152(d). 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-68), 1-3-1995; Ord. No. 06-31, § 1, 2-21-2006; Ord. No. 09-69, § 1, 5-18-2009)  
Sec. 82-181. - Denial of service. 
(a)  If after a review of its own records, the village finds that an applicant for water service has failed to pay past due charges for water service at the same or at another address, the village may refuse to provide service unless the applicant pays any past due bill. Service shall not be denied for nonpayment of bills other than those for water service. 
(b)  The village may refuse to provide water service to any premises for which a claim of lien for unpaid charges for water service has been filed with the county recorder in accordance with section 82-179 on or before the date of application for service, unless the applicant for service tenders to the village the amount of the charges due. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-69), 1-3-1995)  
Sec. 82-182. - Notice of change of owner or tenant. 
In the event of a change in owner or tenant, the village shall be promptly notified and a new application shall be signed. The customer in whose name water service was provided shall be responsible to the village for all charges incurred through the date on which the change in possession is effective or the date on which the village is notified of the charge, whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-70), 1-3-1995)  
Sec. 82-183. - Village authorized to institute proceedings for nonpayment. 
The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute proceedings, in the name of the village, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which a water bill has remained unpaid for 60 days after it has been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 95-2, § 1(28-71), 1-3-1995)  
Secs. 82-18482-200. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - WATER RATES

For each residential single-family, owner occupied condominium, municipal, school or church user of the waterworks system within the village limits, the bi-monthly charge shall be as follows: 
Number of gallons used 	Rate

Each owner occupied single-family dwelling unit shall pay a minimum bi-monthly bill of $15.61 for the first 1,000 gallons, and $10.61 for usage over 1,000 gallons as defined in this section. For a condominium unit to receive these rates, proof of ownership must be provided to the village clerk's office. 
(Code 1972, § 28-81; Ord. No. 08-37, § 2, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 10-52, § 1, 3-15-2010; Ord. No. 11-76, § 1, 5-16-2011; Ord. No. 16-167, § 1, 10-13-2016; Ord. No. 18-038, § 1, 3-15-2018; Ord. No. 19-093, § 1, 6-6-2019)

Sec. 82-208. - Bulk water fill charge. 
All water used in conjunction with the filling of tank trucks or similar vehicles shall be procured at the tank fill facility at the water division. The following rate shall prevail: $6.00 per 1,000 gallons, plus $0.50 surcharge; $6.50 per 1,000 gallons. The $0.50 per 1,000-gallon surcharge shall be rescinded upon recovery of indebtedness incurred in construction of the facility. 
(Code 1972, § 28-88; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Secs. 82-20982-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - WATER METERS AND CHARGES 
 
Sec. 82-231. - Meter required. 
(a)  All premises using water from the village water system shall be equipped with an accurate water meter, provided by the village, but paid for by the customer. In two-flat buildings, each flat and/or apartment shall be provided with a separate water meter. No building permit shall be issued for the construction or improvement of two flats unless the plans provide for a separate water meter for each flat and/or apartment. For all premises in which there is a residential and a commercial user, the portion of the premises to each of such users shall be provided with a separate water meter. Except for permitted uses, no water shall be taken from the village water system except through a village water meter. All meters are and shall continue to be the property of and maintained by the village. 
(b)  No premises shall be occupied until a water meter has been installed and sealed by the water division. 
(c)  All water meters from 1½-inch and larger shall be flanged type meters installed by a licensed plumber. All installations of meters must be inspected by the water division for approval within 24 hours. 
(Code 1972, § 28-91; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-232. - Installation charges. 
Original smaller water meter installations with the exclusion of the piping shall be performed by the village water division. The charge for the installation, including labor and the remote meter reading device, shall be established by water division policy, based on the reasonable cost thereof to the village. 
(Code 1972, § 28-92; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-233. - Equipment charges. 
Charges for meter equipment and required appurtenances, such as ball valve, backflow preventer, meter copperhorn, etc., associated with meter installations shall be established by water division policy, based on the reasonable cost to the village for such equipment. 
(Code 1972, § 28-93; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-234. - Installation and location of meters, remote meter reading device. 
(a)  Water meters shall be installed by the water division or by a licensed plumber; remote meter reading devices shall be installed by the water division. The remote meter reading device shall be located on the exterior of the building and shall be not less than three feet or more than four feet above finished grade, and so that future additions and/or enclosures will not obstruct the meter readout. On residential homes, the remote meter reading device shall be located near the front side of the building. In the event an addition or enclosure is constructed to obstruct the meter reader in the process of reading the meter, the costs involved to move and replace the reading device shall be at the property owner's expense. No water meter shall be located in an outside pit. Meters located in crawl spaces shall not be more than two feet either side of access door, and shall include electric light in crawl space at access door. 
(b)  Each water meter serving a building must be equipped with a lock type shutoff valve at the service before the meter. Each meter from five-eighths inch to one inch in size shall be equipped with a meter yoke. The lock type valve and meter yoke must be picked up at the water division. There shall be only one village water meter fee for single-family residential occupancy. Water meters shall be located in such a position as to afford easy access for inspection, maintenance and reading. 
(Code 1972, § 28-95; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-235. - Reading meters. 
The superintendent of the water division shall read, or cause to be read, every water meter used in the village at such times as are necessary for the bills to be sent out at the proper time. In the case of those buildings having outside reading devices, the reading shall be taken from the master meter located within the building. 
(Code 1972, § 28-96)  
Sec. 82-236. - Master meter as controlling record for water usage. 
The master meter shall at all times be considered the control meter of record for water usage within the village. 
(Code 1972, § 28-98)  
Sec. 82-237. - Meter maintenance. 
For all water meters used in conjunction with business and multifamily users, each user shall be required to replace such meter from time to time at the expense of the property owner. Such period of replacement shall be determined by the water superintendent, according to the standards set by the meter manufacturer. 
(Code 1972, § 28-99)  
Sec. 82-238. - Responsibility of owner, occupant and user for damages. 
When a meter has been installed on the premises to be served, it shall be the duty of the owner of the premises, the occupant and user of the service to preserve and protect such meter from damage by freezing, excessive heat, mechanical injury, and from theft; and the owner of the premises, the occupant and user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay the costs of repairing or replacing a meter if damaged or lost for any of the foregoing reasons. 
(Code 1972, § 28-100)  
Sec. 82-239. - Water bill review procedures. 
If at any time a user contends that the water meter is not registering correctly, the following procedures will be followed: 
(1)  A serviceman will be sent to the premises to physically check the meter reading and to check the plumbing for problems. 
(2)  If the meter reading was correct, and if no obvious plumbing problems are located, the property owner may request a shop test at the water division shop. If such a request is made, the procedure shall be as follows: 
a.  A deposit of $50.00 must be made for five-eighths-inch through one-inch meters, and a deposit of $100.00 must be made for 1½-inch and larger meters before the water division will remove the meter and test it at the water division shop. The deposit may be waived if the owner witnesses the shop test. 
b.  If the water division shop test indicates that the meter was recording inaccurately in accordance with the latest specifications for testing, as adopted by the American Water Works Association, the deposit shall be returned to the property owner and the bill shall be adjusted accordingly. 
c.  If the water division shop test indicates that the meter was recording accurately in accordance with the latest specifications for testing, as adopted by the American Water Works Association, the property owner shall forfeit the deposit and shall be required to pay the total bill, or the owner may request further testing. 
(3)  The owner may hire an independent testing agency to perform a test on the meter. If the certified test determines that the meter was recording inaccurately, the property owner will be reimbursed by the village for the cost of the test, and the water bill will be adjusted accordingly. If the certified test determines that the meter was recording accurately, the owner shall be required to pay the total water bill. 
(Code 1972, § 28-101; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 82-240. - Plumbing to comply with Code prior to water being furnished; exception for construction work. 
No water shall be turned on for service in premises in which the plumbing does not comply with this Code and other ordinances of the village; provided, that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 28-102)  
Secs. 82-24182-265. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - WATER CONSERVATION 
 
Sec. 82-266. - General regulations. 
(a)  All services connected to the village water mains must be metered. 
(b)  Water use. All new plumbing fixtures and any replacement plumbing fixtures shall comply with the following standards of water use: 
(1)  Water closet-tank type: Maximum 3.5 gallons (13.2 liters) per flush. 
(2)  Water closet-flushometer: Maximum three gallons (11.4 liters) per flush. 
(3)  Urinal-tank type: Maximum three gallons (11.4 liters) per flush. 
(4)  Urinal-flushometer: Maximum three gallons (11.4 liters) per flush. 
(5)  Showerhead: Maximum flow three gallons (11.4 liters) per minute. 
Special purpose showerheads, where necessary, may be exempted from this requirement upon approval of the superintendent of building construction. 
(6)  Lavatory sink faucets: Maximum flow four gallons (15.1 liters) per minute. 
The maximum flow rate for lavatory sink faucets is measured with both hot and cold water supply fully opened. 
(c)  Public lavatories. Faucets or lavatories located in restrooms intended for public use shall be of the self-closing type. 
(d)  Water pressure reducing valves. When internal (water) system pressure exceeds 60 psi (413.69 pascals), pressure reducing valves shall be installed to reduce the pressure to a maximum of 50 psi (344.74 pascals) in residential dwelling units and other uses where the reduced pressure is compatible with the owner's requirement. This requirement for the installation of pressure reducing valves does not apply to fire protection water uses. 
(e)  Consumers are required by this article to conserve water and to limit water usage to the lowest practical amount in all aspects of the water service. 
(f)  Car wash installations, in all new construction and replacement of fixtures, shall be equipped with a water recycling system. 
(g)  All water-medium air conditioning units in all new construction and remodeling shall be closed system type. 
(Code 1972, § 28-111(a), (c)(h))  
Sec. 82-267. - Outside use of water restricted. 
(a)  Commencing on May 15 of each year and extending through the following September 15, mechanical sprinkling of lawns and gardens shall be permitted only as follows: 
(1)  On properties having odd-numbered street addresses: Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. and between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. on dates of the month having an odd number. 
(2)  On properties having even-numbered street addresses: Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. and between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. on dates of the month having an even number. 
(b)  The watering of trees, shrubs, flowers and gardens shall be permitted at all times provided such watering is by means of handheld devices and only with such devices designed and intended for such purpose. 
(c)  New sod and seed lawns shall be water by permit only. 
(1)  Such permit shall be valid for a period of three weeks from the date sod or seed is installed, and shall not be renewed. 
(d)  During any period during which an extreme shortage exists in the village water supply, as determined by the village president, no water from village water mains shall be used for any purpose outside a residence, business or other building other than for the extinguishment of fires or other emergencies. 
(e)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine in an amount of not less than $25.00 nor more than $200.00 for each violation. 
(Code 1972, § 28-112; Ord. No. 16-017, § 2, 1-21-2016)  
Secs. 82-26882-290. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - WELLS 
 
Sec. 82-291. - Private wells prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No private water well shall be constructed, reconstructed or reconditioned within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  This section shall not pertain to existing state certified public water supply systems serving more than ten parcels of land. The repair or replacement of pumping equipment in existing wells shall be permitted, provided, however, that the village water mains are not available abutting the parcel being serviced by the well. 
(Code 1972, § 28-121)  
Sec. 82-292. - Sealing of wells required. 
Upon connection to the village water system, any wells serving the property shall be abandoned and plugged in accordance with applicable state regulations. 
(Code 1972, § 28-122)  
Sec. 82-293. - Installation or drilling of wells; prohibited. 
(a)  The use or attempt to use as a potable water supply groundwater from within the corporate limits of the Village of Westmont in that area depicted on Exhibit A, by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited. This prohibition expressly includes the Village of Westmont. 
Editor's note Exhibit A as referenced above is not set out herein but can be found on file with the village. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to $750.00 for each violation. Each day is a new violation. In addition to monetary penalties, the village declares any violation of the provisions of this section to constitute a nuisance, entitling the village to pursue injunctive and other equitable relief against any such person. 
(c)  Definitions. 
Person is any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
Potable water is any water used for human or domestic consumption, including but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, or preparing foods. 
(Ord. No. 11-70, §§ 13, 5-16-2011) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 11-70, §§ 13, adopted May 16, 2011, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, these provisions have been added as § 82-293, at the editor's discretion.  
Secs. 82-29482-325. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PRIVATE WATER SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 82-326. - Inspections; repair of defects. 
(a)  The water division shall periodically make inspections of the privately maintained water distribution systems. The system owner or official custodian shall be notified in writing of all deficiencies which have the potential of affecting the water distribution system. They shall be given a reasonable period of time to make the necessary repairs. If the deficiencies are not corrected within the given period of time, the water division shall secure the services of an outside contractor to make the repairs at prevailing rates. 
(b)  In the event of an emergency situation in the water distribution system, i.e., water leakage, etc., the water division shall notify the responsible party and they shall make the repairs immediately. If the owner or official custodian cannot take immediate action to make the repairs, the water division shall assume responsibility and make the repairs or secure the services of an outside contractor to make repairs at prevailing rates. 
(c)  The owner of the private water distribution system shall be responsible for all costs associated with correcting deficiencies in the system. 
(Code 1972, § 28-126; Ord. No. 07-106, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Secs. 82-32782-350. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - CONSTRUCTION OF UTILITY FACILITIES IN THE RIGHTS-OF-WAY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 07-179, § 2, adopted Nov. 19, 2007, repealed the former Art. VIII, §§ 82-35182-374, and enacted a new Art. VIII as set out herein. The former Art. VIII pertained to construction of utility facilities in public rights-of-way and derived from Ord. No. 99-158, § 2(82-32782-349), adopted Nov. 1, 1999; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, adopted June 4, 2007; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, adopted June 4, 2007. 
 
Sec. 82-351. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish policies and procedures for constructing facilities on rights-of-way within the village's jurisdiction, which will provide public benefit consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the village rights-of-way and the village as a whole. 
(b)  Intent. In enacting this article, the village intends to exercise its authority over the rights-of-way in the village and, in particular, the use of the public ways and property by utilities, by establishing uniform standards to address issues presented by utility facilities, including without limitation: 
(1)  Prevent interference with the use of streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways and other public ways and places; 
(2)  Prevent the creation of visual and physical obstructions and other conditions that are hazardous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic; 
(3)  Prevent interference with the facilities and operations of the village's utilities and of other utilities lawfully located in rights-of-way or public property; 
(4)  Protect against environmental damage, including damage to trees, from the installation of utility facilities; 
(5)  Protect against increased stormwater run-off due to structures and materials that increase impermeable surfaces; 
(6)  Preserve the character of the neighborhoods in which facilities are installed; 
(7)  Preserve open space, particularly the tree-lined parkways that characterize the village's residential neighborhoods; 
(8)  Prevent visual blight from the proliferation of facilities in the rights-of-way; and 
(9)  Assure the continued safe use and enjoyment of private properties adjacent to utility facilities locations. 
(c)  Facilities subject to this article. This article applies to all facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the rights-of-way within the jurisdiction of the village. A facility lawfully established prior to the effective date of this article may continue to be maintained, repaired and operated by the utility as presently constructed and located, except as may be otherwise provided in any applicable franchise, license or similar agreement. 
(d)  Franchises, licenses, or similar agreements. The village, in its discretion and as limited by law, may require utilities to enter into a franchise, license or similar agreement for the privilege of locating their facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the village rights-of-way. Utilities that are not required by law to enter into such an agreement may request that the village enter into such an agreement. In such an agreement, the village may provide for terms and conditions inconsistent with this article. 
(e)  Effect of franchises, licenses, or similar agreements. 
(1)  Utilities other than telecommunications providers. In the event that a utility other than a telecommunications provider has a franchise, license or similar agreement with the village, such franchise, license or similar agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof. 
(2)  Telecommunications providers. In the event of any conflict with, or inconsistency between, the provisions of this article and the provisions of any franchise, license or similar agreement between the village and any telecommunications provider, the provisions of such franchise, license or similar agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof. 
(f)  Conflicts with other articles. This article supersedes all articles or parts of articles adopted prior hereto that are in conflict herewith, to the extent of such conflict. 
(g)  Conflicts with state and federal laws. In the event that applicable federal or state laws or regulations conflict with the requirements of this article, the utility shall comply with the requirements of this article to the maximum extent possible without violating federal or state laws or regulations. 
(h)  Sound engineering judgment. The village shall use sound engineering judgment when administering this article and may vary the standards, conditions, and requirements expressed in this article when the village so determines. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the ability of the village to regulate its rights-of-way for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 07-179, § 2, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 82-352. - Definitions. 
As used in this article and unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and terms listed shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. Any term not defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to it in 92 Ill. Adm. Code § 530.30, unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
"AASHTO" means American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials. 
"ANSI" means American National Standards Institute. 
"Applicant" means a person applying for a permit under this article. 
"ASTM" means American Society for Testing and Materials. 
"Backfill" means the methods or materials for replacing excavated material in a trench or pit. 
"Bore" or "boring" means to excavate an underground cylindrical cavity for the insertion of a pipe or electrical conductor. 
"Cable operator" means that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(5). 
"Cable service" means that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(6). 
"Cable system" means that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(7). 
"Carrier pipe" means the pipe enclosing the liquid, gas or slurry to be transported. 
"Casing" means a structural protective enclosure for transmittal devices such as: carrier pipes, electrical conductors, and fiber optic devices. 
"Clear zone" means the total roadside border area, starting at the edge of the pavement, available for safe use by errant vehicles. This area may consist of a shoulder, a recoverable slope, a non-recoverable slope, and a clear run-out area. The desired width is dependent upon the traffic volumes and speeds, and on the roadside geometry. Distances are specified in the AASHTO Roadside Design Guide. 
"Coating" means protective wrapping or mastic cover applied to buried pipe for protection against external corrosion. 
"Code" means the Municipal Code of the Village of Westmont. 
"Conductor" means wire carrying electrical current. 
"Conduit" means a casing or encasement for wires or cables. 
"Construction" or "construct" means the installation, repair, maintenance, placement, alteration, enlargement, demolition, modification or abandonment in place of facilities. 
"Cover" means the depth of earth or backfill over buried utility pipe or conductor. 
"Crossing facility" means a facility that crosses one or more right-of-way lines of a right-of-way. 
"Director of public works" means the village director of public works or his or her designee. 
"Disrupt the right-of-way" means for the purposes of this article, any work that obstructs the right-of-way or causes a material adverse effect on the use of the right-of-way for its intended use. Such work may include, without limitation, the following: excavating or other cutting; placement (whether temporary or permanent) of materials, equipment, devices, or structures; damage to vegetation; and compaction or loosening of the soil, and shall not include the parking of vehicles or equipment in a manner that does not materially obstruct the flow of traffic on a highway. 
"Emergency" means any immediate maintenance to the facility required for the safety of the public using or in the vicinity of the right-of-way or immediate maintenance required for the health and safety of the general public served by the utility. 
"Encasement" means provision of a protective casing. 
"Engineer" means the village engineer or consulting engineer or his or her designee. 
"Equipment" means materials, tools, implements, supplies, and/or other items used to facilitate construction of facilities. 
"Excavation" means the making of a hole or cavity by removing material, or laying bare by digging. 
"Extra heavy pipe" means pipe meeting ASTM standards for this pipe designation. 
"Facility" means all structures, devices, objects, and materials (including, but not limited to, track and rails, wires, ducts, fiber optic cable, antennas, vaults, boxes, equipment enclosures, cabinets, pedestals, poles, conduits, grates, covers, pipes, cables, and appurtenances thereto) located on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within rights-of-way under this article. For purposes of this article, the term "facility" shall not include any facility owned or operated by the village. 
"Freestanding facility" means a facility that is not a crossing facility or a parallel facility, such as an antenna, transformer, pump, or meter station.
