Sec. 90-36. - Vehicle condition and equipment. 
All taxicabs shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, properly equipped with brakes, lights and warning signals, and in good operating condition. The police department shall from time to time make inspections to determine whether the requirements of this section are being complied with. 
(Code 1972, § 27-21) 
Cross reference Vehicle equipment and condition generally, § 78-86 et seq.  
Sec. 90-37. - Liability insurance required; amount. 
Any person licensed under this article shall maintain, and keep on deposit in the office of the village clerk evidence of public liability insurance covering any liability arising out of the ownership, maintenance, use or operation by the licensee of any taxicab within the village, with limits of not less than $100,000.00 for personal injury, including death, to any one person, not less than $300,000.00 for personal injury, including death, in any one accident, and with limits of not less than $25,000.00 for property damage in one accident. 
(Code 1972, § 27-22)  
Sec. 90-38. - Drivers to be licensed; register of drivers to be kept. 
No person licensed under the provisions of this article shall permit any taxicab to be used in his business unless such taxicab is operated by a driver licensed by the state as a chauffeur. Every licensee under this article shall keep a register showing the names of every driver in his employ, and indicating which vehicle is being operated by each driver. 
(Code 1972, § 27-23)  
Sec. 90-39. - Chauffeur's license required by drivers. 
No person shall drive a taxicab within the village without first having obtained a chauffeur's license from the state. 
(Code 1972, § 27-24)  
Sec. 90-40. - Rates to be approved by village; posting. 
The maximum rates of fares charged by any person licensed under this article shall first be approved by the village board of trustees. A current rate schedule shall be prominently displayed in each taxicab. 
(Code 1972, § 27-25)  
Sec. 90-41. - Receipts for fares. 
Any passenger of a taxicab paying a fare shall be entitled to a receipt showing the amount paid. 
(Code 1972, § 27-26)  
Sec. 90-42. - Advance fares. 
Every driver of a taxicab shall have the right to demand a reasonable fare in advance from the person employing him or entering his vehicle, and such driver may refuse to convey any person who shall not comply with such demand. 
(Code 1972, § 27-27)  
Sec. 90-43. - Refusal to convey passengers. 
Subject to the provision of section 90-42, no owner or driver of any taxicab in the village shall refuse to convey any person with or without baggage when applied to for that purpose, or having undertaken to convey such person, shall omit or neglect to do so. 
(Code 1972, § 27-28)  
Sec. 90-44. - Soliciting trade prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any vehicle licensed under this article to solicit, by word, gesture, or otherwise, the patronage of any person at any railroad station or upon any public street or place in the village. 
(Code 1972, § 27-29)  
Sec. 90-45. - Delivery of passengers by taxicabs licensed in other municipalities. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to prevent a taxicab licensed in another municipality from delivering passengers picked up outside of the village to a destination in the village. 
(Code 1972, § 27-30)  
Sec. 90-46. - Discounted rate tickets for senior citizens and persons with disabilities. 
(a)  The village shall print and sell, at a discounted rate, tickets for taxicab rides for the exclusive use of senior citizens and persons with disabilities who reside within the corporate limits of the village. Such tickets shall be honored by any taxicab company licensed by the village for taxicab rides at the rates provided in section 90-40. Taxicab companies shall maintain a record of trips provided in exchange for such tickets on forms provided by the village. This record may include the date, time, name of the passenger, points of origin and destination, and the value of discount tickets collected for each trip for which the taxicab company collects discounted tickets. Any such taxicab company that furnishes to the village the tickets which are utilized by senior citizens or persons with disabilities for taxicab rides offered by such companies, along with the fully completed and executed record of such trips as required in this section, shall be reimbursed by the village for the actual value thereof. Proper execution of the record shall require the signature of the manager or shift supervisor on duty during the shift in which the discounted tickets are collected. 
(b)  The discounted rate tickets provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall not be used by senior citizens or persons with a disability, and shall not be accepted by a taxicab company, for taxicab rides to or from any airport. No taxicab company shall accept such discounted rate tickets for rides to or from airports. The village shall not reimburse a cab company for tickets used for rides to or from airports. 
(c)  No taxicab driver or taxicab company shall knowingly present discounted rate tickets to the village for reimbursement under false pretenses. 
(d)  No taxicab company shall refuse to serve any person using the discounted rate tickets who is a senior citizen or a disabled person or refuse to accept discounted rate tickets from a senior citizen or disabled person. 
(e)  Any taxicab company which violates the terms of this section shall be subject to prosecution and a fine of $750.00 per violation and restitution for village expenditures under this section. In addition, any license issued under this article may be revoked or suspended for violation of this section pursuant to the procedures set forth in section 90-33. Prosecution of this ordinance violation is in addition to any federal, state, or local civil or criminal actions the individual taxicab user, the state, or the village may have against the taxicab driver or the taxicab company. 
(Ord. No. 97-99, § 2, 11-3-1997)  
Sec. 90-47. - [Restrictions regarding designated taxicab loading zones and prohibited taxicab parking spaces.] 
All taxicabs licensed under this article shall adhere to restrictions of chapter 78, section 78-310 regarding designated taxicab loading zones and prohibited taxicab parking spaces. A violation of said section 78-310 shall subject the taxicab to ticketing and shall constitute a violation of this article, entitling the village to suspend, revoke or not renew the license. 
(Ord. No. 09-189, § 2, 11-16-2009)  
APPENDIX A - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes:

Editor's note Printed herein is Ord. No. 79-33, § 3, as adopted by the village board on October 1, 1979. Amendments to the ordinance are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, headings and catchlines have been made uniform and the same system of capitalization, citation to state statutes, and expression of numbers in text as appears in the Code of Ordinances has been used. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. The zoning map is on file in the village offices. 
Cross reference Advertising, ch. 6; alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; animals, ch. 14; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; economic development director, § 18-3; businesses, ch. 22; engineering and flood control, ch. 34; tattooing and body piercing establishments, § 46-200 et seq.; planning and development, ch. 63; telecommunications systems, ch. 76; vehicles for hire, ch. 90; land development, app. B; schedule of fees, taxes and charges, app. C. 
State Law reference Zoning, 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - TITLE 
(A)  This comprehensive amendment, including the rezoning district map made a part hereof, shall be known and may be cited and referred to as "The Village of Westmont Zoning Ordinance." 
(B)  This comprehensive amendment was approved by the president and board of trustees on October 1, 1979, and has thereafter been amended from time to time.  
ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE AND INTENT 
 
Sec. 2.01. - Purpose. 
This comprehensive amendment is adopted to the end that: 
(A)  Adequate natural light, pure air, privacy, convenience of access to property, and safety from fire, explosion, noxious fumes, panic and other dangers may be secured; 
(B)  Overcrowding of land may be prevented; 
(C)  Undue concentration of population may be avoided; 
(D)  Value of land and structures throughout the village may be conserved; 
(E)  Congestion in the public streets and highways may be lessened or avoided; 
(F)  Hazards to persons and damage to property resulting from the accumulation or runoff of storm or flood waters may be lessened or avoided; 
(G)  Aesthetic values throughout the village may be preserved and enhanced; and 
(H)  Public health, safety, comfort, morals, convenience and general welfare may otherwise be promoted.  
Sec. 2.02. - Intent. 
To achieve these ends, the comprehensive amendment sets forth regulations and standards to: 
(A)  Encourage the most appropriate use of land throughout the village; 
(B)  Regulate and limit the height and bulk of structures hereafter to be erected; 
(C)  Establish, regulate and limit setback lines along streets; 
(D)  Regulate the intensity of land use and determine the area of permanent open space; 
(E)  Classify, regulate and restrict the location of trades and the location of structures designed for business, industrial, residential and other specified uses; 
(F)  Divide the village into zoning districts of such character, number, shape and area as are best suited to effect the foregoing purposes; 
(G)  Prohibit structures or uses incompatible with the character of such districts; 
(H)  Prevent additions to and alterations or remodeling of existing structures in such a way as to avoid the restrictions and limitations lawfully imposed in this comprehensive amendment; 
(I)  Fix standards to which structures therein shall conform; 
(J)  Provide for the gradual elimination of structures and uses which are incompatible with the character of the districts in which they are located; 
(K)  Define and limit the powers and duties of the administrative officers and bodies as provided in this comprehensive amendment; and 
(L)  Prescribe penalties for the violation of the provisions of this comprehensive amendment or of any amendment thereto.  
ARTICLE III. - INTERPRETATION AND SEPARABILITY 
 
Sec. 3.01. - Interpretation. 
In their application, the provisions of this comprehensive amendment shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion and protection of the public health, safety, morals and general welfare, and the provisions shall be interpreted in accordance with the following: 
(A)  Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this comprehensive amendment are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable standards imposed by any other provision of this comprehensive amendment or by any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
(B)  This comprehensive amendment is not intended to abrogate any ordinance, permit, easement, covenant or other private agreement, provided that where the regulations of this comprehensive amendment are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than such ordinance, permit, easement, covenant or other private agreement, the requirements of this comprehensive amendment shall govern. 
(C)  No structure or use not lawfully existing at the time of the adoption of this comprehensive amendment shall become or be made lawful solely by reason of the adoption of this comprehensive amendment; and if any unlawful structure or use is in conflict with the requirements of this comprehensive amendment, such structure or use remains unlawful hereunder.  
Sec. 3.02. - Separability. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the president and the board of trustees that the several provisions of this comprehensive amendment are severable in accordance with the following: 
(A)  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any provision of this comprehensive amendment to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect any other provision of this comprehensive amendment not specifically included in such judgment. 
(B)  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge invalid the application of any provision of this comprehensive amendment to a particular structure or use, such judgment shall not affect the application of the provision to any other structure or use not specifically included in the judgment.  
ARTICLE IV. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 4.01. - Control over use. 
(A)  Establishment of new uses. The use of a structure or lot established after the effective date of this comprehensive amendment shall be for a use which is herein specified as a permitted, special or accessory use in the district regulations applicable to the district in which such structure or lot is located. 
(B)  Existing building permits and existing uses. 
(1)  Where a building permit for a structure has been issued in accordance with law prior to the effective date of this comprehensive amendment, and where construction has been begun within 90 days of such effective date and is being prosecuted to completion within one year of the effective date of this ordinance, the structure may be completed in accordance with the approved plans, and further, may, upon completion, be occupied under a certificate of occupancy for the use originally designated. 
(2)  Where the use of a structure or lot existing at the time of the adoption of this comprehensive amendment is rendered nonconforming under the provisions of this comprehensive amendment, the provisions of article XII shall apply to each use. 
(3)  Where a structure and the use thereof or use of a lot lawfully exists on the effective date of this comprehensive amendment, and is classified by this comprehensive amendment as a special use in the district where it is located, such use shall be considered a lawful special use, but a special use permit issued in accordance with procedures herein set forth shall be required for any expansion or alteration of such existing legal special use.  
Sec. 4.02. - Control over bulk. 
(A)  Establishment of new buildings. New buildings shall conform with the bulk regulations established herein for the district in which each such building is located. 
(B)  Existing buildings. Existing buildings shall not be enlarged, reconstructed, structurally altered, converted or relocated in such a manner as to conflict or further conflict with the bulk regulations of this comprehensive amendment for the district in which such buildings are located. 
(C)  Existing lots of record. The following standards shall control the use, development and redevelopment of existing lots of record at the time of adoption of this ordinance which are deemed substandard lots because they fail to meet the minimum bulk requirements of minimum lot width and/or minimum lot area. 
(1)  Any lot of record at the time of adoption of this ordinance which contains a minimum lot width of 50 feet or greater may be used, developed or redeveloped without a variance provided all other provisions of this ordinance are met. 
(2)  Any lot of record at the time of adoption of this ordinance which contains a minimum lot width of less than 50 feet or which does not meet the minimum lot area requirements of this ordinance shall only be used, developed or redeveloped after obtaining a variance. 
(3)  Any vacant lot which is adjacent to another lot under common ownership shall be considered a single lot in interpreting this section. 
(D)  Building height. 
(1)  No building shall be erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered to exceed the height limit of the district in which it is located, except that: 
(a)  Penthouses or roof structures for the housing of elevators, stairways, tanks, ventilating fans or similar equipment required to operate and maintain the building; and chimneys, fire and parapet walls, water tanks or similar structures may be erected 15 feet above the height of the structure on which it is located even though the overall height may exceed the height limitation of the district in which it is located; however, such building appurtenances shall be so located or shall be so screened by parapet walls as to conceal their view when viewed from the adjoining street from an eye level height of five feet; 
(b)  Poles, radio and television antenna (transmitting and receiving) may be erected to a height of 60 feet above grade; 
(c)  Public, semipublic or public service buildings, hospitals, institutions or schools, when permitted in a district, may be erected to a height not exceeding 60 feet, and churches and temples may be erected to a height not exceeding 75 feet if the building is set back from each yard line at least one foot for each foot of additional building height above the height limit otherwise provided in the district in which the building is located. 
(2)  Detached accessory buildings in residence districts shall not exceed one story or 15 feet, whichever is lower. 
(3)  Grade from which building height is measured shall be the existing or established grade at the building setback line midway between the two side lot lines. 
(E)  Minimum lot area, two or more uses on a lot. Where two or more permitted or special uses, each requiring a minimum lot area, are provided in the same building or on the same lot, the required lot area shall be the sum of the areas required for each use individually. 
(Ord. No. 85-15, 2-4-1985; Ord. No. 05-02, § 2, 1-3-2005)  
Sec. 4.03. - Control over yards and other open space. 
(A)  Required yards. Yards and other open space as required by this comprehensive amendment shall be located on the same lot as the principal building or use and shall have not less than the minimum width and area as herein required for the district in which such building or use is located, except as otherwise provided in this comprehensive amendment for planned developments. 
(B)  Through lots. On vacant through lots, the front lot line shall be along the street right-of-way designated by the building inspector, except that when a front lot line has been established on one or more lots in the same block and all have front lot lines established along the same street right-of-way line, the street right-of-way line designated as the front lot line for such lot or lots shall be the front line on all vacant through lots in such block. Only such obstructions as herein permitted in front yards shall be located in that part of a rear yard adjoining a street that is equivalent in depth to a required front yard, except for lots backing to thoroughfares in subdivisions where no-access strips have been provided on the recorded plats; or where a solid fence is provided along the thoroughfare, the yard adjoining such thoroughfare shall conform to the regulations applicable to rear yards. 
(C)  Nontransferable. No legally required yards, open space or lot area for any building or use shall be used to satisfy yard, open space, or lot area requirements for any other building or use. 
(D)  Corner lots. On a corner lot, the front lot line shall be the lot line having the shortest dimension along a street right-of-way line. 
(E)  Existing yards. No yards allocated to a building or use existing on the effective date of this comprehensive amendment shall be subsequently reduced or further reduced below the yard requirements of this comprehensive amendment, except a yard adjoining a street may be reduced in depth equivalent to the amount of right-of-way taken or otherwise conveyed to a public authority for street or highway widening.  
Sec. 4.04. - Control over setbacks along streets and thoroughfares. 
Minimum setbacks on lots abutting a street or thoroughfare shall be the distance required for a front yard, or side yard adjoining a street, in the districts where such lots are located, measured from the existing right-of-way line of the street or thoroughfare, or from the proposed right-of-way as designated on the official map of the village, and as duly established by other ordinances of the village or as established by county or state highway authorities, whichever has the greater right-of-way width requirements.  
Sec. 4.05. - Control over accessory structures and uses. 
(A)  Establishment of accessory uses . Accessory structures and uses are permitted and special uses may be allowed in the various districts. They shall be compatible with the principal use and shall not be established prior to the establishment of the principal use. Accessory uses shall not include the keeping, propagation or culture of pigeons, rabbits, livestock, horses or other nonhousehold animals whether or not for profit, except as regulated and permitted in chapter 14, "Animals." 
(B)  Distance between accessory and principal buildings. A detached accessory building shall not be nearer than ten feet from the nearest wall of the principal building; and [for] each foot over ten feet in length that the wall of an accessory building parallels and is adjacent to the principal building, the required distance between the two shall be increased by one additional foot. 
(C)  Limitations on accessory buildings and structures . 
(1)  No accessory building shall be constructed upon a lot until the construction of the main building has been actually commenced, and no accessory building shall be used for dwelling purposes. 
(2)  Only one accessory building shall be permitted on any residential lot in addition to a detached private garage, and such additional building shall not exceed 144 square feet in area. 
(3)  Garages, detached, not more than 576 square feet in size, nor larger than 28 feet in length, except when approved by a variance. 
(4)  Fences, in general . 
a.  The property owner shall be responsible for installing the fence within the property line. No part of a fence, including post hole excavation, may extend beyond the property line without being indicated on the plat of survey and without the written approval of the adjacent property owner. 
b.  No fence shall be constructed that may impede the natural flow of storm water. 
c.  Fences shall be installed with the "finished side" out, facing the adjacent property. 
d.  Fence posts shall be set below grade a minimum of 36 inches. 
(D)  Allowable building encroachments in yards. Detached accessory buildings in rear yards shall: 
(1)  Have a coverage of not more than 30 percent of the area of the rear yard, not including swimming pools as an accessory structure; 
(2)  Observe the side yard adjoining a street requirement; 
(3)  Be located not less than three feet from side lot lines in R-3 district and five feet in all other districts, from the nearest lot line, but in no case the rear lot line setback shall be less than five feet; and 
(4)  Be located not less than ten feet from another accessory building.

Sec. 4.06. - Air rights. 
The development of air rights above land utilized for railroad, streets and drainage channels shall be processed as planned developments.  
Sec. 4.07. - Lot divisions. 
No lot shall hereafter [to] be divided into two or more lots for the purpose of transfer of ownership, unless all lots resulting from each such subdivision shall have lot areas and widths as required by this comprehensive amendment.  
Sec. 4.08. - Lots to have adequate access. 
Every building shall be on a lot which faces upon a public street or a permanent easement of access to a public street, which easement shall have a minimum width of 30 feet.  
Sec. 4.09. - Trailers, tents and boats. 
(A)  Trailers, recreational trailers and motor homes. 
(1)  Trailers, recreational trailers and motor homes shall not be permanently affixed to the ground as a principal building or accessory structure on a lot in any district. 
(2)  Trailers, recreational trailers and motor homes shall not be occupied for dwelling purposes. 
(3)  In single-family residence districts, not more than one recreational trailer or motor home may be stored or parked on any lot in the open. In a general residence district, not more than one recreational trailer or motor home for each dwelling unit may be parked or stored on a lot and only when specifically designated parking spaces have been provided above and beyond the required off-street parking spaces. 
(4)  All recreational trailers and motor homes parked in any district shall have valid and current license plates from the State of Illinois, or any other state. 
(B)  Temporary parking. 
(1)  Temporary parking and use of trailers shall be permitted when a permit has been issued by the building inspector for temporary office or storage uses incidental to and only for the period of time of construction of a building development, provided such trailers are located on the same or contiguous lots to the building development. 
(2)  Temporary parking of recreational trailers and motor homes shall be permitted in the front yard of any residential district for a maximum of three consecutive days, for purposes of loading and unloading, cleaning, and/or parking for temporary guests. Temporary parking of recreational trailers and motor homes in the front yard of any residential district for a period of between four consecutive days to a maximum of seven consecutive days may be allowed only upon the issuance of a temporary parking permit from the village economic development department. 
(C)  Tents . Tents shall not be erected, used or maintained on a lot (commercial or residential) without the advance approval of the village's community development department and fire prevention bureau. Any person proposing to erect and use a tent shall first complete a tent permit application, receive approval of said permit application, pay the required tent permit fee. and shall follow all regulations as set forth in the village's tent guidelines, as amended from time to time, and incorporated herein by reference. 
(D)  Boats. Boats may be stored in the open when customary in the operation of a lawfully established principal use. In single-family residence districts, not more than one boat (not exceeding 24 feet in length) may be stored or parked on any lot in the open, and only when a trailer is not stored on the same lot in the open. In general residence districts, not more than one such boat for each dwelling unit may be parked or stored on a lot and only when specifically designated parking spaces have been provided above and beyond the required off-street parking spaces. 
(E)  Parking for boats and trailers. The designated parking spaces for trailers and boats referenced in paragraphs (A)(3) and (D) above shall be located behind the front setback (building) line and away from the side yard adjacent to a street. All parking spaces for trailers and boats shall consist of asphalt, concrete or a gravel surface, as approved by the village public works department, and shall be counted towards lot area coverage for any such lot. 
(Ord. No. 85-15, 2-4-1985; Ord. No. 02-07, §§ 13, 1-21-2002; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 16-008, § 2, 1-21-2016)  
Sec. 4.10. - Sewerage and water systems. 
Each use hereafter established within the village which requires sewerage and water facilities shall be served by public sewerage and water systems.  
Sec. 4.11. - Off-street parking and loading. 
Off-street parking and loading shall be provided as accessory uses as regulated in article X.  
Sec. 4.12. - Signs. 
Signs may be erected as regulated in article XI.  
Sec. 4.13. - Underground utility services. 
For all new construction, electric power transmission and telephone lines, and other appurtenant installations, other than transformers and street lights, shall be installed underground. For all electrical upgrades and remodeling projects, such service may remain overhead. 
(Ord. No. 06-167, § 1, 9-5-2006)  
Sec. 4.14. - Storage of junk, refuse and disabled or damaged motor vehicles. 
The open storage of junk, refuse, scrap, disabled or damaged motor vehicles, whether awaiting repair or not, is prohibited in all zoning districts. For the purposes of interpretation, open storage shall be any storage not contained completely within a building or structure enclosed on all sides by walls and by a solid roof on the top.  
Sec. 4.15. - Outdoor lighting. 
Where outdoor lighting is provided on any lot, the lighting fixtures shall be so designed and so located as to confine the rays of light within the boundaries of the lot.  
Sec. 4.16. - Supplemental setback lines. 
(A)  On certain streets named in this section, supplemental setback lines shall be and hereby are established which are to be measured from the street right-of-way line in each case respectively, and which shall take precedence over and be binding regardless of any of the other building line setback provisions of this ordinance. 
(B)  Along the streets herein designated no building shall be erected or altered so as to place its front or side line nearer to the present right-of-way line of the street than the setback given for such street, nor shall that part of the existing building projecting beyond the setback line herein designated be altered or remodeled except when such alteration or remodeling is not structural in character and does not increase the bulk of that part of the building so projecting. 
(C)  Supplemental setback lines are hereby designated as follows: 
(1)  Fifty-fifth Street shall have a setback line of 30 feet. 
(2)  Cass Avenue shall have a setback line of 30 feet from the right-of-way line; except from 55th Street on the south to Naperville Road on the north shall have a setback line of 50 feet from the centerline of the dedicated roadway. 
(3)  Naperville Road shall have a setback line of 30 feet west of Cass Avenue and 30 feet east of Cass Avenue to Warwick Avenue and 30 feet on the south side of Naperville Road from Warwick Avenue to Wilmette Avenue. 
(4)  Thirty-fifth Street shall have a setback line of 30 feet. 
(5)  Sixty-third Street shall have a setback line of 30 feet. 
(6)  Chicago Avenue, east of Cass Avenue, shall have a setback line of 30 feet. 
(7)  Ogden Avenue shall have a setback line of 30 feet. 
(8)  Pasquinelli Drive shall have a setback line of 30 feet. 
(9)  Fairview Avenue shall have a setback line of 30 feet. 
(10)  Route 83 shall have a setback line of 75 feet. 
(Ord. No. 88-29, 3-7-1988)  
Sec. 4.17. - Temporary storage pods. 
(A)  Any person in any zoning district desiring to use a temporary storage pod shall first obtain a permit from the community development department prior to placement of the temporary storage pod upon their property. The permit fee shall be $25.00. 
(B)  A storage pod may be placed only upon a residential driveway or commercial parking lot, provided the placement upon the commercial parking does not impede the flow of traffic and its location is approved by the director of community development or his/her designee. Temporary storage pods shall not be placed on any public rights-of-way. Only one storage pod is allowed at a time on residential property, and shall not exceed 16 feet in length. 
(C)  No person shall place a temporary storage pod upon their property for more than 15 days. An extension may be requested, in writing, to the director of municipal services, or his/her designee, for no more than ten days provided good cause is shown. No person shall place a temporary storage pod upon their property for more than two such periods per year. 
(D)  Any and all storage materials in said pod shall only consist of personal property, and shall be non-toxic, non-flammable, and be non-offensive in nature. 
(E)  No person shall conduct business or sell merchandise or property from a temporary storage pod. 
(F)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to $750.00 per violation for each day that a violation continues. Violations include, but are not limited to, failure to obtain a permit prior to using a temporary storage pod, improper placement of a temporary storage pod, exceeding the maximum time period for use of the temporary storage pod, and storage of materials not allowed by this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-204, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 14-186, § 1, 11-13-2014)  
ARTICLE V. - ZONING DISTRICTS AND MAP 
 
Sec. 5.01. - Establishment of districts. 
In order to carry out the purposes and provisions of this comprehensive amendment, the village is hereby divided into the following zoning districts: 
R-1 	Single-family detached residence 
R1(A) 	Single-family detached residence 
R-2 	Single-family detached residence 
R-3 	Single-family detached residence 
R-4 	General residence 
R-5 	General residence 
R-6 	Special residence 
B-1 	Limited business 
B-2 	General business 
C-1 	Commercial 
M 	Manufacturing 
O/R 	Office/research 
PD 	Planned development 
 
(Ord. No. 00-149, § 2a, 12-4-2000; Ord. No. 07-15, § 2, 2-5-2007)  
Sec. 5.02. - Zoning district map. 
(A)  Zoning district map. The zoning districts and their boundaries are as shown upon the rezoning district map, as annually adopted pursuant to state law, which map and all amendments thereto and all notations, references and other information shown thereon are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this comprehensive amendment, with the same force and effect as if fully set forth in this comprehensive amendment. The zoning district map, properly attested, shall be filed with the village clerk. 
(B)  Boundaries of districts. Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of the various zoning districts as shown on the zoning district map, the following rules apply: 
(1)  A zoning district boundary line following a street or extension thereof shall be construed to be the centerline of such street or extension; 
(2)  A zoning district boundary line approximately following a lot line or extension thereof within a subdivision shall be construed as following such lot line or extension; 
(3)  Questions concerning the exact locations of district boundary lines shall be resolved by the board of trustees.  
Sec. 5.03. - Annexed land. 
Land hereafter annexed to the village shall be zoned in the R-1 single-family detached residence district and shall remain so zoned until such time as the board of trustees shall amend the zoning district map of this comprehensive amendment so as to rezone such land.  
ARTICLE VI. - RESIDENCE DISTRICTS 
 
Sec. 6.01. - Residence districts provisions. 
(A)  Home occupations. Permitted home occupations in all residence districts shall be any business or occupation located within a single-family detached dwelling and carried on by members of the immediate family and/or employees residing within the dwelling in connection with which: 
(1)  The home occupation is incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling for dwelling purposes and does not occupy more than one-fourth of the floor area of a story or cellar; 
(2)  There are no signs, display or activity that will indicate from the exterior that the building is being used, in part, for any purpose other than that of a dwelling; 
(3)  There are no commodities sold or services rendered that require receipt and delivery of merchandise, goods or equipment by other than a passenger motor vehicle, by U.S. letter-carrier mail service, parcel post, or United Parcel; 
(4)  All activity, including storage, is conducted completely within the dwelling unit; 
(5)  There are no special structural alterations or construction features to the dwelling, nor the installation of special equipment attached to walls, floors or ceilings; 
(6)  There is no perceptible noise, odor, smoke, electrical interference or vibration emanating from the structure or any danger to the surrounding neighbors; 
(7)  There are no more than two customers or clients on the premises at the same time; and 
(8)  There is no activity between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(B)  Conversions. In any residence district, the conversion of a structure to provide more dwelling units than presently exist, if permitted under the other district regulations, shall produce dwelling units, each of which has not less than a total of 500 square feet of habitable floor area and not less than an average of 160 square feet per room exclusive of bathroom and closets, except an efficiency dwelling unit may contain not less than 400 square feet of habitable floor area. 
(C)  Required usable open space. 
(1)  In all residence districts, there shall be provided and perpetuated on every lot used, in whole or in part, for dwelling purposes minimum usable open spaces as follows: 
(a)  For single-family detached, single-family attached and single-family semidetached, and two-family detached dwellings: The area of the required yards, except that when more than 30 percent of the required yards are occupied by off-street parking spaces and access drives, there shall be within the buildable area of the lot usable open spaces having areas equivalent to at least the area by which such uses exceed 30 percent yard coverage. 
(b)  For multiple-family dwellings: As set forth in [subsection] (a) above, provided the usable open spaces shall not be less than 250 square feet of area per dwelling unit. 
(D)  More than one residential building on a lot. There shall be no more than one residential building located upon a single lot. When two or more buildings which contain single-family attached dwellings, single-family semidetached dwellings, or two or more multiple-family dwelling buildings, or combinations thereof, are on a lot or on contiguous lots comprising a unified development under the same ownership or control, the application for development shall be processed as a planned development, and the spacing between buildings shall be as provided in the approved planned development documents. 
(E)  Parking limitations. Parking of trucks and all commercial vehicles is prohibited in all residence districts except within an enclosed garage. 
(F)  Site plan approval. 
(1)  Prior to the issuance of a building permit for any structure located on a lot, parcel or tract of land in the R-4, R-5 or R-6 districts, a site development plan, to include a landscaping plan, shall have been approved by the village board. 
(2)  The purpose of site plan approval is to provide for development of sites which consider all the elements of good land planning, as applicable, so as to provide an adequate relationship (a) between structures both on the site and on adjacent properties and (b) between the land uses both on the site and on adjacent properties while at the same time providing for adequate space, light, air, use and bulk limitations, to promote the health, safety and welfare of the village and its residents. 
(3)  In granting or withholding approval of site plans, the board of trustees shall be guided in the reasonable exercise of their discretion by the following standards: 
(a)  All plans shall be so designed that the public health, welfare and safety will be protected. 
(b)  The proposed development of the site shall be such that it does not cause substantial injury to the value of other property in the neighborhood. 
(c)  All plans shall provide for protection of both aesthetics and function of the natural environment, which shall include, but not be limited to, conditions pertaining to floodplains, soil and geologic characteristics and preservation of vegetation. 
(d)  All plans shall provide for the transmission, retention or detention of stormwater with such facilities installed so as to complement existing or proposed stormwater facilities, unless the board of trustees shall determine upon recommendation of the public works director that stormwater facilities need not be provided or a cash contribution in lieu of such facilities is made. In the event the board of trustees determines that a cash contribution be made in lieu of installation of stormwater facilities, such amount shall be determined by the public works director and the use thereof shall be restricted to the provision of stormwater facilities installed by the village. 
(4)  No site plan approval shall be withheld unless the board of trustees shall determine that one or more of the foregoing standards is not satisfied. The reason for such withholding of approval shall be recorded in the proceedings of the board of trustees. 
(G)  Dwelling unit restrictions; applicable regulations and definitions. A single dwelling unit shall house no more than one family. Regulations regarding habitable room space per occupant and definition of family shall apply. 
(H)  Driveway regulations. Driveways for single-family dwelling units shall be improved with a hard-surface pavement or concrete approved by the village economic development department and subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The minimum width of the driveway at any point shall be nine feet, and the maximum width of the driveway at any point shall be 22 feet, including paver bricks and other impervious material added to the sides of the driveways. However, the driveway may include a reasonable flair at the street and at the garage, and may include a reasonable turning area at or near the garage, subject to approval by the economic development department, taking into account the configuration of the lot. 
(2)  The driveway must meet the total lot area coverage permitted by the zoning ordinance, and the maximum lot coverage in the front yard shall be 0.40. 
(3)  The driveway shall be constructed on only one side of the principal structure upon the lot, and may not be constructed closer than three feet to any sideyard. 
(4)  Driveways shall be constructed in compliance with the village public works department's standards and specifications pertaining to driveways. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, 1-16-1984; Ord. No. 84-49, 5-21-1984; Ord. No. 85-15, 2-4-1985; Ord. No. 88-35, § 1, 3-21-1988; Ord. No. 01-118, § 1, 10-1-2001; Ord. No. 06-166, § 1, 9-5-2006; Ord. No. 07-101, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-104, § 1, 6-4-2007)

Sec. 6.05. - R-6 special residence district. 
(A)  Permitted uses: Multiple-unit residences, commonly referred to as senior/elderly housing and accessory uses, including but not limited to chapels, dining halls, craft and game rooms, professional facilities (doctor, nurse, dentist), barber and beauty shops and convenience marts, each of said accessory uses being for the primary use of the residents of the senior/elderly complex and as special use any special use permitted in the R-4 and R-5 general residence district, by compliance with its applicable district regulations. 
(B)  Lot size requirements: 
(1)  Minimum lot area: 40,000 square feet 
(2)  Square feet per building: All structures containing three or more dwelling units shall provide a minimum area per dwelling as follows: 
One-bedroom and efficiency units: 1,000 square feet. 
Two bedrooms: 1,500 square feet. 
Three or more bedrooms: 2,000 square feet. 
Any room other than a kitchen, bath, dining or living room shall be considered as a bedroom for purposes of determining the above requirements for lot area per dwelling unit. 
(C)  Bulk regulations: 
(1)  Yard requirements: 
(a)  Minimum front yard: 30 feet; however, for buildings in excess of 30 feet in height, the front yard shall be increased six inches for each foot building exceeds 30 feet to a maximum front yard requirement of 40 feet. 
(b)  Minimum side yards: ten feet for interior side yards and 30 feet for corner side yards. 
(c)  Minimum rear yard: 20 feet. 
(d)  Maximum floor area ratio: 1.50. 
(2)  Maximum height of buildings and structures: 65 feet. 
(D)  Density: Maximum gross density of one unit per 1,200 square feet of gross acreage, with a maximum net density of 46 units per net acre (excluding perimeter streets and alleys). 
(E)  Dwelling standards: Every dwelling unit shall have a minimum floor area per dwelling unit, measured from the outside of the exterior walls, excluding utility rooms, cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces not used during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes as follows: 
Dwelling units with two bedrooms: 650 square feet. 
Dwelling units with one bedroom: 550 square feet. 
Dwelling units termed efficiencies: 400 square feet. 
Dwelling units termed assisted living residences: 300 square feet net minimum. 
(F)  Parking standards: One parking space shall be provided for each three dwelling units plus one parking space for each employee assigned to the complex. 
(G)  Minimum contiguous area: The minimum contiguous area for land zoned for this use shall be one acre. 
(H)  Use limitations: 
(1)  Within a complex planned for the use herein described, provision may be made for barber and beauty shops, gift shops, commissary type operations, and like amenities for the residents housed therein. The total square footage of such facilities shall be subtracted from the gross area of the complex prior to computing densities. 
(2)  No zoning district hereafter established for this use shall be altered, modified or enlarged so as to conflict with the regulations outlined herein. 
(Ord. No. 81-75, 12-21-1981; Ord. No. 88-49, 5-2-1988; Ord. No. 98-108, §§ 1, 2, 10-5-1998)  
ARTICLE VII. - BUSINESS DISTRICTS 
 
Sec. 7.01. - Preamble. 
Business district regulations are intended to govern the location and uses of a full range of business and commercial establishments needed to serve the citizens of Westmont and its trade area. The regulations of the various business districts are designed to provide for groupings of business and commercial establishments that are compatible in scope of services and method of operations. The B-1 district is intended for application in the prime business centers and planned shopping centers characterized mainly by nonautomotive-oriented retail stores and shops. The B-2 district is intended for those portions of the village where highway-oriented retail business establishments are appropriate as well as general business activity. The C-1 district is intended for the South Westmont Business District and is created to encourage retail and sales tax generating commercial uses. All business establishments in the various business districts are intended to be retail trade or service establishments dealing directly with consumers. The production of goods on the premises is intended to be limited to those sold on the premises, or clearly incidental and accessory to the principal retail trade or service. 
(Ord. No. 07-15, § 3, 2-5-2007)  
Sec. 7.02. - Business district provisions. 
(A)  Dwelling units. Dwelling units and lodging rooms are not permitted in the B-1, B-2 and C-1 districts except as follows: 
(1)  In a permitted hotel, motel, convent, monastery, parsonage or rectory. 
(2)  In a special use where residential quarters are required for security and management on the site; these quarters shall be one dwelling unit. 
(3)  In the central business district, dwelling units may be permitted in conjunction with commercial enterprises. 
(4)  Dwelling unit(s) existing upon the date of this amendment shall be allowed to continue as a residence, when located in a business district. 
(5)  In the B-2 district, residential dwelling units may be permitted as part of a planned development where the majority use of the non-residential portion of the principle building is office use. 
(B)  Enclosure of operations. All business, servicing, storage or processing shall be conducted within completely enclosed buildings except: 
(1)  Off-street parking or loading; 
(2)  Drive-in type of operations and automatic teller machines (ATMs) when conducted as a special use in the B-1, B-2 or C-1 district; 
(3)  Open sales lots when operated as a permitted or special use in the B-2 district; and 
(4)  Special outdoor sales events of limited duration sponsored by an association of merchants for the promotion of a business district. 
(C)  Performance standards. All activities shall conform with the performance standards established for the M manufacturing district. 
(D)  Parking limitations. Parking of trucks or commercial vehicles in excess of one hour when accessory to the conduct of a permitted use shall be limited to trucks or commercial vehicles having capacity of less than 1½ tons, except for pickup or delivery services during normal business hours. 
(E)  Site plan approval. 
(1)  Prior to the issuance of a building permit for any structure located on a lot, parcel or tract of land in the B-1, B-2 and C-1 districts, a site development plan, to include a landscaping plan, shall have been approved by the village board. 
(2)  The purpose of site plan approval is to provide for development of sites which consider all the elements of good land planning, as applicable, so as to provide an adequate relationship (a) between structures both on the site and on adjacent properties and (b) between the land uses both on the site and on adjacent properties while at the same time providing for adequate space, light, air, use and bulk limitations, to promote the health, safety and welfare of the village and its residents. 
(3)  In granting or withholding approval of site plans, the board of trustees shall be guided in the reasonable exercise of their discretion by the following standards: 
(a)  All plans shall be so designed that the public health, welfare and safety will be protected. 
(b)  The proposed development of the site shall be such that it does not cause substantial injury to the value of other property in the neighborhood. 
(c)  All plans shall provide for protection of both aesthetics and function of the natural environment, which shall include, but not be limited to, conditions pertaining to floodplains, soil and geologic characteristics and preservation of vegetation. 
(d)  All plans shall provide for the transmission, retention or detention of stormwater with such facilities installed so as to complement existing or proposed stormwater facilities, unless the board of trustees shall determine upon recommendation of the public works director that stormwater facilities need not be provided or a cash contribution in lieu of such facilities is made. In the event the board of trustees determines that a cash contribution be made in lieu of installation of stormwater facilities, such amount shall be determined by the public works director and the use thereof shall be restricted to the provision of stormwater facilities installed by the village. 
(4)  No site plan approval shall be withheld unless the board of trustees shall determine that one or more of the foregoing standards is not satisfied. The reason for such withholding of approval shall be recorded in the proceedings of the board of trustees. 
(F)  B-1 business district development permits. 
(1)  All development and/or redevelopment in the B-1 district shall first require approval of a "development permit" granted by the board of trustees. The terms "development" and "redevelopment" shall include all new uses and occupancies to a property and/or unit, regardless of whether new construction or structural alterations are required. No person, firm, entity or governmental body shall be exempt from the development permit requirement. 
(2)  The purpose of the development permit is to revitalize the B-1 district as a development district pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-74.3-1 et seq., by regulating and promoting development projects that achieve one or more of the following goals: 
(a)  Protect and enhance the aesthetics and safety of the B-1 district through the use, construction or alteration of property; 
(b)  Enhance the sales tax base and real estate tax base of the village; 
(c)  Add to the quality mix of diverse businesses within the B-1 district; and 
(d)  Maintain and enhance on-site parking or available public parking. 
(3)  In determining whether to approve or deny a development permit, the village board of trustees shall consider the following nonexclusive list of criteria: 
(a)  Aesthetics such that the current architecture is supported and enhanced; and 
(b)  Health and safety such that construction and repairs are building code compliant, there is no environmental detriment and parking is sufficient; and 
(c)  Promotion of the primary development goal of adding to the village's sales tax base through high-quality retail, upscale and family-oriented sit-down restaurants and specialty shops. 
(d)  Businesses which do not directly contribute to the sales tax base of the village may be approved if they otherwise attract shoppers and diners to the B-1 district, otherwise add to the positive mix of businesses within a vibrant downtown, and fill space that would otherwise remain vacant. 
(Ord. No. 80-46, 11-17-1980; Ord. No. 85-15, 2-4-1985; Ord. No. 86-102, 10-20-1986; Ord. No. 88-35, § 2, 3-21-1988; Ord. No. 99-16, § 1(A), 2-1-1999; Ord. No. 06-50, § 1, 3-20-2006; Ord. No. 07-15, §§ 46, 2-5-2007; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 10-201, § 1, 12-6-2010)

Sec. 7.04. - Special conditions. 
Prior to the authorization for a special use and the granting of a special use permit, special conditions where identified in article [section] 7.03 shall be required in addition to compliance with the requirements for satisfactory plans, specifications and public hearings as required in article XIII. The following list of special conditions are identified by code numbers corresponding to those which appear in article [section] 7.03 in connection with specific special uses: 
Code No. 
1  Such special use may be permitted provided that no buildings or outdoor portions of the lot containing such use are located within 100 feet of a residence district. 
2  Such special use may be permitted where the owner satisfactorily establishes that there will be no appreciable traffic congestion or hazard to pedestrian safety. 
3  Such special use may be permitted only as an integral part of a planned business center of over four acres in area where vehicular access to the establishment is from the parking lot driveways. 
4  Such special use may be permitted provided that no buildings or outdoor portions of the lot containing such use are located within 500 feet of a residence district. 
5  Such special use may be permitted on a lot which is not less than 20,000 square feet in area. 
6  Such special use may be permitted provided that no buildings or outdoors portions of the lot containing such use are located within 1,000 feet of a school (not to include nursery schools). 
7  Such special use may be permitted provided that there shall be compliance with an approved landscaping plan providing for the screening from view of vehicles awaiting service or customer pickup; or provided that there shall be enclosed storage of all vehicles awaiting service or customer pickup. 
8  Such special use may be permitted provided the owner of the facility and the host premises provide for adequate security as determined preliminarily by the chief of police for the Westmont Police Department with such determination to address all relevant factors, including but not limited to the use of the host premises, the use of parcels adjacent to and nearby the host premises, the material and design constituting the facility, lighting, alarm systems, personal or mechanical surveillance, visibility from rights-of-way, crime rates in the vicinity, limitations upon access to the facility, pedestrian and traffic flow in the vicinity of the facility, and the number of facilities of like kind located nearby the proposed facility and available to the residents of the village and the customers and employees of businesses in the village. 
9  Such special use may be permitted provided the work area for refinishing and repairs totals no more than 55 percent of the total building space, provided a retail space of at least 20 percent of the building space is provided; provided only hand-held tools are utilized for refinishing and repairs, and provided there is sufficient protection against the emission of fumes, dust, noise and vibrations from the property. 
10  Such special use may be permitted on the ground floor. 
11  Such special use may be permitted provided the microbrewery operation is no more than 50 percent of food, retail or restaurant sales. 
12  Such special use may be permitted with administrative approval if the business space is less that 1,000 square feet. 
13  Such special use may be permitted where it meets the definition of and restrictions upon video gaming cafes set forth in Chapter 10, Section 10-36(22) of the Westmont Code of Ordinances and where there is a sufficient distance separation from other establishments in the village which offer video gaming. 
14  Such special use may be permitted provided that such use is separated by at least 1,000 feet from a public or private school, and by at least 300 feet from a public park, measured from lot line to lot line. 
15  Such special use may be permitted provided that the facility provides 1.5 parking stalls per 100 square feet of interior seating area. 
16  Such special use may be permitted provided that no more than 50% of the total square feet of the premises shall be designated for interior seating area for the retail sale of craft alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. 
17  Such special use may be permitted with an outdoor seating area, as defined in the definition section of this Appendix A, provided that no outdoor seating area exceeds 50% of the allowable interior seating area and provided that the outdoor seating area meets the requirements of chapter 10 of this Code of Ordinances.
