ARTICLE IX. - PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT 
 
Sec. 9.01. - Preamble. 
In addition to the objectives prescribed in previous sections, the PD district is included in the zoning ordinance in order to achieve the following purposes: 
(A)  To encourage more creative design and development of land. 
(B)  To promote variety in the physical development pattern of the village. 
(C)  To concentrate open space in more useable areas or to preserve natural resources of the site. 
(D)  To provide means for greater creativity and flexibility in environmental design than is provided under strict application of the requirements of other zoning districts, while at the same time preserving the health, safety, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare of the Village of Westmont and its residents. 
(E)  To allow flexibility in development of land as necessary to meet changes in technology and demand what will be in the best interest of and consistent with the general intent of the comprehensive guide plan of the village. 
(F)  To provide for the more efficient allocation and maintenance by private initiative of useable open space to all residential and commercial areas and to allow the most efficient use of public facilities and land in keeping with the best interests of the village.  
Sec. 9.02. - Application of regulations. 
(A)  Overlay district. The planned development district regulations shall supplement the regulations of the existing underlying zoning district, and may, as set forth in this section [article], modify or nullify specific regulations of the underlying district. 
(B)  Right to develop under underlying district. Application of the planned development to a tract of land shall not affect the rights of the property owner or owners to develop the property in conformance with the provisions of the underlying zoning district, except that when contractual agreements, as required herein, have been consummated and site development of such planned development has commenced, there shall be the obligation to complete the approved planned development. 
(C)  Air rights development. The development of air rights above land utilized for railroad, streets and drainage channels shall be processed as planned developments.  
Sec. 9.03. - Permitted uses. 
Uses specified as permitted uses in the existing underlying zoning district, except that where single-family detached dwellings are permitted, two-family detached, single-family attached, single-family semidetached, and multiple-family dwellings shall be permitted, and on tracts of land under unified ownership and over 40 acres in area, one-tenth of the total area may be used for uses permitted in the B-1 district.  
Sec. 9.04. - Minimum area for overall planned development. 
There shall be no minimum area requirements for overall planned developments.  
Sec. 9.05. - Maximum gross density. 
Maximum gross density for planned development districts shall be as follows: 
(A)  In the R-1 district: Not more than three dwelling units per acre, provided that at least 20 percent of the gross area is maintained in open space* and developed for recreational use. No more than 50 percent of the required open space* shall be used for stormwater retention or detention. 
(B)  In the R-2 district: Not more than four dwelling units per acre, provided that at least 20 percent of the gross area is maintained in open space* and developed for recreational use. No more than 50 percent of the required open space* shall be used for stormwater retention or detention. 
(C)  In the R-3 district: Not more than five dwelling units per acre, provided that at least 20 percent of the gross area is maintained in open space* and developed for recreational use. Not more than 50 percent of the required open space* shall be used for stormwater retention or detention. 
(D)  In the R-4 and R-5 districts: Lot areas per dwelling unit required in each district shall be measured on the basis of gross site area and may be reduced by not more than ten percent in return for the provision of amenity features such as open spaces,* fountains or terraces. 
*If the village board determines that the size, shape, access and other features of the open space meet the park and recreational needs of the development, such open space (or such portion which qualifies) may be used to reduce or satisfy the requirements of paragraph 4.05, appendix B (Land Development Ordinance) of the Municipal Code relative to park and recreation land. Also, if a portion of the open space is needed and dedicated for a school site, such portion may be used to reduce or satisfy the requirement of paragraph 4.05, appendix B, relative to school site dedication.  
Sec. 9.06. - Maximum floor area ratio. 
The floor area ratio requirements of the underlying districts are applicable to the entire planned development and not to specific uses which may be located within the planned development.  
Sec. 9.07. - Minimum lot width. 
The minimum lot width requirements of the underlying district may be waived in the planned development.  
Sec. 9.08. - Maximum building height. 
The maximum building height requirements of the underlying district may be waived in the planned development.  
Sec. 9.09. - Minimum yards. 
The minimum yard requirements of the underlying district are applicable along the exterior boundaries of the planned development only.  
Sec. 9.10. - Development plan and specifications. 
The design features and standards of development within the PD planned development district shall, in addition to the regulations set forth in this ordinance, conform to a development plan, including details and specifications as may be required, which is reviewed by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the village board. The development plan shall include, as a minimum, the following: 
(A)  *An accurate topographic and boundary line map of the project area and a location map showing its relationship to surrounding properties. 
(B)  *The pattern of public and private roads, driveways and parking facilities, and intended design standards. A traffic impact study may be required. 
(C)  *The size, arrangement and location of lots or of proposed building groups. 
(D)  Location, type and size of proposed landscaping. 
(E)  *The use, type, size and location of structures. 
(F)  The location of sewer and water facilities, and an analysis of the impact of the development upon the capacities of adjoining systems and upon treatment and supply facilities. 
(G)  Architectural drawings and sketches illustrating the design and character of proposed structures. 
(H)  The location of recreational and open space areas and areas reserved or dedicated for public uses such as school, park, etc., and open space to be owned and maintained by a property owner's association. 
(I)  Existing topography and storm drainage pattern and proposed storm drainage system showing basic topographic changes. Computations relating to stormwater runoff and detention and retention required and provided shall be shown. 
(J)  *Statistical data on total size of project area, area of usable open space, density computation and proposed number of residential units by type, and other similar data pertinent to a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed development. Such data will also present the allowable density on the property under its existing underlying zoning classification. 
Editor's note *See the provisions of § 9.11(B)(3). 
(K)  An analysis of the impact of the proposed development upon school enrollments and school capacities. 
(L)  A copy of the intended organizational structure related to property owners' association, deed restrictions and provision of services. Aspects of the maintenance of common open space areas and of the provisions relating to the future use of private property (additions, expansion, changes in use, etc.) shall be fully set forth in such documents. 
(M)  Other information or data as deemed appropriate by the planning and zoning commission. 
(N)  Preliminary plat of subdivision if required.  
Sec. 9.11. - Procedure. 
(A)  Prepetition conference. Prior to official submittal of a petition for consideration of the planned development district, the petitioner shall meet with the planning and zoning commission for a preliminary discussion as to the scope and nature of the proposed development. 
(B)  Petition. 
(1)  Following the preliminary consultation with the planning and zoning commission, petition may be made to the board of trustees by the owner, or his agent, for the approval of a specific project plan under the provisions of these regulations, and for the application to the project area of the PD planned development district. 
(2)  A copy of such application shall thereafter be forwarded by the village clerk to the planning and zoning commission with a request to hold a public hearing and submit to the board of trustees a report of its findings and recommendations. Such public hearing shall be held upon public notice as required by the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
(3)  Upon filing such an application, the petitioner shall submit three copies of those items specified in section 9.10, above, which are designated with an asterisk. 
(4)  Following review of these preliminary materials, the planning and zoning commission may suggest modifications to the plans prior to the public hearing and prior to requiring the submittal of the balance of the supporting documents specified in section 9.10, above. 
(5)  Following preliminary meetings with the petitioner and following receipt of three copies of all reports and maps, the planning and zoning commission shall hold the required public hearing. 
(6)  Within 45 days following the conclusion of the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall forward their recommendations to the village board. 
(7)  The board of trustees, upon report of the planning and zoning commission and without further public hearing, may grant or reject an amendment for the establishment of a PD planned development district, or may refer it back to the planning and zoning commission for further consideration. 
(8)  In case a written protest against a planned development amendment is signed and acknowledged by owners of 20 percent of the frontage proposed to be altered, or by the owners of 20 percent of the frontage immediately adjoining or by owners of 20 percent of the frontage directly opposite the frontage to be altered, is filed with the village clerk, the amendment cannot be passed except on the favorable vote of two-thirds of all members of the board of trustees. 
(C)  Contract with the village. 
(1)  When a planned development is approved by the board of trustees, the developer shall enter into a contract with the village to guarantee the implementation of the development according to the terms of the conditions established as part of the development plan. The contract shall include but not be limited to provisions covering the following aspects of the planned development: (1) use standards and design of the project in conformance with submitted documents, (2) the timing and phasing of the project, (3) the method of guaranteeing the preservation of open space, (4) the method and procedure for payment of annexation, utility and other village fees, (5) bond requirements, if any, and (6) conditions under which the contract may be terminated in the event of nonperformance. 
(2)  Any subsequent change or addition to an approved plan shall first be submitted for review by the planning and zoning commission. A public hearing shall be held by the planning and zoning commission. Following the public hearing the planning and zoning commission shall make and forward its recommendation to the board of trustees and the board of trustees shall thereafter approve, approve conditionally, or disapprove the proposed changes. 
(3)  Failure to comply with the conditions and regulations as herein established and as specifically made applicable to a special project development shall be cause for termination of the approval of said project. At least 15 days' notice shall be given to the developer to appear before the planning and zoning commission and answer any such charge of noncompliance. If the planning and zoning commission finds the charges substantiated, they may recommend such termination of the project approval by the board of trustees if the situation is not satisfactorily adjusted within a specified period. 
(D)  Previously approved planned developments. Where planned development ordinances for specific properties have been approved by the village board prior to the effective date of this ordinance, such developments shall be completed or substantially under construction within one year from the effective date of this ordinance. Failure to comply with these terms shall, upon notice to the property owner by the village board, result in the automatic termination of such previously granted approval.  
ARTICLE X. - OFF-STREET PARKING AND OFF-STREET LOADING 
 
Sec. 10.01. - Scope of regulations. 
The off-street parking and off-street loading provisions of this ordinance shall apply as follows: 
(A)  Accessory off-street parking and off-street loading facilities shall be provided as required by the regulations of this article for all buildings and structures. However, where a building permit has been issued prior to the effective date of this ordinance, and provided that construction is begun within six months of such effective date and diligently prosecuted to completion, parking and loading facilities in the amounts required for the issuance of said building permit may be provided in lieu of any additional amounts required by this ordinance. 
(B)  When the intensity of use of any building, structure or premises shall be increased through the addition of dwelling units, gross floor area, seating capacity or other units of measurement, such additional parking and loading facilities as required herein shall be provided. 
(C)  Whenever the existing use of a building or structure shall hereafter be changed to a new use, parking or loading facilities shall be provided as required for such new use. However, if the said building or structure was erected prior to the effective date of this ordinance, additional parking or loading facilities are mandatory only in the amount by which the requirements for the new use exceed those for the existing use.  
Sec. 10.02. - Existing parking facilities. 
Accessory off-street parking facilities in existence on the effective date of this ordinance and located on the same lot as the building or use served shall not thereafter be reduced below the requirements for a similar new building or use under the provisions of this ordinance.  
Sec. 10.03. - Permissive parking and loading facilities. 
Nothing in this ordinance shall be deemed to prevent the voluntary establishment of off-street parking and loading facilities to serve any existing use of land or buildings, provided that all regulations herein governing the location, design and operation of such facilities are observed.  
Sec. 10.04. - Damage or destruction. 
When any building or use which is in existence on the effective date of this ordinance is restored and continued in operation after being damaged or destroyed by fire, collapse, explosion or other cause, there shall be required only the off-street parking or loading facilities equivalent to any maintained at the time of such damage or destruction.  
Sec. 10.05. - Control of off-site parking facilities. 
In cases where parking facilities are permitted on land other than the lot on which the building or use served is located, such facilities shall be on a lot in the same possession of the title holder of record as the lot occupied by the building or use to which the parking facilities are accessory. A covenant running with the land must be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds of DuPage County, Illinois, on the lot upon which the accessory off-street parking is located, which prohibits any other use on that lot, and a certified copy of the recorder of deeds of DuPage County, Illinois, of the recorded covenant is deposited with the building inspector. The covenant shall not be released until such time as either one of the following conditions occur: 
(A)  The structure on the lot containing the principal use is removed and the principal use terminated; or 
(B)  Another lot of the required size within the required distance is properly developed and used for the required accessory off-street parking in place of and in lieu of the initial lot used for accessory off-street parking with the same requirements, covenants and conditions attaching to such substitute accessory use lot as required for approval of such initial off-street parking. Off-street parking facilities in a common lot for two or more uses may be owned by a nonprofit corporation or secured by other legal arrangement provided guarantees covering development and utilization are approved by the board of trustees.  
Sec. 10.06. - Off-street parking. 
Off-street parking facilities for motor vehicles shall be provided in accordance with additional regulations set forth hereinafter: 
(A)  Use. Off-street parking facilities required as accessory to uses listed herein shall be solely for the parking of automobiles of patrons, occupants or employees. When bus transportation is provided for patrons, occupants or employees of a specific establishment, additional open or enclosed off-street parking spaces for each bus to be parked on the premises shall be provided. 
(B)  Exemptions. 
(1)  When the application of the off-street parking regulations specified hereinafter results in a requirement of not more than three spaces on a single lot in the B-1 or B-2 districts, such parking spaces need not be provided; however, in the B-1 district, a payment of cash-in-lieu of providing such parking spaces, as set out in section (3), below, must be received by the village for such parking space waivers. Note, where two or more uses are located on a single lot, only one of these uses shall be eligible for the above exemption. This exemption shall not apply to dwelling units. 
(2)  In the event that an applicant or petitioner requests a variance in the form of a waiver of required off-street parking spaces in the B-1 district, said applicant or petitioner shall be required to pay an amount of money for each off-street parking space waived by variance. The schedule of applicable fees is set out in section (3), below. Such fees shall be placed in the parking fund for the purpose of acquiring property for public parking, to construct new public parking facilities, and/or to make improvements to existing public parking facilities. The village board may, at their sole discretion, reduce and/or waive this fee in the downtown B-1 central business district. 
(3)  Cash-in-lieu fee schedule for parking waiver variations: 
For parking waivers of three parking spaces or less$500.00 flat fee; 
For parking waivers of four to ten parking spaces$250.00 per parking space, after payment for the waiver of the first three parking spaces set forth above; 
For parking waivers of 11 to 20 parking spaces$500.00 per parking space, after payment for the waiver of the first three parking spaces set forth above, and payment for the waiver of spaces four to ten set forth above; 
For parking waivers of more than 21 parking spaces$750.00 per parking space, after payment for the waiver of the first three parking spaces set forth above, and payment for the waiver of spaces four to ten, and 11 to 20 set forth above. 
(C)  Computation. When determination of the number of off-street parking spaces required by this ordinance results in a requirement of a fractional space, any fraction of one-half or less may be disregarded while a fraction in excess of one-half shall be counted as one parking space. 
(D)  Collective provision. Off-street parking facilities for separate uses may be provided collectively if the total number of spaces so provided is not less than the sum of the separate requirements for each such use and provided that all regulations governing location of accessory parking spaces, in relation to the use served, are adhered to. Further, no parking space or portion thereof shall serve as a required space for more than one use unless otherwise authorized by the planning and zoning commission. 
(E)  Area. A required off-street parking space shall have a width and length exclusive of access drives or aisles, ramps, columns or office or work areas in accordance with Westmont standards of design. 
(F)  Access. Each required off-street parking space shall open directly upon an aisle or driveway of a width and design in accordance with Westmont standards of design. All off-street parking facilities shall be provided with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or alley. 
(G)  In yards. Off-street parking spaces, including vehicles displayed in connection with the operation of a new or used car dealership, open to the sky, may be located in any yard except a front yard, a side yard adjoining a street, or in front of any setback (building) line established by code or recorded plat of subdivision. An exception shall be that in single-family residence districts the parking of vehicles which are otherwise permitted in the district is permitted in the front yard in a private residential driveway. 
(H)  Design and maintenance. 
(1)  Open and enclosed parking spaces. Accessory off-street parking spaces located on the same lot as occupied by the use served may be open to the sky or enclosed in a building. Accessory off-street parking spaces located elsewhere than on the same lot occupied by the use shall be open to the sky. 
(2)  Surfacing. All open off-street parking areas and driveways shall be improved with concrete or asphalt as approved by the public works director. Surfacing and landscaping of parking areas and driveways must be completed within 60 days following the issuance of an occupancy permit unless such time is extended up to a maximum of 180 days by the public works director due to seasonal conditions. Temporary parking lots to serve temporary uses or model homes may be improved with gravel base and surfacing. 
(3)  Screening and landscaping. All off-street parking areas containing more than four parking spaces and nonresidential driveways adjacent to lot lines shall be suitably screened on each side and rear lot line by a screen fence or wall not less than four feet in height plus a planting strip of four feet minimum width in accordance with the following, or on an alternate arrangement as approved by the village board. Suitable landscaping and ground cover shall be provided and maintained on a continuing basis within the planting strip. On the street lot line, a planting screen not less than three feet in height shall be installed. Such planting screen shall be adjacent to the parking area. Suitable landscaping and ground cover shall be provided and maintained on a continuing basis between the screen fence and the curbline. At least one tree of not less than three-inch diameter size class shall be provided for every 1,500 square feet of pavement area up to 6,000 square feet. At least one tree of not less than three-inch diameter size class shall be provided for every 3,000 square feet of pavement area over 6,000 square feet. 
Tree placement shall be within the pavement area as opposed to perimeter planting. The selection of trees, hedges, shrubs, ground cover and other planting materials shall be approved by the economic development director, and all planting shall be performed in accordance with the standard specifications for the Village of Westmont. 
(a)  Walls, fences and screens. 
(1)  Planting screens, or hedges, fences or walls shall not exceed two feet in height where location is such that sight lines are necessary for vehicular movement across pedestrian ways. 
(2)  Fences or walls may be constructed with any of the materials listed below and shall receive the same architectural treatment on both sides. Materials other than those listed below shall be subject to approval by the economic development director. 
a.  Fences. 
;i1=110q; Wood: Board, panel or picket concrete panel. 
;i1=110q; Metal: Wrought iron or panel. 
b.  Walls. 
;i1=110q; Concrete: Plain or textured. 
;i1=110q; Brick: Plain or glazed tile or architectural block. 
;i1=110q; Stone: Natural, block stone or rubble stone. 
(4)  Lighting. Illumination of an off-street parking area shall be arranged so as not to reflect direct rays of light into adjacent residential districts and streets. 
(5)  Repair and service. No motor vehicle repair work of any kind shall be permitted in off-street parking areas. No gasoline or motor oil shall be sold in conjunction with any accessory parking facilities unless such facilities are located within a completely enclosed building in which case gasoline and motor oil may be sold within such building to the users of such facilities, provided that no advertising sign is visible from outside the building and provided further that all pumps shall be effectively screened from view of the street. 
(I)  Location. All parking spaces required to serve residential buildings or uses, erected or established in residence districts after the effective date of this ordinance, shall be located on the same lot as the building or use served. Other buildings or uses may be served by parking facilities located on land other than the lot on which the building or use served is located, provided such facilities are within 600 feet walking distance of said building, and located in a district where off-street parking areas or storage garages are a permitted or special use and where there is compliance with requirements herein set forth in section 10.05 of this article. 
(J)  Employee parking. Parking spaces required on an employee basis shall be based on the maximum number of employees on duty or residing, or both, on the premises at any one time. 
(K)  Required spaces. The minimum number of off-street parking spaces accessory to designated uses shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  Dwelling uses. 
(a)  Hotels and motels: one parking space for each room or suite of rooms comprising a lodging unit, plus one parking space for each 100 square feet of retail sales and dining areas. 
(b)  Multiple-family dwellings: 
(1)  Efficiency - 1 parking space for each dwelling unit. 
(2)  1 Bedroom - 1 ½ parking spaces for each dwelling unit. 
(3)  2 Bedroom - 2 parking spaces for each dwelling unit. 
(4)  3 Bedrooms and over - 2 ½ parking spaces for each dwelling unit. 
(c)  Single-family dwellings: No restrictions on number of parking spaces, but see section 6.01(H) for related restrictions. 
(d)  Two-family dwellings: two parking spaces, but not more than four parking spaces for each dwelling unit. 
(2)  Schools, institutions and auditoriums or other places of assembly. 
(a)  Auditoriums and auditoriums as accessory to churches, schools, and other institutional establishments: one parking space for each five seats or for each 90 lineal inches of seating space in the main auditoriums or assembly hall. 
(b)  Colleges, junior colleges and universities: one parking space for each seven students, based upon the maximum number of students that can be accommodated in accordance with design capacity. 
(c)  Gymnasiums, stadiums, grandstands, meeting halls, convention halls and exhibition halls: one parking space for each five seats or for each 90 lineal inches of seating space. When such facilities for public assembly are accessory to a school, and when approved by the zoning board of appeals, the required number of parking spaces may be reduced by the number of spaces provided, as required herein for the applicable school. 
(d)  Hospitals: one parking space per bed for 100 beds or lesser size; 1.1 parking spaces per bed for 101 to 300 beds; 1.2 parking spaces per bed for 301 to 500 beds; and 1.3 parking spaces per bed for over 500 beds. 
(e)  Libraries, museums, art galleries and aquariums: one parking space for each 600 square feet of floor area. 
(f)  Nursing homes and similar types of establishments: one parking space for each five beds, one space for each two lodging accommodations, and one space for each full-time employee. 
(g)  Private clubs and lodges: one parking space for each lodging room and one parking space for each five seats in accordance with design seating capacity of the main meeting room. 
(h)  Schools: When the number of parking spaces as required herein is provided for an auditorium or other places of public assembly accessory to a school, and when approved by the planning and zoning commission, additional parking spaces need not be provided when the number of parking spaces for such auditorium or other places of public assembly is equal to or in excess of the applicable requirements set forth in [subsection] (1), (2), or (3), below. 
(1)  Commercial or trade, music, dance or business: one parking space for each two employees, plus one space for each seven students, based on the maximum number of students that can be accommodated in accordance with design capacity. 
(2)  High, public or private: one parking space for each seven students based on the maximum number of students that can be accommodated in accordance with design capacity and one parking space for each faculty member and each other full-time employee. 
(3)  Nursery, elementary or junior high, public or private: one parking space for each faculty member and each other full-time employee. 
(3)  Recreational uses; commercial or noncommercial. 
(a)  Bowling alleys: seven parking spaces for each lane plus such additional spaces as may be required herein for affiliated uses such as restaurants and the like. 
(b)  Health salons, swimming pools, skating rinks and dancehalls, commercial: one parking space for each three persons, based upon the maximum number of persons that can be accommodated at the same time in accordance with such design capacity, and one parking space for each two employees. 
(c)  Parks, recreation areas and community centers: one parking space for each two employees, plus spaces in adequate number as determined by the planning and zoning commission to serve the visiting public. 
(4)  Business, commercial and industrial uses. 
(a)  High volume commercial uses. The following business establishments having a relatively high volume of customer activity relative to their area shall provide one off-street parking space for each 200 square feet of floor area: 
(1)  Bakeries, retail sales only. 
(2)  Candy and ice cream stores. 
(3)  Clothing stores. 
(4)  Department stores. 
(5)  Drugstores. 
(6)  Dry goods stores. 
(7)  Food stores. 
(8)  Gift and souvenir stores. 
(9)  Haberdashery stores. 
(10)  Hobby shops. 
(11)  Jewelry stores. 
(12)  Launderettes. 
(13)  Leather goods and luggage stores. 
(14)  Liquor stores, package. 
(15)  Meat markets. 
(16)  Millinery shops. 
(17)  Music stores, phonographs, records and sheet music. 
(18)  Notions shops. 
(19)  Optical sales, retail. 
(20)  Shoe stores and shoe repair shops. 
(21)  Sporting goods stores. 
(22)  Tailor shops. 
(23)  Variety stores. 
(b)  Moderate volume commercial uses. The following business establishments having a relatively moderate volume of customer activity relative to their area shall provide one off-street parking space for each 400 square feet of floor area: 
(1)  Art and school supply stores. 
(2)  Automobile accessory stores. 
(3)  Battery and tire sales and service establishments. 
(4)  Bicycle sales, rental and repair not including motor-driven vehicles. 
(5)  Books, stationery and school supply stores. 
(6)  Camera and photographic supply stores. 
(7)  Cleaning and dyeing establishments, clothes pressing only. 
(8)  Cleaning and dyeing establishments, receiving only. 
(9)  Cleaning and dyeing establishments, retail, including accessory processing only. 
(10)  Coin and philatelic stores. 
(11)  Electrical and gas appliance stores. 
(12)  Flower shops. 
(13)  Furrier shops. 
(14)  Garden supply stores. 
(15)  Hardware stores. 
(16)  Household appliances, retail sales and accessory repair only. 
(17)  Motorcycle sales and service establishments. 
(18)  Office supply stores. 
(19)  Paint and wallpaper stores. 
(20)  Pet shops. 
(21)  Travel agencies. 
(c)  Low volume commercial uses. The following business establishments having a relatively low volume of customer activity relative to their area shall provide one off-street parking space for each 600 square feet of floor area: 
(1)  Antique shops. 
(2)  Automobile sales, new cars. 
(3)  Automobile sales, new and used cars. 
(4)  Blueprinting and photostating establishments. 
(5)  Business machine sales and service. 
(6)  Carpet and rug stores. 
(7)  Clothing and costume rental. 
(8)  Custom dressmaking. 
(9)  Exterminating shops. 
(10)  Frozen food lockers. 
(11)  Furniture stores, including accessory upholstering. 
(12)  Greenhouses, retail and wholesale sales. 
(13)  Glass sales and repair shops. 
(14)  Interior decorating shops. 
(15)  Locksmith shops. 
(16)  Machinery and equipment sales establishments. 
(17)  Musical instruments, sales and repair. 
(18)  Orthopedic and medical appliance sales. 
(19)  Photography studio. 
(20)  Taxidermists. 
(d)  Employment-based commercial uses. The following business establishments shall provide one off-street parking space for [each] two employees, based upon the maximum number of employees on the premises at any time: 
(1)  Bottling and distribution plants. 
(2)  Cabinetmaking and sales. 
(3)  Catering establishments. 
(4)  Contractor's offices and shops, including plumbing shops and similar service facilities. 
(5)  Employment agencies. 
(6)  Fuel and ice, retail sales only. 
(7)  Heating and air conditioning shops. 
(8)  Job printing shops. 
(9)  Laboratories, medical, dental, and optical. 
(10)  Laundries. 
(11)  Linen, towel and diaper service establishments. 
(12)  Loan offices. 
(13)  Machine, sheet metal and welding shops, employing less than five persons. 
(14)  Mail order houses. 
(15)  Manufacturing establishments, limited. 
(16)  Model homes or garages, display and sales. 
(17)  Monument sales. 
(18)  Newspaper offices, including printing. 
(19)  Newspaper distribution establishments. 
(20)  Printing, publishing or lithography establishments. 
(21)  Radio and television studios. 
(22)  Recording studios. 
(23)  Wholesale, jobbing and warehousing establishments. 
(e)  Other business, commercial and industrial uses. 
(1)  Animal hospitals and veterinarian offices: one parking space for each four seats of seating capacity. 
(2)  Auction rooms: one parking space for each four seats of seating capacity. 
(3)  Automobile laundries: 
(A)  Automatic and semiautomatic: one parking space for each one employee on site, and in addition, reservoir standing spaces to accommodate automobiles awaiting entrance to the automobile laundry equal in number to five times the maximum capacity of the automobile laundry, times the operating cycle time of the automatic and semiautomatic washing equipment. Maximum capacity, in this instance, shall mean the greatest possible number of automobiles undergoing some phase of laundering at the same time. 
(B)  Manual: one parking space for each one employee on site, and in addition, reservoir standing spaces to accommodate automobiles awaiting entrance to the automobile laundry equal in number to five times the maximum capacity of the automobile laundry. Plus, one space for each vacuum space and one space for each drying space. Maximum capacity, in this instance, shall mean the greatest possible number of automobiles undergoing some phase of laundering at the same time. 
(C)  Combination of manual, automatic and semiautomatic: spaces required as defined in paragraphs (A) and (B). 
(D)  Auxiliary automobile laundry regulations: 
1.  Conservation of water usage by recycling and, if a private well is on the property, it shall be capped per EPA regulations. 
2.  Rumble strips installed at exit point to prevent water from entering street surface as a result of car washing operation and water drippings shall be directed on the property. 
3.  When weather is conducive to freezing, then the operator of the facility is responsible to see that corrective measures are taken to deter the street surface from freezing, i.e., applying salt, etc., to wet surfaces. If unable to fulfill this contingency, the car wash facility must close. 
4.  If stacking of vehicles occurs and affects off-premises traffic flow, a temporary closure sign must be displayed at entranceway and potential customers flagged away until further stacking becomes available on the premises. 
5.  Left and right turns in and/or out must be proven as to not cause traffic hazards and/or congestion. An in-depth traffic analysis of the car wash itself and the surrounding area shall be provided by using the village's traffic consultant. 
6.  If a water crisis occurs, the car wash facility shall be subject to the same restrictions imposed by the water superintendent on the other commercial businesses. 
7.  Emergency escape lane shall be provided for those waiting in line to leave, if they choose to do so. 
(4)  Automobile service stations: one parking space for each island of gasoline pumps, plus two for each service stall. 
(5)  Automobile garages: one parking space for each two employees and three for each automobile repair bay. 
(6)  Bakeries, retail sales with processing for on-premises sales only: one parking space for each 200 square feet of sales area plus one for each employee. 
(7)  Banks: one parking space for each 300 square feet of floor area plus in the case of drive-in facilities seven additional on-site reservoir parking spaces for each drive-in window. 
(8)  Barbershops and beauty parlors: one parking space for each employee plus two for each patron service area. Except, nail salons shall have one parking space for each employee and one parking space for each patron service area. 
(9)  Building material sales: one parking space for each employee plus one for each 1,000 square feet of sales area or showroom. 
(10)  Business, professional and public administration or service office buildings: one parking space for each 275 square feet of floor area. 
(11)  Cartage, express and parcel delivery establishments, scavenger services, taxi and bus companies, etc.: one parking space for each vehicle used in the business plus one for each employee. 
(12)  Exhibition halls: as determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(13)  Manufacturing, fabricating, cleaning, testing, assembling, repairing or servicing establishments as permitted in the manufacturing district: one parking space for each two employees based upon maximum number of employees that can be accommodated in accordance with building code regulations. 
(14)  Medical and dental clinics: one parking space for each 50 square feet of floor area contained within the waiting or reception room plus 1½ spaces for each treatment room, each examination room and each doctor's office. 
(15)  Meeting halls: as determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(16)  Mobile homes and trailer sales and rental: one parking space for each employee plus three additional spaces. 
(17)  Physical culture and health services: one parking space per employee plus one for each two potential patrons based upon the capacity of the establishments. 
(18)  Restaurants, not including fast-food-service or drive-in establishments: one parking space per 100 square feet of floor area excluding kitchen and storage areas, or one parking space per each four seats including those seats in bars, cocktail lounges and waiting areas, whichever is greater, plus two spaces per each three employees using the maximum number of employees working at any given time. 
(19)  Restaurants, fast-food-service and drive-in: where a substantial portion of the business involves the sale of food in disposable containers for consumption off the premises in addition to sit-down facilities on the premises: one and one-half parking spaces per 100 square feet of floor area. 
(20)  Taverns: one parking space for each three spaces of seating capacity. 
(21)  Theaters: one parking space for each two seats. 
(22)  Theaters, automobile drive-in: reservoir standing spaces equal in number to ten percent of the vehicle capacity of such theaters. 
(23)  Undertaking establishments and funeral parlors: one parking space for each 100 square feet of floor area. 
(24)  Public utility and public service uses: one parking space for each two employees. 
(25)  Automatic teller machines: Two parking spaces for each teller machine located at any one premises; provided, however, that the two parking spaces shall not apply to drive-through automatic teller machines that are adjacent to a bank drive-through facility which have a designated drive-through lane specifically devoted to such automatic teller machine. 
(26)  All other uses not specified in the foregoing sections: one parking space for each 250 square feet of floor area. 
(Ord. No. 85-15, 2-4-1985; Ord. No. 87-66, 8-3-1987; Ord. No. 99-16, § 1(F), 2-1-1999; Ord. No. 99-104, § 1, 8-2-1999; Ord. No. 01-118, § 3, 10-1-2001; Ord. No. 03-104, § 1, 8-4-2003; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 10-67, § 1, 4-19-2010; Ord. No. 11-06, § 1, 2-7-2011; Ord. No. 15-126, § 2, 7-9-2015)  
Sec. 10.07. - Off-street loading. 
There shall be provided off-street loading spaces not less than the minimum requirements specified in this section in connection with any building or structure which is to be erected or substantially altered, and which requires the receipt or distribution of materials or merchandise by trucks or similar vehicles. 
(A)  Location. All required off-street loading spaces shall be located on the same lot as the use to be served, and no portion of the vehicle shall project into a street or alley. No permitted or required loading spaces shall be located within 25 feet of the nearest point of intersection of any two streets, nor shall it be located in a required front yard, or side yard adjoining a street. 
(B)  Size. Unless otherwise specified in this ordinance, a required off-street loading space shall be at least ten feet in width by at least 65 feet in length, exclusive of aisle and maneuvering space, and shall have a vertical clearance of at least 15 feet three inches. 
(C)  Access. Each required off-street loading space shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or alley in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movements and shall be subject to approval of the public works director. 
(D)  Surfacing. All open off-street loading space and driveways shall be improved with concrete or asphalt as approved by the public works director. Surfacing and landscaping of parking areas must be completed within 60 days following the issuance of an occupancy permit unless such time is extended by the public works director up to a maximum of 180 days, due to seasonal conditions. Temporary parking lots to serve temporary uses or model homes may be improved with gravel base and surfacing. 
(E)  Repair and service. No storage of any kind nor motor vehicle repair work or service of any kind shall be permitted within any required loading space. 
(F)  Space allowed. Space allowed to any off-street loading space shall not, while so allocated, be used to satisfy the space requirements for any off-street parking facilities or portions thereof. 
(G)  Off-street loading space requirements. 
(1)  The minimum number of off-street loading spaces accessory to nonresidential uses in residence and business districts shall be: one loading space for buildings containing 10,000 to 100,000 square feet of gross floor area, plus one additional loading space for each additional 100,000 square feet of gross floor area or fraction thereof. 
(2)  The minimum number and size of off-street loading spaces accessory to uses in the M manufacturing and O/R office/research districts shall be in accordance with the following schedule: 
Floor area of

Such additional loading space shall be at least 12 feet in width by 65 feet in length, and have a vertical clearance of not less than 15 feet three inches.

Cross reference Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; electrical fees for signs, § 18-263. 
 
Sec. 11.01. - Preamble. 
Whereas there is a significant relationship between the standards used in displaying signs, aesthetics, the public welfare, and the value and economic stability of adjoining property; and whereas the reasonable display of signs is necessary as a public service and necessary to the conduct of competitive commerce and industry; now, therefore, the regulations in this article establish minimum standards for the display of signs in direct relationship to the use of property, to the intensity of development as permitted within the zoning districts which are provided in this ordinance, and to the public welfare as affected by the aesthetic virtue or harm of signs within the village. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.02. - Permits required. 
Except as otherwise provided in this ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person to erect, enlarge, alter or maintain within the village any sign as defined in this article, without first obtaining a permit from the community development department. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.03. - Permit fees. 
Permit fees shall be calculated in accordance with the building permit fees as prescribed in section 18-487. Temporary signs and banners shall be a flat fee of $25.00 per permitted display period. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.04. - Maintenance of signs and premises. 
(A)  All signs together with their supports, braces, guys and anchors shall be kept in good repair and shall at all times be maintained to conform to the minimum standards prescribed therefor. 
(B)  It shall be the duty of the owner of the lot or premises on which said sign is erected, to at all times maintain said lot or premises in the vicinity of such sign in neat, clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition, to keep the same free and clean of all debris, junk and other materials and substances which would tend to create a condition detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Westmont. 
(C)  If the economic development director shall find that any sign or other structure regulated herein is unsafe or insecure, or is a menace to the public, or has been constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this article or other applicable provisions of this Code, he shall give written notice to the permittee thereof. If the permittee fails to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the standards herein set forth within ten days after such notice, the economic development director may request the village attorney to apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an order that the violation be abated and that such sign be removed or altered to comply at the expense of the permittee or owner of the property upon which it is located, or to take whatever other action to enforce this ordinance as may be permitted by law. The economic development director shall refuse to issue a permit to any permittee or owner who refused to pay costs so assessed. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.05. - Removal of certain signs. 
Any sign now or hereafter existing which no longer advertises a bona fide business conducted, or a product sold, except noncommercial signs, shall be taken down and removed by the owner, agent or person having the beneficial use of the building or structure upon which such sign may be found. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.06. - Nonconforming signs. 
Any sign that existed lawfully on the effective date of the sign regulations of this article that remains or becomes nonconforming by reason of adoption of these sign regulations or because of subsequent amendments to these sign regulations, or that become nonconforming by reason of annexation to the village of the lot on which the sign is located, are considered nonconforming signs and their continuance is allowed in accordance with the following regulations: 
(A)  Ordinary repairs and maintenance, including the removing and replacing of the outer panels is permitted, provided that the panels are replaced with identical panels and that no structural alterations or other work that extends the normal life of the nonconforming sign is permitted. 
(B)  Single panels on multi-panel monument signs for multi-tenant shopping centers may be changed to reflect tenant changes. 
(C)  No repair or alteration that increases the size of the nonconforming sign is permitted. 
(D)  No nonconforming sign may be moved in whole or in part to any other location on the same or any other premises unless every portion of such sign is made to conform to all of the regulations of this article. 
(E)  If a nonconforming sign structure or cabinet is abandoned or discontinued for a continuous period of 365 days or more, it must be removed and any subsequent sign must conform to all of the sign regulations of this article. 
(F)  These provisions do not apply to signs granted variations by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.07. - General provisions. 
(A)  Wall signs : 
(1)  Number : Only one wall identification sign shall be permitted for each business and shall be oriented to the street frontage except as follows: 
(a)  On corner street frontages, two signs, one facing each street, shall be permitted. Such signs may have a total area equal to the permitted gross surface area for each individual frontage. 
(b)  When a business or building has a primary entrance oriented to an internal parking lot and not a primary street frontage, frontage(s) to the parking lot shall determine permitted signage. 
(c)  If the portion of the building that faces the street is considered rear of the building, yet has been architecturally designed with the same material integrity of the front facade, then one additional sign facing the street frontage is permitted; however, the frontage does not contribute to the allowable gross surface area for total signage. 
(2)  All new wall signs shall be individual letter, either mounted independently on the wall or attached to a typical raceway; new cabinet or box type signs are prohibited. 
(B)  Ground signs : 
(1)  Number : Only one ground sign shall be permitted for each lot and shall be oriented to the street frontage, except as follows: 
(a)  On corner street frontages, two signs, one facing each street, shall be permitted when access exists on each street frontage. Signs shall be oriented to each frontage access. 
(b)  Shopping centers and multi-tenant developments (except on any property zoned O/R Office/Research District) shall be permitted one sign per street frontage. Any subdivided outlots shall be permitted one ground sign each. 
(c)  For any buildings or multi-tenant developments located in the O/R Office/Research District, in addition to the permitted one sign per street frontage, as provided in section 11.07(B)(1)(b) above, freestanding wayfinding signs are permitted as follows: 
Freestanding wayfinding sign: A freestanding wayfinding sign and associated structure is freestanding in nature and seeks to direct traffic to specific tenants within the development. Freestanding wayfinding signs are permitted in the O/R Office/Research District in addition to all other allowable signage, with the approval of a sign permit and subject to the following conditions: 
i.  Number permitted: One sign permitted per each entrance into the property/development with a maximum of four total for the entire property. 
ii.  Maximum size and height: 35 square feet per side and 70 square feet in total sign face area and ten feet in height. 
iii.  Setback: Such signs shall not obstruct or impede traffic flow and shall not be placed in any engineered sight or corner vision triangles for public road or private drives or lanes. A minimum setback of 25 feet is required from all property lines. 
iv.  Graphics: Graphics are limited to tenant names and logos, addresses, directional symbols and architectural elements associated with the development. 
(2)  Size : The calculated sign area for a ground sign shall be a portion of the permitted gross surface area of all signage as determined by the frontage, and may account for up to 50 percent of overall allowed signage, except as follows: 
(a)  When a corner lot elects to install only one ground sign when two ground signs are permitted, the cumulative frontage to each street may be used for calculations; however signage may only account for up to 35 percent of overall allowed signage. 
(b)  Shopping centers and multi-tenant developments shall be permitted a maximum gross surface area equal to 50 percent of the lot frontage dimension to a maximum of 200 square feet per ground sign. 
(3)  All ground signs shall be constructed with a base at least 50 percent of the overall sign width up to eight feet in height, or 75 percent when permitted to be taller; pole signs are prohibited. 
(4)  No ground sign shall be placed nearer than ten feet to any other sign, nor so placed as to obscure the view from the public right-of-way of any other sign on adjacent property. 
(5)  Signs shall not obstruct or impede traffic flow, and shall not be placed in any engineered sight or corner vision triangles for public roadways. 
(6)  Ground signs shall prominently display the building addresses (with numerals) that are a minimum height of six inches. 
(7)  All newly constructed ground signs require a landscape plan with permit application and shall be landscaped to the standards below: 
(a)  Sign shall have a minimum landscaped area of five feet around the base of the sign. 
(b)  Seventy-five percent of the landscape bed shall be planted with vegetation. 
(c)  Vegetation shall include shrubs, ornamental grasses and perennials and shall have year-round interest. 
(d)  Plantings shall be large enough to cover the base of the sign but should never reach a mature height that will obscure the sign face. 
(e)  Any ground sign proposed in existing parking areas shall be surrounded by a masonry barrier. 
(f)  All plantings shall be continuously maintained and replaced as necessary. 
(8)  A portion of any ground sign may be constructed as an electronic message board subject to section 11.07(D)(8). 
(C)  Temporary signs : 
(1)  In nonresidential districts, banners advertising or directing attention to a sale, promotion, or other special event conducted by or on behalf of an on-premises business, business commodity, business service or for-profit entertainment shall be permitted with a permit only as follows: 
(a)  One temporary sign permitted per business per display period. 
(b)  The maximum display period for a permit shall be 30 days. 
(c)  Permits for temporary signs shall be issued for a maximum of 60 days each calendar year per business, and any display of a temporary sign without a permit shall count towards the maximum number of days for the business. 
(d)  Sign may be attached to the leased frontage of a building, or as an anchored freestanding sign. 
(e)  When freestanding, the sign shall be a minimum of five feet from property lines, 15 feet from any vehicular private drives or entries, shall not obstruct or impede traffic flow, and shall not be placed in any engineered sight or corner vision triangles for public roadways. 
(f)  No temporary sign shall be used concurrently with an sandwich board sign for the same business. 
(g)  For multi-tenant properties, only one freestanding sign is permitted per street frontage at any time. 
(h)  Maximum size : 32 square feet. 
(i)  Maximum height : Eight feet, only applicable to freestanding temporary signs. 
(2)  Special events banners or posters publicizing approved special events sponsored in whole or in part by the village located in, on or over the public right-of-way. Such signage shall require the approval of the board of trustees as part of the special event permit approval and shall be subject to time, place and size restrictions imposed by the village board. 
(D)  Other sign types, restrictions and prohibitions : 
(1)  For the purposes of calculating allowable signage based on frontage, frontage is defined as the portion of a building designed to face to a street or parking lot and typically has customer entry, transparent windows, and is constructed to a higher standard of detail than non-frontages. When a building has multiple frontages, frontage containing building service areas will not contribute to calculated signage allowances. A double-faced sign shall count as a single sign. 
(2)  No sign or other advertising structure as regulated by this ordinance shall be erected at the intersection of any streets in such a manner as to obstruct free and clear vision; or at any location where, by reason of the position, shape or color, it may interfere with, obstruct the view of, or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device; or which makes use of the words "stop," "look," "drive-in," "danger," or any other word, phrase, symbol or character in such manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to display upon any sign or other advertising structure any matter in writing or in picture which, considered as a whole, predominantly appeals to prurient interest. 
(4)  An angular sign shall mean a sign which is mounted to a building frontage in such a manner that the sign face is not parallel to the face of the building, but forms a triangle with the apex of the triangle a maximum of 18 inches from the face of the building. The lowest point of such sign shall be a minimum of eight feet above the ground. 
(5)  Open sales lots . 
(a)  For properties defined as open sales lots, the maximum gross surface area of permitted signs shall not be calculated as a ratio of building facade. Open sales lots shall be permitted signs with a maximum gross surface area equal to 50 percent of the lot frontage dimension. 
(b)  Gasoline service stations may be considered as having an open sales lot use, and, in addition to the maximum number of signs otherwise allowed by this article, may locate or install one additional canopy sign in addition to each permitted wall sign; however, all signage must comply with the allowable gross surface area for total signage and cannot front towards a residential district. 
(c)  Automobile dealerships may be considered as having an open sales lot use, and, in addition to the maximum number of signs otherwise allowed by this article, may locate or install one additional wall sign in addition to each permitted wall sign; however, all signage must comply with the allowable gross surface area. 
(6)  Projecting signs. A projecting sign is a sign and associated structure which extends out from a building facade or wall in a perpendicular manner. Projecting signs shall be permitted in the B-1 District in addition to all other allowable signage, with a permit only as follows: 
(a)  Number permitted : One sign permitted per each first floor business for each facade with street frontage (public or private) or adjacent to an off-street parking area where customer access is also available. When a business occupies a corner frontage and is permitted two signs, the business may elect for a single corner blade sign installed at 45 degrees at the corner. 
(b)  Maximum size: Six square feet per side, or ten square feet for a corner sign. The width, height and area of a blade sign shall be measured by taking the smallest rectangle that encloses the entire sign face. Sign brackets and light fixtures are excluded from the determination of the blade sign width, height, and area. 
(c)  Minimum clearance : A minimum clearance of eight feet measured from the bottom of the sign to the sidewalk or grade above which the sign extends. Minimum clearance includes any sign structure or illumination. 
(d)  Maximum overall height : Sign shall not be placed higher than 15 feet above grade, and sign structure and light fixtures shall not extend higher than 18 feet above grade. No portion of the sign, structure or lighting shall exceed the height of the building or architectural first-floor facade. Sign shall not obstruct windows or accessways. 
(e)  Maximum projection : Three feet from facade. 
(f)  Illumination : External illumination, internally illuminated individual channel letter signage, and bare bulb signage is permitted. Internally illuminated box signs shall only be permitted when accessory to a primary sign and letters/sign copy must be dimensional. Sign lighting shall be designed to prevent light spillage and glare onto any adjacent residentially zoned property or public right-of-way. External light fixtures shall not extend beyond two feet from the centerline of the sign. 
(g)  Maintenance : All signage, structure and lighting must be properly maintained in accordance with section 11.04. 
(h)  License agreements : If the sign encroaches over public property or right-of-way, a license agreement must be executed between the village and property and/or business owners. Such agreement requires the owner to specifically acknowledge responsibility for any injury or property damage caused by the sign encroachment, agrees to indemnify the village, and provide proof of insurance. The economic development director is authorized to execute all such agreements on behalf of the village, utilizing a form agreement prepared by the village attorney. 
(7)  Illumination : Where reflecting, radiating or other illumination of signs is permitted: 
(a)  Light shall not be projected toward or onto properties located in a residence district. 
(b)  Any such illumination in the line of vision of approaching vehicular traffic shall not resemble any authorized traffic sign. 
(c)  No flashing or blinking, incandescent or stroboscopic lights shall be permitted. 
(d)  Gooseneck reflectors and lights may be permitted on permanent signs; provided, however, that any such reflectors or lights shall be installed in such a manner that the direct rays of light are concentrated on the sign and are shielded or otherwise constructed so as to avoid any glare upon streets or adjacent properties. 
(8)  Electronic message board signs. The use of electronic message board signs are subject to the following regulations and restrictions, in addition to the other applicable regulations and restrictions contained in this article, regardless of the content of the messages on said signs: 
(a)  Electronic message board signs are permitted in the B-2, B-3, C-1, O/R, and O/R-1, and M districts. Electronic message board signs are allowable in residential districts for educational, governmental and religious uses only, and only after issuance of a special use permit pursuant to the procedures set forth in article XIII, section 13.09 of this appendix. Electronic message board sign messages for educational, governmental and religious uses may advertise for the on-site use and may advertise for community events within the village. 
(b)  The electronic message board component of a sign shall comprise no more than 40 percent of a ground sign's total allowable sign face area, or 75 percent if a ground sign in a monument style (not a pole sign). 
(c)  An electronic message board sign must be accessory to the primary ground sign for the premises. The electronic message board sign must be mounted or located below the primary business/location identification area. 
(d)  Restrictions on display of messages : 
i.  Electronic message board signs shall not contain messages with flashing, animation, illusion of movement or similar displays. 
ii.  Live or pre-recorded video is prohibited. 
iii.  Messages must instantaneously change; no transitions. 
iv.  Messages cannot change more than once every five seconds. 
v.  The maximum light intensity regulations of this article shall be met. 
vi.  Text and numeral displays shall appear with a solid black background. 
vii.  The sign module must include dimmer controls which can be adjusted to meet village light emission standards. Proof of such sign module controls must be presented at the time of permit application. 
viii.  Messages shall only direct attention to a business, commodity, service or entertainment conducted, sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located. 
(9)  No sign, including temporary signs, shall be located, erected, altered or maintained: 
(a)  On the roof of a building. 
(b)  Projecting above the building wall unless designed as an architectural element such as a marquee. 
(c)  So as to obstruct any fire escape, or any window or door or opening used as a means of egress, or for firefighting purposes, or so as to prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof. No sign shall be attached in any form, shape or manner to a fire escape or be so placed as to interfere with any opening required by law for ventilation. 
(d)  In, on or above any street, alley, park, parkway, sidewalk or other public place, except as permitted under sections 11.07(C)(2), 11.07(D)(6) and 11.11 (B). 
(e)  On fences, except as permitted in section 11.11(D)(3). 
(f)  On utility poles, street lights, electric traffic signals or other public poles or posts. 
(g)  Off-premises commercial advertising signs, which are those signs that direct attention to a business, commodity, service or entertainment conducted, sold or offered elsewhere than upon the premises where such sign is located. This does not include advertising signs as defined and permitted in section 11.10. 
(h)  Projecting signs which are those signs which are mounted upon a building and erected perpendicular to the facade of said building, except as permitted under section 11.07(D)(6). 
(i)  Terminated business or use signs as referenced in section 11.05. 
(j)  Wind driven devices, any signage with flashing, blinking or movement, balloon or inflatable devices. 
(k)  Temporary signs attached to an automobile, truck or motor vehicle of any kind. 
(l)  In any location in violation of the village of Westmont zoning ordinance or as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017; Ord. No. 17-190, § 2, 12-21-2017; Ord. No. 19-026, § 2, 2-28-2019)  
Sec. 11.08. - Construction standards. 
(A)  All signs and other advertising structures shall be designed and constructed as required in the current adopted building codes under section 18-62 and other ordinances of the village of Westmont. 
(B)  Signs shall not be painted on the wall of a building or adhered to the wall of a building with glue or mastic. In no case shall any wall sign be secured with wire, strips of wood or nails. 
(C)  All new ground signs structures shall be properly engineered. No building permit shall be granted or plans approved for any new ground sign structure unless such plans are prepared by an Illinois licensed architect or structural engineer. This requirement may be waived, on a case by case basis, at the discretion of the economic development director. 
(D)  The lettering or advertising designs to be illuminated may be composed of glass or other transparent or semitransparent material. Any glass forming a part of any sign shall be safety glass or plate glass at least one-fourth inch thick; and in case any single piece or pane of glass has an area exceeding three square feet, it shall be wired glass. 
(E)  Any movable part of a sign such as the cover of a service opening shall be securely fastened by chains or hinges. 
(F)  Signs shall be constructed with rigid materials. Vinyl and fabric signs shall be considered temporary signs, and shall not be permitted as permanent signs. 
(G)  Every sign hereafter erected shall have the date of installation, the permit number and the voltage of any electrical apparatus used in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.09. - Applicability of sign regulations to zoning districts. 
Signs are a permitted use in every zoning district of the village of Westmont subject to erection, construction, display, maintenance, and other regulations in conformance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.10. - Area, display and illumination of signs. 
Signs which are permitted in any zoning district shall be in accordance with the standards listed in the following chart:
