(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017)  
Sec. 11.11. - Exemptions. 
The provisions and regulations of this article shall not apply to the following signs; provided, however, said signs shall be subject to the provisions of sections 11.04, 11.05, and 11.07(D)(2), (3) and (9): 
(A)  Address numbers, non-illuminated or directly illuminated, located on the structure. 
(B)  Signs erected by a governmental body, or under the direction of a governmental body, such as traffic signs, railroad crossing signs, safety signs and signs identifying public and municipal facilities, and signs erected by not-for-profit organizations located within the village and which are funded in whole or in part by the village, and which promote such organizations. For such not-for-profit organization signs, the advance approval of the village board is required as to the time, location and size of such signage. 
(C)  Exempt signs on properties being used for residential purposes (excluding multiple-family), regardless of zoning: 
(1)  Flags displaying only non-commercial speech, images or messages. 
(2)  Real estate signs not exceeding nine square feet in area nor six feet in height which advertise the sale or lease of the premises upon which said signs are located only. One sign per street frontage shall be permitted. 
(3)  Temporary construction or contractor yard signs: No more than one such sign, not to exceed six square feet in area nor six feet in height, which shall be removed within 30 days after construction or remodeling is complete. 
(4)  In addition to the signs specifically allowed in this section, each property is allowed temporary non-commercial, non-illuminated wall and ground mounted signs subject to the following requirements: 
(a)  Sign area per individual sign shall be a maximum of four feet in area. 
(b)  Sign height shall be a maximum of five feet including support structure. 
(D)  Exempt signs on properties being used for commercial purposes (including multiple-family residential), regardless of zoning: 
(1)  Flags displaying only non-commercial speech, images or messages. 
(2)  Real estate signs not exceeding 32 square feet in area nor eight feet in height which advertise the sale or lease of the premises upon which said signs are located only. One sign per street frontage shall be permitted. 
(3)  Temporary construction signs for work actively under construction, not to exceed 32 square feet in area per sign. Such signs shall be located on the property under construction, including on any construction fencing and shall be removed within three days after construction or remodeling is complete. 
(4)  Entry, exit or other on-premises traffic direction signs provided such signs do not exceed five square feet per side (nine square feet per side in the O/R Office/Research District), ten square feet in total sign face area (18 square feet in total sign face area in the O/R Office/Research District) and three feet in height (six feet in height in the O/R Office/Research District). 
(5)  Bulletin boards not to exceed 32 square feet in area for public, charitable or religious institutions when located on the premises of such institutions. 
(6)  Signs of a non-advertising nature and which are related to a business (i.e., hours of operation, help wanted, open/closed, and similar signs), not to exceed two signs per business and limited to four square feet per sign. 
(7)  Memorial signs or tablets, names of buildings and date of erection when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other incombustible materials. 
(8)  Professional nameplates (wall-mounted) or name and address plates (wall-mounted) which give only the name and address of the business resident of the building and which is not more than one square foot in sign area. 
(9)  On-premises signs denoting sections of a building such as lavatory facilities and public telephone areas, not to exceed two square feet in area per side and bearing no commercial advertising, logos or establishment name. 
(10)  Window signs of paper or similar materials, not to exceed 40 percent of the total window area. Window signage shall not prohibit transparency and shall not create a safety hazard to customers, employees, pedestrians and traffic. Signs allowed by subsection (6) of this section are exempt from these window sign regulations. 
(11)  Menu boards for restaurants with drive-through lanes, provided there are no more than two menu boards per property, provided the maximum allowable surface area (measured as total surface area on one side) for the menu boards combined on the property shall be no more than 50 square feet, and provided that the menu boards do not serve as an additional advertising mechanism to attract further customers from the street. 
(12)  Restaurant menu displays shall not exceed four square feet in area, and shall be enclosed in a glass or plexi-glass frame. One such sign shall be permitted per restaurant. 
(13)  Pennants or logo flags may be placed on private light poles in nonresidential districts; only one pennant shall be permitted on each pole and may not exceed four square feet. Must be attached with a rigid frame that does not allow for wind movement. 
(14)  In addition to the signs specifically allowed in this section, each property is allowed temporary non-commercial, non-illuminated wall and ground mounted signs subject to the following requirements: 
(a)  Sign area per individual sign shall be a maximum of 12 square feet. 
(b)  Sign height shall be a maximum of five feet, including any support structure (e.g., sign, frame, building). 
(c)  Sign location shall be on privately owned property and shall not be placed in any engineered sight or corner vision triangles for public roadways. 
(E)  Sandwich board signs, also known as A-frame signs, are permitted and regulated within the zoning districts as defined below. 
(1)  Permitted districts : B-1, B-2, B-3, C-1, R-4, R-5, and R-6 General Provisions 
(a)  Signs shall not exceed eight square feet per side and shall not exceed four feet in height. 
(b)  Signs shall be removed and stored indoors when the establishment is not open for business. 
(c)  Signs must be professionally made and maintained in good condition. 
(d)  Signs shall be of an A-frame design and properly weighted so as not to create a windblown hazard. 
(e)  Signs shall not have any nails, tacks, wires or sharp metal edges protruding therefrom. 
(f)  Signs must be located on the ground and not be attached to any structure or person. 
(g)  One sign permitted per business, subject to location and separation distance or additional allowances specific to the districts listed below. 
(h)  Signs shall not be used in conjunction with any other temporary signage for a single business. 
(i)  Signs shall be a minimum of 15 feet from any vehicular private drives or entries, shall not obstruct or impede traffic flow, and shall not be placed in any engineered sight or corner vision triangles for public roadways. 
(j)  A minimum separation distance of 25 feet between any other commercial signage shall be maintained, including freestanding temporary signs. 
(k)  Signs shall be permitted on private sidewalks (except in the B-1 District permitted on both public and private sidewalks), provided that the signs must be located entirely or partially on the sidewalk in front of the business, allowing for at least five feet of continuous sidewalk clearance. 
(l)  Signs are prohibited from any parking lots, parking spaces or vehicular drives. 
(2)  Districts : B-1 Additional Requirements 
(a)  Any signs encroaching on public right-of-way must comply with the village's indemnity policy as set forth in section 11.07(D)(6)(h). 
(3)  Districts : B-2, B-3 and C-1 Additional Requirements 
(a)  Signs shall be located on private property a minimum of five feet from property lines. 
(b)  Individual businesses on single-user corner lots are permitted one sign per frontage. 
(4)  Districts : R-4, R-5 and R-6 Additional Requirements 
(a)  Permitted for multiple-family developments of at least 50 dwelling units. 
(b)  Signs shall be located on private property a minimum of five feet from property lines. 
(c)  One sign is permitted on each street frontage for the development. 
(Ord. No. 17-156, § 2, 10-26-2017; Ord. No. 19-026, § 3, 2-28-2019)  
ARTICLE XII. - NONCONFORMING STRUCTURES AND USES 
 
Sec. 12.01. - Purpose. 
The regulations of this article are intended to provide controls over nonconforming structures and uses and to specify those circumstances and conditions under which certain structures and uses which are deemed incompatible with the character of adjacent property in the district in which they are located and with that of the village as a whole shall be gradually eliminated in accordance with the authority vested in it by the Illinois Compiled Statutes.  
Sec. 12.02. - Authority to continue nonconforming structures and uses. 
Following the effective date of this ordinance, any nonconforming structure or use may be continued subject to the following regulations: 
(A)  Repairs and alterations. Normal repairs and improvements may be made to a nonconforming structure, provided that no structural alterations shall be made in or to such structure, all or substantially all of which is designed and intended for a use not permitted in the district in which it is located, except those required by law or to make the structure and use thereof conform to the regulations of the district in which it is located. The extent of normal repairs and improvements shall be determined by the building review committee. 
(B)  Enlargement of nonconforming structures. 
(1)  A nonconforming structure shall not be enlarged in any manner or undergo any structural alteration unless to make it a conforming structure. 
(2)  A structure which is nonconforming only as to bulk may be enlarged for a use permitted in the district, provided such enlargement conforms to the bulk regulations of the district in which it is located and, further, that the enlargement in no way increases the existing nonconformity. 
(C)  Moving. No structure shall be moved, in whole or in part, to any other location unless every portion of such structure and the use thereof is designed and used or intended for a use permitted in the district to which it is moved, and further, that such structure shall be in conformance with the other regulations of such district. 
(D)  Restoration of damaged nonconforming structures. A nonconforming structure which is destroyed or damaged by fire, other casualty, act of God or a public enemy, to the extent of 50 percent or more of its market value at the date that the damage was sustained, shall thereafter conform with all regulations of the zoning district in which it is located, except that a nonconforming structure which met the minimum yard requirements in effect prior to the amendment to the zoning ordinance passed and approved on January 19, 1998, shall not be required to conform to the minimum yard requirements established by such amendment, but shall be required to conform with all other regulations of such districts as of the date permit is issued to rebuild such structure. In the event such damage or destruction is less than 50 percent of its market value, no repairs or restoration shall be made unless a building permit is secured and reconstruction is started within 90 days from the date of the partial destruction and is diligently prosecuted to completion. Determination of the market value and the cost of restoration shall be made by the building review committee. 
(E)  Discontinuation of use of nonconforming structures. Where the use of a nonconforming structure has ceased by discontinuance or abandonment on the effective date of this comprehensive amendment, or thereafter is abandoned and remains unoccupied or is not used for a continuous period of three months, the structure shall not be thereafter occupied by a nonconforming use and the lot shall not thereafter be improved except by a conforming structure. 
(F)  Nonconforming use of conforming structures. The existing nonconforming use of a part or all of a conforming structure may be continued subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The nonconforming use of a part of a conforming structure shall not be expanded or extended into any other portion of such structure; or the use of such structure, or part thereof, shall not be changed to any other nonconforming use. 
(2)  If a nonconforming use of such a structure is discontinued or abandoned for a period of three months, it shall not be renewed; and any subsequent use of such structure shall conform to the use regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(G)  Nonconforming use of land. 
(1)  Nonconforming use of land without a building. The nonconforming use of land, not involving a principal building, shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(a)  Such nonconforming use of land shall not be expanded or extended at any time following the effective date of this comprehensive amendment. 
(b)  If such nonconforming use of land is discontinued for a period of 90 consecutive days, it shall not thereafter be renewed, and any subsequent use of such land shall be by a conforming use. 
(c)  A nonconforming use of land shall not be changed to another nonconforming use. 
(d)  The outdoor or exposed storage of materials in yards within nonresidential districts shall be discontinued within five years of the effective date of this comprehensive amendment, and within one year such exposure shall be eliminated by a solid wall or fence. Where such nonconforming use is located in a residence district, it shall be discontinued within one year. 
(2)  Nonconforming use of land accessory to a structure or building. The nonconforming use of land where accessory to a building or structure shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(a)  Where the nonconforming use of land is accessory to the nonconforming use of a structure, it shall be discontinued on the same date on which the nonconforming use of the structure is discontinued, except such outdoor use of land shall be effectively screened by a solid wall or fence within one year. 
(b)  Where the nonconforming use of land is accessory to a conforming structure, such use may be continued as long as the use of the structure or building remains a conforming use, except such outdoor use of land shall be effectively screened by a solid wall or fence within three years. 
(H)  Condemnation of nonconforming structures. The village, at any time, and from time to time by resolution or by ordinance duly enacted, may acquire by purchase, condemnation or otherwise, any nonconforming structure and all land which is necessary or appropriate for the rehabilitation or redevelopment of the area and after such acquisition the village may: 
(1)  Remove or demolish all such nonconforming structures so acquired; and/or 
(2)  Hold and use any remaining property for public purposes; and/or 
(3)  Sell, lease or exchange such property as is not required for public purposes, subject to the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
No such acquisition shall be made until such time as the planning and zoning commission, at the request of the board of trustees or upon its own initiative, has made a study of the area within which such nonconforming structure is located and has filed a written report on such study with the board of trustees. 
(I)  Nonconforming due to amendments. The foregoing provisions of this article shall apply to structures and uses hereafter becoming nonconforming as a result of future reclassification of districts or of other amendments to this comprehensive amendment. Provisions for the discontinuance of land uses as stipulated in this article shall commence on the effective date of the zoning district map amendment. 
(J)  Nonconforming nursing homes. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this article XII, any nursing home which is a legal nonconforming use in the B-2 general business district may enlarge its structure by not more than 1,200 sq. ft., provided the enlarged structure is used for nursing home and related uses, and provided that all other ordinances and codes of the village are met. 
(Ord. No. 98-02, § 8, 1-19-1998; Ord. No. 09-95, § 1, 7-6-2009)  
ARTICLE XIII. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 13.01. - Organization. 
The administration of this comprehensive amendment is hereby vested in: 
(A)  Community development director. 
(B)  Planning and zoning commission. 
(C)  [Reserved.] 
(D)  Board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019)  
Sec. 13.02. - Office of the community development director. 
The community development director shall enforce this comprehensive amendment and in furtherance of his authority shall: 
(A)  Determine conformance of applications for zoning certificates with regulations of this comprehensive amendment. 
(B)  Issue all zoning certificates and zoning verification letters, following approval as required in this comprehensive amendment, and maintain records thereof. 
(C)  Issue all certificates of occupancy and maintain records thereof. 
(D)  Conduct inspections of structures and uses of land as required. 
(E)  Maintain permanent and current records of the administration and enforcement of this comprehensive amendment, including but not limited to applications, processing and decisions for all amendments, special uses and special uses granted by the board of trustees, variations and appeals; and designate on the zoning district map each amendment and special use. 
(F)  Decide or make recommendations on all other matters under this comprehensive amendment upon which the community development director is required to act. 
(G)  Initiate, direct and review, from time to time, a study of the provisions of this comprehensive amendment, and make reports of his recommendations to the planning and zoning commission not less frequently than once a year. 
(H)  Upon the approval of the board of trustees being first obtained, issue permits regulating the erection and use of temporary buildings for specific periods of time for purposes such as community, religious, eleemosynary, education, amusement, recreation and commercial; provided, however, that uses thereof are in conformance with all other ordinances and codes of the village. 
(I)  Provide and maintain public information facilities relative to all matters pertaining to this comprehensive amendment. 
(J)  Collect and administer zoning escrow deposits as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, 1-16-1984; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, adopted March 23, 2019, amended § 13.02 and in doing so changed the title of said section from "Office of economic development director" to "Office of the community development director," as set out herein.  
Sec. 13.03. - Zoning certificates. 
(A)  No building permit or license pertaining to the use of structures or land shall be issued by any officer or employee of the village, unless the application for such permit has been examined by the community development director and has affixed to it a certificate of the community development director that the proposed structure and uses comply with all of the provisions of this comprehensive amendment, and any certificate issued in conflict with the provisions of this comprehensive amendment shall be null and void. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful to start the construction of a new building, structure or sign, or the enlargement or any alteration or removal of a building or structure which involves a change in use, without having received a zoning certificate. Construction or development authorized by a permit shall be started within a period of six months and shall proceed with reasonable continuity until completion, the permit otherwise becoming invalid. 
(C)  All applications for zoning certificates shall be accompanied by a current registered survey of the lot in duplicate, drawn to scale, showing the shape, area and dimensions of the lot to be built upon, the exact size and location on the lot of the existing buildings and accessory buildings, and the lines within which the new structures shall be erected, prepared by a registered surveyor. The plans shall show existing and intended use of each structure, the number of dwelling units or lodging rooms a building is designed to accommodate, location of driveways, and location and number of off-street parking and off-street loading spaces, and such other information with regard to the lot and neighboring lots and performance standards that shall be necessary to determine and provide for the enforcement of this comprehensive amendment. One copy of such plans shall be returned to the owner when such plans have been approved by the community development director. The lot and location of the building thereon shall be staked out on the ground before construction is started. 
(Ord. No. 80-16, 4-21-1980; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019)  
Sec. 13.04. - Zoning verification letters. 
Any person may request a zoning verification letter from the community development director pertaining to property located within the village. A zoning verification letter provides verification of zoning-related information for a particular property, including but not limited to, the zoning classification of the property, whether existing improvements comply with the bulk and development standards of the underlying zoning district, whether existing off-street parking meets the minimum parking requirements, whether the existing use is legal and conforming, and whether signs on the property are legal and conforming. The person requesting the zoning verification letter shall pay the fee set forth in this article in advance. 
(Ord. No. 85-15, 2-4-1985; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, adopted March 23, 2019, amended § 13.04 and in doing so changed the title of said section from "Filing for zoning certificates" to "Zoning verification letters," as set out herein.  
Sec. 13.05. - Certificate of occupancy. 
(A)  No land shall be occupied or used in a manner different than that existing on the date of the passage of this comprehensive amendment, and no structure hereafter erected or altered shall be occupied or used in whole or in part for any purpose whatsoever until a certificate of occupancy shall have been issued by the community development director stating that the structure or land improvement complies with all its plans and all the building and health laws and with the provisions of this comprehensive amendment. No change of use shall be made in any structure or land improvement or part thereof, now or hereafter erected or altered, without an occupancy permit having been issued by the community development director, and no permit shall be issued to make such change unless it is in conformity with the provisions of this comprehensive amendment and amendments thereto. Nothing in this section shall prevent the continuance of the present occupancy or use of any existing structure or land improvement, except as may be necessary for the safety of life and property. 
(B)  No certificate of occupancy permit for a change of use in an existing structure or land improvement shall be issued until the premises have been inspected and certified by the economic development director to be in compliance with applicable requirements for the zoning district in which it is located. 
(C)  Application for a certificate of occupancy shall be made and shall be issued within ten days after the erection or alteration of the structure has been completed. A record of all certificates of occupancy shall be kept on file in the office of the community development director, and copies shall be furnished on request to any person having proprietary or tenancy interest in the land or structure affected. 
(D)  Pending the issuance of a regular certificate of occupancy, a temporary permit may be issued to be valid for a period of no more than 60 days during months of the year permitting exterior construction and not more than 180 days during other times of the year. Application for a temporary permit shall be accompanied with a statement covering the items of work to be completed and the reasons the temporary permit is requested. 
(Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019)  
Sec. 13.06. - Zoning escrow deposits. 
Any zoning applicant who submits a zoning application that requires the review of the planning and zoning commission shall, in addition to meeting all other zoning application requirements, fund an escrow account with the village to secure and cover reimbursement to the village for the reasonable fees of third party consultants to the village who provide professional consulting services on any matter pertaining to the applicant's zoning application. The zoning applicant shall complete a development escrow agreement on such form as proscribed by the community development director. The community development director shall reasonably determine the amount of the escrow deposit required based on the complexity of the proposed development and the nature and extent of consulting services anticipated. If the escrow deposit is depleted and additional consultant reviews are required, the zoning applicant shall replenish the escrow account in such amount as reasonably determined by the community development director before further consultant reviews are performed. The community development director shall promptly refund to the zoning applicant any deposit remaining in an escrow account after the completion of all consultant reviews. 
(Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019)  
Sec. 13.07. - Variations. 
(A)  Authority. The planning and zoning commission shall recommend all applications for variations of the provisions of this comprehensive amendment after a public hearing conducted by the planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission shall recommend a variation only after they have made findings of fact specifying the reason or reasons which justify the variation. Such findings shall be based upon the standards prescribed in subsection 13.07(D) of this article. 
(B)  Initiation. An application for a variation may be made by any person, firm or corporation having a freehold interest, a possessory interest entitled to exclusive possession, a contractual interest which may become a freehold interest, an option to purchase, or any exclusive possessory interest applicable to the land or land and improvements described in the application for a variation. 
(C)  Application for variation and notice of hearing. An application for a variation shall be filed with the community development department, on forms prescribed by the village, along with all required fees and required supporting documentation. A copy of such application shall thereafter be forwarded by the community development department to the planning and zoning commission with a request to hold a public hearing and submit to the board of trustees a report of its findings and recommendations. Such public hearing shall be held upon public notice as required by the Illinois Compiled Statutes. Variations granted shall be exercised within a period of 12 months after the date of the variation or shall otherwise become invalid. Any new construction or structural alterations performed in furtherance of the variance shall be diligently pursued to completion, or the board of trustees may revoke the variance. 
(D)  Standards for variations. 
(1)  The planning and zoning commission shall not recommend a variation to the regulations of this comprehensive amendment as authorized herein unless it shall have made findings of fact based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that: 
(a)  The property in question cannot yield a reasonable return if permitted to be used only under the conditions allowed by the regulations in the district in which it is located; 
(b)  The plight of the owner is due to unique circumstances; and 
(c)  The variation, if granted, will not alter the essential character of the locality. 
(2)  For the purpose of implementing the above rules, the planning and zoning commission shall also, in making its recommendations whether there are practical difficulties or particular hardships, take into consideration the extent to which the following facts, favorable to the applicant, have been established by the evidence: 
(a)  The particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical features of the specific property involved would result in a particular hardship upon the owner, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of the regulations were carried out. 
(b)  The conditions upon which the petition for variation is based would not be applicable, generally, to other property within the same zoning classification. 
(c)  The purpose of the variation is not based exclusively upon a desire to make more money out of the property. 
(d)  The alleged difficulty or hardship has not been created by the owner of the property. 
(e)  The granting of the variation will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property or improvements in the neighborhood in which the property is located. 
(f)  The proposed variation will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property, or substantially increase the congestion in the public streets, or increase the danger of fire, or endanger the public safety, or substantially diminish or impair the property values within the neighborhood. 
(3)  The planning and zoning commission may recommend such conditions and restrictions upon the premises benefited by a variation as may be necessary to comply with the standards set forth in this subsection to reduce or minimize the injurious effect of such variation upon other property in the neighborhood, and better to carry out the general intent of this comprehensive amendment. 
(E)  Decisions. The board of trustees, upon report of the planning and zoning commission without further public hearing, may grant or deny any proposed variation in accordance with Illinois Statutes and the Westmont Village Code, or may refer it back to the planning and zoning commission for further consideration. The board of trustees may by ordinance impose special conditions upon variance approval, designed to protect the public health, safety and welfare and designed to ensure compliance with the variance standards listed herein. A violation of any such variance conditions shall constitute a violation of this zoning ordinance and shall constitute grounds for revocation of the variance. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 3, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 10-201, § 2, 12-6-2010; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019)  
Sec. 13.08. - Appeals. 
An appeal to the planning and zoning commission may be made by any person, firm or corporation, or by any office, department, board, or bureau aggrieved by a decision of the community development director under this comprehensive amendment in accordance with Illinois Statutes, and the following: 
(A)  An application for an appeal shall be filed with the village clerk within 20 days of the date of the action from which the appeal is being filed, and thereafter the village clerk shall forward such application to the planning and zoning commission for processing. 
(B)  An appeal stays all the proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the community development director from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the planning and zoning commission, after the notice of appeal has been filed with him, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property in which case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by the planning and zoning commission or by a circuit court on application, on notice to the economic development director from whom the appeal is taken, and on due cause shown. 
(C)  The planning and zoning commission shall fix a reasonable time, not to exceed 90 days, for the hearing of the appeal and give due notice thereof to the parties and decide the same within a reasonable time. The planning and zoning commission may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determinations as in its opinion ought to be made on the premises and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal was taken. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 3, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019)  
Sec. 13.09. - Special uses. 
(A)  Purpose. The formulation and enactment of a comprehensive zoning ordinance is based on the division of the entire village into districts in each of which are permitted specified uses that are mutually compatible. In addition to such permitted compatible uses, however, it is recognized that there are other uses which it may be necessary or desirable to allow in a given district but which may have a unique, special or unusual impact on the use and enjoyment of neighboring property and upon public facilities and therefore need to be carefully regulated with respect to location or operation for the protection of the community. Such uses are classified in this comprehensive amendment as special uses and fall into two categories: 
(1)  Uses either municipally operated or operated by publicly regulated utilities, or uses traditionally affected by public interest. 
(2)  Uses entirely private in character which, on account of their peculiar locational need, the nature of the service they offer to the public and their possible damaging influence on the neighborhood, may have to be established in a district or districts in which they cannot reasonably be allowed as an unrestricted permitted use under the regulations of this comprehensive amendment. 
(B)  Initiation. Special uses may be proposed by any person, firm or corporation having a freehold interest, a possessory interest entitled to exclusive possession, a contractual interest which may become a freehold interest, an option to purchase, or any exclusive possessory interest which is specifically enforceable on the land which is described in the application for a special use. 
(C)  Processing. 
(1)  An application for a special use shall be filed with the community development department, on forms prescribed by the village, along with all required fees and required supporting documentation. If not otherwise required by this zoning ordinance, the community development department may require an applicant to submit a site plan for approval in conjunction with the special use request. 
(2)  A copy of such application shall thereafter be forwarded by the community development department to the planning and zoning commission with a request to hold a public hearing and submit to the board of trustees a report of its findings and recommendations. Such public hearing shall be held upon public notice as required by the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(3)  After denial of a special use request by the village board, the same applicant may not apply for the same or substantially similar special use for the property in question until at least one year have [has] elapsed since the date of the denial. 
(D)  Standards. A proposed special use shall substantially meet the following standards in order to obtain the recommendation of the planning and zoning commission and approval of the board of trustees: 
(1)  That the establishment, maintenance or operation of the special use will not be detrimental to or endanger the public health, safety, morals, comfort or general welfare. 
(2)  That the special use will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other property in the immediate vicinity for the purposes already permitted, nor substantially diminish or impair property values within the neighborhood. 
(3)  That the establishment of the special use will not impede the normal and orderly development and improvement of surrounding property for uses permitted in the district. 
(4)  That adequate utilities, access ways, drainage and/or other necessary facilities have been or are being provided. 
(5)  That adequate measures have been or will be taken to provide ingress and egress so designed as to minimize traffic congestion in the public streets. 
(6)  That the special use shall in all other respects conform to the applicable regulations of the district in which it is located, except as such regulations may in each instance be modified by the village board pursuant to the recommendation of the plan commission. 
(E)  Decisions. The board of trustees, upon report of the planning and zoning commission and without further public hearing, may grant or deny any proposed special use in accordance with applicable Illinois Statutes or may refer it back to the planning and zoning commission for further consideration. The board of trustees may by ordinance impose special conditions upon special use approval, designed to protect the public health, safety and welfare and designed to ensure compliance with the special use standards listed herein. A violation of any such special use conditions shall constitute a violation of this zoning ordinance and shall constitute grounds for revocation of the special use. 
(F)  Limitations on special uses. 
(1)  A special use shall apply only to the property for which it was originally granted. 
(2)  A special use shall run with the land, except as limited herein. A special use shall automatically terminate upon the cessation of the special use for a consecutive period of at least 365 days. For purposes of this section, cessation of the special use shall mean a failure to substantially operate the special use activity upon the property, whether by affirmative choice, bankruptcy, liquidation, foreclosure, eviction, or other reason. A cessation of the special use shall not occur when the special use activity is temporarily halted due to the making of repairs or upgrades to the property where a building permit is obtained, where the nature of the repairs or upgrades makes the continued operation of the special use impractical, and where the repairs or upgrades are diligently pursued to completion. 
(3)  Upon the termination of a special use for any reason, new special use approval is required in order for that use to continue upon the property. 
(4)  A special use shall become null and void (i) 180 days after the date of village board approval if the special use is not commenced on the property, unless the delay is due to construction or alteration of any structures in connection with the special use as addressed herein, or (ii) 24 months after the date of village board approval if any construction or alteration of any structures in connection with the special use is not substantially completed and the special use in not commenced within that time period. Upon written request and good cause shown, the board of trustees may, by ordinance, in its sole discretion, grant extensions of the time limitations set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 3, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 10-201, § 3, 12-6-2010; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019; Ord. No. 19-129, § 2, 8-29-2019)  
Sec. 13.10. - [Reserved.]  
Sec. 13.11. - Amendments. 
(A)  Authority. The regulations imposed and the districts created under the authority of this comprehensive amendment may be amended from time to time by ordinance in accordance with applicable Illinois Compiled Statutes. An amendment shall be granted or denied by the board of trustees only after a public hearing before the planning and zoning commission and a report of its recommendations has thereafter been submitted to the board of trustees. 
(B)  Initiation. Amendments may be proposed by the board of trustees, planning and zoning commission, village official, and by any other person, firm or corporation having a freehold interest, a possessory interest entitled to exclusive possession, a contractual interest which may become a freehold interest, an option to purchase or any exclusive possessory interest which is specifically enforceable on the land which is described in the application for an amendment. 
(C)  Processing. 
(1)  An application for an amendment shall be filed with the community development department, on forms prescribed by the village, along with all required fees and required supporting documentation. 
(2)  A copy of such application shall thereafter be forwarded by the community development department to the planning and zoning commission with a request to hold a public hearing and submit to the board of trustees a report of its findings and recommendations. Such public hearing shall be held upon public notice as required by the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(D)  Decisions. 
(1)  The board of trustees, upon report of the planning and zoning commission and without further public hearing, may grant or deny any proposed amendment in accordance with applicable Illinois Compiled Statutes and the Westmont Village Code, or may refer it back to the planning and zoning commission for further consideration. 
(2)  In case a written protest against any proposed amendment is signed and acknowledged by owners of 20 percent of the frontage proposed to be altered, or by the owners of 20 percent of the frontage immediately adjoining or across an alley therefrom, or by owners of 20 percent of the frontage directly opposite the frontage to be altered, is filed with the village clerk and service of the written protest is made pursuant to the applicable Illinois Compiled Statutes, the amendment cannot be passed except on the favorable vote of two-thirds of all members of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 3, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 10-201, § 4, 12-6-2010; Ord. No. 19-085, § 2, 3-23-2019)
