ARTICLE IV. - SUBDIVISION DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 4.01. - Streets. 
(a)  Street plan: The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade, and location of all streets shall conform to the comprehensive plan, and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets; to reasonable circulation of traffic within the subdivision and adjoining lands; to topographical conditions; to runoff of stormwater; to public convenience and safety; and in their appropriate relations to the proposed uses of the area to be served. 
(b)  Streets and other ways: 
(1)  Right-of-way widths shall conform to the following minimum dimensions: 
Type 	Residential 
subdivision 	Manufacturing 
or business 
subdivision 
(a) 	Arterials 	as shown on official map, and in no instance less than 80 feet 	as shown on official map, and in no instance less than 80 feet 
(b) 	Collector streets 	70 feet 	80 feet 
(c) 	Minor streets 	60 feet 	70 feet 
(d) 	Cul-de-sac streets 	60 feet 	70 feet 
(e) 	Frontage road 	45 feet 	45 feet 
(f) 	Half streets 	one-half the right-of-way of the proposed street or as required by the planning and zoning commission 	not permitted 
(g) 	Utility easements 	10 feet 	10 feet 
(h) 	Alleys (if permitted) 	20 feet 	30 feet 
(i) 	Pedestrian ways 	15 feet 	15 feet 
 
(2)  Minor streets shall be so aligned that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(3)  Streets should intersect at right angles or form T's and Y's. Acute angle intersections should be avoided. Jogs in street intersections should be at least 150 feet apart. 
(4)  A cul-de-sac street in single-family residential districts shall be not more than 600 feet in length, measured along its centerline from the centerline of the street of origin to the end of its right-of-way, or it may be longer than 600 feet provided that not more than 26 lots have exclusive access from it on both sides of the street. In multiple-family residential districts, such streets shall not exceed 300 feet in length. Each cul-de-sac shall have a terminus of circular shape with a minimum diameter of 120 feet, except a cul-de-sac street that has not more than five lots fronting on its right-of-way, or a temporary cul-de-sac street, may have a terminus of the "T" type or other variation of shape, as approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
(5)  Where there is a deflection in horizontal centerlines in excess of ten degrees, a curve shall be inserted having a centerline radius of not less than 125 feet for minor streets and not less than 300 feet for collector streets. A tangent of at least 100 feet in length shall be provided between all horizontal curves. 
(6)  Half streets shall be prohibited except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations, and where the board of trustees finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever an existing or dedicated half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract. A half street, where included, shall be graded at one level, and the regrading or new construction of any half street shall conform to the grade and pavement of the adjacent half street. Where a half street is provided, the developer shall be required to deposit sufficient funds in escrow to cover the cost of its resurfacing when the balance of the street is constructed. 
(7)  Provisions shall be made for vehicular and pedestrian access to residential property abutting a thoroughfare either by: (a) frontage roads, or (b) double frontage lots backing to the thoroughfare. Where the double frontage "back-up treatment" is used, a no-access strip shall be provided. These standards are established for the purpose of providing protection to residential properties and to separate through and local traffic. 
(8)  Gradients of street gutters shall be at least four-tenths of one percent, and of centerlines shall not exceed five percent for collector streets and six percent for minor streets. 
(9)  Where streets are dedicated (whether used or not), but not improved to the standards of this ordinance, and are wholly within the proposed subdivision land, they shall be improved to the standards of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 5, 6-19-1995)  
Sec. 4.02. - Easements. 
(a)  Easements shall be provided for underground utility services, including stormwater drainage, water main, and sanitary sewer service, where necessary. They shall be a minimum of ten feet wide, or larger if determined by the public works director, and shall be established at the rear of each lot and along such other lot lines as to provide continuity of alignment from block to block. If located between two adjoining lots, the easement shall be centered on the property line. 
(b)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a natural watercourse, drainageway, channel, or stream, there shall be provided a drainage easement approved by the public works director, conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse, and/or as approved by the public works director. 
(Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 4.03. - Blocks. 
(a)  In residential subdivisions, the maximum length of blocks containing any lots less than 100 feet in width shall be 1,500 lineal feet, and the maximum length of blocks containing lots 100 feet and over in width shall be 2,000 lineal feet. No blocks shall be less than 900 lineal feet in length unless approved by the planning and zoning commission. Pedestrian ways leading to schools, parks, or other common destinations may be required by the planning and zoning commission. For blocks over 900 feet in length, pedestrian ways not less than 15 feet in width shall be provided where deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  In industrial and business districts, maximum length of blocks shall be as approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
(c)  The shape of blocks shall be determined by topographical features, the basic street system and traffic pattern, lot depths, and areas designated for public and other nonresidential land uses. 
(d)  Where a subdivision borders upon or is traversed by a railroad right-of-way or arterial street, the planning and zoning commission may require a street on one or both sides of such right-of-way or street located approximately parallel to and at a distance removed suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, i.e., park purposes, deep residential lots fronting on it with a no-access strip along the rear property lines, and off-street parking, business, or other uses as permitted by the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 5, 6-19-1995)  
Sec. 4.04. - Lots. 
(a)  General: 
(1)  In general, lots should be as nearly rectangular in shape as practicable. Flag lots are prohibited. 
(2)  Width and area of lots shall conform with lot width and area requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance of the village or that of DuPage County in the unincorporated areas beyond the village limits. Corner lots shall be increased in width by 20 percent over the width of typical interior lots, except that corner lots need not exceed 90 feet in width, if the 90 feet in width is greater than the width of the typical lot. 
(3)  Double frontage lots shall be permitted only where lots back up on an arterial street, provided that no vehicular access between the lots and the arterial street is permitted; or where the topography of the land might render subdividing otherwise unreasonable. 
(4)  In the subdividing of any land, due regard shall be shown for all natural features such as tree growth, watercourses, or similar conditions. 
(b)  Residential subdivision: 
(1)  All lots for single-family detached residential use shall abut upon a street or easement. Flag lots are prohibited. 
(2)  Double frontage lots shall be permitted only where lots back up on an arterial street, provided that no vehicular access between the lots and the arterial street is permitted; or where the topography of the land might render subdividing otherwise unreasonable, provided that an additional depth of ten feet shall be required as a no access strip to provide protective screen planting. 
(c)  Industrial subdivision: 
(1)  Depth of lots shall be not less than 200 feet. 
(2)  All lots for industrial subdivision shall abut upon a street. Flag lots are prohibited. 
(3)  Double frontage lots shall be permitted only where lot depth is 300 feet or more; where lots back up on an arterial street, provided that no vehicular access between the lots and the arterial street is permitted; or where the topography of the land might render subdividing otherwise unreasonable. 
(Ord. No. 07-112, § 2, 6-18-2007)  
Sec. 4.05. - Public use areas. 
The planning and zoning commission may recommend and the village board may require each applicant to dedicate land for park and recreational purposes and land for school sites, to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the parcel, to make a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or to provide a combination of both at the option of the village. Such dedication is necessary to ensure proper provision of park and school sites for persons who are expected to reside within the subdivision or development, which sites would otherwise have to be acquired at the expense of the general public but whose utility would generally be limited to residents of the parcel. 
(a)  Criteria for requiring park and recreation land dedication: 
(1)  Applicant may be required to dedicate for park and recreation purposes an amount of land determined on the basis of 5.5 acres per 1,000 persons calculated as provided in paragraph (e), table of estimated ultimate population. 
(2)  The location of the site to be dedicated shall be determined by the village board upon recommendation of the planning and zoning commission and the Westmont park district, taking into account the suitability of the site for park purposes or development, its relationship to population concentrations, and its proximity to other park or recreational lands. 
(3)  No storage of any materials, including spoil materials or topsoil, will be allowed on any land designated as park district land for use as recreational use. 
(4)  Credit for private open space and recreation areas. Private open space or recreation areas may be utilized in lieu of the dedication required by this subsection (a), provided that detailed improvement plans shall be approved by the planning and zoning commission and village board and that satisfactory guarantees of the permanency of the use and its maintenance, enforceable by the village, shall be entered into by the applicant. 
(b)  Criteria for school site dedication: Applicants may be required to dedicate for school purposes an amount of land determined by: 
(1)  Obtaining the ratio of estimated children to be generated by the proposed subdivision or development within each school classification, calculated as provided in paragraph (e), to the maximum number of children to be served within each school classification, calculated from the table in this paragraph (b). 
(2)  Multiplying that ratio by the minimum number of acres for a school site within each school classification determined from the table in this paragraph (b). Calculation to be extended to three decimals. 
(3)  No storage of any materials, including spoil materials or topsoil, will be allowed on any land designated as future or proposed school sites. 
BASE SCHOOL POPULATION AND SITE SIZE

by grades 	Maximum

(c)  Criteria for requiring a contribution in lieu of park and school sites: Where the resulting site in a proposed subdivision or development is too small to be usable for the purpose intended or where it is inappropriate for park and recreational purposes, or a school site, the village may require the applicant to contribute cash in lieu of the land dedication. The cash contributions in lieu of park and recreation land dedication shall be held in trust by the village, or other public body designated by the village, solely for the acquisition of park and recreation land as hereinbefore classified, which will serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of that subdivision or development or for the improvement of other existing park and recreation land which already serves such needs. The cash contributions in lieu of school sites shall be held in trust by the village, or other public body designated by the village, solely for use in the acquisition of land for a school site to serve the immediate or future needs of children from that subdivision or development, or for the improvement to any existing school site which already serves such needs, but not for the construction of any school buildings or additions thereto. If any portion of a cash contribution in lieu of park and recreation land dedication, or cash contribution in lieu of school site, is not expended for the purposes set forth herein within seven years from the date of receipt, it shall be refunded to the applicant who made such contribution. 
(1)  Fair market value. The cash contribution in lieu of land shall be based on the fair market value of the acres of land, as improved, that otherwise would have been dedicated as park and recreation or school sites. It has been determined that the present fair market value of such improved land in and surrounding the village is $125,000.00 per acre, and such figure shall be used in making any calculation herein unless the applicant files written object thereto. In the event of any such objection, the applicant shall submit an appraisal showing the fair market value per acre of such improved land or other evidence thereof and final determination of said fair market value per acre of such improved land shall be made by the village board based upon such information from other sources which may be submitted to the village board by the park district, school district, or others. 
(d)  Criteria for requiring dedication and a fee: There will be situations when a combination of land dedication and a contribution in lieu of land is necessary. These occasions will arise when: 
(1)  The subdivision or development does not have sufficient or adequate land to meet the dedication requirements hereunder. That portion of the land within the subdivision or development which is adequate or sufficient for the park or school location shall be dedicated as a site as aforesaid, and a cash contribution in lieu thereof shall be required for any additional land that would have been required to be dedicated. 
(2)  A major part of the local park or recreation site or school site has already been acquired and only a small portion of land is needed from the subdivision or development to complete the site. The portions needed to complete the park or school site shall be dedicated, and a cash contribution shall be required in lieu of the balance of the required dedication. 
(e)  Density formula: The following table of population density is generally indicative of current and short range projected trends in family size for new construction and shall be used in calculating the amount of required dedication of acres of land or the cash contributions in lieu thereof unless a written objection is filed thereto by the applicant. In the event an applicant files a written objection to the table of estimated ultimate population listed herein, he shall submit his own demographic study showing the estimated additional population and, in that event, final determination of the density formula to be used in such calculations shall be made by the village board based upon such demographic information submitted by the applicant and from other sources which may be submitted to the village board by the park district, school district, or others. 
(f)  Improved sites: The slope, topography and geology of the site to be dedicated as well as its surroundings must be suitable for its intended purposes. Grading on sites dedicated for park and recreational uses shall not differ greatly from surrounding land. Before dedication, all sites shall be improved as required under this ordinance or acceptable provisions shall be made for such improvement before dedication. 
(Ord. No. 87-97, 12-7-1987; Ord. No. 95-41, § 5, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 96-98, § 2, 12-2-1996)

Sec. 4.06. - Library services; cash contributions. 
(a)  Amount of cash contribution. As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision, or of a final plat of a planned unit development, each subdivider or developer will be required to pay a cash contribution for library purposes as set forth in paragraph (b). 
(b)  Calculation of cash contributions. The cash contribution shall be calculated by multiplying the number of people per unit as set forth in the table of estimated ultimate population per dwelling unit (section 4.05) times $20.00. 
(c)  Time of payment. 
(1)  Where territory is located outside of village. Where the territory in such subdivision or planned unit development is located outside of the village boundaries but within its plan jurisdiction, the cash contribution required by this ordinance shall be payable to the village when application is made to the village to approve such subdivision or planned unit development. 
(2)  Where territory is located within the village. Where the territory in such subdivision or planned unit development is located within the village boundaries, the cash contributions required by this ordinance shall be payable to the village either upon the sale of each lot or parcel, or at the time application is made to the village for the issuance of a residential building permit in connection with any premises in said subdivision or planned unit development, whichever event occurs first. 
(Ord. No. 86-109, 11-17-1986)  
Sec. 4.07. - Municipal services; cash contributions. 
Municipal contributions: It is the policy of the village that all construction shall provide for reasonable contributions to the village for the anticipated impact of a proposed development on the village for village services and infrastructure. Such contributions may include, but are not limited to, the cost of providing the general municipal services reasonably required to serve the proposed development or the incremental cost of any such service or facilities as may be fairly attributed to the needs of a proposed development. Such contributions shall be incorporated into any annexation agreement governing such property and shall not affect the developer's obligation to make other contributions as set forth in this ordinance, or to develop the property in accordance with the requirements of this ordinance. 
(a)  Amount of cash contribution. As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision, final plat of a planned unit development, or of a site plan, each subdivider or developer will be required to pay a cash contribution for municipal purposes as set forth in paragraph (b). 
(b)  Calculation of cash contributions. The cash contribution shall be calculated by multiplying the number of square feet of floor space times $0.10 in B, M, O/R and PD developments. 
(c)  Time of payment shall be at the time the building permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 88-31, 3-7-1988)  
ARTICLE V. - REQUIRED LAND IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 5.01. - General requirement. 
Before a final plat of subdivision may be approved by the planning and zoning commission and the board of trustees, the owner or subdivider shall submit to the public works director complete plans and specifications, prepared by an Illinois registered professional engineer, and shall certify in writing to the planning and zoning commission and the board of trustees that such improvements and utilities meet the following minimum requirements and other applicable requirements of the village. No required land improvements shall be installed prior to the recording of the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 5, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 5.02. - Sewers. 
(a)  A complete system of sanitary sewers shall be installed, including sewer stub terminals at the property line of each lot, to serve all lots in a subdivision or lot division. Said system of sewers shall be connected with a sanitary sewer system approved by the village and appropriate sanitary district. All connections to said sewer systems shall comply with existing ordinances and shall be subject to the approval and inspection of the public works director or any other party assigned by the board of trustees to inspect same. 
(b)  All sanitary sewer systems shall be constructed in accordance with standards and specifications of the village and other governmental authorities having jurisdiction. All sewer design, plans, and specifications shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission, and the public works director for approval and file. Each lot platted for the subdivision shall be served by the sanitary sewer system. 
(c)  Where sanitary sewer mains of larger capacity than necessary are required, as directed by the board of trustees to serve the subdivision as delineated in the preliminary plan, the developer shall be required to adhere to the requirements of the appropriate sanitary district. 
(d)  A subdivision plat shall in no case be approved which shall be dependent upon individual septic tanks and wells, except where lots therein contain not less than one acre each. If the subdivision is served with public water, the lots with septic tanks shall contain not less than 20,000 square feet each. However, if public water and sanitary sewers are accessible, no septic tank or private well for potable water will be permitted. 
(e)  An adequate system of stormwater drainage shall be constructed and installed, consisting of natural watercourses, swales, storm sewers and other necessary facilities in accordance with village standards and specifications. 
(f)  Any outfall storm sewer that drains into an existing open ditch or natural watercourse shall have a reinforced concrete headwall and a concrete apron, the design of which shall be approved by the public works director. Other structures may be used as approved by the public works director. 
(g)  The stormwater drainage system shall be separate and independent of the sanitary sewerage system, and be installed in accordance with sound engineering standards and specifications. 
(h)  Where storm sewer mains of larger capacity than necessary are required, as directed by the board of trustees to serve the subdivision as delineated in the preliminary plan, the developer shall be required to pay for the installation of the entire system and he will be afforded the opportunity to enter into an agreement for the recapture of funds for that portion of the costs which exceed the proportionate benefit to his subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 5, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 5.03. - Water supply. 
(a)  A community water system approved by the village shall be extended throughout the entire subdivision in such a manner that every lot in such subdivision may be serviced by means of a connection within its own frontage. All construction shall be in accordance with standards approved by the State of Illinois and the village and in accordance with AWWA standards, and connections to water mains shall comply with existing ordinances and shall be subject to the approval and inspection of the public works director. 
(b)  In subdivisions located in the unincorporated areas within 1½ miles of the limits of the village, individual wells located on the lot may be installed to serve lots containing 20,000 square feet or more in area provided installation conforms with standards approved by the DuPage County health department and other applicable governmental authorities. 
(c)  Water transmission mains shall be a minimum of six inches in diameter, shall include installation of shutoff valves and fire hydrants, and shall be free from dead-end mains wherever possible. 
(d)  Fire hydrants shall be installed in all subdivisions with a maximum spacing of 300 feet; hydrants shall be of a type approved by the public works director and with valve openings and hose connections in accordance with standards and hose thread as established by the village. 
(e)  Consideration shall be given to water reclamation and reuse in commercial and industrial tracts for the purposes of conservation and relief of demands on existing residential supply. 
(f)  Where installation of water mains of larger capacity than required to serve only the subdivision as delineated in the preliminary plan is required by the board of trustees to serve future growth in the vicinity of the subdivision, the subdivider shall be required to pay for the installation of the entire system and he will be afforded the opportunity to enter into an agreement for the recapture of funds for that portion of the costs which exceed the proportionate benefit to his subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 5.04. - House services. 
House services for sewer and water shall be constructed to connect each lot or building site with the utility service mains for each utility required in the provisions of this ordinance with sound engineering standards and specifications.  
Sec. 5.05. - Streets and other ways. 
(a)  Street grading: 
(1)  All stumps, trees that cannot be saved, boulders, and similar items in street rights-of-way shall be removed from the site by the contractor or developer. 
(2)  Before any paving work is commenced, all street grading shall be properly completed as shown on the grading plan and approved by the public works director. 
(3)  After grading of streets is completed and approved, and before any base course of the roadway pavement is laid, all of the underground work, such as water, sewer, and gas mains, house service connections therewith and all underground conduits for electric and telephone lines, shall be completely installed in place and approved. 
(b)  Roadway improvements: 
(1)  All streets shall be improved with roadway pavements to an overall width in accordance with the following minimum dimensions: 
	Roadway widths 
(between backs of curbs) 
Type 	Residential 
subdivision 	Manufacturing 
or business 
subdivision

Roadway pavement in cul-de-sac street terminus shall have a minimum diameter, measured from backs of the outside curb, of not less than 80 feet with sodded and landscaped islands having a diameter of 26 feet for residential subdivisions and not less than 100 feet for manufacturing and business subdivisions. 
(2)  Roadway pavements shall be installed in accordance with the following minimum requirements: 
Pavement type 	Required cross section

(3)  Concrete curbs and gutters shall be constructed along the outside edges of all street pavements of the type designated by the public works director and installed in accordance with village standards and specifications. 
(4)  Stormwater inlets shall be provided within roadway improvement at points not less than 400 feet apart or as specified by the public works director. 
(c)  Nonroadway improvements: 
(1)  A paved access driveway from the street lot line to the street pavement shall be provided. 
(2)  Side stripes shall be required on both sides of all streets. They shall be graded and prepared for seeding by the subdivider with at least four inches of topsoil. Median strips shall be considered as side strips unless paved. 
(3)  Sidewalks shall be installed in all residential and commercial subdivisions and shall be constructed in accordance with village standards and specifications. Minimum width of sidewalks in residential districts shall be five feet and in commercial districts six feet. 
(4)  Trees shall be planted along all streets where trees do not exist. Trees shall have a trunk diameter, measured 12 inches above the ground, of not less than three inches, and shall be spaced not more than 50 feet apart. This requirement will be satisfied if an equivalent number of trees of the same size or larger size are planted in a naturalistic manner in the front yards of the adjoining lots. The plantings shall be restricted to thornless honey locusts, sugar maples, hackberries, pin oaks, sycamore, ginkgoes, and/or any other trees approved by the planning and zoning commission. Chinese elm, box elder, willow, poplar, silver maple, cottonwood, American elm, and similar fast-growing brittle-wood species are prohibited. Trees shall be maintained and dead trees replaced by the subdivider for a period of two years after initial planting. 
(5)  Street signs shall be provided by the subdivider in accordance with village standards and specifications and shall be located so as to identify every street within the subdivision. 
(6)  Provisions shall be made for the electric lighting of streets within the proposed subdivision with the plans for such installation subject to village approval. 
(7)  Concrete, barrier-type curbs shall be provided for all parking lots accommodating five or more parking spaces for the purpose of protecting landscaping, improving site maintenance, preventing vehicle encroachment and controlling drainage. 
(d)  Waiver and cash in lieu of certain public improvements: 
(1)  In certain instances where it is impractical or undesirable that certain of the above-stated public improvements be installed at the time of development, the public works director may allow a waiver of certain public improvements. If a waiver is granted, then a cash contribution shall be made to the village for such public improvements which are not installed. 
(2)  The criteria for waiving certain public improvements and requiring a cash contribution are as follows: 
STREETS 
a.  Where road widening will be 250 feet or less in length (exclusive of any transitional tapers) as measured parallel to the centerline on the right-of-way. 
b.  Where road widening will require transitional pavement extending outside of the corporate boundaries of the village. 
c.  Where the public works department determines that road widening may conflict with other existing or planned public improvements. 
STREET LIGHTING 
d.  Where only one street light is required by design standard. 
e.  Where the public works department determines that adequate street illumination exists in the immediate area. 
f.  Where the public works department determines that the required street light location and/or type may conflict with other existing or planned public improvements. 
(3)  Where a cash contribution is allowed in lieu of certain public improvements, the amount of such contribution shall be approximately equal to the cost of construction/installation of the waived public improvements. The public works director shall publish a contribution schedule based on the approximate cost of construction/installation of each public improvement. The cash contribution shall be paid upon or before completion of public improvements for the development. 
(Ord. No. 86-79, 8-18-1986; Ord. No. 07-67, § 1, 5-7-2007; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 5.06. - Public utilities. 
(a)  All utility distribution lines for telephone, electric and gas service in the subdivision shall be placed underground. Installation of such facilities shall be made in compliance with the applicable orders, rules and regulations of the Illinois Commerce Commission now or hereafter effective and the subdivider shall be responsible for compliance with rules and regulations, now and hereafter effective and filed with said commission pursuant to the Illinois Public Utilities Act, of any public utility whose service will be required for the subdivision with respect to the provision of such facilities. 
(b)  Underground telephone, electric and gas service shall be placed within easements or dedicated public ways in a manner which will not conflict with other underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall be located so as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public.  
Sec. 5.07. - As-built plans. 
Upon completion of the installation of improvements in a subdivision, one set of transparencies, suitable for use in reproduction, which shows all improvements as actually installed in the field, shall be filed with the public works director. (Also see section 2.05(b).) 
(Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
ARTICLE VI. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 6.001. - Minimum standards for subdivisions. 
All subdivisions shall meet the following requirements: 
(a)  The side lines of all lots shall be approximately perpendicular to the street line. 
(b)  The minimum depth of residential lots shall be 125 feet and the minimum width 60 feet unless otherwise provided by the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  All corner lots shall be so platted as to maintain the full required setback as required by the village zoning ordinance upon both streets. 
(d)  In subdivisions bordering on railroads, streets parallel to the railroad shall be so laid out as to leave a 150-foot strip of land alongside the railroad right-of-way, to provide for clear vision and for safe grades in case of grade separation. This land shall be dedicated to park purposes wherever practicable, but where necessary may be platted for industrial, commercial or residential uses. 
(e)  Reserved. 
(Code 1956, § 8.312; Ord. No. 73-17, § 1, 5-14-1973; Ord. No. 78-26, 7-5-1978; Ord. No. 84-32, § 1, 4-16-1984) 
Editor's note Sec. 6.001 of this appendix was originally designated § 24-32 of the 1972 Code, was saved from repeal by Ord. No. 78-26, enacted July 5, 1978, and was included herein as § 6.001 at the discretion of the editors.  
Sec. 6.01. - Fee for filing preliminary plan. 
A fee of $150.00 plus $0.50 per lot shall be paid by the subdivider or owner to the village clerk at the time of submission of the preliminary plan. No plan shall be forwarded to the planning and zoning commission for review without a receipt from the village clerk being exhibited showing full payment of the fee. Payment of the fee is in no way contingent on whether the plan of subdivision submitted is approved or disapproved.  
Sec. 6.02. - Public works director's services. 
The cost incurred by the village for review and inspection services performed either by the public works director, engineering consultants retained by the village, or other village employees, shall be paid by the developer, prior to commencing the installation of any improvements. Fees shall be calculated as stipulated in section 18-486 of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 86-7, 1-6-1986; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007)  
Sec. 6.03. - Building code and other applicable ordinances. 
No building permit as regulated by the building code shall be issued by any governing official for the construction of any structure or improvement to land or any lot within a subdivision, as defined herein, which has been approved for platting until all requirements of this ordinance have been fully complied with, unless an agreement is entered into, the builder or owner and the village waiving or postponing such requirements.  
Sec. 6.04. - Occupancy permit. 
No occupancy permit shall be granted by any governing official for the use of any structure or land improvement within a subdivision approved for platting or replatting until required utility facilities have been installed and made ready to service the structure or land improvement, and until roadways providing access to the lot or lots containing such improvements have been constructed or are in the course of construction and are suitable for vehicular traffic.  
Sec. 6.05. - Variations. 
[(a)  Recommending variances: ] The planning and zoning commission may recommend variances from the literal application of the design standards specified in this section: 
(1)  Where conformance with these standards is made impossible by topography or surrounding development; or 
(2)  Where an existing plat is to be replatted in a manner which more nearly complies with these requirements than the existing plat. 
(b)  Conditions: In recommending any variance, the planning and zoning commission shall specify conditions necessary to assure that the proposed subdivision: 
(1)  Will not be detrimental to the neighborhood and to the community as a whole; 
(2)  Complies with the comprehensive plan of the village; 
(3)  Complies with the intent of this ordinance; 
(4)  Does not violate any other ordinances or regulations of the village. 
(c)  Procedure: Such recommendations shall be communicated to the board of trustees or governing county authorities in writing, substantiating the recommended variations. The board of trustees or county authorities may approve variations from these requirements for subdivisions when, in its opinion, such variations will not adversely affect the comprehensive plan or the spirit of this ordinance. The village shall notify the owner or subdivider and other interested parties as to the time and place of the planning and zoning commission meeting at which the variations are being considered and where the owner or subdivider and other interested parties will be afforded an opportunity of being heard. Such notice shall be published, posted or delivered in such form as prescribed by the village attorney. Where the development has been processed as a planned development in accordance with the provisions of the Westmont zoning ordinance, variations to the development code may be incorporated within the planned development documents without the necessity for separate hearings or separate action by the planning and zoning commission or the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 5, 6-19-1995)  
Sec. 6.06. - Enforcement. 
No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to be recorded in the recorder's office or have any validity until it shall have been approved in a manner prescribed in this ordinance.  
Sec. 6.07. - Record of plats. 
All of such plats of subdivision, after the same have been submitted and approved as provided in this ordinance and recorded in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of DuPage County, shall be filed and kept by the village clerk among the records of the village.  
Sec. 6.08. - Separability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance.  
Sec. 6.09. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation which is charged with a duty under this ordinance and who fails, neglects or refuses to abide by the same or to perform such duty, or who knowingly violates any of the provisions of this ordinance, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $500.00. Each day that the violation of this ordinance continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(b)  Whoever shall sell or offer for sale, lease or offer for lease while this ordinance is in effect, any lot or lots or block or blocks within the incorporated limits of the village, or any additions thereto, or any resubdivision of any lot or block therein, or within contiguous territory and not more than 1½ miles beyond the incorporated boundary of the village, before all of the requirements of this ordinance have been complied with, shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $250.00 for each lot, block or part thereof so disposed of, offered for sale or leased.  
ARTICLE VII. - RULES AND DEFINITIONS 
 
Sec. 7.01. - Rules. 
The language set forth in the text of this ordinance shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction: 
(a)  The singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular. 
(b)  The present tense includes the past and future tenses and the future the present. 
(c)  The word "shall" is mandatory, while the word "may" is permissive. 
(d)  The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter. 
(e)  Whenever a word or term defined hereinafter appears in the text of the ordinance, its meaning shall be construed as set forth in the definition thereof; and any word appearing in parentheses directly after a word herein defined shall be construed in the same sense as that word. 
(f)  The following words and terms, wherever they occur in this ordinance, shall be construed as herein defined.  
Sec. 7.02. - Definitions. 
Alley is a right-of-way which affords secondary means of access to properties abutting upon a street. 
Arterial is a street with a high degree of continuity and serving as an arterial trafficway between the various districts of Westmont and its environs. 
Bedroom is any room in a dwelling which has all of the following characteristics: (i) it is larger than 100 square feet in area; (ii) it has access to a full bathroom, with a shower or bathtub, on the same level of the dwelling; (iii) it has a closet; and (iv) it is not open to any other room. 
Block is a tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets and public parks, railroad rights-of-way, or other similar natural or manmade boundaries. A block may be located in part beyond the corporate limits of the village. 
Board of trustees is the board of trustees of the Village of Westmont, Illinois. 
Building setback line is a line within a lot or other parcel of land which denotes the area between such line and the adjacent street right-of-way line where a building and other obstructions are prohibited, except those encroachments that are permitted by zoning ordinance regulations. 
Collector street is a street within a subdivision which has wider right-of-way and roadway widths, and which is a prime entrance or circulating street. Its primary function is to distribute and collect traffic to and from minor streets. 
Comprehensive plan refers to the composite of the functional and geographic elements of the official comprehensive plan of the village and its environs or any segment thereof, in the form of plans, maps, charts, reports, implementing ordinances, and the official map. 
Cul-de-sac is a minor street with a single outlet, and is permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround. 
Easement is a quantity of land set aside over or under which a liberty, privilege, or advantage in land, without profit, is dedicated or granted either to the public, a particular person, or a combination of both, and is distinct from ownership of the land. 
Economic development director is the building inspector of the Village of Westmont, or his duly authorized representative. 
Final plat is a map or plan of a subdivision and any accompanying material as described in article III of this ordinance. 
Flag lot is a lot having the configuration of an extended flag and pole. The pole represents access to the building site which is usually located to the rear of another lot fronting a dedicated street. The width of the pole measures less than the required minimum lot width for the zoning district. 
Frontage road is a minor road which is parallel to and either adjacent to or within the right-of-way of a thoroughfare. 
Half street is a street of less than the total required width among one or more boundary lines of a subdivision. 
Land improvement is any sanitary sewerage system, storm sewer system, water supply and distribution system, roadway, sidestrip, sidewalk, pedestrian way, no-access strip, off-street parking area, lot grading, or other improvement which the village may require under this ordinance. 
Lot is a portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. 
Lot, butt is a lot at the end of a block and located between two corner lots. 
Lot, double frontage is a lot which has a pair of opposite lot lines along two substantially parallel streets. 
Minor street is a street of limited continuity. Its primary purpose is to serve abutting properties. 
No-access strip is a land area at least 12 feet wide along the rear lot lines of double frontage lots and abutting a thoroughfare within which no private vehicular driveway or walkway shall be permitted. 
Owner or subdivider shall include any person, firm, association, partnership, private corporation, public or quasipublic corporation, or a combination of any of them, or other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided or divided to commence and maintain proceedings under the provisions of this ordinance. 
Pedestrian way is a right-of-way across or within a block designated for pedestrian use. 
Planning and zoning commission is the Village of Westmont planning and zoning commission. 
Preliminary plan is a map depicting a tentative land plan as described in article III of this ordinance. 
Public works director is a professional engineer, registered in the State of Illinois, who has been duly appointed as the public works director of the village. 
Roadway is that portion of the street designated for vehicular use. 
Sidestrip is the unpaved strip of land within a street right-of-way and is parallel to the roadway. 
Sidewalk is that portion of the street designated for pedestrian use. 
Street is a right-of-way which affords primary means of access by pedestrians and vehicles to abutting properties, whether designated as a street, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, easement, or however otherwise designated. 
Street width is the shortest distance between the right-of-way lines of a given street. 
Subdivision is: 
(1)  A described tract of land which is to be or has been divided into two or more parcels of land; 
(2)  Any division of land which creates a lot for transfer of ownership and/or building development where a new street is involved; or 
(3)  The dedication of streets, ways, or other areas for the use of the public. 
All subdivisions shall comply with the provisions of the village land development code where applicable, with the exception of recording of a final plat when such recording is specifically exempted under the Plat Act (765 ILCS 205/0.01 et seq.), as may be amended from time to time. 
Subdivision design standards are the basic land-planning principles established as guides for the preparation of preliminary plans. 
Village is the Village of Westmont, Illinois. 
Village clerk is the Village Clerk of the Village of Westmont, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 95-41, § 5, 6-19-1995; Ord. No. 97-27, § 1, 4-7-1997; Ord. No. 00-61, § 2, 5-1-2000; Ord. No. 07-102, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-103, § 1, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 07-112, § 2, 6-18-2007)

Editor's note Printed herein is the schedule of fees, taxes and charges, as adopted by the village board. Amendments to the schedule are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original schedule. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, headings and catchlines have been made uniform and the same system of capitalization, citation to state statutes, and expression of numbers in text as appears in the Code of Ordinances has been used. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets.
